Title: Music Review: Naan Sirithal
Content: Hiphop TamizhaThe album of Raana’s romantic comedy Naan Sirithal has a line-up of six songs, all of which clock around crisp three minutes. Breakup Song by Hiphop Tamizha is a fast-paced number, which is quite self-explanatory thanks to its title. The song, which begins with the screeching noise of a conch, sets the tone for the song. While the lyrics seem quite redundant, the song is backed by interesting instruments.Dhom Dhom is a breezy number rendered by Sanjith Hegde and Hiphop Tamizha. Sanjith adds a charming presence to this otherwise normal song. Anjukku Gumukku, rendered by Hip Hop Tamizha, fails to make a mark, save for the catchy interludes. Naan Siricha by Kaushik Krish and Gana Vinoth is a fun addition to the line-up, which explains the perplexities of laughing at inappropriate moments, a condition that the protagonist goes through. The song is elevated by upbeat, conversational humour in its lyrics.Happy Birthday, rendered by Diwakar and Ka Ka Balachander, falls a bit flat, sounding a bit too familiar to Hiphop Tamizha’s earlier work. Keka Beka by Rajan Chelliah and Hiphop Tamizha, depicts the downsides of constant ‘nervous laughter’, which is quite hummable.

Title: How a Kannada song for Popcorn Monkey Tiger ended up with English lyrics
Content: If you have not heard the song Maadeva yet, you have to work on staying updated on the Kannada music scene. For here is a number, put together by lyricist Ritwik Kaikini , composer Charan Raj , singer Sanjith Hegde along with rapper HanuManKind , for the soon-to-be-released Dhananjaya-starrer Popcorn Monkey Tiger , that is soaring up the charts. What’s seems to be working for this number is the fact that the lyrics are mostly in English, as aspect that is not only breaking a stereotype, but is also connected with a new generation of music lovers. The team tells us what went into the making of this track…The idea was to write something based on Dhananjaya’s character, his struggles, decisions and his choices. Suri’s vision for the characters in the film and Charan Raj’s thought process of blending different worlds of music seamlessly were influential in the making of the lyrics. As for using English lyrics in a Kannada film, we hoped to be able to attract the new age audience to the Kannada film industry. We wanted the song to reach out to a wider audience and not just limit it to people in Karnataka. We aimed at breaking the stereotype and transcending genres. Our audience has been growing wiser each year and they deserve something that the can relate to.When you work with people like Suri (the director of Popcorn, Monkey, Tiger) who give you the freedom and space to work, it allows us composers the opportunity to experiment. The decision of using English vocals on this number was rather organic. For Maadeva, we worked according to the visuals, and when Suri reviewed what we had done, he said this was exactly what he was looking for. Now with the song doing well among listeners, it feels great to see our work being appreciated.I’m primarily an English rapper. So, for me, to come up with lyrics and to rap for a Kannada song was a completely new experience. While at the studio, with Charan Raj and Sanjith Hegde, I think it was the mood and the vibe at that point that seamlessly translated into words. I came up with the lyrics after I watched the trailer, and based on what Charan told me. I wanted to balance the concept and the mass appeal in the song. For me, it was about putting myself into a different pair of shoes and I wrote for the character.I look up to Charan. He’s like my elder brother and he pushes my boundaries. I was skeptical about singing this song in English. But Charan wanted the sound to be very raw. He wanted me to be myself. I just sang what Ritwik had penned. At that time, this song was not even called Maadeva. It was just something called Wah Wah Wah. It was renamed as Maadeva by Charan. Later, after HanuManKind came on board, we recorded the song together and the rest, as they say, is History.Watch the song here

Title: Shivaji Surathkal wouldn’t exist without Ramesh Aravind, says Akash Srivatsa
Content: Every time director Akash Srivatsa talks about actor-filmmaker Ramesh Aravind , the fanboy in him rears his head. In the years since he first assisted Ramesh on the latter’s directorial — Accident, Vatsa, as he is popularly known, has maintained a close relationship with his ‘mentor’. He has also often turned to Ramesh for guidance, while also harbouring a dream of directing the actor one day. While that didn’t work out for his directorial debut, Badmash, Vatsa has finally realised his dreams by getting Ramesh to play the title character in his next, Shivaji Surathkal . Incidentally, this has also turned out to be milestone of sorts for Ramesh too, as this is his 101st film , which comes after a gap of nearly three years.The film is special to Vatsa on many levels. “When I was planning my next movie, my co-writer Abhinandan YR told me a one-line murder mystery subject that I found quite intriguing. As has been practice, I told Ramesh sir about it and his interest was also piqued. So, we set out to develop it into a full-fledged script. Both Ramesh sir and I are fans of the detective thriller genre, especially the Sherlock Holmes series, so, Abhi and I thought that we could spin the story on similar lines. The film is our tribute to the genre and Sherlock Holmes. We first called it Ranagiri Rahasya, and the protagonist here was named Shivaji. We ran the script by Ramesh sir at various stages and he would dissect it, not as an actor or filmmaker, but as a member of the movie-watching audience, and give us valuable feedback to avoid flaws. He also mentioned that like all popular detectives, Hercule Poirot, Sherlock Holmes or Byomkesh Bakshi, for that matter, had a first and second name. Surathkal is a place that always fascinated me, as back in my college days, it was considered that only the really smart ones manage to get into colleges there. It was a matter of prestige. So, I thought it was apt to call our protagonist, Shivaji Surathkal,” explains Vatsa.Given his inspiration, one wonders if Shivaji Surathkal has been written as a genius with personal flaws, like Holmes and Poirot. “Shivaji sure has his own issues, but they are very different. He battles insomnia, is emotional and angry and is then tasked with finding out who killed a minister’s son in 48 hours. It’s a complicated and bizarre case that brings him to Ranagiri, a place that has a lot of myths surrounding it. Into that midst comes a rational detective, who is looking for clues and evidence to put his case together,” adds the filmmaker.Once the script was in place, Ramesh, says Vatsa, became a director’s actor. “Whatever creative inputs he had until then, ceased. Truth be told, on the first day on set, I was scared about having to call out action and cut to a man I revere. There is a fanboy in me. But in no time, he put me at ease, and showed just how non-interfering he would be. The only pressure I ever felt was during scripting, which took at least a year, as I knew that we needed a different approach to seeing Ramesh sir onscreen in his 101st film,” says Vatsa. Ranagiri Rahasya is only the first in what the director hopes will be a franchise. “The fun fact is that if Ramesh sir had not agreed to be part of the film, I would not have made it, instead trying something else. Shivaji Suratkal and his mysteries are only for Ramesh sir,” Vatsa signs off.

Title: Ashika Rangnath is the mystery woman in Sriimurali’s next
Content: There has been much intrigue since director Mahesh Kumar (of Ayogya fame) announced his next with Sriimurali , Madagaja. With several names of heroines doing the rounds, fans were wondering who would finally be paired opposite him. On Thursday, Mahesh released a teaser poster showing the back profile of a langa-davani clad heroine, along with a promise to reveal her name on Valentine’s Day.Sure enough, the name is out; along with a picture of the actress and it is none other than Bangalore Times Fresh Face runner-up Ashika Rangnath . “The character is that of an educated girl who has a keen interest in farming and agriculture. The role required an actress who would not fuss about getting tanned through the making of this film as that is required for her to get into the skin of the character. Ashika agreed, and she therefore, will be seen in a refreshingly new avatar through this film,” says Mahesh.

Title: Prabhudeva gets a wacky look in Adhik’s new film
Content: Some time ago, Adhik Ravichandran (of Trisha Illana Nayanthara fame) had announced that he’s working on a film with Prabhudeva. The first look of the film, titled Bagheera , was released yesterday, which has Prabhudeva in a wacky appearance.The poster has the actor-choreographer-director in a tonsured look, wearing sunglasses that reflect three images — an image from The Jungle Book, 11:11 and a car. “All the three images have a connect to the story. Bagheera is a character that I loved from The Jungle Book. He is more like a mentor-protector, but can also destroy. Prabhudeva master’s character is similar to this.”The film happens to be Prabhudeva’s 55th film, informs the director. We have seen him romance, dance and do fantastic comedy. But this role will be different from all that he has done before. As a matter of fact, this genre is completely different for me, too. It is more of a mystery thriller, with elements of romance,” says Adhik.The team has completed over 70 per cent of the shoot. Also starring Amyra Dastur, the film has been shot in Chennai, Kochi and Mumbai. “We will begin the next schedule by the end of February. We will be shooting in Goa and Sri Lanka, too. We are hoping to wrap up by April,” he says.

Title: Music Review: Oh My Kadavule
Content: The soundtrack of Ashwath Marimuthu’s Oh My Kadavule is backed by the vocals of powerful singers, including Sid Sriram, Anirudh Ravichander, Sanjeev T, and Leon James, the film’s composer. The film, starring Ashok Selvan, Ritika Singh and Vani Bhojan in lead roles, is touted to be a breezy romantic story with a twist. The film’s soundtrack complements the film’s narrative.The album begins with Kadhaipoma, which seems like the perfect meet-cute song. Sid Sriram injects his characteristic charm in the song, which brims with beautiful acoustics. Next comes Friendship Anthem, which paints a nice picture of a long-standing friendship. The crisp song is rendered by Anirudh with peppy notes. Also tracing the friendship along with Anirudh in the song are Leon and MM Manasi. Ennada Life Idhu is a bright number by Santhosh Narayanan and Leon, ruing the complexities of life.Kadhal Kozhappudhey begins with sharp tunes of jazz and goes on to shine in Sanjeev T’s voice. The song stands out with its conversational lyrics. Haiyo Haiyo in Leon’s voice sounds crisper in its remastered version.

Title: My First Shot: Shankar sir said I looked peculiar when I danced, says Bharath
Content: I have been part of the dance group, The Swingers, since 1998 and have done performances with the troupe. It was the beginning of 2002… I heard Shankar sir was looking to cast youngsters in his next film and was also auditioning several newcomers. One day, his team had come to the dance institute and taped a whole sequence that we had done. Shankar sir had seen that and thought I had performed well. He then called me and one of the first things he told me was, ‘You look peculiar when you dance’.I guess that worked for me and I gave my audition. A few rounds later, I was finally cast in Boys . Camera was new to me and it was a surreal experience. The first-ever time that KV Anand sir (one of the film’s cinematographers) saw me through the camera was for a small sequence in which I had to walk along the beach, humming a line. Shankar sir had a beach house on ECR and we were shooting there. Anand sir was using an Aari 435 camera.Technically speaking, that was my first experience in front of the camera. The first shot I gave for the film was also my introduction scene of sorts. It was also the first shot of Boys I think. I’d be playing the guitar and singing, and this girl whom I was trying to flirt with would just shut the window on my face. I looked so different in my first film… young, super lean… but I thoroughly enjoyed doing that film.

Title: CAA Protests: Peaceful CAA opposers not 'traitors, anti-nationals': HC
Content:
The anti-CAA protest at Delhi's Shaheen Bagh, going on since Parliament passed the new Act, has been largely p... Read More

AURANGABAD: People wanting to agitate in a peaceful way "cannot be called traitors, anti-nationals only because they want to oppose one law", the Aurangabad bench of the Bombay high court has said in an order on Thursday on a petition challenging denial of police permission to an agitation against the CAA."The submissions made show that there will be no question of disobedience of provisions of CAA by such agitation. Thus, this court is expected to consider the right of such persons to start agitation in a peaceful way. This court wants to express that such persons cannot be called as traitors, anti-nationals only because they want to oppose one law. It will be an act of protest only against the government for the reason of CAA," the bench said.The bench quashed and set aside two orders passed by the additional district magistrate (ADM) of Beed district and the Majalgaon city police in Beed. The police had cited the ADM's order as the basis for refusal of permission.“India got freedom due to agitations which were non-violent and this path of non-violence is followed by the people of this country till this date. We are fortunate that most of the people of this country still believe in non-violence,” the bench said.In the present matter also the petitioners and companions want to agitate peacefully to show their protest," the bench said. "In the British period our ancestors fought for freedom and also for human rights and due to the philosophy behind the agitations, we created our Constitution. It can be said that it is unfortunate but the people are required to agitate against their own government now but only on that ground the agitation cannot be suppressed," the bench added.It further said, "In such matters, the court needs to consider whether fundamental rights of citizens are breached by the order under challenge."The ADM's order had cited the Beed superintendent of police's report apprehending deterioration in the law-and-order situation on account of agitations for various reasons, such as damage to crops due to excess rain, price rise of essential commodities, social protection demanded by various communities, and the protest against CAA. Petitioner Iftekhar Zakee Shaikh had challenged police's refusal of permission for peaceful protests against CAA and NRC at the old Idgah Maidan at Majalgaon for an indefinite period between 6pm and 10pm."It can be said that though the (ADM's) order on face appears to be against everybody, in reality the order is against persons who want to agitate, to protest against CAA. At present such agitations are going on everywhere and there was no whisper of agitations of other nature in this region. Thus, it can be said that there was no fairness and the order was not made honestly," the bench said.

Title: Noida fest draws students from across the country
Content:
Students practising folk songs in the lawns of the venue

Students participate in mehendi making competition

Students showcase acting prowess in One-Act Plays

A one-act play on love in the time of social media by students of Shivaji University, Kolhapur

Learning new experiences

Recently, students from across the country visited Noida to participate in the 35th Association of Indian Universities (AIU) National Youth Festival, which was organised at Amity University . Nearly 1,500 students from 90 universities participated in the inter-varsity competition, which concluded on February 7. The cultural events at the venue included competitions like one-act play, mimicry, classical dance, cartooning, instrumental (western & classic), debating, rangoli making, mehendi making and more.From plays based on themes, like love during the time of social media, climate emergency to classics written by renowned playwrights, students from universities in Maharashtra, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh , Assam and Punjab among others, presented one-act plays on various topics. The plays were performed in Hindi, English and regional languages as well. A one-act play includes only one act and is evaluated on its duration as well as setup time taken.Students of Punjab University , Chandigarh, presented 'Nagmandal', written by Girish Karnad. "This was a fantasy story, which follows a snake who falls in love with a woman, who was feeling neglected by her husband. As artistes, we have given our best to do justice to the storyline as all of us have immense respect for Girish Karnad. We have been practicing this play for the past four months,” said Arun Thakur, a participant from the University.Another play by Shivaji University, Kolhapur showed a young man struggling to decipher his girlfriend’s social media messages with the help of his friends. The play showed how today's youth try to map the behaviour of others through their social media activity and how important it has become in their day-to-day lives.With the venue bustling with activity, students said the festival allowed them to interact with students from various corners of the country. Karam Pal, a student of Punjab University, Chandigarh, said, "We have made friends with some students of other universities and it's great to learn new things from people from different cities. Being here makes me realise the diversity of our country.""I have been to Delhi earlier but this is my first time in Noida. Though we haven't had the chance to go outside yet, we do plan to go to the mall on our last day as we have heard it is one of the largest in the country," said Srishti Sharma, a student of Punjab University.In Video: National Youth Festival held in Noida

Title: Jaipurites plan romantic getaways as V-Day kicks off a long weekend
Content: The Valentine’s Day is over but the fun is not over yet. With an extended weekend that came along with the Day of Love, Jaipurites, especially those who love to travel, are looking forward to exciting times.Rajeev Kale, President and Country Head, Holiday, MICE, Visa, Thomas Cook (India) Ltd, says, “Jaipur is a key source market for us. With a growing demand of over 23% for Valentine’s Day celebrations, we have observed that travellers from Jaipur have planned romantic holidays to iconic locales like Agra’s Taj Mahal, the Eiffel Tower in France, Swiss Alps, privates islands in the Maldives, etc.”“While curated experiences like an igloo stay in Manali, a hot stone bath experience in Bhutan, skiing in Gulmarg, scuba diving in Mauritius, sunset sailing in Abu Dhabi, and ayurvedic spa in Kerala have been popular; luxury stay-cations at renowned historical properties are also attracting consumers from Jaipur,” he adds. He further says, “What is noteworthy is the emerging demand for Bollywood destinations, such as romantic and uber-chic Paris, picturesque Lake Como, historic Venice, Gstaad, Montreux and Zurich in Switzerland, and iconic attractions like Glacier 3000, Jungfrau and the Golden Pass.”Also, apart from couples, the number of solo travellers, groups of friends or family, and those looking for unconventional travel experiences, like white-river rafting in Rishikesh, jeep safaris in Jaisalmer or Thekkady, and swimming with sharks in Thailand, is also rising.Daniel D’souza, President and Country Head,Leisure, SOTC Travel, says, “We have seen a rise in the number of requests from couples in Jaipur wishing to travel on Valentine’s Day. Romantic getaways also include non-traditional experiences, like taking a cooking class, wine tasting, hot-air ballooning, scuba diving, hiring private yachts for a day, private island picnics and couple spa.”Noticing that more couples are opting for offbeat and unconventional destinations to celebrate the day, Peshwa Acharya, CMO, Sterling Holidays, says, “A lot of bookings have been made for hill stations like Dharamshala, Corbett and Mussoorie. Couples usually enjoy hot-air balloon rides, adventure treks and trails, and quiet sun-downers during such holidays ,” he says.Newly-weds Kartik and Aastha Sharma have booked a room at a resort in Pushkar. “Since it’s an extended weekend, we thought of planning a trip to Pushkar and explore every nook and corner of the city. We have booked a spa session for ourselves,” says Kartik, who works as an execution manager in Jaipur.Pooja Khandelwal, a graphic designer, has gone to Phuket with her husband Gaurav Mathur. She says, “We wanted to go out for a very long time. Thus, we decided to travel to Phuket on Valentine’s Day. We have three days to make memories. We just can’t wait to experience the best that Phuket has to offer.”

Title: Vishal-Shekhar excited to remix their own song for the first time
Content: Composer duo Vishal Dadlani and Shekhar Ravjiani were recently in the news when they expressed their displeasure regarding remixes. They even issued a legal warning to people against remixing their work without their consent or giving incorrect credits.Attempts by a section of the music industry publishers to remake/recreate an old song by adding or changing a couple of lines, crediting the new composer for it and delinking the original composers from their actual work, was unacceptable to them. What triggered this move was the news that their hit track ' Dus Bahane ' was being recreated for 'Baaghi 3'. That’s when the duo decided to be proactive; they intervened in the project and recreated the 15-year-old dance number themselves.Talking about it, Vishal said, “This is the first time we have recreated our own song. We did it because a lot of the new remixes are just substandard quickie jobs, which have been done on low budgets, by people looking to make a quick buck or to add their name to an already successful product. We didn’t want that to happen to songs that we have created in the past. 'Dus Bahane 2.0' still sounds fresher than a lot of the music being made now. We didn’t want it to be given the chop-shop treatment that usual remixes sound like. We wouldn't want anyone else to remix our songs.”Vishal, however, maintained that recreations can never be better than the original, “As the saying goes, ‘Baap baap hota hai’. The idea was to just refresh the song, with a strong hint of nostalgia, and a beat that makes you dance. What we did was to try and keep the essence of the original intact, and since it’s our song, to have a little fun with it.”Working on the recreation was a challenge for the composers because the song had already been shot and they had to match their composition with it.Shekhar explained, “The tempo was faster than we would have liked, but we had to keep that because it had already been shot. So, we started from scratch and made a track that fit Tiger Shroff ’s vibe and Shraddha Kapoor ’s moves.”The duo retained the original voices of Shaan, KK, their own and added female vocals of Tulsi Kumar Working on their own chart buster was a rush of memories for the duo. “While working on it, we sent a lot of love to our dear friends Anubhav Sinha (Director, Dus), Abhishek Bachchan, Sanjay Dutt Sir and Zayed Khan who are all long-time friends, and the guys whose swag matched the song,” states Shekhar.“This particular instance will also define the future of how songs are respectfully and correctly re-used with the consent of and full credit to the original creators. I hope it is a breakthrough for not just this film and crew, but for the entire industry,” signed off Vishal.

Kashiyatra, the three-day cultural fest of IIT-BHU was a rocking affair. It was a perfect blend of talent and entertainment. The youngsters showcased their talent right from painting to emoting and host of other performing skills.Salim Merchant (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The most awaited event of the festival was the Bollywood night that had the talented music composers Salim and Sulaiman taking the stage by storm. The duo along with their team were loudly applauded as they made an appearance. Giving a dreamy feel to the evening was their song Shukran Allah with the audience singing along. The youngsters could not contain their excitement as they sang their Main Toh Aive Aive Lut Gaya. Soon the ground turned into a dancing floor. They went on to croon their popular numbers like Haule Haule and Kurbaan Hua.The Local Train band performing at the event (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The duo also turned interactive with the students. “Aap log photos kheech kar social media par dalte ho, is event ki bhi upload karoge. Aaj is instrument, jo mein baja raha ho ki bhi photo upload karna. This is zen drums from which I create various sound according to my mood," said Sulemain.(L) Zakir Khan (R) Uneven (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The DJ night had the presence of Italian artist Uneven, who belted out different genres of music much to the delight of the audience.The comedy night featured Zakir Khan. Title: Salim and Sulaiman add music ka tadka to IIT BHU's fest
Content: Kashiyatra, the three-day cultural fest of IIT-BHU was a rocking affair. It was a perfect blend of talent and entertainment. The youngsters showcased their talent right from painting to emoting and host of other performing skills. Salim Merchant (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The most awaited event of the festival was the Bollywood night that had the talented music composers Salim and Sulaiman taking the stage by storm. The duo along with their team were loudly applauded as they made an appearance. Giving a dreamy feel to the evening was their song Shukran Allah with the audience singing along. The youngsters could not contain their excitement as they sang their Main Toh Aive Aive Lut Gaya. Soon the ground turned into a dancing floor. They went on to croon their popular numbers like Haule Haule and Kurbaan Hua.The Local Train band performing at the event (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)The duo also turned interactive with the students. “Aap log photos kheech kar social media par dalte ho, is event ki bhi upload karoge. Aaj is instrument, jo mein baja raha ho ki bhi photo upload karna. This is zen drums from which I create various sound according to my mood," said Sulemain.(L) Zakir Khan (R) Uneven (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar) The DJ night had the presence of Italian artist Uneven, who belted out different genres of music much to the delight of the audience.The comedy night featured Zakir Khan. The stand-up comedian with his hilarious anecdotes of school time that tickled the funny bone.The nukkad nataks addressed social issues and one of them was even titled Intolerance.(L) Askari and Saksham (R) Bishakha (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Madhu (R) Muskan (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Nancy and Aditi (R) Niveksha Roy (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Ratanpriya and Ayushi (R) Sachi Gupta (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)Rohit Chawla and Isha Dang (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)Sahib, Kanchan, Kajal, Aanant, Amit, Aman and Vishkha (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)(L) Sulaiman (R) Shivam Rai (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Title: Rahul Sharma to lead a 47-piece orchestra
Content: Indian music lovers can now look forward to seeing one of the favourite instruments, the santoor, finally taking lead in the hour-long 47-piece Cape Town Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra India’s santoor maestro Rahul Sharma is elated. “This is the first time that a prestigious international orchestra will include me in one of the finest Opera Concerto halls in Cape Town. It is a dream come true!” he exclaims, adding, “With this the santoor completes an amazing journey that my father and guru Pt Shivkumar Sharma began, which continued through some of my humble efforts in jazz, fusion, electronica and finally, an international orchestra.”Rahul has worked with several international musicians and has a repertoire of pieces with artistes such as KennyG, Richard Clayderman , Deep Forest‘s Eric Moquet , Peter Gabriel, and a good 60 albums. “Working with this orchestra was tricky and challenging as santoor is a 100-stringed instrument. The symphony was conceived with my friend and arranger, Jackie V.”The musician will soon be heading to Cape Town to rehearse with Brandon Phillips , the resident conductor. “He will be the key in bridging the gap between the symphony orchestra and myself. He has been studying the compositions closely and we are looking forward to our rehearsals,” says the santoor player.

Title: Bhagyashree: No one held my hand and said they will launch me in Bollywood: Abhimanyu Dassani
Content:
Abhimanyu Dassani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

How was Lucknow, how did it treat you

Abhimanyu Dassani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Is the before-the-camera fright any less with your second film?

Do you feel pressurised by your mom’s success? Does it bug you when you’re constantly called her son and not an individual entity?

Has being Bhagyashree’s son helped you in Bollywood.

What’s your take on nepotism?

What’s your parents reaction now that you’re doing your second film?

Is the Friday before the release a fear factor for you?

What’s your biggest fear now.

Abhimanyu Dassani maybe just one film old in Bollywood but he talks like a veteran. Son of Maine Pyaar Kiya fame actress Bhagyashree , Abhimanyu was shooting in Lucknow for his next when we caught up with him. A foodie at heart, while Lucknow proved to be a haven for him, Abhimanyu says that being his mother’s son has been of no help in his acting career and the finance graduate feels proud to say that “no one held my hand and said they will launch me in Bollywood”.Excerpts from the young actor’s interaction with LT.I used to come to Lucknow quite frequently because I was into infrastructure for a while. But this trip to Lucknow when I was shooting for Nikamma has been absolutely fantastic. It warms my heart, it’s a special city to me now. I have absolutely loved-loved and loved the food here. The weather was amazing and the people were so warm and friendly. I can’t wait to come back to Lucknow, I’m being honest and spend some more time here, eat some more amazing food. A shout out to Mughal’s Dastarkhwan for giving me the best galawati kababs I’ve ever had. And haan yaar, bahut mazaa aaya, bahut achha khana khaya, bahut achha weather tha and humne bahut achha kaam kiya. Ab aur main kya maang sakta hoon? It was all perfect in Lucknow.Abhimanyu Dassani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Before-the-camera fright, I haven’t had that because I have been in the industry for the last ten years now. It’s exciting to get in front of the camera. Haan woh 30 seconds jo hota hai camera ke saamne aane ke baad action aur cut ke beech mein, I feel like Superman, I feel like Popeye after he’s had some spinach. But yes, this is an absolutely new school, new genre for me so before going sets I watched a lot of films, did a lot of research and in fact, I also spoke to Ranveer Singh on his film Simmba because it’s the same genre. But yes, I was nervous when I was on set but once I was in front of the camera, it was all fine. I love being in front of the camera.Sach toh bol rahe hain yaar. I am mother’s son toh aur kya bolenge. But the intention behind that is to kind of a product of nepotism , which is not true. Anyone who’s seen my film and refers to me as Surya or the man who feels no pain, as in Mard Ko Dard Nahi Hota, that really excites me because Surya is much more famous than Abhimanyu and speaks volumes for what I have done in my film and in international cinema. So it would be great if people appreciated that and kind of like and gave me the credit for whatever I have achieved as an actor already.No. Not at all. Being ‘Bhagyashree’s son’ hasn’t helped me at all. For everyone I am just Abhimanyu Dassani.So it’s about time that we know the truth about nepotism because people have actually blurred and distorted the whole true meaning behind it. And most don’t understand what it is and what process is. It happens in every industry, all over the world. It’s a fact of life and life is unfair and it’s unfair to everyone at some point and that’s what makes it fair. So, no, we just gotta move ahead with it and whoever is speaking on it, your poster boy or poster girl, for the outsiders, quote-unquote are actually in the industry because of nepotism. So….They’re very excited because they’ve seen me change from Surya, this self-confident boy who’s energetic and loves to do everything for everybody to become this nikamma at home. And they’ve seen that gradual change in me to that person I was to the character that I am. So they’re very excited to actually see what I have done because that’s not me as a person. I’m not that loud. So they’re excited to see how I’ve challenged myself and portrayed myself in this upcoming film of mine. I can’t wait for them to see it and I really (emphasises) want my parents to be proud of me.Not at all. For me it’s always been about the journey and the effort that I’ve put in. And I love the grind and getting dirty and going through the whole process and that’s what I’m actually in love with. The results are not in my hands, you can call it luck, fate destiny, whatever you want, but as long as you put in your hundred percent, which I hope and strive to do, every single day, so you know, today, tomorrow or day after, the results will come as long as you work hard and you’re proud of the work that you’ve done in a day, you sleep peacefully. And to be honest, at the end of the day that’s what really matters, right?You know, being able to act and being able to do what I love to do, it makes me feel alive. And you never know, a day mighty come when I’m not able to do what I want to do, not do what I love to do. I think that’s the day I fear most. I don’t know how to exactly put it in words, but it is what it is.

Title: Rakul Preet Singh goes the vegan way
Content: Sometimes, you do something on a whim and then, decide to stick to it for the rest of your life. Rakul Preet Singh would agree. The actress decided to turn vegan suddenly, without any pre-panning or thought, but says that it’s one of the best decisions she ever took.She says, “I have been a hard core non-vegetarian all my life. Not that I didn’t like my veggies, but meat was a crucial part of my diet, especially eggs. However, one day, I just decided to turn vegan. It was a sudden decision — something that came from within, and not prompted by any trend. Now, I feel lighter and full of energy.”Given that her profession includes a lot of travelling, how easy is it going to find vegetarian fare everywhere? Rakul replies, “When shooting in Mumbai, I carry vegan shake, fruits and meals from home. The only trouble is when you are travelling abroad — in many countries, it’s easier to get grilled chicken and fish. But where there is a will, there is a way. If nothing, my team buys any vegetable they can find, and cooks it with some yellow dal and rice, almost like a khichdi. I add vegan ghee to it for taste.”

Title: Auto Expo: Less star power this year
Content:
John Abraham has been to every edition of the expo since 2006. The actor gave it a miss this year

Slowdown in auto sector and Coronavirus scare caused celeb footfall to decrease by almost half this year. While some celebs did attend, frequent visitors like John Abraham, Sachin Tendulkar & Akshay Kumar didn't

From a dozen celebs in 2018 to only eight attending this year

Sachin Tendulkar has missed only one expo since 2002. It is the first time in a decade that Sachin wasn’t present at the biennial event

Sachin Tendulkar has missed only one expo since 2002. It is the first time in a decade that Sachin wasn't present at the biennial event

'There were fewer launches than ever at the Expo this time

Akshay Kumar drew huge crowds during his visits in the previous two editions; (Above) The actor at the expo in 2018

Akshay Kumar drew huge crowds during his visits in the previous two editions; (Above) The actor at the expo in 2018

Did Coronavirus scare keep the celebs away?

Katrina Kaif attended the expo in 2016

Katrina Kaif

attended the expo in 2016

Kareena attended the expo in 2014

Kareena attended the expo in 2014

Not just Bollywood stars, even the sporting fraternity was missing

Celebs who visited this year

The section called'Why Attend' on the official website of the 2020 Auto Expo has one point that states visitors can "get up close and personal with movie stars, sports icons". For years, celebrity spotting has been integral to the mega auto show. This year, however, a combination of factors – most notably slowdown in the auto sector and the Coronavirus scare – meant that the celebrity footfall at the event was negligible.Held at the India Expo Mart in Greater Noida between Feb 7 and 12, the expo registered a footfall of over six lakh – highest ever – as per the organisers. The celebrity footfall, however, reduced by almost half. The previous editions of the event have seen about a dozen celebs every time with the 2016 expo seeing visits from 15 celebrities. This year, the number was eight. Shah Rukh Khan was among the rare big names who visited the expo this year but he did so on the opening day of the event, which is open only for exhibitors and not the general public. In fact, the only film stars who visited the expo on days open for the public were Gul Panag and Soha Ali Khan . Most of the other celebs, including Daler Mehndi and Huma Qureshi, visited on the first two days, when the show wasn't open for general public. This was in stark contrast with the previous editions that saw names like Akshay Kumar, Priyanka Chopra, Kareena Kapoor , Alia Bhatt, and Ranbir Kapoor among others visit on the days open for public.According to an executive with a Japanese auto manufacturer at the expo, "The stars are mostly called by the brands they endorse to launch a new vehicle. But if you notice, there were fewer launches than ever at the Auto Expo this time. That's why most brands did not bother calling their brand ambassadors. The number of launches has been low because of a general slowdown in the auto sector in India." Someone like John Abraham – who has been constant at the show for over a decade – was conspicuous by his absence.A lot of visitors and exhibitors at the event could be seen wearing face masks in light of the Coronavirus scare prevalent in all of Asia. Was that also a reason for some stars staying away? Exhibitors say it could have contributed to some of them giving the event a miss. "Nobody has said on record that this is the reason a star won't visit but many stars' representatives did express concerns about it. It may not have been the biggest reason but could have been a factor in some people's decision,” says an organiser on the condition of anonymity.The absence of celebs did not mean fewer people at the expo but it did dull the experience for many. Nachiket S, a Gurgaon resident who has been visiting the expo since 2012, says, "There is no time table as to when a star will visit the expo. But in previous years, there were one or two celebs every year. This year, there was nobody for days. The main aim of my going there was to see the cars but it was strange not even getting a glimpse of one star." Tanya Singh, a student, adds, "Our college is close to the venue we go there every year. My seniors have selfies with stars they met at the expo in the previous editions. But we found nobody there this time. It looked slightly low key."But it's not just Bollywood that has been absent from the expo this year. The sporting fraternity hasn't made its presence felt either. While previous editions of the event would see visits by top cricketers like Virat Kohli, Sachin Tendulkar, Zaheer Khan, and Gautam Gambhir , this year, the only sportsperson present was former Formula One driver Narain Karthikeyan . "With the Indian cricket team on tour and most other top stars busy with other commitments, none of them could be here. Sachin, who was a constant here for the auto brand he endorses, was also not available," says an insider from the organising team. The Indian cricket team – led by Virat Kohli – are touring New Zealand while Sachin Tendulkar was in Australia to take part in a charity cricket match held simultaneously as the expo. It is the first time in a decade that Sachin wasn't present at the biennial event.SRK led a handful of celebs, including Huma Qureshi, Soha Ali Khan, Daler Mehndi, Gul Panag, Angad Bedi and Narain Karthikeyan, who didattend the expo this year

Title: How journaling helps boost mental health
Content:
Writing, especially anything positive or humourous helps alleviates depression.

Reading your posts lead to higher levels of self-confidence. For instance if you document how you may have felt during a relationship that ended and compare with the present, it will make you see how far you have come.

Writing is a relaxing task and aids better sleep.

On the work front, if you keep a journal of your tasks, it makes for a kind of checklist that can motivate you to do more. It also gives an at-a-glance look at what has worked and what hasn’t.

It also boosts the immune system.

You’ve probably taken down culinary jottings while cooking, notes during an office meeting or even written something absent-mindedly while waiting for a friend. Now, make that a habit. Writing regularly in a diary about one’s personal occurrences and experiences as well as personal reflections, called journaling, is a top strategy for better mental health. Says 38-year-old stock market analyst Tamira Shah, “I never had a diary during my teens or even later. A few months ago, a friend suggested I try journaling. I began with writing once a week and now I do so everyday. It really helped me relax and destress.” A famous quote by Oscar Wilde goes: “I never travel without my diary. One should always have something sensational to read on the train.” Time you started doing so, too...Studies show that penning thoughts this way can have numerous positive effects.- Begin with journaling a pleasant memory or event. Putting such positive thoughts to paper spells positive reinforcement. So, if the week starts off on a wrong note, you can always go back to the happy experience you had a few days ago.- Be true to yourself in your journal.- Writing about nature — the blue sky, rain, and breeze, is seen to be destressing. - It’s a good idea to paste stickers on your pages. If it’s a food page, use a foodie sticker or doodle. For a travel post, add a small ticket or souvenir from a place you visited.- Don’t let the entries be long-winding. Short is the keyword.

Title: Welcoming spring: Delhiites say hello to polo
Content: It's the time to flaunt flowy dresses, floral chiffon saris and oversized hats at the polo grounds as the polo spring season is in full bloom. The season kicked off this month with a big match between Rajnigandha Achievers and Jindal Panther. It mainly saw members of the city's corporate families in attendance, apart from polo players who usually spend Sundays with their families at the Jaipur Polo Grounds. The match, which went on for more than an hour, was won by Rajnigandha Achievers.The audience stands were fully packed with people having fun in the sun. "It is not just a warm, bright and sunny day, but also a day when the air quality is far better than what we have witnessed in the past," said the commentator as many guests nodded and clapped in agreement.Twinning: Kavita Bhartia and Nisha SinghMichael ANN Oquaye Esq, High Commissioner of The Republic of Ghana, said, "This is the perfect day for a polo match, and this match has been really exciting."VC Burman and Sweety Burman Sunjay Kapoor 's one-year-old son Azarius is turning out to be a head-turner at polo matches. This time, a tiny mallet in his hand grabbed eyeballs. The little one even tried to hit the ball, which made some lensmen leave the field to capture him.Baby's day out: Sunjay Kapur with son AzariusTanisha Mohan and Shallu JindalRobby Mohan and Atul PunjMinnie Burman and Neva JainAdhiraj Singh and Michael ANN Oquaye Esq, High Commissioner of The Republic of GhanaUday Kalan and Sanjeev Bijli

Title: Amol Palekar's acting prowess keeps audience on tenterhooks
Content: Co-directed by Sandhya Gokhale (Amol Palekar 's wife), 'Kusur' (The Mistake) revolves around a retired Assistant Commissioner of Police Ashok Dandavate ( Amol Palekar), who has been deputed to the emergency control room of the Mumbai Police . Adapted from Gustav Möller 's Danish film, ' Den Skyldige ', the play is a well-crafted and engaging story of a police officer who is awaiting his trial the next day. In that one night, he oscillates between attending endless phone calls from people seeking police assistance and his conscience pricking him for the guilt of his past actions.Of those frantic phone calls asking for police assistance, one particular one irks him the most. It is the wavering voice of a middle-aged woman, pitched with fear and tension, and who is sobbing between the words. He believes she has been kidnapped by her husband. Despite being repeatedly warned by his friends and colleagues to not get emotionally involved in the cases he is handling, he does exactly that.The plot is simple and predictable. It picks up pace only after this particular woman calls up. One is left wondering as to who this woman is and what is the intent behind her husband kidnapping her and taking her away from their young children.The play marks Palekar's comeback to stage after almost 25 years, and the veteran actor brings the same affability and relatability to his character as he does in films like 'Golmaal', ' Chitchor ' and ' Rajnigandha ', among others.It's not an easy role to play, be it physically or emotionally, but Palekar manages to do full justice to the role. With Palekar's powerful acting and well-coordinated sound design, this 80-minute solo act keeps the audience on tenterhooks. The set design is minimalist and features a simple table that has control panels, buzzing telephones and blinking lights that immediately transport you to the control room and help in building suspense.With Palekar's character, who brings forth a whole gamut of emotions, 'Kusur' (The Mistake) highlights the fact that despite one's good intentions, sometimes it gets difficult to let go of one's prejudices.

Title: Music review: Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan
Content: Directed by Hitesh Kewalya, the upcoming social romcom ' Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan ' has Ayushmann Khurrana Jitendra Kumar , Gajraj Rao and Neena Gupta headlining the cast.A spin-off to 2017’s ' Shubh Mangal Saavdhan ', which dealt with erectile dysfunction, the film focuses on same-sex relationship this time.The soundtrack is as interesting as the subject and opens with a quintessential Bollywood love song with the song 'Mere Liye Tum Kaafi Ho', which captures the essence of the film beautifully. This track has multiple things going for it. Right from actor-singer Ayushmann’s effortless crooning to Tanishk ’s fresh composition or Vayu ’s simple, yet heart-whelming words like, ‘Yeh duniya mile na mile humko, khushiyan bhaga dengi har gham ko/ Tum saath ho phir kya baaki ho, mere liye tum kaafi ho’. While the gender-neutral lyrics capture the universal, all-encompassing emotion of love, Shomu Seal’s guitar and Tanishk’s programming with the addictive beats are worth a hear. This could easily be one of Tanishk’s best compositions.Around 35 years ago Bappi Lahiri’s 'Yaar Bina Chain Kahan Re' ('Saaheb', 1985) with lyrics by Anjaan, was not just a chart-buster, it had also won popular awards. Composed by Bappida (as he is popularly called), a pioneer of disco music in the 80s, he also sang the song with S Janaki.Now, the iconic track has been recreated as 'Arey Pyaar Kar Le' by Tanishk and Ayushmann completely rocks this new version as he wields the mic along with the original singer. The song, penned by Vayu with rap by Ikka, does notdisappoint.The third track 'Pyaar Tenu Karda Gabru' is debuting our Top 20 Charts at Number 9. This is not the first time that Ayushmann-Tanishk-Romy-Vayu have worked together, they have been heard in 'Badhaaiyan Tenu' ('Badhai Ho', 2018) earlier. Inspired by the Yo Yo Honey Singh song, 'Gabru', the song has not been altered much by Tanishk. It also has the lead actors show off their moves in this typical Punjabi dance number.

Title: Love don't cost a thing? Rejection might!
Content: On Valentine's Day, you planned the perfect evening – a romantic meal, some champagne, or a romantic movie night. You also planned on proposing to your lady love, albeit through the clichéd methods – hiding a ring in the champagne flute or going down on one knee while the most romantic song plays that evening. Sounds about right? You've not factored in one key element, though – the girl rejecting your proposal, or maybe, her not turning up!On February 14, dinner dates can be harrowing if things don't go well, and when we spoke to staff members of various hotels and restaurants, they told us that the ultimate question, after all those rejections and heartbreaks, is, 'who will pay the bill – the boy, the girl, or well, the staff?'A staff member of a restaurant tells us, "On Valentine's Day, a couple came in and right before they placed the order, the guy proposed to the girl. I assume she said no because the boy kept asking her why she even came for the date. After about 30-40 minutes, after we kept asking them to place their order, the guy turned to me and, in a calm voice, said, 'Iss ladki ne mere Rs 50-70k restaurant mein ek mahine mein uda diye. Aur yeh abb mujhe mana kar rahi hai.' He then told the girl, 'Theek hai phir! Aaj ka bill toh tu hi degi.' He then placed an order for the most expensive food and drinks on the menu, while the girl remained silent. He ensured that the girl paid the bill, which amounted to around Rs 10-12k.”You may have been rejected and thought that others around you didn't hear your embarrassment; however, this is far from the truth. A staffer at a restaurant tells us, "We once had a couple on Valentine's Day, who looked like they were college students. He must have proposed to the girl, because she said out loud – 'No. We're just friends'. I wasn't trying to eavesdrop, but it was a small restaurant so I couldn't help hearing the conversation. When I gave him the bill, the boy took out his card and said – 'We're just friends, so we'll split the bill as friends do.' He didn't seem embarrassed, but it was quite embarrassing for me."There are times when the girl walks out on you but if it happens on Valentine's Day, my friend, you're doomed. This once happened to a young man at a Hauz Khas Village (HKV) restaurant. The manager narrates the incident, saying, "On Valentine's Day, some boys go overboard. I was working at a popular restaurant chain in HKV, where a boy made elaborate arrangements for the evening. I assume the girl thought it's a get-together and not a date, because the moment she saw the arrangements, she was like 'NO', and left. The guy neither said anything nor stopped her, but he was so heartbroken that he started howling. I felt sad for him, so, whatever he had ordered till then, I told him the bill will be on me."A staff member of a restaurant chain also tells us, "On Valentine's Day, sometimes couples place an order and before the meal arrives, they fight and the order is returned. Sometimes they leave just after having starters, and at times, one person is left at the table crying, and the manager, to retain the client, takes care of the bill."A head staff member of a restaurant chain shares, "It seems that people love creating a scene during V-Day dinners – be it angrily throwing wine on their partner, crying hysterically, calling their ex or just fighting because they didn't like the gift. But some guests compensate for their partner's misbehaviour by leaving a good tip for their waiter. On Valentine's Day, a married couple had a non-stop argument, so much that other guests felt uncomfortable. When they were leaving, the lady told her husband to double the tip for the inconvenience they caused."

Title: Are you set for Singles Awareness Day today?
Content:
Meet up with your single pals and go on a lunch/dinner date.

Exchange gifts or little handwritten-notes on the others in the group to make them feel special.

Self-love matters so send yourself hand-delivered bouquet of flowers.

Get some self-indulgence with a soothing spa massage or exotic facial.

Organise a board game get-together at someone’s place.

Get your single bestie and go on a day-long trip.

Why wait for someone to approve your outfit choices? Go shopping and rejuvenate your wardrobe, your way.

Ask pals to sign up to learn a new skill with you, like cooking or painting.

Make a note to start a healthy habit.

This is day that’s usually lost in the shadows of its more famous counterpart, Valentine’s Day. But not many know February 15 is just as important, and in fact, must be celebrated, too. Singles Awareness Day, which falls today, is meant for all those who are unattached, by choice or not.With single women often plagued by the question as to when they might settle, or even feeling low about not finding a boyfriend or girlfriend, the day only reiterates why there’s no love lost, pun intended, if they don’t land up receiving heart-shaped balloons, cuddly soft teddies and mushy greeting cards. It’s serves a reminder that a romantic relationship is not the only kind of relationship one needs to be happy in.

Title: Rift over Elgar move? Pawar says Maha step 'not proper'
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

KOLHAPUR: NCP chief Sharad Pawar on Friday expressed his disapproval regarding Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray's consent to hand over the investigation of the Elgar Parishad case to the National Investigation Agency (NIA).

"It was not proper for the Union government to take over the investigation from the state government in the first place, and it was not at all proper for the state government to grant consent," Pawar said in Kolhapur. He, however, added that it was the CM's prerogative to take the decision.

Pawar said the Union government decided to take over the Elgar case investigation at 3pm on the same day that the state government had a meeting on the subject from 9am to 11am. "Law and order is a state topic but the Union government went ahead with its move, which is not proper," he said. Pawar has been demanding that a special investigation team headed by a senior IPS officer look into the complaints against some police and home department officers in connection with the Elgar case.

The state law and judiciary department had said that it was within the powers of the Union government to take over the case. The Elgar case file, along with the opinion of the law and judiciary department, was sent to state home minister Anil Deshmukh of the NCP, who was not keen to hand over the investigation to the NIA.

Deshmukh had contended that the state government should request the Union government to reconsider its decision as the Pune police had made considerable progress in the investigation. He was also insisting that the state government seek the opinion of the advocate general.

The file, along with Deshmukh's opinion and the views of the law and judiciary department, was sent to Thackeray on Wednesday and he approved of the investigation by NIA. Accordingly, the home department issued an order saying it had no objection to the NIA taking over the investigation. Deshmukh said on Thursday that Thackeray had overruled his proposal.

When asked to comment on Pawar's statement, Sena spokesperson Neelam Gorhe said, "The CM must have taken the decision in the larger interest of Maharashtra, one should not look for any political point. The CM must have applied his conscience while taking the decision."

Congress spokesperson Sachin Sawant preferred not to comment on Thackeray's decision ands Pawar's reservation about the same.

Title: From Oct, motorbikes to have additional hand grips, footrests, protective covers to make journeys safer
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: From October this year, every motorcycle manufactured will need to have permanent hand grip on the side or behind the driver's seat, a foot rest and a protective device covering not less than half of the rear wheel. While the first two provisions will bring comfort to the pillion riders, the third provision will help prevent the clothes of the pillion rider from being entangled in the wheel.

In a comprehensive set of amendments to the Motor Vehicle Rules , the road transport ministry has also proposed the exact dimensions of the containers that can be allowed on any two-wheeler. This specifications will bring uniformity at a time when food delivery using two-wheelers is becoming the new normal across cities.

“The specifications have been made to see that the vehicles don’t lose balance and there is no overloading. Till now there is no uniform standard and we are fixing the norms,” said a source. As per the proposal, the boxes shall not exceed 550 mm in length, 510 mm in width and 500 mm in height. The weight of the container including its mounting and the load carried in the container shall not exceed 30 kgs.

This will also become applicable from October 1.

As per the draft notification, vehicles, which gets the Tyre Pressure Monitoring System (TPMS), will have to comply with the norms. This will minimise accidents risks and will also help increase the fuel efficiency.

The notification also proposes that all agriculture tractors and construction equipment vehicles will need to get safety cabin for drivers with windscreen and windows.

Title: Lift remaining J&K curbs, EU tells India
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

A group of 25 foreign envoys were in J&K earlier this week

NEW DELHI: The European Union asked the Indian government to "lift the remaining restrictions" in J&K "swiftly" while acknowledging that India had taken positive steps to restore normalcy. The statement came even as NSA Ajit Doval met with the envoys just back from their visit to Kashmir on Friday.

Following a visit to J&K by 25 foreign envoys, which included some European Union ambassadors, the EU issued a statement from Brussels on Friday, saying: "The visit confirmed that the Government of India has taken positive steps to restore normalcy. Some restrictions remain, notably on internet access and mobile services, and some political leaders are still in detention. While we recognise the serious security concerns, it is important that the remaining restrictions be lifted swiftly," the statement from Virginie Battu-Henriksson, EU spokesperson for foreign affairs and security policy, read.

It said the programme by the government "included meetings with civil and military authorities, political representatives, as well as selected members of civil and business community...The visit presented a welcome opportunity to see the situation on the ground and to interact with local interlocutors."

The EU statement comes days before foreign minister S Jaishankar is scheduled to travel to Brussels for talks with EU and to prepare for PM Modi's forthcoming summit in Brussels scheduled for March 13. Meanwhile, others like the Afghan ambassador Tahir Qadiry went on record to say it was "great to come to Kashmir, it's good to see the 'mehman nawaz' people of Kashmir."

Uganda's high commissioner to India Dinah Grace Akello was quoted as saying: "People I have been talking to want this region to be developed. I see a lot of hope now."

Title: Sanjeev Chawla invokes govt's vow to UK, sent to Tihar jail
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Delhi high court stepped in on Friday to cancel the police custody of alleged bookie Sanjeev Chawla , recently extradited from the UK, taking note of his claim that Indian government had assured its British counterpart that he will be kept in Tihar Jail.

Chawla, a British citizen who is key accused in one of cricket's biggest match-fixing scandals that involved former South African captain Hansie Cronje, had been sent to face custodial interrogation of Delhi Police's crime branch by a trial court on Thursday.

Directing the police to ensure that Chawla goes to Tihar immediately, Justice Anu Malhotra said he will be in judicial custody till further orders, even as the bench made Union home ministry (MHA) a party to the case, seeking its stand along with that of the police. Appearing for Chawla, senior advocate Vikas Pahwa cited three letters of assurance (LoA) given by MHA to the United Kingdom clearly stated that he has to be extradited to face trial in the case, in which police filed a chargesheet in 2013. He maintained that the MHA also assured UK government the Chawla will be kept in Tihar Jail as an undertrial and later, if found guilty, as a convict.

"The police remand goes against the assurances given to the UK. Where is the need for custody when the chargesheet has been filed and investigation is over? This is not the mandate of extradition proceedings which have only allowed my client to face trial," the counsel submitted before HC.

The court said it was essential to hear the Centre on the matter as the letters of assurances were issued by the MHA. The petition referred to the MHA's letters dated February 28, 2017, September 22, 2017 and June 11, 2018 giving assurances to the UK government. "The said assurances are the sovereign assurances given by the government of India and are binding upon the government and enforcing agencies inasmuch as the guarantees and assurances are the basis of extradition," it said. "The Indian government had given assurances which are solemn and sovereign assurances that at all times, during pre-trial custody, the petitioner would be lodged in Tihar Jail and therefore, no police remand can be granted," the plea said.

The trial court on Thursday had sent Chawla to 12-day custodial interrogation by Delhi Police, noting the matter was to be probed further for which he had to be sent to various cities across the nation.

Since the investigating officer of the case wasn’t present in HC during the hearing that lasted after the official court hours, Justice Anu Malhotra directed the crime branch to file a status report on the matter while asking MHA too to respond by next date of hearing on February 19.

Title: Four days after he got bail, Kafeel Khan held under NSA
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

AGRA: The UP police late on Thursday night slapped the National Security Act (NSA) on Gorakhpur paediatrician Kafeel Khan , hours before he was expected to walk free from Mathura jail, four days after he was granted bail by an Aligarh court.

Aligarh district magistrate CB Singh said, "Protests had continued in the city and AMU for days after Khan delivered an inflammatory speech on the university campus. In fact, students turned violent on the campus on December 15".

Deputy inspector general (Aligarh) Akash Kulhary told TOI that the NSA allows preventive detention for months if the authorities feel that the person is a threat to national security or law and order.

Khan was booked on December 13 under section 153A of the IPC (promoting enmity between different groups) for a speech at AMU during an anti-CAA protest a day earlier and was arrested from Mumbai airport on January 29 by UP Police's special task force. He was remanded in judicial custody for 14 days on January 30.

Khan continues to be in Mathura jail despite bail being granted to him by the CJM's court on February 10.

Khan's younger brother, Kashif Jameel, who visited Mathura jail on Friday hoping to take his brother back home, told TOI that he was very disappointed with the government's decision of slapping NSA on his brother.

"My brother is being harassed by the government because of his surname 'Khan'. Many political leaders, including those from BJP, had given inflammatory speeches but none of them have been harassed like my brother. They are trying to suppress his voice," he said.

On Friday, Khan's wife Shabistan Khan also reached Mathura jail to meet her husband but she started feeling unwell after she came to know about the NSA charges against him.

Khan's lawyer Irfan Ghazi said they would soon challenge imposition of NSA in court. "The state government doesn't want him to get out of jail," he said.

Claiming a threat to Khan's life in jail, Ghazi said that he has been isolated from other prison inmates and is not getting his medicines.

Title: V-Day: Young couples throng city hotspots
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

PATNA: Love was in the air as Patnaites celebrated Valentine’s Day at coffee shops, malls, hotels, clubs and restaurants across the city on Friday. Most of them spent the day together, ate dinner at fancy restaurants and posted pictures on social media.

Cafés and restaurants lured a large number of customers, especially couples, by introducing exciting offers on V-Day. They also made arrangements for special delicacies, music, dance and games. Shreshkar, the owner of a restaurant on Boring Road, told this newspaper, “We gave several combo offers to couples, as a result of which we witnessed an insane footfall in the afternoon and at night.”

The manager of a confectionery on Boring Road claimed that customized waffles were in high demand. “Many people told us to make heart-shaped waffles with their partners’ names on them. We, on the other hand, asked them to stick notes for their loved ones on a V-Day special board,” he said.

Meanwhile, youngsters had an amazing time on V-Day. Boring Road resident Ankita Sinha, who got married in December last year, said, “This was my first V-Day after marriage. I baked a cake for my hubby and cooked his favourite dish. I also decorated my house with red balloons.”

Kadamkuan resident Shivam Kumar does not believe in celebrating V-Day, but took his girlfriend on a surprise dinner. He said, “Later, we went on a long drive together.”

Singletons, on the other hand, celebrated the day with their friends. “Like every year, my best friend and I watched a movie and drank coffee. We exchanged handmade cards as well,” said Khushboo Kumari, a resident of Danapur.

Title: Three children pay with their lives for playing with fire
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

One of the children had lit a matchstick and had thrown it on the wall of their hut

Rajkot: In a tragic incident , three children , who were playing with matchsticks , were charred to death when their hut got engulfed in flames in Hanumangadh village of Ranavav taluka in Porbandar district on Friday afternoon.

One of the children had lit a matchstick and had thrown it on the wall of their hut made out of dry coconut leaves and dry grass. The hut immediately caught fire and the three children, who stood inside out of curiosity, were charred to death.

“A child who had a matchbox on him, threw a burning matchstick on the wall of the hut. The wall immediately caught fire and soon, the it engulfed the entire hut,” said Devraj Vadhia, head constable with Ranavav police station.

There were three other children in the hut who were lucky to escape the fire. Scared of the leaping flames they ran out of the hut and escaped unhurt.

However, Lakshmi Thavala (4), Ravi Bamania (3) and Nirmala Bamania (2) were not so lucky, and they were charred to death as the fire engulfed the hut.

The parents of the deceased are farm labourers who have come from Jhabua in Madhya Pradesh. Three other huts also got gutted in the flames.

Title: Youth stabbed to death over old enmity in Jasdan, one held
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Rajkot: A resident of Jasdan was arrested on Friday for allegedly stabbing an 18-year-old youth to death in Lati plot locality of Jasdan in Rajkot district on Thursday evening.

Police said the accused, Sanjay Makwana (24) along with his aides — Kiran Makwana and Anil Makwana —, had allegedly stabbed to death Kiran Parmar over old enmity.

“Kiran and Parmar, who were classmates in Jasdan Industrial Training Institute (ITI), lived in the same locality of Ambedkarnagar in Jasdan. They used to have frequent fights over trivial issues. Nursing a grudge against Parmar, Kiran and his aides decided to kill him,” said N H Joshi, sub-inspector with Jasdan police station.

On the fateful day, Parmar along with his cousin Jaideep had gone to the ITI. After the classes were over, Kiran called up Parmar on his phone and asked him to come to Lati plot where both fought with each other. Kiran and his aides had come armed with the intention to kill Parmar, and hence they attacked him with knives. When Jaideep intervened, he, too, was attacked.

Parmar after being stabbed four to five times, was rushed to Jasdan Civil Hospital, where he succumbed to injuries. His family members, who refused to accept his body, ultimately claimed the body and performed the last rites after the police arrested Sanjay.

Meanwhile, the police have intensified manhunt for other accused Kiran and Anil.

Parmar’s grandfather Gordhan Parmar is an ex-member of Jasdan municipality, while his father Ramesh Parmar works as a driver.

Title: Woman tries to end life at police commissioner’s office
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Anju Mulji Dabhi (in circle) is a sanitation worker with the SMC

Surat: A 27-year-old woman sanitation worker tried to commit suicide by consuming phenyl in the premises of Surat police commissioner’s office in Athwalines on Friday afternoon alleging harassment by loan shark. She was rushed to the New Civil Hospital (NCH) where her condition was said to be stable.

The woman identified as Anju Mulji Dabhi, is sanitation worker with the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) residing at Cotton Mill Chawl in Navsari town. She had come to the police commissioner’s office to meet senior officers over the alleged harassment meted out on her family by a loan shark.

Sources said that the woman did not meet any officer and that she was sitting in the parking area of the commissioner’s office. She consumed phenyl when she was spotted by a few policemen.

The cops tried to snatch the phenyl bottle, but the woman had already consumed a small amount. She was taken to NCH in a private car.

Sources in the Umara police station said that the woman had borrowed Rs 4 lakh from a private financier Kamlesh Kahar a couple of years ago. She has claimed that despite paying Rs 9 lakh with interest, the financier were demanding her to pay Rs 7 lakh. The loan shark also threatened the family with dire consequences.

Assistant sub-inspector of Umara police station, Dinu Patel told TOI, “The woman told us that she was fed up with the harassment meted out by the loan shark.”

Patel added, “The woman’s condition is normal. We have started the process of registering a complaint in this regard and further investigations are going on.”

Title: Kidnapped minor girl found dead near Bayad
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Palanpur: Body of a girl aged 17 years and eight months , who was kidnapped few days ago , was found in a canal near Vatrak River , nine km from Bayad town , in Aravalli district on Friday.

The girl was identified by her parents who belong to Khadbi village. On February 12, her father had lodged a complaint naming on Sandeep Solanki of Choili village alleging that he had kidnapped the girl, said HS Gadhvi, deputy superintendent of police, Aravalli.

“The decomposed body of the girl was spotted by some passerby near Vatrak riverbed at around 5pm. We have send the body for postmortem to confirm if she was sexually assaulted or she had committed suicide,” said NP Gohil, inspector, Bayad police station.

Solanki is yet to be arrested.

Title: Gujarat: Man wanted in wife’s murder caught after eight years from Odisha
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: A man wanted in the murder of his wife for the last eight years was caught by the sleuths of Surat crime branch from Ganjam district in Odisha on Friday.

The accused, identified as Kalucharan Gaud (31) a resident of Saroda village in Odisha’s Ganjam district, had eloped with one Rinki Shetty, a resident of Makhanpur village in Odisha’s Ganjam district in 2011. The duo had come to Surat and both started residing in Utkalnagar slums in Katargam. The accused started working in an embroidery unit in Katargam.

In 2012, Rinki delivered a baby girl. However, Gaud suspected Shetty to be involved in an extra-marital relationship and did not accept the girl. The duo would fight with each other on various occasions and Gaud would thrash her accusing her of giving birth to a baby girl born out of her illicit relationship.

On March 1, 2012, Gaud came home in the afternoon and picked up a fight with his wife. Gaud allegedly strangled her and escaped from the spot. A complaint in this connection was registered by Katargam police station, following which the police launched a manhunt for Gaud.

“Meanwhile, we got a tip-off about Gaud, and we traced his location to Babanpur village in Odisha’s Ganjam district. Gaud was working as a masonry in the village and had married to some other woman,” said C R Desai, sub-inspector with Surat crime branch.

Desai added, “The accused was arrested and brought to Surat. We will be producing him before the court to seek his remand.”

Title: CCI probe: HC gives Amazon, Flipkart relief
Content:
(Representative image)

BENGALURU: In a breather for Amazon India and Flipkart, the Karnataka high court on Friday granted an interim stay into a probe ordered by the Competition Commission of India (CCI) against the e-tailers’ business practices. The court has given two months for all the parties involved, which include trade body associations of small merchants, to respond to the plea before it hears the matter again.Trade bodies Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) and Delhi Vyapar Mahasangh (DVM), on whose complaint the probe was initiated, have decided to file an appeal against the HC order “very soon”, a statement by CAIT said.The court’s decision is a relief for Amazon and Flipkart, which is owned by US-based retail giant Walmart. Both the e-taliers have faced tightening regulations as protests from traders against their business practices have increased. Both the US-based companies have invested billions in India, but have faced complaints of deep discounting and favouritism towards select sellers, among others. As TOI reported on Friday, CCI had began a probe but the judgment is a temporary setback for the anti-trust regulator.DVM representatives had gone to the CCI office in Delhi on Thursday for their deposition. “While we welcome and respect the decision of the court, this is just a step in the legal process. We are confident about our compliance,” an Amazon spokesperson said. Flipkart did not respond to an emailed query by TOI.During the hearing, Flipkart’s legal counsel made the company’s first official submission on the matter, essentially agreeing with arch-rival Amazon’s plea on the CCI probe. Flipkart also highlighted that the competition regulator did not have adequate prima facie evidence for a probe under section 26 (1) of the Competition Commission Act, by which an investigation cannot be appealed to CCI. Amazon India had sought an interim stay on the matter under Article 226 of the Constitution of India, under which one can appeal to stay such a probe.“CCI was arguing that the matter cannot be given an interim stay under Article 226 but Amazon submitted a list of such cases under the said section where such interim stay has been given, including one by the Karnataka HC elated to Intel. Amazon’s team prepared the list overnight after Friday’s arguments by CCI,” said one of the legal representatives of Amazon, who did not wish to be quoted.Earlier, Amazon cited cases, where such a probe was quashed by the apex court and the Bombay HC. This was reiterated by Flipkart in the court as well. Justice P S Dinesh Kumar was the judge hearing the matter.Amitabh Kumar, former director-general at CCI and a former partner at law firm J Sagar Associates, said that an order under Section 26(1) is a prima facie one and law does not mandate a hearing before passing such order. “The CCI can call for a preliminary conference before passing prima facie order and has done so many times in the past but not in all cases. It may be difficult to challenge for not having called the party(s) for a preliminary conference. However, sufficiency and adequacy of evidence before the regulator for a prima facie order has yet to be determined by judicial pronouncements,” Kumar said.Legal experts said there is a likelihood that the matter might end up in the Supreme Court.CCI’s January 13 order to probe Amazon came days before the company’s CEO Jeff Bezos landed in India last month, where he announced $1 billion of new investment. Right after Bezos’s announcement, commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal kicked up a row saying Amazon wasn’t ‘doing any favour’ to India by investing as it was to cover up losses, even questioning how a marketplace could lose so much money.The complaint against Amazon and Flipkart has been in the making for a while as small traders have been complaining to the government over various practices by e-tailer throughout 2019, which eventually led CCI to announce the probe. Prior to that, CCI had conducted a detailed study on the e-commerce market. Also, effective February last year, the government tightened the laws for FDI in e-commerce which forced Amazon and Flipkart to make operational changes that affected their relations with certain sellers. For example, Amazon reduced its stake to 24% from 49% in Cloudtail, one of the largest sellers on Amazon India, following the new FDI guidelines.

Title: Aishe Ghosh visits Park Circus sit-in and campuses, slams ‘fascist forces’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Aishe Ghosh speaks to students at Presidency University on Friday evening

KOLKATA/HOWRAH: Aishe Ghosh on Friday attacked RSS and its affiliates BJP and ABVP for targeting the student community and democratic atmosphere on campuses. The JNU students’ union president was at Jadavpur University to address members of the Students’ Federation of India (SFI). She said the RSS feared the nation-wide agitation by students against its ideology of a homogeneous culture and “Hindi, Hindu, Hindustan”.

Sources on campus said Ghosh attacked ABVP because the RSS-affiliated students’ body has fielded nine candidates in various panels in Arts and engineering for the first time. “It (ABVP) is an organization which sends masked goons to campuses to beat up those who stand for the rights of students and campus democracy. They believe in using force whereas universities are places that provide space for free speech and debates,” said Ghosh.

ABVP had earlier objected to Ghosh’s programme on the campus as the modal code of conduct has come into play. After the university authorities refused permission, Ghosh’s programme was shifted outside gate 4.
