Earlier in the day, after walking in a rally in Howrah, the students’ leader said the Trinamool was creating space for RSS and BJP in the state by preventing others from hitting the streets against CAA and NRC. “If Trinamool was serious about resisting CAA and NRC, they would have aligned with other like-minded organizations,” said Ghosh who was prevented from attending a programme in Calcutta University on Thursday.

“The objective of Trinamool Congress is to create space for BJP and RSS in the state by muzzling all other voices,” Ghosh signed off.

In the evening, Ghosh addressed students at presidency University before visiting the sit-in at Park Circus to interact with the protesters who have been demonstrating there for over a month. More than 1,500 people turned up to see her. “I have immense respect for you who have been protesting here to save the country and the Constitution despite having so many other responsibilities. You are making a huge sacrifice and I have come to assure you that the entire student community is behind you. I will go back to Delhi and tell my comrades about the brave women of Kolkata. You have have scared the fascist forces who were trying to divide us on the basis of religion,” Ghosh told the crowd.

Title: Kolkata: No time for grand wedding, SDO, DSP tie knot at work
Content:
Tushar Singla and Navjot Simi register their marriage on Friday

Tushar Singla, a 2015 batch West Bengal cadre IAS officer posted as SDO in Uluberia, and Navjot Simi, a 2017 batch Bihar cadre IPS officer posted as DSP in Patna KOLKATA: Unable to take time out from their tedious schedules, a couple got married in the groom’s office on Valentine’s Day. On Friday morning, Tushar Singla, a 2015 batch West Bengal cadre IAS officer posted as SDO in Uluberia, and Navjot Simi, a 2017 batch Bihar cadre IPS officer posted as DSP in Patna, received the marriage registrar at Singla’s office and signed on the dotted line.Though Simi travelled all the way from Patna to get married in Bengal, both of them are from Punjab and have been in a relationship for a long time. According to officials in the SDO’s office, Singla had not been getting time to go to Punjab for the wedding and it had been getting postponed.After the wedding, the couple promised a grand reception for all those present, but only after the 2021 state assembly elections in Bengal were over.Though Singla was not available over phone, one of the officials close to him said the SDO was not ready to compromise with his duties.Senior state officials said the couple is planning for a change in cadre so they can stay together.

Title: Kolkata: Presidency University's 230 girls stay out of hostel till after 10pm
Content:
The girls outside the hostel in Salt Lake On Thursday

KOLKATA: Around 230 Presidency University students who live in the university’s girls’ hostel in Salt Lake defied the 10pm deadline on Thursday night, staying out till 11pm to assert their demand for relaxation of the curfew for practical and emergency purposes. University authorities, though, pointed out that the 10pm deadline was already beyond what other institutions permitted.On Thursday, the protesting girls finished dinner early and stepped out of the hostel at BF 141. They marched outside, shouting slogans against the hostel authorities, raising a host of issues, including the curfew hour. Some of the other issues were the lack of adequate drinking water facilities in the hostel, refusal to waive guest charges, absence of sanitary napkin vending machines and closure of hostel during vacations.The university authorities, who had earlier written to the guardians seeking their opinions on the relaxation of deadline, argued that the curfew hour at Presidency University was more relaxed than other institutes that did not have hostels on campus. “We will place the demand with the varsity administration,” a hostel official said.A senior university official said the 10pm deadline wasn’t unreasonable. “Most of the hostels in the city have a deadline of 8pm. Compared to that, the boarders of the girls’ hostel in Salt Lake get two extra hours to wrap up work and reach the hostel. When students stay in a hostel, their safety is the university’s responsibility. The deadline and other security measures have been put in place keeping in mind the well being of the boarders,” said the official.Students have been laying siege to the office of the dean of students for the past 48 hours. “We have been requesting the authorities to review the 10pm deadline. The last bus from the university on College Street reaches Salt Lake at 8pm. Thereafter, there is hardly any time to step out because we have to rush back by 10pm,” said Priyanka Das, one of the boarders.Students also alleged that the guest charge of Rs 250 per day — if a woman relative stayed over at times of emergency — was too steep. The hostel charges another Rs 30 for meals. The protesters also complained that the number of water purifiers was inadequate to cater to 230 students. “Last week, my roommate got food-poisoning and we had to call the superintendent for permission to take her to the hospital. Precious time was wasted,” said Teesta Roy, another boarder.Arun Kumar Maity, dean of students, did not comment on the matter.

Title: Begusarai SP faces ire of Giriraj Singh
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Giriraj Singh

PATNA: Top police officials came under attack of Union minister and Begusarai MP Giriraj Singh on Friday for their failure to control crime in the district.

The minister, a firebrand ‘Hindutva’ leader, spoke to Begusarai SP Awakash Kumar over phone on Friday, asking him to pull up his socks. Apparently upset over a spurt in crime, Giriraj said, “Tell the CM that either the people of Begusarai will vacate the district or I will tender my resignation.”

His remarks on the deteriorating law and order situation came on the sidelines of his visit to Phulwaria village, which witnessed three murders within a fortnight. After meeting the bereaved family members of a student, who was killed recently, Giriraj told the SP over phone, “You are an honest officer, but that does not mean everything is fine under your jurisdiction.”

Casting aspersions on police for working hand in glove with anti-social elements, the BJP MP said, “I came to know that police are more interested in picking up close relatives of the victims than initiating action against the accused. Even women are not being spared and summoned to police stations at night in violation of the prescribed rules.”

Giriraj also claimed that there was no fear of police among the criminals. “The situation can be gauged from the fact that three people were killed in Phulwaria alone in a fortnight. What is happening in the district?” he asked.

A transporter, Ravindra Rai and the student of a private school, Prince, were among those killed in the district recently. The Union minister also talked to DGP Gupteshwar Pandey over phone and sought his intervention in controlling crime in the district.

Later, a video depicting the conversation between the minister and the SP vent viral on social media. The SP, however, refused to make any comment on the issue. A DSP-rank officer posted in Begusarai, said, “This is not the way to talk to any IPS officer (read SP). He (Giriraj) is doing so to take political mileage and nothing else.”

Title: Patna: Tejashwi Yadav’s ‘rath’ ready for yatra
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Tejashwi Yadav

PATNA: Leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav will start his ‘Berozgari Hatao Yatra ’ in a customized bus christened ‘Yuva Kranti Rath’ from Patna on February 23.

Painted in various shades of green, the bus has been specially designed to meet rally needs and has slogans and issues written all over it. Tejashwi’s close aide Mani Yadav said the bus can accommodate 10 to 12 people.

The bus has RJD written on its front top and ‘New Bihar’ on the left side of the front glass. It also has photos of Tejashwi along with his parents – RJD chief Lalu Prasad and former chief minister Rabri Devi – and lantern, the party’s poll symbol.

On both sides of the bus, issues like employment, health, education, public welfare and socialism have been mentioned. It is also equipped with sound system and lights. As of now, the bus is parked inside Tejashwi’s official 1, Polo Road residence.

“People want employment, education and health facility. No one wants hatred or bloodshed which NDA government always focuses on. In this yatra, we will focus on people’s need and not on hatred,” Tejashwi said.

His another aide, Sanjay Yadav, said the opposition leader would cover all the districts in two months. “The schedule is being made in such a way that in big districts he will hold two public meetings and in smaller ones at least one meeting. Since the budget session is going to start, yatras will be done on non-working days,” said Sanjay.

The yatra will begin with a public gathering at Veterinary College ground in the state capital. On Friday, Tejashwi also addressed a meeting of RJD functionaries from Patna, Bhojpur and Vaishali and discussed with them the preparedness for the success of the yatra.

Title: ‘BJP’s Delhi defeat increased CM Nitish Kumar’s bargaining power’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Many political observers believe that the BJP’s recent defeat in Delhi has strengthened CM Nitish Kumar ’s bargaining power in the NDA and it would be visible during the finalization of seat-sharing with the saffron party for Bihar assembly election , likely to be held in October-November this year.

JD(U) leaders are hopeful of getting lion’s share in Bihar as far as NDA seat-sharing is concerned after the BJP’s big defeat in the national capital. “Given the BJP’s performance in Delhi polls, the JD(U) will certainly be in an advantageous position when the matter of seat-sharing will come up before the top NDA leaders. However, being a responsible ally, we will not discuss the seat-sharing issue before media,” a top JD(U) functionary, who did not want to be identified, told TOI on Friday.

“In fact, our bargaining power increased when the BJP lost the election in Jharkhand due to its sour relation with ally AJSU Party. The BJP lost elections in at least 14 assembly seats in Jharkhand as the AJSU Party candidates made dent in the votes of the saffron party. After Delhi results, our bargaining power has strengthened further,” he said.

A section of senior JD(U) functionaries admitted in private that the seat-sharing formula of 1:1.4 between the BJP and JD(U) floated by poll strategist Prashant Kishor a few weeks ago, had a very strong logic based on the seat-sharing during 2010 and performance of both the allies during 2015 election.

“Since Prashant is now out of the party, it will not be proper to react on his formula. The JD(U) may insist for more,” said another party leader.

JD(U) national secretary general K C Tyagi said there was no confusion among the NDA partners on the issue of seat-sharing for Bihar election. “Top leaders of JD(U), BJP and LJP will sit together at an appropriate time and finalize the seats as we did during the last Lok Sabha polls. The issue of seat-sharing is not discussed on public platforms or before media,” Tyagi told TOI.

He said the Delhi results would give a very positive impact in favour of the NDA in Bihar. “Arvind Kejriwal’s victory in Delhi has given a strong message that people will award only those who work for welfare of general public. In Bihar, Nitish Kumar is doing more for public welfare than Kejriwal,” he said, adding, “Nitish is an enlarged edition of Kejriwal”.

Bihar BJP spokesperson Nikhil Anand said the Delhi election result has reflected the local sentiment of the voters and it has nothing to do with Bihar politics.

“We are confident in Bihar because first of all, the BJP as well as our NDA allies, JD(U) and LJP, are extensively involved in strengthening the organizational structure at the grassroots level. Secondly, the NDA in Bihar has a long-standing credential where all the partners have a good voter base in state. Third reason is we have a proven face of Nitish who has been successfully leading the coalition governments in state since 2005. Fourth, though we couldn't succeed in Delhi, the unified campaign of NDA has given positive message to our cadres in Bihar. The NDA will sweep the 2020 assembly election in Bihar under the leadership of Nitish,” Anand said.

Title: Govt schools, offices asked to hold programme on environment once a month
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

PATNA: Chief minister (CM) Nitish Kumar on Friday asked all state government offices, schools, other educational institutions as well as government organizations like boards and corporations to hold at least an hour-long programme on a working day every month to create awareness about environment protection and bad effects of climate change.

The CM issued the order during a high-level meeting convened at his residence to review the ongoing implementation of the state government’s Rs 24,524 crore ‘Jal Jivan Hariyali Abhiyan’.

“No other state in India has so far made provision to hold an hour-long programme on environment in its offices and schools every month. It is a unique decision taken by Bihar CM to protect environment,” a senior official told TOI.

He said as per the CM’s order, the schools, other educational institutions and government offices can hold either discussion, debate or different types of competitions on environmental issues with a motive to create awareness among public.

Besides the state’s chief secretary Deepak Kumar and development commissioner Arun Kumar Singh, heads of each important departments like education, health, environment and forest, road construction, water resources, agriculture, PHED and animal and fish resources were present at the meeting.

The CM asked the water resources department officials to work fast on the Ganga Water Lift Project so that safe drinking water could be supplied to the water-alarmed towns like Gaya, Rajgir and Nawada. Under the multi-crore project, the state government has planned to lift water from the Ganga river from Patna district and supply it to Gaya, Rajgir and Nawada towns through pipeline. The Ganga water will be thoroughly processed for drinking purpose within the supply chain system before going to the consumers’ tap.

He asked the officials to give priority to the work of land acquisition under the Ganga Water Lift Project so that the pipeline laying and other construction work could be expedited.

The CM also called for developing eco-tourism at Kakolat in Nawada district and Karkatgarh in Rohtas district.

Title: Builder held for driving carpenter to suicide
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Rajkot: A builder was arrested on Friday for allegedly abetting suicide of a carpenter in Dwarkadhish Society near Gokuldham locality of Rajkot.

Police said the accused, identified as Jaman Kaneria (42), had allegedly abetted the suicide of Rakesh Dharaiya (42). Dharaiya had consumed pesticides at his home in Dwarkadhish Society on Tuesday. He died late that night.

According to the police, Kaneria had given contract of making furniture to Dharaiya, and he had made furnitures worth Rs 2.25 lakh. However, once the furniture was ready, Kaneria refused to make the payment.

“Dharaiya, who had brought the raw materials on credit, was under extreme pressure to pay off his debt, while Kaneria was not releasing the payment. This drove Dahariya to take the extreme step,” said N N Chudasma, inspector with Malaviyanagar police station.

In his suicide note, Dharaiya has blamed Kaneria for his death.

Title: Dangling cables, wires pose serious threat to lives
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Surat: A 56-year-old man in Adajan was mowed down by a luxury bus when he fell down from his two-wheeler after he got entangled in an overhead cable wire hanging loosely on a tree in May 2019. This may be a rare incident, but the dangling cables and wires have emerged as a major safety concern for the pedestrians and vehicle drivers on the roads.

One could find the wires and cables hanging loosely on the trees, across the road, on the fly-overs, hoardings etc., at the major junctions and the main thoroughfares across the city, which are posing a serious threat to the pedestrians and two-wheeler riders.

Majority of the overhead cables and wires hanging dangerously across the city are of the internet and direct to home (DTH) service providers. These cables are hanging on the trees, flyover bridges, above the road-dividers, electricity light poles and hoardings. There are uncovered wires hanging loosely in several areas and at many places, the wire joints are lying uncovered, which may cause an accident.

The textile markets located on Ring Road, Sahara Darwaja and Salabatpura have the cobwebs of such hanging wires and cables, threatening the innocent lives of hundreds of people visiting the markets on daily basis.

Champalal Bothra, secretary of Federation of Surat Textile Traders’ Association (FOSTTA), said, “The hanging cables are a real nuisance. When the SMC (Surat Municipal Corporation) is running a campaign in the textile markets for fire safety, it should also consider the serious threat of the hanging wires to the people in the city. Such service providers should be fined for illegally hanging the wires on the public properties and trees.”

Social activist Rajesh Modi has written a letter to the SMC demanding action against the service providers for risking the lives of the pedestrians and two-wheeler riders by hanging the wire illegally on the main thoroughfares and at the traffic junctions. “At many places, these cables are tied on the SMC trees planted in road divider, the SMC light poles or even on the SMC office buildings. Why there is no actions taken by any of the SMC departments. It’s as if taken for granted that anyone can lay such cables across the city without getting any permission and without paying any rent to the SMC,” he said.

“The hanging cables and wires are posing a serious threat to the pedestrians and two-wheeler drivers as the snapping of the wires can result in accidents and deaths,” Modi added.

SMC deputy municipal commissioner N V Upadhyay told TOI: “We are yet to frame any policy regarding the hanging wires and cables in the city. The cables and wires are not in just one area, but across the city. We will have to sit and think about the possible action against those who are risking the lives of the people.”

Title: 22 fishermen captured by Pakistan agency off Jakhau coast
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Rajkot: Four Indian fishing boats belonging to Okha in Devbhoomi Dwarka district with 22 fishermen on board were apprehended by Pakistan Maritime Security Agency (PMSA) off Jakhau coast in Kutch district early Friday morning.

Bharat Modi, president of Porbandar Fishermen’s Association, said, “We have learnt that 22 fishermen on four boats have been apprehended mid-sea by PMSA near the international maritime boundary line (IMBL) in the Arabian sea on Friday. The fishermen will be taken to Karachi Port.”

“We are yet to ascertain the names of the boats that have been seized. We will get the details, once the boats reach Karachi port in Pakistan,” he added.

Title: 'Nalanda University campus to be fully operational by December next year'
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

The new campus is spread over 465 acres of land in Rajgir, about 110km southeast of Patna

PATNA: All the non-residential buildings of Nalanda University (NU) will become fully operational by December next year. The new campus is spread over 465 acres of land in Rajgir, about 110km southeast of Patna.

According to vice-chancellor (VC) Suniana Singh, five of the 17 non-residential buildings, including the academic, administrative, laboratory, teaching and faculty blocks, are already operational.

“There will also be 80 residential buildings that will include the VC’s bungalow, hostels for girls, boys and married couples as well as quarters for teaching and non-teaching employees. As of now, we only provide accommodation to the students enrolled in postgraduate (PG) courses,” the VC said.

At present, NU has altogether 100 students in different postgraduate courses and 650 in diploma and certificate programmes. Almost 60% of them are from Australia, New Zealand, America, Canada and other European countries.

Talking about the facilities on the new campus, Singh said, “We are developing a green and zero waste campus with most areas covered with trees and water bodies. We will also have battery-operated vehicles, organic farms, composting system, cycling tracks, green corridors, shaded walkways as well as waste-to-energy, sewage treatment and solar power plants here.”

Besides, there will be research centres, auditorium, library, incubation centre, sports complex, gym, buildings for various programmes and a common facility centre on NU campus.

The VC said, “The School of Business Management, which will become functional from this academic session, will run an MBA programme in sustainable development and management. Three more centres — Centre for Bay of Bengal, Centre for Conflict Resolution and Peace Building, and Common Archival Resource Centre — will also come up soon.”

Stressing on the need for research centres, Singh pointed out, “At the Centre for Conflict Resolution, which had been envisioned by chief minister Nitish Kumar, scholars will study the conflicts going around in the world and come up with solutions. The Ministry of External Affairs has approved the Common Archival Resource Centre, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had announced the Centre for Bay of Bengal.”

She added that NU would soon be among the top universities.

Presently, NU has four schools — languages and literature/humanities, historical studies, Buddhist studies, philosophy and comparative religions, and environmental studies.

Title: Two injured as Kanhaiya Kumar’s convoy attacked in Ara
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

A damaged car after the attack in Ara

ARA/PATNA: CPI functionary and former JNU Students’ Union president Kanhaiya Kumar had a narrow escape when his convoy was pelted with stones near Ara in Bhojpur district on Friday. While two people suffered injuries, a vehicle was damaged in the incident. The injured have been admitted to the sadar hospital at Ara for treatment.

Earlier in the day, Kanhaiya was greeted with black flags in Buxar where he had gone to address an anti-CAA meeting at Quila Maidan. Banners were torn and slogans like ‘Go Back Kanhiaya’ rent the air. This is for the eighth time when his convoy has been attacked in the past 14 days of his month-long ‘Jan Gan Man Yatra’ in different districts of the state.

A group of people started pelting stones at the CPI leader’s convoy near Bibiganj under Gajrajganj police outpost in Bhojpur district when it was proceeding towards Ara from Buxar. Shakeel Ahmad Khan, a former JNU Students’ Union leader, who was accompanying Kanhaiya, said, “We had to abandon the car as it got damaged in the attack. We reached Ara in another vehicle and Kanhaiya addressed the people at Ramna Maidan.”

Bhojpur SP Sushil Kumar said two people were injured in stone pelting. While a youth, who was part of the cavalcade, was wounded while trying to flee after the commotion, another motorcycle-borne youth got injured. We are trying to verify whether the second injured was a trouble maker or part of the cavalcade,” he told this newspaper over phone, adding that two people were detained for interrogation and a motorbike seized.

Meanwhile, addressing the gathering at Ramna Maidan in Ara, Kanhaiya, said, “I have been attacked for the eighth time during my yatra. But I will continue to raise voice against divisive politics till my last breath. We don’t want ‘azadi’ (freedom) from country but from problems plaguing the nation.”

Taking a dig at the Nitish Kumar-led NDA government in the state, Kanhaiya said, “They are diverting the people’s attention from real issues. There is no job and people are migrating from the state in search of job. The students are compelled to complete graduation in five years instead of three years. Moreover, no steps have been taken to make small towns like Ara a tourist destination.”

Title: Gujarat: Basement exile for girls in periods
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Girl students outside the Sahjanand Girls Institute on Thursday

RAJKOT: The demaning ordeal that 68 girl students of Shree Sahjanand Girls Institute in Bhuj is a repeat of the infamous 2017 Muzaffarnagar episode, where a warden in a residential school forced around 70 girl students to strip to check for menstrual blood.

The onset of periods practically ostracise the girls like pariahs, a victim told TOI, while talking about the institute’s archaic rules.

The girls in the menstrual cycle have to sign a register in the hostel while going to the basement to stay in ‘quarantine’ for four days

“The basement area is in a pathetic condition with heaps of rubbish strewn everywhere. All girls hesitate to go there as it is not only difficult to live there alone in the dark but is also very frightening at times. We have to sleep on cement slabs, carry our own makeshift bedding and utensils. We cannot go to our room or even meet friends in the common area for dinner or lunch. Kitchen, dining area and place of worship were totally out of bounds for these girls, which often make many sink into severe depression,” she said, her voice quivering from the trauma.

That’s not all. In the final assault, these quarantine girls are also not allowed to attend the general assembly or sit in the classrooms like normal days. The ‘outcasts’ have to strictly occupy the back benches only.

And it’s a vicious monthly cycle till they graduate and leave the institute finally.

“It was sheer mental torture and we don’t have words to describe it,” said the victim, who claims that the Monday backlash was actually an outcome of the authorities suppressed anger of not finding a few names for a lengthy period of time in the basement register. The discovery of a soiled sanitary pad in the garden outside the hostel on Monday was just the trigger point, she added.

Title: Telco distress call: SBI says it’s prepared for the worst
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: State Bank of India (SBI) chairman Rajnish Kumar on Friday said the bank was prepared for the worst following the Supreme Court order asking telecom companies to immediately pay adjusted gross revenue (AGR) dues to the government. SBI has Rs 29,000-crore loan exposure to telecom, the largest among Indian banks.Shares of SBI fell 8%, while other lenders with large exposure to telcos like Yes Bank and IndusInd Bank also dropped up to 5% on Friday. Analysts fear that the SC order could lead to a Vodafone Idea shutdown. “It may result in Rs 1.2-lakh-crore debt default, large-scale job losses and subscriber churn,” said Motilal Oswal in a report.Addressing reporters on the sidelines of the Nasscom Software summit here, Kumar said: “Our exposure to them is Rs 29,000 crore. After this order we will ask them what their plans are to comply with the order and whatever is the situation, we are capable of handling it.” He added that he expected the telcos to have identified “a course of action” as the order was known for some time.So far, SBI has provided only for non-performing assets (NPAs) in its telecom loans. “We had NPAs of about Rs 9,000 crore and there is recovery expected there. On the standard assets, we did not feel the need to provide,” said Kumar. Besides the loans, SBI has an additional Rs 14,000 crore of non-fund exposure, which includes guarantees to the government, where the telcos have not defaulted.“It is now for the telecom companies to decide how to find the money or what course of action they will take,” said Kumar. Analysts had earlier expected that the government would provide relief to the telcos. The Centre is counting on Rs 90,000 crore of spectrum dues from Vodafone, which in turn owes banks Rs 30,000 crore. Given that the promoter’s investment in the company is Rs 15,000 crore there is a likelihood that Vodafone and Aditya Birla group will walk away.In December last year, Aditya Birla Group chairman Kumar Mangalam Birla had said that Vodafone Idea may have to shut down if there is no relief in the statutory dues. If Vodafone shuts shop, it is seen to benefit Reliance Jio and Airtel. “Bharti is relatively well placed considering Rs 18,800-crore cash on books and its ability to raise requisite capital. In the absence of any government support, we see this market heading towards a duopoly, which is likely to boost Bharti’s market share,” said Sandip Agarwal of Edelweiss Research.Last month, India Ratings had downgraded Vodafone India from ‘IND BBB-’ from ‘IND BBB’ and retained on rating watch with negative implications. “The downgrade reflects the crystallisation of adjusted gross revenue related liabilities for Vodafone Idea after the Supreme Court’s adverse ruling on January 16, 2020, dismissing the review petition filed by telcos. The SC ruling provides clarity on the liabilities that are payable by Vodafone Idea to the department of telecommunications, which was earlier contingent upon the outcome of the review petition,” said Priyanka Bansal, senior analyst with India Ratings after the January 16 decision.

Title: 80 developers, 180 projects, at Great Times Property show
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The Great Times Property Festival, a first-of-its-kind initiative by the Times Group , is a one-stop shop for homebuyers.

The month-long home-buying festival, which will conclude on February 23, features over 80 leading developers with inventory spanning 180 projects across Mumbai, Delhi, Gurgaon, Bengaluru, Chennai, Pune, Ahmedabad and Vadodara. Potential buyers can visit Timespropertyfestival.com and check out projects and offers within the city of their choice.

Developers from all segments of real estate will offer their housing formats. The website has project-specific information with descriptive pictures of amenities, videos, floor plans, as well as special deals and incentives offered by each developer. Potential homebuyers will have several options for housing available on one portal. Each featured developer offers special deals that are available for a limited period.

The average home loan interest rates stand at 8%, the lowest in a decade. The government has set up an alternative investment fund (AIF) to provide relief to developers with unfinished projects. Additional deduction of Rs 1.5 lakh on interest paid on affordable housing loans is extended to March 31, 2021. GST rates stand at 1% for affordable housing projects and 5% for others.

According to a recent study, 87% of consumers are looking to buy a home for self-use this year, while 64% are looking to make the transition from a tenant to a homeowner this year.

Title: Flyer who lost cabin bag carrying jewellery gets it back a week later
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jayalakhsmi Chatterjee (extreme right) with her family members at the NSCBI airport police station with her ba... Read More

KOLKATA: An elderly Hindusthan Park resident who had lost her cabin baggage that had gold and diamond jewellery worth Rs 5 lakh at Kolkata airport last week got the bag back — with the valuables intact — on Thursday night after cops and airline officials tracked the man from CCTV footage who had “accidentally” picked it up and had taken a flight to Silchar. They convinced him to come back and return the woman’s luggage.

Jayalakhsmi Chatterjee, cops said, verified that the bag was still sealed and all the ornaments were in place.

According to cops, the woman was about to board an IndiGo flight to Hyderabad with two bags on February 6. She was placing one bag at the manual X-ray machine when she suddenly realized the small metallic blue trolley she had placed by her side was missing. “She had alerted the airline staff and CISF officials, who began a search but couldn’t locate the missing bag. By the time they managed to locate the man, they realized he had already taken a flight to Assam. The woman subsequently left for Hyderabad. She lodged an official missing complaint after returning to the city on February 9,” said an official of NSCBI airport police station.

Meanwhile, assistant SI Suraj Dutta and two officials of IndiGo’s vigilance team — Biswadip Bose and Ayan Saha — contacted the man, Upendra Sahu. However, he had already gone home to the Nagaon district, around 200km from Silchar. “The man said he had come to Kolkata to attend a wedding and had accidentally picked up the bag while heading home with relatives. We were in touch with him over all these days. He informed us that he was coming to the city on Thursday and would be coming with the woman’s bag,” said the official.

On Thursday evening, officers received him at the airport and escorted him to the police station, where Sahu returned the bag to Chatterjee in presence of senior officers.

“The woman checked the contents of the bag and was sure that nothing was missing,” the official said.

Title: Indian pharma companies want Chinese imports tested
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Worried by the spread of deadly COVID-19 (coronovirus), pharma companies have asked the government to set up a mechanism under which imports of raw materials (active pharmaceutical ingredients) from China, are tested in laboratories, once they enter the country.Industry body, Indian Drug Manufacturers’ Association ( IDMA ) recently raised concerns about possible spread of infection, and wanted the mechanism to be put in place, once imports from China resumed. India imported Rs 17,400 crore worth of APIs from China in FY19. APIs for manufacturing cardio-vascular, diabetes, antibiotics, anti-infectives and vitamins are imported, while for certain APIs, dependence on China is around 80-90%.A similar directive was issued for agriculture shipments from China, and sent to importers, exporters and plant quarantine offices nationwide on February 5.“We are planning to ask the government to have the samples inspected and tested in laboratories, or get them cleared by agencies (like Indian Council of Medical Research) to rule out any contamination,” an IDMA official told TOI, adding, a final decision is yet to be taken.Most pharma ingredients and intermediates imported from China are produced in Hubei province or adjoining areas, while Wuhan , Hubei’s capital, is the epicentre of the outbreak. If the production stoppage prolongs in regions like Hubei, it would have an impact on Indian industry, with a possible spike in prices, and shortages. Last week, Cipla and Lupin top management said after their earnings’ call that they have stocks available for two-three months.Due to panic and "speculative buying", bulk drug prices of Paracetamol, Penicillin, cardio-vascular and diabetes have reportedly started rising from January."At the moment, we haven’t seen any major disruption in API supplies due to Coronavirus outbreak in China. Supply has been impacted for few API products and we are closely monitoring the situation. We have sufficient inventory of API and raw materials for the short term,” a Sun Pharma spokesperson said.

Title: Coronavirus Impact: Coronavirus may hit 28% Indian imports
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The country’s construction, auto, chemicals and pharma sectors are expected to be the worst affected due to COVID-19 , which carries the risk of global supply chain disruptions. Five import items that are heavily dependant on China -- electrical machinery, machinery and mechanical appliances, organic chemicals, plastics and optical & surgical instruments -- that make up about 28% of India’s import basket could be hit the most due to a potential shutdown, analysts say.As a result, construction, transport, chemicals and machinery manufacturing could be affected, though the overall impact of COVID-19 on India’s trade is expected to be modest. There may not be much impact on the country’s exports as China accounts for just 5% of the country’s total outgo, but certain commodities like organic chemicals and cotton could face headwinds as they have a sizeable share in exports.China accounted for around $73 billion, or 14%, of India’s total imports of $507 billion in FY18. China is the biggest source for imports, though its contribution to India’s total imports is less than one-seventh. The coronavirus is likely to keep factories and industrial hubs in China closed beyond February 17 when the Lunar new year holidays end until the epidemic is brought under control, leading to extensive potential production losses.Among imports, organic chemicals is likely to be among the worst-affected commodities due to the crisis. India imports close to 40% of its organic chemicals from China, while other sources — US and Singapore, also depend on China to varying degrees, says a note from ICICI Securities.India also imports 40% of its electrical machinery from mainland China, and with Hong Kong, its share goes up to 57%. Over half of India’s electrical machinery imports are likely to get impacted. Further, India imports almost one-third of its machinery and mechanical appliances from China, and a prolonged shutdown is likely to put 30-40% of machinery imports at risk.For optical and surgical instruments, China is the largest supplier with a 16% share, hence these could be also impacted. Around 54% of India’s import basket is dependent on China — of which 28% is heavily dependent, and the remaining 26% has modest dependence. Import items among the 26% include iron, steel and inorganic chemicals. Plastics are also likely to be hit, although at a lower extent.Domestic pharma companies could also face disruption if the crisis extends beyond three to four months, as key raw materials (active pharmaceutical ingredients — APIs) and intermediates are imported from China. For certain API used for anti-infectives, antibiotics, vitamins, anti-diabetes, dependence on China is 80-90%, industry experts say.

Title: Bihar gets award for record egg production
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Bihar was conferred with the ‘ Best State Award 2020 ’ on Friday under the India Poultry Awards 2020 category for achieving excellence in egg production with spectacular growth rate of 44.72% in the last three fiscals, four times the national average, animal husbandry and fishery resources (AHFRD) said on Friday.

AHFRD principal secretary N Vijaya Lakshmi received the award at a function held in Delhi. The organisers of the award rated Bihar’s achievements made in the poultry sector as the “mega success story”.

The department maintained that while Bihar with over 88% of people dependent on agriculture sector had been the consumer state in the non-agriculture produce like eggs and fish, spectacular growth achieved in the last three fiscals had changed the scene.

The projected growth rate for the current 2019-20 fiscal over the previous one is estimated to be 50.57% at 265 crore of egg production, while in fish production the gap between the import from the state like Andhra Pradesh and local production in Bihar has also been drastically narrowed, AHFRD added.

Egg production in the state was 100 crore in 2015-16, followed by 111 crore in 2016-17 fiscal, 122 crore in 2017-18 and 176 crore in 2018-19. The leap in the egg production growth rate has been whopping 65% in 2018-19.

As a matter of fact, remarkable growth rate has been witnessed in all the segments of non-agriculture produce in the last three fiscals – like egg production (65%), meat (19.63%), fish (18.47%) and milk (17.43%), the AHFRD said, adding that the livestock production constituted 36% of the overall contribution by the agriculture sector to the gross state domestic product (GSDP). While the sector has gone a long way in poverty reduction in the state, it has also created self-employment opportunities for the people concerned.

Title: Tej Pratap Yadav bats for Tejashwi Yadav as CM, vows to uproot NDA
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Tej Pratap Yadav releasing a poster in support of his younger brother Tejashwi Prasad Yadav at Patna on Thursd... Read More

PATNA: Incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s elder son Tej Pratap Yadav , who had embarrassed his party by raising questions over distribution of tickets in 2019 general elections, seems to be determined to work with his younger brother Tejashwi Prasad Yadav ahead of the upcoming assembly elections in the state.

Tej released a poster on Thursday with a punch line ‘Tej raftar, Tejashwi sarkar’. “Tej raftar badhana aur Tejashwi ko mukhyamatri banana hai,” Tej said at the poster launch event at his official residence on Strand Road here. “We are ready for mission 2020 and our target is to form government of poor people,” he added.”

Speaking at another public meeting at Bihta on Thursday, Tej said all RJD workers should unite to make Tejashwi the next CM of the state. “This is our concept and we will move ahead with this while organizing various programmes ahead of the election,” he said.

Tej was health minister in Mahagathbandhan government headed by chief minister Nitish Kumar from November 2015 to July 2017. Though he has claimed on numerous occasions that Tejashwi is his ‘Arjun’ and he is ‘Krishna’, Tej also left his party red-faced on many occasions during and after the 2019 general election.

Tej had fielded two of his own candidates as independents in two parliamentary constituencies – Jehanabad and Sheohar. However, the nomination papers of his choice for Sheohar seat were rejected on technical grounds. Later, JD(U) candidate won from Jehanabad constituency by a margin of little over 1,000 votes.

Days after the announcements of results of the Lok Sabha election, Tej wrote to Tejashwi in May, stating that those who distributed tickets and the candidates should take the responsibility for the poll debacle.

Over the next few months, the elder Yadav scion kept floating different outfits, such as ‘Tej Sena’ and ‘Lalu-Rabri Morcha’, which led to rumours about him trying to distance himself with Tejashwi. However, none of these outfits is working on the ground. The latest in the series is ‘Lalu Prasad Brigade’, the logo of which was seen on the poster released by Tej Pratap on Thursday.

Political observers said by launching the new poster in support of Tejashwi, Tej is trying to send out the message that all is well in the family, especially among the two brothers.

Tej also attacked CM Nitish Kumar while launching the poster. “Aapki palti mari Se trast hai Bihar, ab Bihariyo ko chahiye tej raftar Tejashwi sarkar,” Tej tweeted on Thursday.

Title: Prepare DPRs for Ashok Rajpath and Karbigahiya elevated roads: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

PATNA: The city is set to get a major infrastructure boost with the road construction department (RCD) on Friday approving preparation of detailed project report (DPR) for the proposed nearly three-km-long elevated road between Kargil Chowk and NIT Mor on Ashok Rajpath .

A decision in this regard was taken at a meeting convened by road construction minister Nand Kishor Yadav to review some major projects of Bihar Rajya Pul Nirman Nigam Limited (BRPNNL).

The road construction department has also approved preparation of DPRs for another elevated road – Karbigahiya to Old Bypass Road – and a four-lane bridge over the Falgu river in Gaya.

“The proposed four-lane elevated road is aimed at decongesting the vehicular movement on Ashok Rajpath. The road will be constructed with an estimated expenditure of Rs 300 crore,” the RCD minister told TOI.

Ashok Rajpath is one of the busiest streets in the city with several major establishments, including Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) and Patna University along it. Besides, there are hundreds of shops and commercial establishments, leading to movement of tens of hundreds of vehicles on the road throughout the day. Encroachments on the road and illegal parking aggravate traffic problem on the road.

The state government has also proposed to construct metro rail line on Ashok Rajpath under the 14.45km north-south corridor (proposed ISBT-Rajendra Nagar Terminal- Ashok Rajpath-Gandhi Maidan-Dak Bungalow Crossing-Patna Junction) in the metro project.

The minister said feedback and suggestions will be taken from state urban development and housing department (UDHD) for construction of the elevated road on this stretch.

Ashok Rajpath apart, the RCD minister said another four-lane elevated road from Karbigahiya to Old Bypass Road will ease vehicular movement for commuters going from Karbigahiya end of Patna Junction to Kankerbagh.

“Only one-way vehicular movement is allowed on the existing railway overbridge (ROB) at Karbigahiya at present, for vehicles going from Old Bypass Road towards Karbigahiya. However, with the construction of the 960-metre-long elevated road, vehicles will move smoothly from the opposite direction as well,” the minister said.

He added that a proposal for a bridge parallel to J P Setu was also reviewed in the meeting. The minister said work on R-Block-Beerchand Patel Marg flyover will be completed soon. The project entails an expenditure of Rs 118 crore.

FOR GRAPHICS:

Project: Elevated road on Ashok Rajpath from Kargil Chowk to NIT Mor

Length: 2,070m

Number of lanes: Four

Project cost: Rs 300 crore

Completion period: Three years

Title: Waterlogging: Govt issues notification for suspension of three officials
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

PATNA: The state general administration department on Friday issued formal notification for suspension of an IAS and two BAS officers for their negligence which led to prolonged waterlogging in Patna in September last year.

The suspended officials are the then managing director of Bihar Urban Infrastructure Development Corporation (BUIDCo) Amrendra Kumar Singh (IAS), the then executive officer of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC)’s Bankipore circle Birendra Kumar Tarun and the then executive officer of PMC’s New Capital circle Shailesh Kumar.

The notification issued by general administration department for suspension of Singh stated that he was found responsible for lapses in making diesel available at 39 drainage pumping stations, repair of damaged generator sets and transformers and ensuring availability of skilled manpower for tackling waterlogging situation.

Earlier, the state government had suspended 14 other senior officers, including Singh, Birendra and Shailesh on the basis of findings of a three-member committee to probe reasons for waterlogging, identifying officials for lapses and recommending measures for preventing waterlogging in future.

The committee was headed by development commissioner Arun Kumar Singh and its three other members included principal secretary of road construction department, finance department and disaster management department. The committee was formed on directives of CM Nitish Kumar.

Many low-lying areas of Patna, which witnessed more than a fortnight-long waterlogging after the rainfall in the last weeks of August and September last year included Rajendra Nagar, Kankerbagh, Pataliputra, S K Puri and Gola Road.

Title: Govt to meet pharma industry reps
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Mumbai: The department of pharmaceuticals has called major industry representatives on February 19 to discuss import-dependence of critical raw materials (APIs) and key intermediates. At present, the domestic industry has an inventory for three to four months, after which it could face disruption. Due to the panic triggered by the spread of the coronavirus and the extended lockdown in China, speculative buying and bulk drug prices of paracetamol, penicillin, cardio-vascular and diabetes have reportedly started rising from January. “At the moment, we haven’t seen any major disruption in API supplies due to Coronavirus outbreak in China. Supply has been impacted for few API products and we are closely monitoring the situation. We have sufficient inventory of API and raw materials for the short term”, a Sun Pharma spokesperson said.

Title: Franco-German firm officials to visit Surat for Metro rail project
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Surat: A team of Franco-German firm officials will pay a final visit to Surat next week for finalization of finance formalities for the Surat Metro Rail Project. It is expected that the 38-km long two-phased rail project with 38 rail stations will commence in May and get completed in 36 months.

Municipal commissioner of Surat, Banchhanidhi Pani said, “The team’s final visit is slotted for next week and once that is done and the government decides, work on the ground will get underway in another three to four months.”

Gujarat Rail Metro Rail Corporation Limited is implementing the Rs12,020 crore project. A 10-member team comprising five members each from German development bank KFW and French development bank AFD who have been working in tandem to finance a number of developmental projects across the world, visited Surat in June 2019 .

The two-corridor project costing Rs12,020 crore will have 20 per cent equity from government of Gujarat, 20 per cent from government of India and the remaining 60 per cent by multi-lateral finance institutes.

The two corridors that are planned for running metro rail include a route which starts from Sarthana and reaches Dream city in Khajod. It is basically designed to cater to thousands of diamond workers from Varachha and Katargam to reach dream city via old city.

The second route of Saroli to Bhesan is designed to provide alternate transport to large working class of the city to travel to their places of work from west and Udhna zone.

Projects revised Detailed Planned report (DPR) says that development of four of the 38 rail stations will be done by local body on PPP basis. The cost of development of a station is estimated at Rs111 crore. The four elevated stations that will be developed by SMC include Rupali canal and Althan Tenement stations on corridor no-1 and Aquarium and Athwa Chowpaty stations that is in corridor no-2.

Under the revised DPR, it has been made clear that the comprehensive mobility plan has been made for 30 years, keeping in mind the population of the city. Maintenance and operation of the project will be done through PPP and systems like automated fare collection and station administration will be managed that way. Transit-oriented development will take place through sale of additional floor space Index (FSI) for additional income and SMC will have percentage partnership as a local body.

Title: Councillor’s threat forces repair of BRT swing gates
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

SMC’s BRTS cell has repaired 13 gates

Surat: Officials of the Surat Municipal Corporation’s (SMC) BRTS cell are on their toes these days.

Following the threat by Hemali Boghawala, chairman of public transport committee of the SMC over non-operational automatic swing gates in the BRTS corridors, the cell has repaired about 13 gates, which were non-operational for the last six months, in just two days.

Bhogiwala had threatened to sit in the office 24x7 until the swing gates become functional again. Majority of the swing gates are non-operational in the corridors located at Pandesara, Udhana, Bhestan, Parvat Patia, Varachha, Kamrej etc.

Boghiwala said despite several reminders to the officials over the past six months, about 38 gates are non-operational.

Talking with TOI, Boghawala said, “I inspected the swing gate at the Pandesara BRTS corridor on Wednesday and they were not working. I immediately summoned the officials on the site and asked them to repair the gate or else I would in the corridor for the whole day. The gate was repaied in just an hour.”

Boghawala added, “If one swing gate could be made operational in an hour, I thought of sitting in the office for 24 hours to get 24 swing gates operational. Due to the non-operational swing gates, motorists are driving in the BRTS corridor without fear and the accident cases are rising.”

Official sources said that there are a total of 276 swing gates installed in the 19 BRT corridors across the city. In the last six months, 38 got damaged due to various reasons.

“Mumbai-based company which has got the contract to maintain these swing gates was given at least 18 notices in the last seven months. Recently, the company was served another notice warning of termination of the contract after which it started repairing the gates,” said executive engineer of BRTS cell, DR Gohil.

Gohil the contractor repaired 13 gates and work for 25 others is on.

Title: Act against lawyer for post on women IAS officers: MLA
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaipur: BJP legislator Anita Bhadel on Friday demanded the government to act against a senior lawyer for posting ‘derogatory’ and ‘obscene’ comments on social media against women IAS officers posted in Ajmer.

Raising the issue in the assembly during the Zero Hour, Bhadel claimed that the lawyer posted "obscene" and "objectionable" against the women IAS officers a few days back on social media. The MLA alleged that the lawyer wrote on social media that there was an obscene video clip of a woman IAS officer which is shameful. Following this, all four-woman IAS officers posted in Ajmer lodged separate cases against him. The legislator added that the accused has not been arrested.

She said the officers accused has been trying to blackmail officers with such wild allegations to get his illegal works done. Bhadel said the police allowed the accused to get bail in court because of their inaction.

"Police did not take timely action and in the meanwhile, the accused got a stay from the court. The government should take legal action through court to get him arrested," the she demanded.

Earlier this month, the lawyer, Rajesh Tondon, claimed on a WhatsApp group that there was an obscene video clip of a woman IAS officer. He, however, did not name anyone. After the post went viral, all the women IAS officers stationed in Ajmer lodged complaints against him.

Title: Cyclist killed, biker hurt in two accidents across city
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolkata: A 47-year-old cyclist was killed and a young man on a bike was severely injured in two separate accidents in the city on Friday.

Around 10.30am, the cyclist was knocked down by a minibus on the Tegharia-Howrah route at Ultadanga crossing. He was taken to the nearest hospital where he was declared dead on arrival.

Also on Friday morning, a 28-year-old biker, Mukesh Jaiswal, was severely injured after being hit by a prison van of Bidhannagar Commissionerate near Atghara on Rajarhat Road while the van was heading towards Chinar Park.

Jaiswal, a businessman and a resident of Dashodrone, was taken to a private hospital where he was admitted with severe injuries on his legs.

Police have seized the bus and the prison van and initiated proceedings against the drivers of the vehicles.

Title: Bihar: Two girls fight it out with knife on Valentine Day
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

BHAGALPUR: Valentine’s Day turned ugly at TNB Law College in Bhagalpur when a “catfight” between two woman students in love with the same man, a fellow student, went out of hand as one of them took out a knife and threatened the other.

The girl who brandished the knife also threatened to slash her own wrist, according to fellow students present during the brawl. The two women fought over “sitting arrangement” in the classroom where a joint class was being held of a senior and a junior batch.

A college administration official said, “The girl who threatened another girl was mentally unstable and the incident happened due to her disturbed mental state. No one received any injuries.”

“The incident is related to a trivial matter. Parents of both girls have been called and a meeting is being held to end the dispute. We will take suitable action against the guilty student,” said Sanjiv, office in-charge of TNB Law College.

Navnish Kumar, SHO of Barari police station, rushed to the spot along with women cops to end the dispute. “No FIR has been lodged as neither party made any written complaint. The matter is being investigated and the college administration is also making internal inquiry. We will lodge an FIR only after the college administration or any of the girls give a written complaint,” the SHO said.

Title: Battling several odds, Varanasi’s acid attack survivors rebuild life with cafe
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Acid attack survivors at the Orange Cafe in Varanasi

VARANASI: Located close to a temple of Goddess Durga, the epitome of women power, Orange Café & Restaurant – a new venture owned and managed by acid attack survivors – is a symbol of grit and spirit to take challenges head on.

Putting the trauma of their past behind, four acid attack survivors, Sanno Sonkar of Jaunpur, Somvati Devi of Bareilly, Sangeeta of Allahabad, Vimla of Rae Bareli and Badama Devi of Varanasi embarked on a new journey with the inauguration of Orange Café in Durga Kund area on Friday. “It is not easy to forget the horror of our past, but we are sure this new venture will heal the scars that we suffered on our soul and help us in leading a respectable life,” said Sangeetawho did not want to recall the horrors of acid attack. “We are happy that we will be able to serve people with best of culinary delights,” said Sanno Sonkar.

“The restaurant has come up with the support of Action Aid India and Care Today. The name Orange symbolizes UNESCO’s ‘Orange the World’ campaign against all forms of violence against women,” said Ajay Patel, the brain behind the venture.

Patel is the founder of Red Brigade which has been working for the cause of women. “After Lucknow and Agra, this is the third café in the state being run by acid attack survivors. But this one is entirely different from other two restaurants. Here, they are not employees but owners. They will share profits,” Patel said.

Before beginning the café, these women were trained on how to take orders, serve food and manage cash counter. The décor of was created with the help of faculty of visual arts of Banaras Hindu University.

Title: Shivraj takes out protest march at Sausar, slams govt
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Shivraj SIngh Chouhan in Sausar on Saturday

Bhopal: Amid war of words on social media between former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan and CM Kamal Nath’s son Nakul Nath over alleged demolition of Chhattrapati Shivaji bust in Sausar town of Chhindwara, Chouhan took out a protest march in Sausar town on Saturday.

Chouhan took out a march and later paid tributes at the place where the statue was installed. Speaking on the occasion, Chouhan slammed the Kamal Nath government and warned, “I will not keep quiet whenever the government tries to disrespect important personalities of our nation. If need be we will shed our blood for the honour of people like Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. His bust was razed, hurting our national pride.”

It may be noted that a couple of days ago, a platform for installing a bust of Chhatrapati Shivaji was set up by some locals in Sausar town. Subsequently, the civic body officials razed it triggering protests. Later, the district administration officials assured the locals that the statue would be installed as per norms.

Chouhan had announced on Twitter on Friday that he will visit Chhindwara and lend support to the protestors, while Nakul Nath welcomed him in Chhindwara asked him not to return without seeing the “Chhindwara model” of development.

Chouhan had tweeted, "Tomorrow (Saturday) I am reaching Sausar at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. I call upon the people to join me and together we can tell Kamal Nathji loud and clear, chanting `Chhatrpati Shivaji Maharaj Ki Jai' that how our roar resonates from Sausar to Bhopal." Thereafter, Congress MP from Chhindwara and chief minister Kamal Nath’s son Nakul Nath tweeted that he will welcome Chouhan to his hometown Chhindwara, but regretted that Shivraj is visiting Chhindwara with a motive to get political mileage in the name of Chhatarapti Shivaji.

Inviting him for lunch at his Shikarpur residence on the outskirts of Chhindwara town, Nakul Nath said he would request Chouhan to take a look at the entire Chhindwara town and its development model before going back, said Nakul Nath in another tweet. In his third tweet over the issue, Nakul said he would get the bust made himself and re-install it at Mohgaon trisection at a grand ceremony and would bear the entire cost himself.

Title: In a first, MP shows way, radio-tags two pangolins
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nagpur: Even as various bodies observed ‘World Pangolin Day’ on February 14, Madhya Pradesh led the way in conservation of the species with world’s first radio-tagged Indian pangolins.

MP has tagged two pangolins rescued from poachers and has rehabilitated them in Satpura Tiger Reserve in Hoshangabad and is successfully monitoring them for the last 3-4 months.

Pangolins, listed under Schedule I of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 and have equal protection like tigers, are most trafficked mammals for their scales. These nocturnal mammals are virtually on the verge of extinction.

Pangolin, the scaly anteater, is targeted for its scales used in traditional Chinese medicines, and meat consumed as a delicacy in many Asian countries. A study by global NGO TRAFFIC for a period 2009-2017 had found nearly 6,000 pangolins in illegal wildlife trade in India. However, this was a conservative estimate as only a fraction of illegal wildlife trade is detected and actual numbers is likely to be higher.

Ritesh Sirothia, in-charge of special task force (STF), MP, says, “Since 2015, 11 cases have been registered against pangolin poachers and 164 persons have been arrested from 12 states.”

Globally, pangolins are considered the most trafficked wild mammals and most of the poaching and smuggling across pangolin range countries is targeted for international markets in China and Southeast Asia.

Now, a joint project by MP forest department and Wildlife Conservation Trust (WCT) has been initiated to understand ecology of Indian pangolins and develop an effective conservation plan. The project involves challenging task of radio-tagging and monitoring this endangered species apart from many other activities.

The fieldwork is supported by Yes Bank under its CSR initiative. MP announced successful radio-tagging of world’s first-ever Indian pangolins from Satpura tiger reserve & biosphere reserve.

“The STF has been actively working to curb wildlife poaching in the state. In recent years, we have successfully busted pangolin smuggling syndicates which involved poachers and smugglers from 12 states,” said Rajesh Shrivastav, MP chief wildlife warden.

“The team has successfully rehabilitated two Indian pangolins in the wild. This is the first-ever case of successful rehabilitation effort of the species where released individuals are monitored in wild using telemetry to ensure better success rate,” said SK Singh, field director of Satpura.

Pangolins evolved scales as a means of protection and this unique protection mechanism has now become its main cause of disappearance. Globally, pangolins have seen a rapid reduction in population. The projected population declines range from 50% to 80 % across the genus.

Out of the eight species of pangolin, Indian pangolin and the Chinese pangolin are found in India. The Chinese pangolin has a distribution in northeast India while the Indian pangolin is distributed widely in India except the extreme arid zones — Himalayas and the northeast.

Indian pangolin has been reported from India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Pakistan. Despite protective measures, pangolins in India are widely exploited and traded both domestically and internationally.

Shrivastav said being an elusive nocturnal species occurring at low densities, there is very little information available on the behaviour and ecology of the Indian pangolin. It is critical to know the ecology of the species to develop an effective conservation plan for an endangered species.

“In anti-poaching operations where pangolin scales are recovered, those animals are already dead. Where live pangolins are involved, globally there is about 50% death-rate among released pangolins,” he adds.

“Given that several pangolins are rescued in central Indian landscape, the new initiative by MP & WCT is to ensure better survival rates of these released individuals in the wild and thus have a positive impact on population of this endangered species,” said Aditya Joshi, wildlife biologist with WCT, who is overseeing the project.

World Pangolin Day, celebrated world over on third Saturday in February, is an attempt to raise awareness about pangolins and bring together various stakeholders to help protect these unique species from extinction.

Title: Rajasthan: Bh​iwadi cops ‘ruin’ Valentine’s Day plans of wanted gangster
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Gangster Vikrant Yadav

JAIPUR: Bhiwadi police ‘ruined’ the Valentine’s Day plans of wanted gangster by arresting him when he was out for shopping with his girlfriend in Delhi on Thursday. The accused was wanted in the murder of BSP leader Jasram Gujjar in Behror last year.

The wanted gangster was identified as 33-year-old Vikrant Yadav who had Rs 30,000 reward on his arrest by Haryana and Rajasthan police .

SP Bhiwadi, Amandeep Kapoor told TOI, “The accused was on the run since Gujjar’s murder last year in July. He would keep changing his locations frequently and travelled through various states including MP, UP, Haryana, Punjab, Rajasthan and others. A team was constituted to track down the accused and police officials also went to many states to catch him. He was spotted in Delhi’s Connaught Place where he was shopping for Valentine’s Day with his girlfriend on Thursday.”

Following this the cops got close to the accused who got a hint of police presence and tried to flee but was arrested. He was also involved in the firing at a dairy in Behror when the owner had refused to give ‘protection money’ last year. During the time when he was on the run, Yadav also made extortion calls to traders and transporters demanding Rs 1 crore from them.

He never used mobile numbers to make calls but instead used other forms like WhatsApp calling which is untraceable. He also changed his phones regularly which made it difficult to pinpoint his exact location. Yadav is part of Vikram Laden’s gang who was arrested last month from Hyderabad. They would induct minors into their gang by posting photographs with weapons on social media and would make the youngsters do their dirty work while themselves remain in the background.

Yadav has multiple criminal cases against him in Rajasthan and Haryana.

Title: A tale of murder, confession & kindness
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kottayam: A 32-year-old woman on Friday transferred the ownership of a house in five cents to a man, whose son had allegedly killed her father 12 years ago.

Naisy Kalayil, employed with a Bengaluru-based private firm, handed over the documents of the property in Thalayolaparambu to Vasu, father of Aneesh, who had allegedly murdered her father Kalayil Mathew in 2008 .

The property originally belonged to Vasu, but Aneesh had pledged it to Mathew, a private moneylender, for availing a loan of Rs 1 lakh.

Mathew attached the property after changing its ownership in his name after Aneesh had failed to repay the amount.

Mathew later went missing in 2008, and his family had no information about him until Naisy received a phone call from Vasu in 2016.

Naisy recorded the phone conversation in which Vasu said his son Aneesh had murdered Mathew in 2008. Based on the revelation, the woman lodged a police complaint.

During investigation, Aneesh reportedly told the police that Mathew’s body was buried where a three-storey shopping complex was later constructed. Investigators soon found the skeletal remains, and arrested Aneesh.

“It was Aneesh who had committed the crime and not his family. Moreover, I came to know about the death of my father through Vasu,” Naisy said, adding that Aneesh’s family had struggled much to buy the land to build the house.

Naisy had come home to Thalayolaparambu specifically to complete the official procedures and hand over the property.

Title: Robotics, aeromodelling a crowd puller at Technex20
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Varanasi: The three-day annual fest of IIT (BHU) Technex20 commenced on Friday with a series of activities competitions, workshops, and the special futuristic workshops. The theme of the fest this year is ‘Back to the Future’.

Students from different colleges took part in various events at Swatantrata Bhawan, the institute’s Gymkhana and Rajputana Grounds to test their mettle against competitors. Robotics events - Maze Explorer, Pixelate and Robowars, and aeromodelling events- Drone-tech, La Trajectoire saw huge participation and entertained the audience with stiff competition.

Innovative ideas to make a difference in the society trickled in the Pahal category’s 18-hour challenge Explica-2-day, SHE and PaperGaper. Riqueza events challenged the business acumen, and Astro-quiz tested the participants’ knowledge of cosmos! The second rounds of these events will take place on Day two of the fest on saturday to handpick the best. Exhibitions and workshops on autonomous driving and other latest technologies inspired the attendees from across the country to innovate and achieve bigger feats in science.

Title: 5 shops collapse in Prem Nagar
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dehradun: Structures of five shops in the city’s Prem Nagar market collapsed on Friday. The shops were standing on temporary structures and were at a height of around 10-feet above the road height, shopkeepers in the area told TOI.

“There is always an element of risk for such shops as their structures are temporary. On Wednesday, a house located on the same stretch had also collapsed. Several sanitation workers were living in the building but thankfully, no one got hurt. The members of the trade union will soon meet the administration regarding the safety of shops in the area,” said Rajeev Punj, president of Prem Nagar’s Vyapar Mandal.

Notably, the district administration had conducted a massive anti-encroachment drive on the same stretch in Prem Nagar in September, 2018. During the drive, several shops were demolished but they resurfaced again with temporary structures some time later.

Title: Police cane protesting party workers: BJP MLA
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaipur: Police had to use ‘mild’ force to disperse crowd as the BJP and Congress workers came to blows at Thadi Bazzar in Malviya Nagar on Thursday, informed minister for parliamentary affairs Shanti Dhariwal in the assembly on Friday.

Malviya Nagar area observed partial shutdown following the incident on Friday.

He was replying to BJP MLA Kiran Maheshwari who raised the issue during Zero Hour through point of information. Kiran Maheshwari said police lathi-charged and misbehaved with women and former chairperson of state women’s commission Suman Sharma suffered injuries on her head and demanded that the errant officials. She said another leader Dharma Chaudhary also suffered grievous injuries on head.

Kiran said BJP leader Suman Sharma reached the Thadi Bazar at sector 3, Malviya Nagar on Thursday morning to enquire to reports of fire which gutted many kiosks in the area. She claimed that the kiosks were legal and has been allotted by the Jaipur Municipal Corporation. She alleged that some unscrupulous elements set the kiosks on fire while the authorities have been claiming that it was gutted in short circuit. But she said there was no electricity connection to the kiosks.

When Suman Sharma and her supports began blocking the road, Congress leader Archana Sharma also reached the spot with her supports. It resulted in an altercation.

When the situation began going out of control, the police had to use force, said the minister. He said police had registered FIR against Suman Sharma and others.

Title: Mercury continues to soar in Kerala
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kochi: India meteorological department (IMD) warned that Alappuzha, Kottayam, Kannur and Kasaragod were likely to be hotter on Saturday as temperatures were likely to rise by 2C-4C. The weather was very dry in Kerala as temperatures soared in many districts including Thiruvananthapuram, Alappuzha (37.3°C), Kannur and Kottayam (37°C) on Friday. Cochin airport recorded 36.8°C.

However, there was no large change in the minimum temperature in Kerala during the past 24 hours. Punalur reported the lowest temperature at 20°C.

Kerala state disaster management authority (KSDMA) asked people to take proper precautions during daytime in districts with higher temperatures. KSDMA said that the temperature recorded in January and February were among the highest recorded in recent years; the temperature was above 37°C in many parts of the state. KSDMA issued an advisory asking people to be vigilant while dealing with health problems as temperature was rising each day.

Temperatures had crossed 36°C in many places since February 10 including Cochin airport, Kottayam, Punalur, Alappuzha, Kannur and Thiruvananthapuram. “We missed our winter this year and it seems summer season has moved to February itself,” said S Abhilash, joint director, ST Radar Centre, Cusat.

Schools have been asked to ensure drinking water in classrooms. Elder persons, pregnant women, children, and those suffering from other ailments should avoid noon heat from 11am to 3pm.

Private weathercaster Skymet said that Kerala was heating up much before the rest of the country for the past few years. The region saw multiple locations reporting maximum temperatures much above the 30-degree mark in the month of February.

It said that relief might come in the form of isolated rain from February 19- 21 due to elevated temperatures and peak humidity. Above-normal temperatures (up by 1.6°C-3°C) will be seen in Tamil Nadu, Puducherry and south interior Karnataka.

Title: Jammu and Kashmir Gujjars, Pashtuns’ genes similar: Study
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a recent study, the city-based Centre for DNA Fingerprinting and Diagnostics (CDFD) has found that Gujjars of Jammu region have a close affinity with Pashtuns from Afghanistan and Sindhis of Pakistan more than Ladakhis.Gujjars and Ladakhis are genetically distant from each other, it said. Gujjars had shown affinity towards the nomadic groups of Afghanistan and Pakistan as well as Sindhis of Pakistan. The researchers used multiple sets of DNA-based markers to conduct the studies.The research was done by CDFD scientists — Nandineni Madhusudan Reddy, Mugdha Singh, Anujit Sarkar and Devinder Kumar.The research paper also revealed that the genetic diversity studies of Gujjars and Ladakhis had clearly established that both are genetically distant to each other as well as to other populations in India.Due to their geographical location, both Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh are believed to have been corridors for migration of ancient humans between the mainland of Indian sub-continent and rest of the world .The researchers said the genetic findings on the populations in the two Union territories were significant — anthropologically and demographically — as these may have shaped the human population diversity.“Interestingly, ‘Y’ chromosome analysis has shown a closer affinity of Gujjars to other nomadic populations of Pashtuns from Baghlan and Kunduz provinces of Afghanistan and Pashtuns and Sindhis of Pakistan. The Gujjars also exhibited lesser genetic diversity as compared to the Ladakhi population,” the researchers said.The samples of Ladakhis were found to be closely associated with Chinese (Uighurs and Han) and Nepalese (Magar) populations.Researchers also said that it was due to their close geographic proximity and past demographic events.The study was published in ‘Nature,’ a multi-disciplinary science journal.

Title: Secretariat official slapped with Rs 3,000 fine
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: State information commission imposed a fine of Rs 3,000 on an official in the secretariat for denying information to application on unacceptable grounds.

Chief information commissioner Vinson M Paul slapped the fine on L T Santhosh Kumar, an official attached to the general administration department, who refused to give information on an application submitted by former MLA Joseph M Puthussery, seeking some details regarding DGP Jacob Thomas.

Puthussery had sought information on whether Thomas had the prior permission of the government before taking classes at Kollam T K M Engineering college.

His application, said Puthussery, was rejected by the official on the ground that such personal information could not be given as per RTI Act. The order by the information commissioner said the information sought was part of the official records and the reason cited by the officer in the rank of undersecretary was not acceptable. The lapse, said the commission, could not be considered an inadvertent one and hence the penalty.

The application was given in October 2016 and the reply was given in November. According to Puthussery, the officer denied information as Thomas was in the good books of the government during that period. His similar applications addressed to chief minister and chief secretary too did not elicit any reply, he said.

Title: Solar-powered bus stands for RSRTC
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas announced setting up solar plants at Rajasthan State Road Transport Corporation (RSRTC) bus stands and scrapping of the Rajasthan terminal development authority. He was replying to the discussion on annual report on Rajasthan state road transport corporation (RSRTC) for the year 2018-19 in the assembly on Friday. He said Sindhi Camp at Jaipur is being developed as a model bus stand. He alleged that the previous BJP government had weakened the state roadways claimed that the Congress government would bail out the corporation of the red by bringing in efficiency in its operation. The minister launched a private bus service in the name of Rajasthan Lok Parivahan Sewa and issued permit on the nationalized routes. This decision had affected the finances of the state roadways further, he said. He said the government had stopped issuing new licenses to Lok Parivahan Sewa buses. Out government would relaunch the Grameen Parivahan Sewa discontinued by the BJP government to connect the rural areas. He said battery-operated buses would be launched soon on Delhi route.

Title: NSA on Kafeel Khan because he exposed government, says brother
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kafeel Khan

GORAKHPUR: Dr Kafeel Khan ’s brother has accused the BJP government of trying to keep Dr Khan quiet by slapping the NSA on him.
