“We will challenge the National Security Act imposed on Dr Kafeel Khan in the court,” said Adil Khan, the brother of suspended BRD Medical College doctor.

“UP government is trying to keep my brother quiet because he had accused it of hiding the facts and figures despite children continuing to die at BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur ,” Adil alleged.

“On February 10, Aligarh CJM court had granted bail to my brother. But when the jail authorities did not release him even after three days, we went to the court and the court ordered Mathura jail authorities to release him. At 6am on Friday, my brother Kashif along with lawyer Irfan Gazi reached the jail, but by 9am police force at jail was increased. The jail officials told us that NSA had been imposed on Kafeel,” claimed Adil.

Citing Ramesh Yadav case vs district magistrate Etah case, Adil said, “The Supreme Court had ruled in Ramesh Yadav case that a person can’t be booked under NSA after bail is granted to him.”

Title: Garment exporters seek aid after Centre junks sops
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaipur: Facing steep competition from countries like Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Vietnam on one hand and withdrawal of Merchandise Exports Incentive Scheme (MEIS) benefits by the Centre on the other, the readymade garment exporters in the state have appealed to the state government to address their difficulties in the state budget to overcome the slump in shipments.

In their recommendations, they also urged the government to bring in a separate policy for readymade garments, decoupling it from textile industry. Rajeev Diwan, president of the Garment Exporters Association of Rajasthan (GEAR) said that demand dip in exporting countries, withdrawal of MEIS benefits and intense competition from Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Vietnam have clouded the outlook of garment exports.

“We have apprised the state government of the difficult business environment the garment exporters are in and sought some helping hand to ride out the phase. Access to credit at lower interest rates, compensating for the loss of MEIS benefits and power at reduced cost are some of the areas where the state can help the industry. We expect the chief minister to announce some incentives to the sector in the state budget,” Diwan said.

Besides, the industry body is also pitching for a separate policy for garments. Currently, the sector is coupled with textile policy. “The requirements of garment or apparel industry is entirely different from that of the textile industry in terms of technology, cost, and infrastructural needs. Being the end-users of the manufactured products of the textile sector, the apparel industry gets only indirect benefits of the policy. That’s why we want a specific policy in consideration of our unique operational needs,” Diwan added.

The garment exporters urged the state government to impress upon the finance ministry at the Centre to facilitate financing against government receivables from banks at benchmark rates with low margins of about 10% without any restriction on the tenor.

“Credit conditions have tightened because of multiple reasons known to everybody. But there are ways that can be explored for reducing the rates for garment exporters,” Diwan said. Readymade garments, along with textiles, gems and jewellery, engineering goods, chemical products and handicrafts, is among the five items from Rajasthan that account for nearly two-thirds of exports. Garments contribute about 5% to the state’s total exports.

Title: Fake job racket: Ex-min appears before cops
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Chennai: Former transport minister and Aravakurichi MLA V Senthil Balaji , who shifted allegiance from the AIADMK to the DMK, on Friday appeared before the cybercrime wing police at the commissioner’s office in connection with the job recruitment scam in which he is an accused.

He was questioned for about an hour. Speaking to reporters after the inquiry, Senthil Balaji said the case was politically motivated and that he was ready to appear before the investigators anytime.

City police had conducted searches at more than 17 places in connection with the job racket scam, including Senthil Balaji’s house in Mandaveli. CCB began reinvestigating the case in November last year after the Madras high court ordered the case be reprobed.

The case pertains to as many as 81 people being defrauded to the tune of Rs 4 crore promising them jobs in the state transport department in 2015, when Senthil Balaji held the portfolio.

Title: Insulted in front of lover, man ends life on Valentine’s Day
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dharmapuri: On Valentine’s Day, a 23-year-old man hanged to death after a college lecturer rebuked him for coming to the college to spend time with his lover.

Infuriated, kin of the deceased protested outside the lecturer’s house in Bedarahalli village near Indur with the dead body, demanding criminal action against him.

The Indur police identified the deceased as S Navin, of Makkanur village. A BSc graduate, he was in search of a job.

A police officer said Navin was in love with a girl, who was studying third-year BA at the Government Arts and Science College in Pennagaram.

“On Valentine’s Day, Navin went to meet her in the college. While they were talking, guest lecturer Gopi, 35, noticed them and chided Navin. He also grabbed Navin’s mobile phone and threw away,” the officer said.

Navin felt insulted as the entire episode took place in front of his lover and he left for home. His father Selva Kumar said, “My son was really upset, and he had narrated the entire incident to me. He went to his room and did not come out since afternoon. Later in the evening, he committed suicide by hanging from the ceiling of the house.”

Selva Kumar and other family members retrieved the body and took it to the lecturer’s house, where they raised slogans against him.

When alerted, the Indur police pacified the kin of the deceased and sent the body to the government medical college hospital in Dharmapuri for postmortem.

Police have registered a case and further inquiry is on.

Title: 4 men attack film critic’s car
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Four members of a right wing organisation allegedly vandalised the car that film critic Kathi Mahesh was travelling in, near Prasads multiplex on Friday. The attack took place days after a case was registered by Hyderabad police against Mahesh in connection with his alleged blasphemous comments about religion.

Police had received a tip off about right wing activists planning a protest at the theatre against Mahesh. The officials reached out to Mahesh before he stepped out of the multiplex. Saifabad police sat in a car that Mahesh was plying in.

On sighting the vehicle, the activists started to protest,stopped the car and resorted to vandalism.

The four persons were taken into custody and criminal cases were registered against them. However, they were let off on bail. TNN

Title: Man makes up ‘loot’ story to avoid paying back debt
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Allahabad: A hoax call about a man being robbed of Rs 50,000 had Pratapgarh police in a tizzy on Friday. Hours later, it turned out that the caller had concocted the account to avoid paying Rs 30,000 to a builder he owed money to. Police said they would soon take action against the accused.

According to reports, a man called the police around 2.30pm and informed them that three men on a motorcycle had robbed his father of Rs 50,000. Identifying himself as Lavlesh Patel, son of Deshraj Patel , he said that he was a resident of Pandit Ka Purwa area. The caller said that his father was returning from the bank after withdrawing the amount when he was looted.

A team of Lalganj police reached the spot for investigaton.

SP (Pratapgarh) Abhishek Singh said, “During investigation and discussions with bank officials, police came to know that no one by the name of Deshraj Patel had withdrawn money from the bank on Friday.”

When police grilled Deshraj, he told the police that he owed Rs 30,000 to a builder. As he did not have enough money to deposit, he made up the story that he was robbed.

Police said the accused had to pay around Rs 63,000 to a building material supplier based in Rampur Babli area. The debtors had asked Deshraj to deposit at least Rs 30,000 every month.

Two auto-lifters arrested: Police on Friday busted an inter-district auto-lifting gang in Pratapgarh and arrested two of its members. The accused were identified as Karua alias Kanhaiya and Nilesh Kumar Yadav, residents of Fatanpur. They also recovered five motorcycles from their possession. The arrest of auto lifters was made near Geeta Nagar canal bridge road when they had come to dispose of stolen bikes. Police said that the auto lifters used to lift bikes from Pratapgarh city pockets and later resale them in dehat areas with forged documents.

Title: Brain-dead Dausa boy gives life to three
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaipur: A 17-year-old boy from Dausa gave a new lease of life to three persons as his parents donated his organs after he was declared brain-dead at Sawai Man Singh Hospital on Friday.

It is the third cadaver organ donation at SMS Hospital within a month. The first was done on January 16 when a 25-year-old donated his organs. The second was reported on February 12 when an 18-year-old donated his organs.

On Friday, the doctors retrieved organs, including two kidneys and one liver were retrieved after his family gave consent to donate his organs to save life of patients battling for life while undergoing treatment for end-stage renal and liver diseases.

Sawai Man Singh Medical college spokesperson Dr SS Yadav said that the boy had met with an accident, who belonged to Dausa on February 6 while he was riding a bike. He had suffered head injury following which he went unconscious. He was given treatment but he did not regain consciousness. A team of doctors of a committee, which is formed to examine patients to declare brain death, examined him and the committee declared him brain dead on February 13.

The boy was admitted to SMS Hospital on February 8, since then he was undergoing treatment for his head injury at neurosurgery department of SMS Hospital.

The boy was kept under intense monitoring at an ICU of Institute of Orthopedics and Traumatology. When the doctors realised that it has become impossible to save life of the patient as the hospital claimed that his brain is dead and other organs are functioning. In this situation, it became impossible to save his life. They advised the hospital to perform a brain dead test by the committee. The hospital officials said that they kept the brain dead patient alive at ICU till they get the consent of the family.

Since the hospital did not find any recipient for heart, they did not retrieve it. The heart has gone waste. However, the kidneys were transplanted into a 43-year-old and 36year-old persons who were on dialysis for quite some time.

Title: Exclusive website launched for Kurumbapatty zoo
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Salem: District forest officer A Periyasamy on Friday launched an exclusive website (salemecotoursim.com) for Kurumbapatty zoological park in the city.

The website will have all the details about the zoo.

The department has arranged two vehicles for visitors to go around the zoo.

“Rs 200 will be charged for four people and Rs 400 for eight people to travel in the vehicles,” the DFO said. Visitors can book the vehicles online through the website with the entry fee. Entry fee for children is Rs 10 and Rs 20 for adults.

Soon, online booking facility will also be made available for Anaivaari Muttal falls, Yercaud park, Karadiyur viewpoint and Cauvery peak eco park.

Title: District electorate is now 29.91 lakh, up 2.33%
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: As per the final electoral roll released by collector K Rajamani on Friday, the district has 29.91 lakh eligible voters. The number voters has gone up by 68,086, an increase of 2.33%, when compared to the previous electoral roll released last December, which had 29.23 lakh voters.

As usual, men were outnumbered by women. The district has 14.79 lakh male voters, 15.11 lakh female voters and 370 transgender voters. With 4,45,651 voters, Kavundampalayam continues to remain the assembly constituency with highest number of voters and Valparai, with the least.

Officials had organized special camps at polling stations as per the directions of the election commission of India (ECI), the collector said. “As many as 1.08 lakh application forms to add and delete names in the list were received. After verifying the applications, 73,910 persons were added to the list, of which 23,878 are new voters.”TNN

Title: Soon, an exclusive track for city’s cycling enthusiasts
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Following post-budget discussion where concerns regarding the neglect of capital city were raised, finance minister T M Thomas Isaac announced additional projects for the city. One among the new proposals will cheer up bicycle enthusiasts and proponents of green living. Project for an exclusive bicycle track on the Pipeline Road has been earmarked Rs 1.5 crore. The track will come up on the 3km stretch from Kowdiar to Vazhayila.

Vehicular movement on the Pipeline Road, which is owned by the Kerala water authority (KWA), is restricted to ensure the protection of transmission pipelines laid beneath it. Now, the public works department (PWD) is planning to lay interlocking tiles to make it useful to bicycle riders.

MLA V K Prasanth announced the proposal in his social media page on Friday. When contacted, the MLA said that PWD will prepare the project report. “The cycle track will be helpful for all bicycle riders who do not have any such facility in the city now,” he said.

Officials of the PWD said that funding was a major hurdle for the proposal, which has been cleared now. “We have not been given any intimation about allocation of funds. However, if the budget has earmarked fund, then we can prepare the detailed project report (DPR) immediately and submit the estimate. This road could be readied for bicycle riders by laying interlocking tiles. The tiles can be laid without disrupting the transmission lines beneath the road. Currently, people living on the sides of Pipeline Road complain about the uneven road surface, which gets waterlogged during rains,” the PWD official said, adding that they will send a request to KWA to hand over land, which could be returned after laying the tiles.

Meanwhile, officials of KWA said that they haven’t got any direction for handing over the area for the work. “We will take steps to ensure that only cycles ply on the road. Proper barricading and fencing should be ensured to prevent entry of other vehicles, as it could damage the underground transmission pipes,” said a KWA official.

The bicycle enthusiasts in the city are highly appreciative of the proposal. City’s bicycle mayor Prakash P Gopinath said that the exclusive cycle track will be a good option for bicycle riders in the city. “The Kowdiar-Vazhayila stretch can be used by cycle riders for a fun ride to Aruvikkara,” he said.

In addition to this, a cycle track is being mooted under the Smart City project, which is expected to come up in the Manaveeyam-Vazhuthacaud-Music College stretch. Rs 22 crore has been earmarked for the non-motorized transport project, which involves construction of cycle track and footpath over the utility duct.

Title: 25,000 people flow in to revitalize Killiyar River
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: According to official estimates, over 25,000 people joined the mass drive to clean Killiyar held on Friday. The drive was held as part of the second phase of Killiyar Mission ‘Karakavinju Killiyar’, which aims for the rejuvenation of the river.

The cleaning drive was held on 22km-long stretch from Karinjathimoola to Vazhayila and also in the 31 streams flowing into the river. Ministers, MLAs and general public participated in the cleaning drive.

Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac, who inaugurated the drive at Kallampara in Nedumangad, said that the public participation for the mission makes it a successful initiative, while minister for forest K Raju, who inaugurated cleaning drive at Azhikode said the drive will be a model for similar activities in other districts.

“Government has allocated Rs 20 crore for rejuvenation of rivers and streams and from this Rs 9.5 crore will be allotted to Killiyar Mission,” said minister for cooperation Kadakampally Surendran, who inaugurated the drive at Vazhayila.

At Karinjathimoola, minister for ports Kadanapally Ramachandran led the cleaning exercise, while minister for agriculture V S Sunil Kumar and D K Murali MLA led the drive at Anad panchayat.

District collector K Gopalakrishnan participated in the cleaning activity at Pazhakutty. C Divakaran MLA, mayor K Sreekumar, district panchayat president V K Madu, grama panchayat representatives, leaders of political parties, employment guarantee scheme workers, Kudumbashree members, fire and rescue service officers and students participated in the mass drive.

The Killiyar Mission committee had conducted extensive promotional programmes for the cleaning drive including conventions, wards-level rallies and street plays.

Convener of Killiyar Mission and Nedumangad block panchayat president Biju B said that over 500kg of waste was cleared from the river during the drive. “The waste removed during the previous cleaning drive was ten times more than that of the present drive. Mostly, plastic and glass bottles were removed during the drive. Such materials will be sent for recycling. In the next stage, we have planned to construct fence, garden and footpath on the banks of the river,” said Biju.

Title: Coronavirus: 13k screened at city airport
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaipur: Twelve thousand nine hundred ninety two passengers have been screened at Jaipur International Airport in the wake of coronavirus alert coming in from 84 international flights till Friday.

In a release by Directorate Medical & Health Services, it was informed that screening of all passengers has been going on since January 28. Five doctors and five paramedical nurses have been deputed at airport. Samples of 80 patients were collected and all 80 were found negative. Additional chief secretary (medical and health) Rohit Kumar Singh issued directions to health officials to remain sensitive and asked them to identify tourists from China and get their thermal screening done.

IANS

Title: Early detection key to treating cancer, say experts
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Over 1 lakh new cancer patients are being diagnosed in Telangana every year and there are 15 lakh new cancer patients in the country annually, said health minister Etela Rajender at the fifth edition of Cancer Conclave organised by Apollo Hospitals.

The conclave being organised from February 14th to 16th at Hyderabad International Convention Centre in Hyderabad will shed light on ongoing research, emerging medical technologies and new advancements in oncology.

Speaking at the inaugural of the conclave, Rajender said, “Early detection is very important and everyone who is above 35 should get a yearly assessment done without fail. Also, treatment should become affordable even for the poor in this country.”

Aimed at improving cancer management in the country and abroad, the Conclave and eight edition of “Cancer CI 2020” is expecting to see over 3,500 delegates from more than 60 countries in three days.

Governor Tamilisai Soundararajan who inaugurated the conclave said ignoring the early symptoms are the cause of the advancement of cancer. It is important that we get assessments done and visit doctor on a regular basis.”

Experts from Indian healthcare sector revealed that as per World Health Organisation (WHO) guidelines one cancer centre is required for every one million population. However, in India only 400 cancer care centers cater to a population of 1.25 billion people.

“Private and government sectors must come together and set up more than 2,000 cancer centres to strengthen India’s capacity to manage the disease,” said Dr P Vijay Ananda Reddy, chairman, organising committee, Apollo Cancer Conclave.

Title: Black leopard found dead in Kotagiri
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Udhagamandalam: The carcass of a female black leopard was found near Kotagiri on Friday.

The three-year-old animal was found dead in a tea estate in Kadakodu village, forest department officials said. The owner of the land informed the department.

“Inspection of the carcass revealed no external injury. It was a weak animal,” assistant conservator of forests Saravana Kumar said.

Local veterinarians conducted postmortem as per the guidelines of the national tiger conservation authority. “Preliminary postmortem report revealed that the liver of the animal was damaged”, the official said. According to him, the animal might have been ailing for some time. “It was a natural death. We have collected samples of the carcass for lab test. Only after the test reports are obtained, we would come to know the cause of death.”

Black leopards are very rarely spotted in the Nilgiris, the official added.

Title: Door to door tuberculosis campaign from February 16
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: The first phase of 2020-21 door to door campaign to detect and treat patients suffering from tuberculosis (TB) will be launched on Monday under the Revised National TB Control Programme.

The drive would be continued till February 27.

In 2018-19, a total of 15,890 TB patients were identified and 9,268 of them were undergoing treatment at different government district hospitals. Besides, 6,222 other patients were getting treatment at other private hospitals and all information regarding the same is being uploaded on portal.

District Tuberculosis Officer (DTO) Dr A K Tiwari said “ A total of 6,910 patients were given Rs 500 per month for nutrition under the national scheme.

He further added “ for the identification of new TB patients, the health department has a target about 10 percent of city population and for that a total of 183 teams have been formed to examine over 6.64 lakh people”.

Besides, Medical Officer in Charge of all primary \community health centers have been appointed zonal supervisors and would be submitting the reports of people scanned \ new patients daily. Every block has a TB detection unit, he added.

The union government aims to root out TB from the country by 2025 and a dense anti-TB campaign is being launched within every three months.

The health teams would be collecting sputum of those suspected to be suffering from the disease. The active case-finding is a part of a nation wide efforts to eradicate the disease which has re-emerged as a potential killer claiming over four lakh lives every year in the country.

Title: Tamil Nadu budget: Rs 1,370 crore allotted for river restoration
Content:
The restoration will mainly consist of improving the hydrology of the drains and enhancing their flood-carryin... Read More

CHENNAI: Concerned at the amount of raw sewage flowing into the city’s three main water bodies, the government in its budget presented on Friday allocated Rs 1,370 crore for river restoration that will mainly focus on cleaning up the various drains.A Chennai River Restoration Trust (CRRT) official said the Adyar river had the most number of drains, 23, including the Mambalam canal, followed by the Buckingham canal with 21, while the Cooum river had just eight.The project will cover Captain Cotton Canal, Otteri Nullah, Virugambakkam Canal, Veerangal Odai among others, all of which currently carry large amounts of untreated sewage, some of them travelling distances of up to 10 km before draining into a river or a larger canal, said the official.The restoration will mainly consist of improving the hydrology of the drains and enhancing their flood-carrying capacity to ensure clean water eventually reaches the rivers, he said.As part of the waterfront development, the Public Works Department (PWD) or Greater Chennai Corporation, depending upon the ownership of the water body, will remove solid waste, construct compound walls or put up chain link fences and plant saplings along the bunds. The work will also involve interception and diversion of sewage outfalls. As far as the sewage outfalls, Metrowater is executing the work of intercepting and diverting the sewage, the official added.The CRRT will prepare a detailed project report (DPR) for the project.There is also the human element to the restoration project — the contentious rehabilitation component which will involve removing hundreds of people from the banks of rivers and moving them into tenements in resettlement colonies, often several km from their workplaces.Such ‘evictions’ have on many occasions sparked acrimony, with activists alleging that the government takes up such schemes without adequate consultations with stakeholders. The process almost always ends in the slum dwellers being denied proper means of livelihood and having to commute huge distances daily, they say. The government had made an announcement in this regard last year. A Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board (TNSCB) official said a total of 60,000 people living along the river banks are set to be rehabilitated under the scheme. The TNSCB, tasked with identifying the people to be relocated, had submitted to the government a proposal, saying an estimated Rs 4,647 crore would be required to build more slum tenements under the project. The government has approached the World Bank for funding, an official said.

Title: Construct memorial stupa for serial bomb blast victims: BJP
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: BJP on Friday requested the state government to construct a stupa at RS Puram in memory of the victims of the Coimbatore serial bomb blasts.

According to police, more than 10,000 cadres of BJP, Vishva Hindu Parishad and Hindu Munnani participated in a rally from Bharathi Park to DB Road junction seeking support for the Citizenship Amendment Act and to observe the 22nd anniversary of the blasts. The functionaries paid floral tributes to the blast victims, slain Hindu Munnani leader Sasikumar and sub-inspector Wilson.

As many as 58 people were killed and more than 1,000 people suffered injuries in the blasts in 1998, BJP leader Pon Radhakrishnan said. “We wish to pay floral tributes to the victims of the bomb blasts at the memorial stupa next year. The state government should take necessary steps to construct it,” he said.

Islamic terrorist organisations that murdered several Hindu leaders since 1980 were behind the serial bomb blasts, Radhakrishnan said. “One such extremist organization killed sub-inspector Wilson at Kaliyakkavilai in Kanyakumari district. The perpetrators were out on bail. The state government should make sure that extremists do not to come out of prisons.”

BJP and other Hindu outfits had been paying floral tributes to the blasts victims at RS Puram for the last 21 years, the senior leader said. “Police used to deny permission to conduct the event and arrest the participants. But the state government granted permission to conduct the event at RS Puram for the first time this year,” he said.

DMK chief M K Stalin is lying when he says that he had collected two crore signatures against CAA, Radhakrishnan said. “How can a party obtain two crore signatures within such a short period?”

Later, addressing party functionaries at RS Puram, he said that some political parties are conducting protests against CAA to gain mileage out of it. “Muslims should not trust DMK. If 15 % of Muslims come out to protest against CAA, 80% of Hindus will also come out to support it.”

BJP state secretary KT Ragavan, state general secretary Vanathi Srinivasan, district president R Nandakumar, Hindu Munnani state president Kadeswara Subramaniam, state secretary Kishor Kumar and VHP state organiser P M Nagarajan attended the rally.

As many as 3,100 police personnel were deployed in the city to maintain law and order in view of the rally.

Title: Tiger attacks man in Neelwai forest
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

A 40-year-old farmer was attacked by a tiger in Neelwai forest range of Mancherial districts Chennur division on Friday.

The victim, Kurmanbek Venkati, a resident of Brahmanapally was grazing his cattle when a tiger suddenly attacked the cattle. The tiger pounced on Venkati when he tried to save the cows.

“When Venkati tried to protect his cattle, the tiger attacked him on his leg. When the farmer panicked and screamed, the tiger ran into the forest,” forest department sources said. Venkati was rushed to Chennur hospital after villagers who heard his cries rushed to the spot.

Forest officials and wildlife activists say that the area where the attack took place is the territory of tigress K4 who is living in Chennur forest area, still with a poacher’s wire snare around its abdomen.

“The area has been the territory of K4 for quite some time now. One or two tiger movements recorded in the recent past in the area,” said Mirza Kareem Baig of NGO Forest and Wildlife Protection Society,

Title: Rajasthan: Two arrested for poaching in Sariska Tiger Reserve
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Poaching incidents appear to be going unprecedented in the tiger reserves across Rajasthan and just a day after two poachers were arrested whose images were captured in a trap camera after they hunted a Cheetal (spotted deer) in Ranthambore Tiger Reserve (RTR), two more were arrested in Sariska Tiger Reserve on Friday for hunting two hares.

The two arrested were identified as Rahul Bawariya and Radheshyam Bawariya. Officials also recovered the country-made weapon which was used for shooting the wild animal.

Seduram Yadav told TOI, “We received information on Friday that the accused had hunted the animal in the reserve. We immediately started an investigation and on the same day both the accused were arrested. The weapon was also recovered.” A case was registered against them under the Wildlife Protection Act 1972 which prohibits hunting and poaching of wild animals. With recent increase in the cases of poaching in the tiger reserves across the state, wildlife enthusiasts have also raised questions on the safety of the tigers in Rajasthan. Babulal Jaju, state incharge, People for Animal, an organisation working for wildlife told TOI, “Currently there are 26 tigers which have strayed out of Ranthambore and most of them have been hunted. I have written to CM Gehlot to start probe in poaching cases. If the government fails to take preventive measures, then I will approach NGT.”

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 14 put under isolation in Allahabad
Content:
Fourteen Allahabad residents who travelled to Asian nations returned to the city in the past one month have be... Read More

ALLAHABAD: Fourteen Allahabad residents who who travelled to Asian nations like China and returned to the city in the past one month have been put under observation as part of the district administration’s precautionary measures against the novel Coronavirus (nCoV) outbreak.According to health department data released on Friday, 36 residents had returned to Allahabad after visiting China and other neighbouring Asian countries like Hong Kong, Thailand and Singapore between December 1, 2019 and February 14. Of these, 31 were put under observation under the Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) December 1 onwards. A person returning from China or an adjoining country has to be kept under surveillance of IDSP for at least 28 days during the three-month period.They had been put under observation in special isolation wards at Motilal Nehru Medical College and Colvin Hospital, and at their homes. While none of the passengers showed any symptoms of the deadly virus, but the move was seen as a precautionary measure.District epidemiologist Dr. Anshu Vaish said, “The department is maintaining a database of travellers arriving in the city from nCoV-affected countries since December 2019. There were 36 such passengers who had arrived in the city since December 1, 2019. They were put under observation and five of them had visited other cities like Jaunpur and Kolkata.”Vaish said that 22 of them were released after being isolated for 28 days. “The remaining passengers have been put under isolated conditions at their homes.” He also said that a dedicated ambulance has been deployed at the Bamrauli Airport to rush any passengers who might exhibit novel Coronavirus-like symptoms.“Apart form coordinating with state IDSP unit and World Health Organisation (WHO) officials, we have also been carrying out sensitisation campaign at airport and railway stations to educate people about n-CoV,” he added.Vaish said that residents are being briefed about the precautions which might reduce the risk of them contracting n-CoV.Novel Coronavirus has claimed as many as 1,300 lives in China, the epicentre of the contagion, over the past two months. The country has reported over 15,000 cases leading to several airlines restricting operations to China. The Indian government recently evacuated. A man in Kerala was the first novel Coronavirus patient to be diagnosed in India in January.

Title: Cargo code of truckers hinder STF crackdown against liquor mafia
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: Liquor mafia ’s reliance on truck drivers to deliver consignments of rectified spirit and illegal alcohol is proving to be the main obstacle in Special Task Force’s ( STF ) crackdown against their operations in the state.

According to police, most liquor smugglers depend on a nexus of truck drivers to deliver their consignments. However, these drivers are not told the exact location where the consignment has to be dropped or the person they are supposed to hand over the package. The drivers are given a ‘code word’ and the men tasked with the job of receiving the consignment would call them and would tell them the location only after the drivers say the code word,” said police.

STF got to know about the modus operandi only after it arrested a truck driver on February 8 along with illegal liquor worth Rs 56 lakh. The accused, Jaswinder Singh alias Kakka, is a resident of Mohali in Punjab and told the police that he had not been given the exact location for the delivery.

The accused also said that racketeers would contact him and tell him the location, only when he said the code word.

Earlier, the racketeers would rope in transporters for delivering the consignments. The transporters used decoy trucks or swapped vehicles and routes as and when required. In addition, the racketeers have check points between two locations to track the consignment.

Additional SP (STF) Neeraj Kumar Pandey said that drivers were being given the consignment and were even not told about the exact location of delivery. “The trucks or mini-trucks they use usually have fake registration plates and drivers are assigned a particular code word for a particular route, which they use to contact the racketeers at the delivery point,” Pandey said.

He said the racketeers used to change their SIMs after every delivery to evade police action.

Pandey also maintained that racket kingpins had stopped travelling in trucks ever since the STF tightened the noose around liquor smugglers.

STF sleuths said gangs often smuggled rectified spirit from Haryana and Punjab to eastern UP, where the final product was prepared. The additional SP said at least nine such gangs were busted last year.

Title: Donor, recipient hemophiliacs, but transplant success
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: Doctors in a Coimbatore hospital transplanted a kidney in a 12-year-old boy suffering from haemophilia, a blood disorder that does not allow it to clot like it is supposed to.

What makes the case rare is that the kidney donor, who was the boy’s maternal uncle, also suffers from haemophilia.

The surgery was performed by replacing the missing protein, which would restore clotting mechanism temporarily, for 10 days, by which time the wound healed reasonably.

Doctors in Kovai Medical Center and Hospital, where the surgery was performed, said they were yet to come across a case of renal transplant in medical literature where the kidney recipient and donor both suffer from haemophilia. “So far, nowhere in the world, a kidney transplant has been done in a recipient with haemophilia from a donor who also has haemophilia as these cases are considered to have a very high risk for bleeding after surgery,” said nephrologist Dr V Mangalakumar.

Doctors say the main risk of operating on such patients is uncontrollable bleeding and the burden of maintaining two patients with the issue. However, faced with no other viable option, they decided to go ahead.

It was around five months ago that a 12-year-old boy, who was suffering from advanced kidney failure, was brought Dr Mangalakumar. The boy has a rare genetic condition called Alport syndrome, which led to the kidney failure. The boy was advised an immediate transplant and his maternal uncle, whose HLA type and blood matched his, came forward to donate one of his kidneys.

However, during evaluations, the doctors found that both the boy and his uncle also had haemophilia.

In haemophilia cases, replacing the missing protein will restore the clotting mechanism temporarily and stop the bleeding. This should be continued for at least 10 days after the surgery to minimise late bleeding complications.

The team, which included Dr Mangalakumar, urologists Dr Barani Kumar and Dr Kuppurajan and vascular surgeon Dr Bala Sundaram, performed the transplant. Both the donor surgery and the recipient surgery went well without any complications.

The donor was discharged five days after the surgery and the recipient went home 10 days after the surgery, with normal kidney function.

Title: Bitcoin fraud: Woman among two held
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The Special Operations Group (SOG) arrested two persons, including a woman from Jaipur, for Bitcoin trading fraud. The complainant had registered a case against the two accused on February 5 following which an investigation was initiated.

The arrested were identified as 32-year-old Manoj Patel and 22-year-old Avika Mishra.

Anil Paliwal, ADG, SOG & ATS said, “The two accused had opened a website claiming that they were Bitcoin traders. They would ask people to invest in their company and the promised the investors a profit of 1% per day. They also held seminars to motivate people for investing.”

Title: 5 days on, auto driver, his aide held for gang-raping 23-yr-old
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Times News Network

Ludhiana: The police on Friday claimed to have arrested three more accused, including a woman, in the February 9 gang-rape case.

An auto-rickshaw driver, along with his two accomplices, had raped a 23-year-old woman and dumped her when she fell unconscious.

Police said the arrested woman, Renu, knew the three accused, as they frequented the eatery where she worked. “Renu helped the three commit the crime,” said a cop.

The first arrest was made on February 12, when Ram Narayan, a labourer, was nabbed from Mundiyan. “Following his interrogation, the three others were arrested from Kohara on Chandigarh Road. They are Barjesh Kumar, 27, the auto driver and resident of Hardoi; Mohammad Malik, 28, a labourer and resident of Bhamiyan Khurd; and Renu, 35, of Kohara,” the cop added.

Additional deputy commissioner of police (ADCP-IV) Ajinder Singh said, “On February 7, the survivor had gone to a Ludhiana village to look for an accommodation on rent. There, she met Renu. Renu introduced her to Brijesh, saying he could help her find a house. Brijesh asked the survivor to come to Samrala with advance payment on February 9. On the day, the survivor told Brijesh that she could not withdraw money for advance payment as banks were closed. On this, Brijesh offered her a lift in his auto, saying he would take her to an ATM kiosk from where she could withdraw money. But instead, he took her to the Clock Tower Chowk, where two of his accomplices boarded the auto.”

The accused took the survivor to an isolated place and gang raped her.

“When the survivor lost consciousness, the accused left her there and escaped. On gaining consciousness, the survivor called up her husband, who rushed to the spot and took her to a hospital. A case under sections 376D (gang rape) and 120 B (criminal conspiracy) of the IPC was registered against the accused,” the ADCP added.

Title: Ex-Armyman arrested for opening fire
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: An ex-serviceman was arrested for opening fire into the air from his licensed weapon during New Year celebrations in his village.

The accused, 42-year-old B Tirumal Reddy, is a resident of Shyampet village in Dharmaram mandal of Peddapalli district. He was arrested under Arms Act and cops seized a double barrel gun, six live rounds and four shells from his house. According to Habeeb Khan, Peddapalli Assistant Commissioner of Police, the accused is a retired Naik of Indian Army.

“On Friday, we received information that Reddy had fired into the air on the intervening night of December 31 and January 1 while showing off his gun at his house. The video of the incident went viral,”the ACP said. Tirumal worked in the Army from 2002 to 2019.

“Tirumal had purchased a licensed double barrel gun and 20 live rounds. After retirement, he shifted to Shyampet but did not inform local police about the weapon, which is violation of rules,” the ACP said. Cops are trying to find out what Tirumal did with the 14 rounds that are unaccounted for. TNN

Title: Discover Japan fair begins
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Geisha dolls made in traditional Kimono welcome one to Ayyankali Hall here, which is decorated with Origami art. The dolls are among an array of products associated with Japan exhibited at the hall, as part of Discover Japan cultural festival organized in the capital.

Organized by the district centre of Alumni Society of Association of Overseas Technical Cooperation for Sustainable Partnership (AOTS), Tokyo, the three-day festival was inaugurated by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Friday.

Vijayan said that Japan and India share a cordial relationship and the festival is an effort to strengthen the support for each other.

“Japan has been supporting India for development of technology and education sectors. During my visit to Japan, investors expressed their interest to invest in Kerala as they find us as an investor-friendly state. The unity, hard work and cleanliness we see in Japan can be model for us,” said Vijayan.

He also mentioned support from Japan-based companies for projects such as Kochi Metro.

The organizers welcomed the guests at the function by presenting Daruma dolls (traditional Japanese dolls) made by them.

Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran spoke about the need to promote Kerala tourism in Japan.

Speaking about the Indo-Japanese cultural relations, Shashi Tharoor MP narrated an incident when former prime minister Jawaharlal Nehru received a request from Japanese school children to gift them an elephant, as the elephants in the zoo had died during World War II. Nehru had then sent an elephant named Indira to Japan.

Former ambassador T P Sreenivasan delivered the keynote address. General manager of AOTS in India Hisashi Kanda, chairman of organizing committee Leon Mohanraj, chairman of programme committee K Asok Kumar, patron of Indo-Japan Chamber of Commerce T Balakrishnan and president of ASATC T D Krishna Kumar also spoke on the occasion.

A session on Japanese culture, art, literature and cinema moderated by Pradeep Panangad will be held on Saturday at 5pm.

Title: Finally, transwoman registers marriage
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: The Valentine’s Day meant a lot for transsexual woman Surekha, 24, and her partner Manikandan, 26. The couple, who got married in 2018, was able to register their marriage. On Friday, their wish was fulfilled at Vadavalli sub-registrar office.

The couple could not earlier register their marriage as under Section 5 (iii) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, the term bride meant woman. The couple first attempted registering their marriage in 2019.

They were getting home rental agreements and electricity connections in Surekha’s name only because they were not legally married yet.

The couple approached the district collector two weeks ago, following which the inspector general of registrations wrote to the Vadavalli sub-registrar clarifying that the Act and the term bride were applicable for transgenders. The department contacted the couple’s lawyer PP Sivakumar and agreed to register their marriage.

The couple has been living in Kavundampalayam. Manikandan is an autorickshaw driver.

“I feel so happy that I feel like I have got a new life,” Manikandan said after registering their marriage. Surekha said it was in this moment that she finally felt legally accepted by society.

“I didn’t feel this way, even when my gender change was published in the gazette and when I got my Aadhaar and voter id card. I file like my married life has just begun,” she added.

“I want to be an example to people who don’t feel confident about being in love with transsexuals and to transsexuals who are in love with either men or women,” said Manikandan.

“I can now provide my marriage certificate for fertility treatment, or child adoption, to take a loan together and open a joint bank account, which is how every other couple lives,” said Surekha.

They were accompanied by Manikandan’s parents, Surekha’s adopted mother and their friends to the sub- registrar office.

Surekha, who works in a dairy farm in Narasimanaickenpalayam, said, “I don’t have my parents or any siblings, because I left home as a child. I also need some legal family.”

The Madras high court in April 2019 ruled that the term “bride” under the Hindu Marriage Act includes transwomen and directed authorities to register a marriage between a man and a transsexual woman.

Title: Burnt body found near Kousika bridge
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: The half-burnt body of a 37-year-old man was recovered from near the Kousika river bridge on Friday morning.

Police identified the deceased as S Thiyagarajan of Muthusamy Road in the city, who was a taxi driver.

Police constable Kathiresan attached to Periyanaickenpalayam police station, who was on night patrol on Thursday, had found a scooter parked on the bridge. He brought the scooter to the station and checked the registration plate to find that it belonged to Thiyagarajan. Around 11am on Friday, police received information about a body near the bridge. It was found 20 metres away from place where the scooter was parked.

Police found a mobile number on the copy of the registration certificate of the vehicle and contacted Aravind, brother-in-law of Thiyagarajan. Thiyagarajan, who hailed form Kumbakonam, had separated from his wife and was staying alone, police said.

Police sent the body to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) for postmortem. They suspect someone killed Thiyagarajan and burnt the body. An investigation is on.TNN

Title: Pulwama martyr’s wife claims cops in Kannauj stopped her pay tributes
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Neeraj Devi, wife of Kannauj martyr Pradeep Singh Yadav, with daughters Sona and Supriya

KANPUR: The wife of Pulwama martyr Pradeep Singh has alleged that the police station in-charge of Indergarh in Kannauj refused to grant her permission to observe the death anniversary of her husband at the village memorial on Friday.

Taking the matter seriously, district magistrate, Ravindra Singh swiftly intervened and gave permission to the martyr’s wife for holding the event.

The DM said, “How can one refuse to give permission to observe the martyr’s death anniversary. It is a proud moment when we pay tributes to martyrs. I wonder how such a thing had happened. I have apprised the senior police officials, including superintendent of police, of the whole issue.”

Constable Pradeep Singh, who belonged to Sukhsenpur Azan village in Tirwa tehsil of the Kannauj district, was 35-year-old when he attained martyrdom. He is survived by wife Neeraj Devi and daughters Supriya (11), Sona (3) and a six-month-old son Prateek.

His wife Neeraj Devi alleged that the police station in-charge of Indergarh Sujit Verma had refused to grant her permission to observe the death anniversary of her husband Pradeep Singh at the memorial in the village.

“I spoke to the police station in-charge of Indergarh to grant permission for observing the death anniversary of my husband at the memorial on Friday, but he refused,” she alleged.

The aggrieved widow claimed that she only got the permission when she approached the district magistrate at the collectorate.

When contacted, police station in-charge Sujit Verma rubbished the charges levelled by the martyr’s widow.

“When she contacted me on the phone, I asked her to submit a consent letter from her inlaws as there is some kind of dispute between her and her inlaws. How can I refuse for the event which is related to the martyrdom of a soldier?”, he said.

To recall, Ajit Kumar Azad, a CRPF personnel from Unnao and Shyam Babu of Raingawan village in Derapur area of Kanpur Dehat, were also among the 44 troopers who had got martyred in Pulwama terror attack.

Ruby Kamal, widow of martyr CRPF jawan Shyam Babu had joined as a junior clerk at the office of the Kanpur Dehat district magistrate. Shyam Babu is survived by his wife Ruby, a five-year-old son Ayush and a year-old daughter Ayushi.

Constable Ajit Kumar Azad of Unnao, who had joined the CRPF in 2007, also attained the martyrdom in the attack. He is survived by his wife Meena (28), and two daughters, Isha (9) and Shreya (7).

“Mummy, now we have become good children as we have started going to school, but Papa doesn’t come. He only used to say that one who goes to school is a good child. Earlier, Papa even used to call us on phone, but now he no more calls us. Mummy, will we meet him in the village?,” the 5-year-old Ayush asked volley of questions from his mother Ruby.

On Friday, Ruby along with her children, went to her inlaws’ place in Kanpur Dehat to take part in the ‘Hawan’ ceremony on the occasion of the first death anniversary of her husband.

Title: Stolen baby found in Sahnewal
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

tnn

Ludhiana: Three days after an unidentified woman stole a newborn girl from civil hospital, the baby was found under bushes at a roadside near Sahnewal airport on Friday evening.

Commuters went to the spot on hearing her cries and sounded the police.

Cops took the baby to civil hospital as she had fever. On reaching the hospital, they learned that she was stolen from there on February 11. “Her parents were called who identified the newborn as theirs. We are trying to trace the accused woman,” said assistant sub-inspector Surjeet Singh, in-charge of Ishwar Colony police post.

Title: Drugs seized from three men
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: The NIB-CID police arrested three men on Friday for smuggling drugs from Kerala.

Deputy superintendent of police R Vincent and team had arrested S Biljulal, H Arjunprasad and G Sarang, hailing from Kerala, after receiving a tip-off. The trio was staying in a rented house at Myleripalayam.

The team seized lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) stamps, methamphetamine and 1.2kg ganja from them.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that the trio used to supply drugs to college students in Coimbatore. They were lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: Poor state of public toilets in Mussoorie: Residents press for maintenance ahead of tourist season
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

yyyyyyyyyyyy

Mussoorie: Deplorable condition of public toilets has become a major cause of concern for residents of the queen of hills. Some of the common issues that people claim to face while using a public loo in the hill town are — broken taps, lack of water supply, no electric lights, poor cleanliness and unbearable stench among others.

The public toilets that are in a poor condition are located on the Mall Road (near Chick Chocolate), on Camel’s Back Road (near Bahuguna Park), near Nagar Palika office, opposite MDDA parking towards Landour, near Inder Bhawan, and at Bata Ghat. Residents of Kolhu Khet (on Mussoorie-Dehradun road) also allege that the public toilet in their area hasn’t been in operation for over two weeks now.

“Public toilets at most places in the town are in a poor state due to lack of cleanliness and maintenance. This causes hardships for both locals and tourists,” said Jagjeet Kukreja, secretary of Mussoorie Traders' Association.

In view of the poor state of public toilets, residents have urged the officials of Mussoorie Municipal Council (MMC) to take immediate action before the tourist season begins.

“During peak tourist season, I have seen tourists requesting hotel owners to allow them access to toilets rather than using public toilets. I would urge the authorities to construct new toilets while ensuring maintenance of existing ones, without further delay,” Mohan Petwal, a resident, said.

Meanwhile, ML Shah, executive officer of MMC, told TOI, “Repair work has been initiated in some toilets. Proper cleanliness and adequate water supply would also be ensured. As for the public toilet at Kolhu Khet, it has been handed over to the tourism department and is currently under maintenance.”

Title: Kolkata must regain its past biz glory: Goyal
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolkata: Kolkata needs to recreate the enthusiasm of the past and encourage businesses to regain its position of pre-eminence on the Indian industrial map, said union commerce and railways minister Piyush Goyal at the ET Bengal Corporate Awards in Kolkata on Thursday. Inaugurating the 7th edition of the awards, Goyal said that the city has lost its ‘competitive edge’ since business and industry has ‘not been allowed to grow in Bengal’. Goyal, however, added that it was reassuring to see new businesses and young entrepreneurs emerge from the state and they were doing the country proud.

Describing Kolkata as ‘a city of freedom fighters, philosophers, educationists, poets, writers and tall industry leaders’, the minister said it was once the economic and financial capital of India. “While the RBI was headquartered in Kolkata, the SBI had its registered office here. Kolkata had the first modern port and of course, the Howrah Bridge. It is an engineering marvel which used steel, 90% of which was produced in India. Compared to the Howrah bridge that was built in just 41 months, it took 14 years to build the Vidyasagar Setu,” said Goyal.

Kolkata, Goyal pointed out, has immense potential. “But the city is losing out on the chance to bring the mojo back,” he said. Business models need to be reconsidered to meet the new global challenges of business, felt the minister. Kolkata could play a leading role in that effort, he said. “You have the Bengal Chamber of Commerce and Industry (BCC&I), which is one of the oldest in the country. We can work together to grow and focus on growth,” said Goyal.

India could indeed grow into a $5 trillion-dollar economy in five years, observed Goyal. “Prime Minister Narendra Modi has laid down this target and it can be a reality. It may sound difficult now but it is good to have an ambitious target. But remember it will only be the cusp for further growth,” said Goyal. He went on to add that the union budget has laid the foundation for a leap to the $5 trillion-dollar target.

Global uncertainties in business necessitated that India Inc stayed together to continue on the path of growth, observed Goyal. He, however, rued that it was difficult to build consensus in India. “For instance, Indian steel is not allowed in some countries though there isn’t any government sanction against us. Their trade bodies block the entry of our products. When I tried to do it to some of their products, there was resistance from the stake-holders in India. This is detrimental to the growth of our industry,” he said.

Union minister of state for environment and forest Babul Supriyo — who was also present at the event — called upon the industry captains to invest more and take advantage of the corporate tax benefits announced in the budget.

Title: Now, birdwatchers flock to Akkulam
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: After a flock of Red Avadavat, locally known as ‘Kumkuma Kuruvi’, was spotted at Akkulam Lake near the National Institute of Speech and Hearing (NISH) campus by bird watchers Anoop Palode and Suraj S R, bird watchers have shifted their focus from Punchakari to Akkulam. However, new development works planned at Akkulam is raising concerns.

The sparrow-sized bird, also known as Red Munia or Strawberry Finch, are commonly found in Kole wetlands in Thrissur. Though one or two were sighted in the wetlands in city, Red Avadavat stayed away from viewfinders due to its nature of avoiding any close contact with human beings. Anoop Palode, who is a bird watcher and photographer for around 15 years, said that he had spotted one in Akkulam during a bird watching programme of World Wild Fund four years ago, but missed to capture in a frame. “These birds prefer to stay away from humans. So when Suraj and I spotted around 20 of them on December 31, we were surprised. Since then, we have been closely studying them. We have spotted a flock of 30 birds last month. After we shared pictures in bird watchers’ groups, more people are visiting the site to see them,” said Anoop.

Presence of tall grass, which is ideal of nesting, and seeds in it are the reasons for Red Avadavat to flock to the area, said Suraj. “Unfortunately, recently we saw some people setting fire on a small portion of grass where we used to spot the bird,” said Suraj.

Anoop too raised concern over the proposal of tourism department to initiate revival works of the lake. “If the construction works are done without considering the natural habitat of these birds, we will lose them forever,” he said.

After they raised concerns, Swasti Foundation submitted a petition to tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran to take necessary action.

“The breeding time of Red Avadavat is during the month of June. Due to climate change, there might be changes in the time. However, we have requested government to be cautious during the next six months so that their natural habitat won’t be destroyed,” said Suraj.

Title: Action plan being prepared to reduce marine pollution
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Optimists: The planning department expects to prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, ... Read More

Mangaluru: The planning department of Karnataka has prepared strategies and an action plan for conservation and sustainable use of the oceans , seas and marine resources for sustainable development. The department expects to prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution, by 2025. The department has observed a decline in coastal water quality.

Department additional chief secretary Dr Shalini Rajneesh, in a presentation, has pointed out that Karnataka has rich marine resources which offer massive employment, food and nutritional security. However, the coastal water quality has been declining and the bivalve production too has seen a drastic decline by 71% during the last 15 years. “The department has set a target of addressing the threats of industrial effluents and sewage through coastal water monitoring and initiate necessary action. More emphasis will be on zero discharge of industrial effluents and sewage. Policies and action plans will be prepared to identify the declining coastal fisheries due to pollution, and initiate measures to improve the ambient coastal water quality,” she said, adding that it is aimed at earmarking 5% of the total budget of fisheries department for the purpose.

Major steps include installation of a number of sewage treatment plants along the coast, and construction of toilets under the Swachh Bharat Mission. Out of 27 urban local bodies (ULB) in coastal districts of Uttar Kannada, Udupi and Dakshina Kannada, 23 have been certified open defecation free (ODF), and third-party inspection is under progress, Shalini said.

With regard to the presence of petroleum hydrocarbons in coastal waters in Kulai, which is an industrial discharge point in Mangaluru, an action plan will be prepared to strengthen the CRZ, and the Coast Guard to monitor pollution levels, she said.

Title: Water board slaps Rs 40L fine on tyre co
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Water board offcials at the tyre company in Nacharam

Hyderabad: A leading tyre manufacturing company, M/s Stallion Tyres Limited, located in Nacharam was found to be drawing water through illegal connections, said water board officials on Friday.

This incident came to light after the vigilance wing of Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) unearthed illegal water connection at the organisation site which was leading to losses of several lakhs to the water board. A criminal case has also been registered at the Nacharam police station by the vigilance wing of the wter board against the company for having set up the illegal connection and defaulting on several payments .

According to an official statement issued by HMWS&SB, after the illegal water connection was identified by the vigilance wing, they asked the company to submit papers to vouch for the legality of the said water connection. However, the owner of Stallion Tyres Limited, VMN Venkatesh failed to produce any documents pertaining to the water connection.

The water board had disconnected water supply to the company in 2016 after the organisation failed to pay a due of Rs 29,42,549.

“Following the termination of connection, the owner procured the illegal water connection and consumed 25,116 litres of water till date,” said HMWS&SB chief vigilance officer, M Ravi Chandan Reddy.

“As per the tariff, we have calculated that the quantity of water that he has consumed and it has amounted to Rs 40 lakh that has to be paid by the accused,” he said.

Based on the complaint lodged by manager of HMWS&SB, Nacharam Housing Board section, criminal cases has been registered under Sections 269, 430 and 379 of IPC and Section 3 of Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act.

Title: Manuu: Meet on mysticism held
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: A seminar on ‘Significance of mysticism in historical perspective of Indian and Iran’ was inaugurated at Maulana Azad National Urdu University ( Manuu ) on Friday.

Dr Mohammed Ali Rabbani, cultural counselor, Iran Culture House, New Delhi, said, “Islamic Sufism is a significant part of intellectual heritage. It is also the connecting point of Indo-Iran cultures and historical relations.” An exhibition on Islamic calligraphy was inaugurated by Iranian scholar Dr Masoud Rabbani. “Mystic and Sufi migrants from Iran introduced Islam in India,” said another scholar.

Prof SM Rahmatullah expressed happiness over the message of mysticism propagated by the scholars. Prof Mohd Kazim Kohdoui, Iranian scholar from University of Yezd, and Dr Masoud Rabbani spoke about importance of mysticism in the historical context .

An Iranian film festival began with the screening of Iranian film Dilbari. Six more films will be screened on Saturday and Sunday. -Omer bin Taher

Title: 3 snake charmers rescued from wildlife smugglers
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: Police rescued three snake charmers, who were allegedly kidnapped by wildlife smugglers after they had failed to supply them Red Sand Boa snake to them in lieu of money.

“All three snake charmers hail from Jogi Dera Basti in the Mangalpur area of Kanpur Dehat. They promised the wildlife smugglers to supply Red Sand Boa snake on February 10 and in lieu of which they had received Rs 45,000 in cash from them.

When they failed to arrange Red Sand Boa snake for the smugglers, they first kidnapped the snake charmer Sanoj Nath and demanded Rs 49,000 as ransom from his family members for his safe release. Later, when the two other snake charmers from Sanoj’s village--Pintu and Gautam Nath--went to Sanompur village in Auraiya to hand over the smugglers the ransom amount, the latter also held them captive after snatching the money (Rs 49,000). Subsequently, the police were informed and the trio were rescued from the Auraiya-Jalaun border on Thursday. The smugglers, who had dumped the trio on the Auraiya-Jalaun border, however, managed to flee,” said inspector Mangalpur Shiv Kumar Rathore. “Separate teams have been formed and dispatched to possible hideouts of the kidnappers to arrest them:, he added.

Not very long ago, a B.Tech student and one other were arrested by the Chakeri police for trying to sell two Sand Boa snakes (Eryx johnii), a protected species, under the Wildlife (Protection) Act.

“Known as ‘domuha’ in the region, the nearly-threatened species is said to have a great demand in the international and domestic markets due to a superstition that it brings good luck and it is also used for making medicines for sexual health”, said a wildlife expert.

Title: Film heritage mission on track, says NFAI director
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: This year’s Union Budget has done away with the separate allocation for the National Film Heritage Mission (NFHM), but the National Film Archive of India (NFAI), the mission’s nodal agency, is not unduly bothered.

“The NFHM project is very much on track. It will receive funding from another head in the budget known as development communication and development of filmic content,” Prakash Magdum, the NFAI director, said.

Against a budgetary allocation of around Rs22 crore in 2019-20, the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (MI&B) had disbursed only Rs3.61 crore to the NFHM.

Officials surmised that such a huge gap between allocation and spending had probably resulted in the NFHM not receiving any allocation at all.

“The non-allocation is part of a rationalisation process of the ministry, so that money can be allocated as per the need of a particular project,” Magdum said.

The NFHM started in 2017 with a mandate to collect, assess, and preserve film reels as well as non-film materials associated with cinema, such as posters, flyers, or booklets, which have historical and aesthetic value.

While the project had a slow start, the initial phases of the project have been completed or are close to completion, with the film assessment phase by a prominent film laboratory over, and the assessed material being handed over to the National Film Archive of India with observations.

While 1, 31,000 reels and other non-film materials were originally meant to be assessed, the final assessment came to nearly 1,50,000, according to the National Film Archive of India.

The next phase of the NFHM will be to digitise and/or restore the matter assessed. The NFAI officials said that the tenders for digitisation and restoration are ready, but a decision on the films and materials needed to be digitised and restored will depend on a “wide matrix” of factors.

“It has been a wide and all-encompassing process. About 4,000 films in various languages are slated to be digitised and restored. So, we are consulting stakeholders from across the film industry, including well-known directors, producers, and even state governments,” he said.

“Then we will take a call on the films to be digitised or restored which again will depend on a wide matrix of factors, such as the language, the physical condition of the film, if it has been made by a renowned director, or starred legendary actors etc,” he added.

Title: Corpn, highways dept to get dedicated road safety wings
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: Roads in the city are expected to be much safer over the next few years, as both the Coimbatore Corporation and highways department will be equipped with dedicated road safety wings. The road safety wing’s main responsibility is to incorporate road safety elements within the design of roads. While highways departments across the state has been granted road safety cells, Coimbatore Corporation is one of three local bodies also granted road safety cells along with Chennai and Madurai.

In his Budget speech in the assembly on Friday, deputy chief minister and finance minister O Paneerselvam allocated Rs 500 crore for the revamped Tamil Nadu Road Safety Fund. This is to mainly fund these dedicated road safety wings. “Simple ways to make new roads safer is to give it dedicated pavements so that pedestrians are protected, give it adequate assigned parking space and ensure signals are in visible space,” said a highways department official. “Also putting clear sign boards announcing barricades, creating safe and smooth speed breakers are also other simple methods,” he said. They expect the road safety wings to bring in more elements.

The panchayats in Coimbatore are also likely to receive more funds this year, with the statement government announcing a grant of Rs 556 crore for urban local bodies. Coimbatore is one of the four districts—the others being Chennai, Madurai and Trichy—included to benefit under this scheme. And it falls under the 15th finance commission recommendations.

The city’s Government College of Technology which is completing 75 years this year has been given a special grant of Rs 10 crore to upgrade its infrastructure and facilities. “In addition to this, the college has number of illustrious alumni, who are willing to contribute to further development of the institution. The government will match the contribution made by the alumni during the 75th anniversary year for the development of the college,” the finance minister said.

Title: Pregnant minor’s suicide: Youth arrested
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Kanjiramkulam police on Friday arrested a 21-year-old man in connection with the death of a 16-year-old girl, who had allegedly committed suicide by self-immolation. The police identified the accused as Sanal of Vallampurayidam House, Kanjiramkulam. He is a fisherman.

There were allegations that the girl was pregnant. On Friday, a post-mortem examination conducted on the body of the deceased confirmed the pregnancy. Relevant sections of rape under Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act and abettment of suicide under IPC were invoked against him. The police said that the accused was in a relationship with the girl and sexually exploited her many times.

Meanwhile, the probe into the unnatural deaths of a 23-year-old woman and her 3-year-old daughter who were found hanging on the two ends of a saree at Kallara was directed towards Meera’s mother, Girija.

Pangode station house officer N Suneesh said that the police found a handwritten note on the calendar in the suspect’s residence. They suspect that it was written by Meera. The note read ‘it is my mother who is responsible for our deaths’.

“The forensic experts visited the house and collected samples of Meera’s handwriting to verify whether it was written by her,” the SHO said adding that some relatives have told the police that Girija and Meera often quarrelled with each other. tnn

Title: Rape accused shot at in police encounter in Kanpur, injured
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

Title: Coimbatore Airport-Uppilipalayam Elevated Road Sanctioned
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: A few years down the line, motorists driving on Avinashi Road neither have to move bumper-to-bumper in traffic jams nor wait for a minute at each traffic signals. Thanks to the state government for it has decided to construct a flyover for 10.1km on the road.

The four-lane expressway would start from Uppilipalayam Junction and end after Kovai Medical Centre Hospital (KMCH) on the road.

During his budget speech in assembly on Friday, deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam said that the state government has accorded sanction for the elevated road to be constructed at the cost of Rs 1,620 crore. “A provision of Rs 200 crore has been made in the Budget estimates for 2020-21 for implementation of the project,” he added.

A senior official from the highways department said that the flyover would have entry and exit ramps for vehicles at four locations near Anna Statue, Fun Mall Junction, Hope College and Airport Junction. This is the first flyover which is to be constructed with multiple ramps in the district.

We have decided to include ramps only at those locations where the requirement of land acquisition is minimum, the official said, adding that they would be acquiring only the space where the compound wall is constructed and vacant space behind it. “We would not acquire any structures,” she added.

“The flyover design is almost at the final stage and once the design is completed, it would be submitted for technical approval. Mostly, the tender to select a suitable bidder for the project would be floated within three months. If everything goes right, the construction work could be commenced within six to seven months,” the official said.

Explaining that close to 10,000 vehicles use Avinashi Road on a day, another official said that more than half of the vehicle population is expected to use the flyover and it in turn would reduce the traffic congestion to a larger extend on the road. The traveling time is expected to be cut down by 15–20 minutes, he added.

Welcoming the move, city-based activists said that it would be a huge relief to the commuters for Avinashi Road is one of the highly congested roads in the city.

With the introduction of ramps at multiple junctions, the flyover would not just be useful for those who travel outside the city, but also to those who travel within, K Kathirmathiyon, a member of road safety committee, said.

“It would be even more better if the government speeds up and complete the ongoing flyover construction work in the district – Trichy Road flyover, Ukkadam flyover and flyovers on Mettupalayam Road - before it commences the construction work as it might increase the inconvenience caused to the commuters,” he added.

“At present, most of the vehicles travelling on the road are waiting for at least for a minute at each signal and it in turn raises the blood pressure for the commuters. The flyover would reduce the tension level of the commuters,” secretary of Coimbatore district road safety association M Devendran said.

He said it would be even more better if the department considers ending the flyover near Chinniampalayam as traffic congestion could be completely avoided within the city limit.

Title: Rotarians in state should engage with MSME sector: Mitra
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolkata: State finance and industries minister Amit Mitra has urged Rotarians from Bengal to engage with MSME (medium and small medium enterprises) sector.

Addressing the Rotary India Centennial Summit 2020 here on Friday, the minister has also asked the Rotary leadership to set up a MSME cell in the state. He added that Rotary which has over 5,000 members in the state can adopt 5-10 MSME clusters.

In the state budget proposed earlier this week, Mitra had announced new MSME clusters, which the state feels is the biggest employment generator. “You (Rotarians) can help them in many ways. MSME entrepreneurs do not know how to scale up, Rotary can help them in this regard. Besides, you can help them in developing human capital, help them finding export market along with other things,” he added.

As many as 4,100 delegates from 40 countries have participated in this Rotary conference. Mitra later added that Rotary has agreed to provide e-learning software and systems to 20,000 school across the state. Rotary members said that they have pumped in over $30 million in West Bengal in various projects for the uplift of the weaker section of the society.

Title: Kin await AC mechanic’s safe return from S Arabia
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Mangaluru: The family of Harish Bangera , a resident of Kundapur, Udupi, who was arrested in Saudi Arabia for his alleged derogatory Facebook posts, is awaiting his safe return. Harish’s family alleges there has been no progress in the case even after two months.

Harish Bangera, 33, an AC mechanic working in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, was arrested by the Saudi authorities for his alleged social media comments on Saudi crown prince Mohammed bin Salman and Mecca. He had allegedly uploaded it on December 19 and was arrested the next day by Saudi officials. The company he was working for had terminated his service after his post drew criticism across the world.

No news since arrest

“We have not heard anything from Harish after he was arrested. Some of his colleagues and friends have told us that the Saudi Arabia police are still investigating the matter, and it will take nearly three months to complete the process. Meanwhile, political representatives including Udupi-Chikkamagaluru MP Shobha Karandlaje have assured of help for his safe return to India,” said Sumana M, Harish’s wife. Sumana is living with her two-and-a-half-old child in a rented house in Kundapur.

“With Harish’s’ arrest, we have not been able to pay rent for two months, and there is no family support for me as ours was a love marriage,” Sumana said.

Harish Bangera went to Saudi Arabia in 2014. For a few years he worked as a machine operator and started working as an AC mechanic from the past two years. “My husband had come on vacations three times after 2014. We want to end all this and he should return back home safely,” said Sumana.

Rumour dispelled

On social media posts doing the rounds that Harish has reportedly converted to Islam in order escape punishment, which includes getting lashing and having to pay a heavy fine, she denied it, saying it was a rumour.

“When we contacted the Indian Embassy in Saudi Arabia, they informed us that this did not happen. It was spread by rumourmongers.”

Suman claims that her husband is innocent, and the post on Facebook were uploaded by a fake social media profile created under his name. “I am aware that he (Harish) had posted something related to the CAA and NRC protest, which turned violent, resulting in two deaths due to police firing. Apart from it, he never posted anything as alleged by others. We have filed a complaint in this regard at the Cyber Economic and Narcotics (CEN) station in Udupi,” she added.

Title: Pune: Civic lens on illegally parked private buses
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020
