Owners of illegally parked buses will be fined Rs 25,000

PUNE: The civic body’s anti-encroachment department has decided to clamp jammers on private buses parked illegally on the road from this week.

“No notices will be served before the action. It will be a direct action,” Madhav Jagtap, head of the PMC’s anti-encroachment department, told TOI.

He said the PMC will slap a fine of Rs 25,000 on each of the owners of buses parked illegally on the road. The private bus service operators are expected to park their vehicles at the designated parking bays allotted to them. Parking at any other place, especially along the road, will attract a fine, Jagtap said.

The private bus owners, however, termed the civic body’s decision to take action against them as an “injustice”. They said that they were left with no option but to park their vehicles on the road because of inadequate parking facilities. “The local self-government body was supposed to provide us with parking facilities at different locations. The pickup points were to be at four directions in the city. But not all the promises were fulfilled,” said Balasaheb Khedekar, president, Pune District Luxury Bus Association.

He said the association will approach the PMC and demand a solution to these problems. A case was filed in the Bombay HC and its directives would be followed by the PMC. The members will also demand a status check during the meeting with the civic authorities.

A Pune police notification in 2018 had put restriction on private buses in the city during daytime. As per the notification, private luxury buses can ply only on four prescribed routes to cities like Mumbai, Nashik, Ahmednagar and Solapur.

It also banned the movement of luxury buses on these prescribed routes from 8am till noon and from 5pm till 9pm. The bus operators had filed a plea against the police directives following which the Bombay HC had granted an interim stay on the notification.

Title: Jobless man booked for raping neighbour
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

TNN

Ludhiana: The police on Thursday evening booked a Ludhiana village resident for raping his neighbour.

The 23-year-old complainant said in her police complaint, “I got married when I was 20-year-old. Later, I parted ways with my husband and came back to my parents’ house. My neighbour, who is in his 20s, has been raping me since I was 17-year-old. I did not tell my parents about it as he had threatened to kill my family if I breathed a word about his misdeeds. Besides, he was blackmailing me.”

In January, the accused called her to his house and raped her again. “I then mustered courage to speak about it,” she added.

Investigating officer sub-inspector Manjit Kaur said, “We are recording the statement of the complainant before court. Her medical examination will be conducted. The accused, who is unemployed, has been booked under Section 376 (rape) of the Indian Penal Code. Raids are being conducted to arrest him.”

Title: Pest control measure proves fatal for couple
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: Tuesday’s tragic incident in which a middle-aged couple died of asphyxiation after their Bibvewadi flat was fumigated once again underscored the lack of awareness over pest control measures.

The couple — Aparna Majali (54) and her husband Avinash (64) — got their flat in Ganesh Vihar Society fumigated on Tuesday morning and, on returning home from around 7pm, did not switch on the fan or open the doors and windows to let in fresh air.

“Sassoon General Hospital, in its advance post-mortem report, has certified the cause death as ‘asphyxiation’. The histopathology report is awaited,” assistant inspector Rajesh Usgaonkar of Bibvewadi police said.

Many pest control agencies guarantee 100% results, but the use of gas-based treatment and fumigation is not permitted in residential areas, under the Insecticide Act, 1968.

This can be done only at the warehouses containing food grains and export items. “Many customers ask us for the gas treatment in their houses as they do not know it is not permitted,” Sachin Nalawade, who runs a pest control agency in the city, said.

Nalawade added gas treatment seldom proves useful, as it does not eliminate insects like bedbugs. “Contact poisoning is the most effective. Spraying chemicals works best,” he said.

Another pest control operator said doors and windows should not be closed during spray treatment. “If the windows are open, toxic vapours will not accumulate in the flat,” he said.

He said it was advisable for people to not inhabit the house for 24 hours after the treatment.

Nalawade further said customers must check that the operator has a proper licence. “Licensed agencies never use hazardous pesticides ... in many cases aluminium phosphate is used, which proves fatal,” he said.

Title: In a first, yoga classes held inside Hyderabad mosque
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: In a first such move in Hyderabad, a mosque committee in the Old City has allowed yoga classes to fight rising non-communicable diseases and obesity. One of the three floors in the Masjid-e-Ishaq at Nawab Saheb Kunta at Tadbun has been converted into a healthcare and medical counselling centre where Yoga is also taught.

“There is not much space in the narrow lanes for walking and outdoor exercises. So, in the mosque our counsellors are not only demonstrating yoga asanas, but also giving YouTube links to some patients to follow Yoga on mobile phones to reduce their waistline,” Mujtaba Hasan Askari, who runs the clinic, told TOI.

Most women attending the mosque clinic are at risk of non-communicable diseases, including heart ailments due to their weight. Every alternate day, yoga is taught to patients in the mosque. Health counsellors follow WHO guidelines on fighting non-communicable or lifestyle diseases and have adopted Yoga as part of the healthcare regimen to keep people in the Old City fit.

The move follows a recent health survey of patients attending the clinic in the mosque. Of the 600 people, mostly women, 70% had a body mass index (BMI) of more than 30 (less than 24.9 BMI is considered healthy). The clinic organisers considered various options and yoga emerged the favourite as the geo-demographic profile of Old City does not permit other options such as outdoor exercises.

Askari, who is also the managing trustee of the Helping Hand Foundation (HHF), said HHF was running the clinic in partnership with SEED, a US-based NGO. The lifestyle clinic at Masjid-e-Ishaq has two dedicated dieticians and two counsellors under the supervision of a lady doctor. Yoga is prescribed after evaluating a WHO-recommended form filled in by the patients. The focus is more on exercises and diet control than on medication.

Dietician Farhat Fatima, who evaluates dozens of patients at the mosque every day, said she was prescribing yoga as it gives the best result and can be performed indoors. “I counsel them in a way that they can relate to. If I tell them to walk daily, they cannot do it in narrow lanes,” she said.

Ayesha Sultana, 46, registered at the lifestyle clinic a month ago. A patient of diabetes and hypertension, Ayesha told TOI that her health has improved after she took to yoga. “I was not aware that diet and exercise will do wonders to one’s health. Now my dependence on medication has come down,” she said.

Title: Doon remains warmest as mercury rises in state
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand has witnessed a sharp rise in temperature in the last 48 hours, with Dehradun being the warmest in the state, as the district’s maximum temperature crossed 29 degrees Celsius on Thursday and almost touched 27 degrees Celsius on Friday.

On Friday, Dehradun’s maximum temperature was at 26.6 degree Celsius, five notches above the average, according to the Met office.

On Thursday, Dehradun recorded a maximum temperature of 29.2 degrees Celsius, which was highest in the state and eight notches above normal. The minimum temperature settled at 11.5 degree Celsius, about three points above the average.

According to the regional meteorological centre, dry weather prevailed across Uttarakhand on Friday, with temperatures settling above normal in both hills and plains.

“Uttarakhand has been witnessing dry weather for almost one week and the current spell is going to continue at least till February 19. Temperatures will also settle above normal during the period,” said Bikram Singh, director, regional meteorological centre.

The weather is likely to change from February 19 evening, as the state can expect thunderstorm in several parts. The wet spell is going to cause a drop in temperatures across Uttarakhand from February 20.

“Temperatures will start dropping from February 20 and are expected to hover below normal during the last week of the month,” said Singh.

Title: Man runs fake firm, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: A fraudster was arrested for running a fictitious company and cheating people by collecting huge amounts on the pretext of providing plots, and holiday packages.

Vikram Shukla, 42, posed as a managing partner of Land Mark Infra Services. He was booked for cheating, criminal breach of trust and relevant sections of Telangana Protection of Depositors of Financial Establishments Act, 1999. TNN

Title: HC seeks response from UPCL after Gauchar villagers say power lines posing threat to their lives
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nainital: The Uttarakhand high court ( HC ) on Friday issued notice to the Uttarakhand Power Corporation Limited (UPCL) after villagers from Gauchar block wrote to the court saying that the power line that runs through the village is posing a threat to their lives.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe has given UPCL two weeks’ to respond to the concerns raised by the villagers. “The court had taken suo motu cognizance of the letter written by villagers of Gauchar. The villagers have said that the power lines run through the village and therefore they are under constant threat. The court has now asked us to look into the concerns raised by the villagers and file a response,” said chief standing counsel Paresh Tripathi.

The villagers have said in their letter that the power lines of 11000 KV don’t only pose threat to their lives but are also an impediment in their daily lives. “The lines can also cause a huge damage in times of a natural disaster which is common in Uttarakhand. Therefore the court should take steps to shift them to a safer location,” the villagers have said.

The court has now said it will hear the case after UPCL submits its response and take a call on the shifting of the power lines.

Title: Mantri seeks inquiry over lecture on ‘Knowing RSS’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: A lecture on ‘Knowing RSS’, which was eventually cancelled, has put the SPPU’s department of communication and journalism in a spot, with state minister Balasaheb Thorat seeking an inquiry into it.

Taking to Twitter, Thorat alleged that RSS “swayamsevaks” were now campaigning inside varsity campuses. “Rather than focusing on giving quality education, they are trying to induct more people as RSS Swayamsevak by intruding schools, colleges & varsity campuses. This is serious and inquiry has to be conducted. I spoke to higher and technical minister Uday Samant & requested probe and action against the offenders (sic),” he tweeted.

Samant, who is on a tour to the Konkan region, could not be reached for his comments.

Even Nationalist Congress Party MP Supriya Sule took strong objection to the mover and tweeted, “What is happening in Savitribai Phule Pune University? Whose idea was it to organise this event? Department of Communication and Journalism has put this up in their time table. Is the Vice-Chancellor aware that such a program is being organized (sic)?”

The Savitribai Phule Pune University in a statement issued late on Thursday said, “In the world view subject under Master of Journalism and Mass Communication course at SPPU, students are made aware of various thought processes so that they are aware of what is happening around them. Various organisations are also a part of this lecture series and this happens in various places. The ‘Knowing RSS’ lecture was a part of this series and this was to happen at Motibaug in Shaniwar Peth. However, there was opposition to this lecture from various quarters, hence, the lecture on Saturday was cancelled. From now onwards, the lectures about various organisations will happen within the department.”

An SPPU official said, “The lecture stands cancelled till we are able to announce the full schedule.”

Title: Rs 500 crore more for Athikadavu-Avinashi Scheme in budget
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Coimbatore: The state government has allotted Rs 500 crore more in the budget for the Athikadavu-Avinashi groundwater recharge and drinking water supply scheme.

The government gave administrative scantion to implement the scheme on March 28, 2018. Environmental clearance was given on December 19, 2019. An amount of Rs 1,000 crore was sanctioned for the project estimated to cost Rs 1,652. A pipeline is to be laid for 1,058 km and six pump houses constructed. A total of 1,048 water bodies will benefit from the scheme which will provide irrigation facilities to 24,468 acres in drought-prone areas and groundwater-depleted areas in Erode, Tirupur and Coimbatore districts. Water will be pumped from the Bhavani river.

The water bodies to be fed include tanks, ponds and check dams in Erode, Tirupur and Coimbatore districts which cover Perundurai, Chennimalai, Nambiyur, Gobichettipalayam, Bhavanisagar, Uthukuli, Avinashi, Tirupur, Annur, Sulur, Sarkarsamakulam, Periyanaickenpalayam and Karamadai blocks.

About 1.50 TMC surplus water will be drawn from the Bhavani basin (limited to pumping of 250 cusecs for 70 days). This will cater to the driking water needs, augment ground water and provide irrigation facilities in the drought-hit areas.

Dr D Prabu, Federation for Athikadavu-Avinashi Groundwater Recharge Scheme, said the federation welcomed the sanction of Rs 500 crore in this budget for speedy implementation of the scheme. “The check dams which are built between ponds and tanks for water conservation and percolation should be filled along with ponds and tanks. Only this will give real time benefit. The check dams which are the real infrastructure for ground water augmentation should not be neglected,” said Prabu.

He said the scheme should be speeded up and finished on target before the 2021 assembly election. Phase - II of the scheme (Sirumugai-Periyakallipatti and Perundurai and surrounding areas) proposed by the government to augment the needs of left out areas should be started at the earliest.

The scheme is being implemented by L&T construction company. Construction of four pump houses has started and work on the remaining two pump houses will begin the next week. Pipelines will be laid soon.

The state government has sanctioned Rs 230 crore for rehabilitation of the Noyyal river basin. According to PWD officials, the Noyyal river basin is 158.35 km long and has 18 anaicuts, 22 tanks and supply channels. “We are repairing the damaged 18 anaicuts. The entire stretch of the river basin is to be delisted and vegetation removed from the bunds and the river.

Title: 253 anganwadis in DK have no permanent address

This story is from February 15, 2020

Lack of proper infrastructure: Across seven taluks in DK, the 253 anganwadis operate out of rented premises, p... Read More

Title: Telangana gets new eco-friendly sewage treatment plant on ARCI campus in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Sewage treatment plant at ARCI campus in Hyderabad

HYDERABAD: The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Neeri), Nagpur has set up Telangana ’s first phytorid-based sewage treatment plant at the campus of International Advanced Research Centre for Powder Metallurgy and New Materials (ARCI) in Hyderabad.

A patent technology developed by the institute headquartered in Nagpur, phytorid wastewater treatment is an environment-friendly technology to curb water pollution. Developed by Neeri director Rakesh Kumar, the technology has been adapted at over 200 places across the country.

It has been installed by the institute’s Centre of Strategic Urban Management (C-SUM) which aims to involve urban local bodies and stakeholders to build sustainable cities. Facilitating recycle and reuse of water, the technology uses plants to absorb nutrients directly from waste water.

According to the scientists, the plant at ARCI has a capacity of treating 15,000 litres of waste water per day. “Till now, the waste water generated at the campus would go directly into the septic tank. However now, the waste water is being efficiently treated and being utilized for maintaining the green cover,” said Ritesh Vijay, principal scientist and head of Mumbai zonal centre, adding that waste water from canteen, office area, toilets and washing area is completely getting treated. In the absence of large-scale STP , decentralized treatment technologies are the best way to save water bodies.

“The topography of ARCI campus was favourable for the plant. The technology is cost-effective and does not have any electrical requirement,” said Vijay.

Title: Education minister goes virtual with 100 schools
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: School education minister Varsha Gaikwad inaugurated e-Balbharati in the city on Friday morning and conducted a virtual classroom session with over 100 schools at a time across the state.

As many as 725 schools in Maharashtra will be connected to the virtual classroom by e-Balbharati, earlier known as Balchitrawani. The students will be able to attend sessions with experts, lectures from renowned personalities, among others, through this virtual medium.

On Friday, students from Osmanabad, Kolhapur, Raigad, Ratnagiri, Ahmednagar and other districts, asked about the number of subjects that would be covered under this programme, how useful the facility would be for them, would the students of semi-English schools benefit from it, would it be used to relieve students’ stress.

Gaikwad said, “The virtual classroom set up in over 700 schools in Maharashtra will help lakhs of students connect and interact with experts. Experts, counsellors, motivational speakers will guide students on exams and how to de-stress during this period.”

Shraddha Patil, a teacher from Uran in Raigad, asked Gaikwad about her journey from being a professor to the education minister. Gaikwad said, “I was a student of a government Marathi-medium school and I would engage in sports activities till Standard X. I completed my postgraduation in Maths, followed by a bachelor's degree in education. I also enrolled for a doctorate degree. But, I joined politics. So, from being a teacher to minister was a tough road for me. But, I feel that each one of you have similar capabilities and can make Maharashtra proud.”

Title: Govt mulls light rail system to link 2nd airport in Parandur
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Chennai: As Parandur in Kancheepuram district has been zeroed in as venue for the proposed second airport, the state government is exploring the possibility of introducing a mass rapid transit link to connect it with the existing airport. While a light rail may link the airport in Meenambakkam to Parandur 62km away for transit passengers, there is also a plan to extend metro rail line from Poonamallee to connect it. Airports Authority of India (AAI) is planning to shift international flight operations to the second airport.

Sources in the industries department said the suggestion for light rail was floated during discussions about setting up the second airport. “Light rail is the only option for passengers landing at Meenambakkam to proceed towards Parandur. For city passengers, metro rail is an option,” an industries department official privy to developments told TOI. The Tamil Nadu Industrial Development Corporation Limited, which will appoint a consultant for the second airport, would also study which option will be feasible.

Light rail has smaller coaches with a train having two or four coaches and has less capacity than metro rail but is less expensive to build. It costs lesser than Rs 100 crore to build compared to the Rs 150 to \Rs 200crore a km an elevated metro line would cost.

The second airport will come up across 4,500 acres in Parandur, chosen due to its proximity to the national highway to Bengaluru. It was chosen after various locations including Mamandur and Cheyyur in Chengalpet district and a land near Gummidipoondi in Tiruvallur district were considered. “The existing airport will get saturated in a few years,” the industries department official added. The second airport plan has been delayed by more than 10 years.

Currently, the phase II line of metro rail that will be built till Poonamallee may be extended to Thirumazhisai, as per reports. It can be further extended to Parandur, which is located off Chennai-Bengaluru highway, sources said. The proposed metro rail line from Poonamallee will connect to existing Central-CMBT-Alandur line at CMBT. CMRL operates direct trains from Central to airport via CMBT and Alandur.

An AAI official said the second airport should have good connectivity to the city by a mass rapid transit system or a broader highway as it will be an aero city with aviation businesses, auxiliary units and training centres. AAI is building a terminal in the existing airport to increase passenger capacity to 30 million passengers as the airport is set to saturate by 2024.

Title: Wheel of change: City man charts a pollution-free path on unicycle
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: When city resident Pranay Upadhyay's son was found struggling with Autism, the doctor said that pollution could be one reason for his son’s diagnosis.

“That man-made problems such as pollution can have long-term impact on our children’s health is what I have experienced first-hand,” says Pranay. The 45-year-old says he after the diagnosis he could not just sit around and do nothing.

For over a decade, Pranay has not used petrol or diesel vehicles to travel. The techie uses his electric unicycle to travel from his home in Bowrampet in the outskirts of the city to Gachibowli. “It takes me around an hour on my one-wheel,” he says, adding that he enjoys the ride, which is eco-friendly, cost effective and easy to manoeuvre.

“Even cars give me way,” he chuckles. On days that there is a traffic block, he can easily manoeuvre through it or simply carry his 'vehicle’ and take public transport.

Pranay wears a board on his back while travelling, which reads: “Do you need a car/SUV during peak hours only to transport one person?” He says spreading awareness is the one thing he can do in the battle against pollution and climate change.

For long distances, the techie, who works for a robotic firm, uses a bicycle, peddling away for even 34hours to get to places such as Bengaluru from Hyderabad. “Since I began my journey, hundreds of people have switched to cycling,” he says.

Pranay says it is the fear of losing balance that probably keeps people away.

Pranay, a paramotor pilot, first came across his one-wheel drive when his aircraft manufacturer spoke about how the front wheel were being used for unicycles across Europe. “The unicycle feels like an extension of my body. It is safe and easy to use. In fact, I have not fallen once since I started using it and avoid potholes too,” he says.

For Pranay, the hope is to reduce one car at a time on the road. And people are taking notice of his novel efforts. Kajal Maheshwari, representing the Citizens for Hyderabad that has taken up several environmental causes said, “Pranay has by his example shown us it (eco-sensitive travel) is possible and doable. We are all looking forward to his help in acquiring the one-wheel wonder so that we can start trying it ourselves.”

Title: Telangana: Trucker takes Rs 50 lakh insurance for uncle, kills him
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A truck owner was arrested on Friday for killing his uncle to claim an insurance amount of Rs 50 lakh while trying to pass off the death as a road accident. Cops said that accused M Ramesh, in a bid to recoup his business losses, came up with the plan to kill his uncle Saidulu (35) after taking an insurance policy in his name with his mother as the beneficiary.

Ramesh, his associates Mahesh, a truck driver, and Sobhan Babu, a labourer, were arrested from Tadvai village in Munagala mandal of Suryapet district. According to police, Saidulu, whose wife had deserted him, did not have any immediate family members and was working as a cleaner on Ramesh’s truck.

“Ramesh had bought four trucks taking loan from private financiers. He suffered huge losses and sold off the trucks, but was still had a debt of Rs 50 lakh. The murder was a way to clear his debts,” Munagala CI S Siva Shankar Goud said.

Police said that on January 23 Ramesh along with the other accused and the victim started from Tadvai in his Bolero.

They stopped vehicle near a BP Petrol pump on Hyderabad-Vijayawada highway near Munagala, got Saidulu drunk and asked him to walk towards the parking bay. “Saidulu, who used to steal small items from parked trucks, went towards the empty parking bay and the accused ran him over,” said CI Goud, adding that Ramesh drove the vehicle over Saidulu multiple times to ensure he was dead

While initially it was thought to be an accident, cops in their preliminary probe found from villagers that Saidulu had a Rs 50 lakh life insurance policy. “We were surprised that Saidulu, who has no family and works as a cleaner, had life insurance of Rs 50 lakh. The insurance policy was taken in July 2019 with Ramesh’s mother Saraswati as the nominee. Ramesh had paid Rs 12,700 as first premium,” the inspector said.

Ramesh and the other accused were taken into custody and during interrogation they confessed to the murder. The petrol pump staff also confirmed that the accused and the victim consumed liquor near the pump on January 23 night, police said.

The police have seized the Bolero and the trio are now in judicial custody.

Title: Kanpur Bar annual election on March 7
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kanpur: The annual general election of Kanpur Bar Association will be conducted now on March 7. The Elders Committee, in a meeting held on Thursday, made some amendments in the election programme.

As per the amendments, the voting will be held at DAV Inter College premises on March 7 from 8am to 5pm. On March 8, counting of votes for posts of president and general secretary will take place at the same venue. Thereafter counting for other posts would be held at Kanpur Bar Association hall, said special associate to Elders Committee Susheel Kumar Verma.

Verma said, the election process has started. The electoral list has been published and objections, if any, have been invited by February 15. Nomination of candidates would be done on February 18 and 19, he added.

For executive committee senior and junior voting would be held on single voting system, said Verma.

Meanwhile, election activities begin in Kanpur Nagar court campus as the campus walls get covered with posters and pamphlets.

Title: Sunny Rana claims best figures by any U’khand bowler in first-class cricket
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dehradun: City-born fast bowler Sunny Rana clinched seven wickets while giving away just 43 runs during his 19-over-long spell during the ongoing Ranji Trophy match against Maharashtra in Baramati on Friday. This is the best bowling figure by any Uttarakhand bowler in a first-class match.

Rana broke the record of Deepak Dhapola who had taken seven wickets while giving away 50 runs against Manipur in a match played in Dehradun in November, 2018.

Speaking to TOI, Rana said, “The current season didn’t go the way I had expected, so I was keen to perform in our last Ranji Trophy match of the season. The wicket was flat and had nothing for fast bowlers. Therefore, it was tough to get wickets following the conventional style. I tried to keep an end tight and dry due to which the opposition batsmen ultimately played risky shots which didn’t turned out well for them. I would like to give credit to my personal coach Manoj Rawat and our team’s bowling coach Ashish Zaidi sir.”

Rana added, “We are trying desperately hard to win this as we haven’t won any game in this year’s Ranji Trophy tournament. Also, if we win this game and Tripura loses its match against Assam, we won’t get relegated back to the Plate Group.”

Notably, Maharashtra has set a target of 270 runs for Uttarakhand to chase in their second innings. After the end of Day 3, Uttarakhand stood at 103/2 with Kamal Singh (40*) and night-watchman Mayank Mishra (19*) at the crease.

Title: CM Trivendra Singh Rawat, seers inspect Kumbh mela works
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Trivendra Singh Rawat

HARIDWAR: Chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat along with urban development minister Madan Kaushik, secretary Shailesh Bagauli, Kumbh mela officer Deepak Rawat and other officials carried out a spot inspection of the works in mela area on Friday.

Akhil Bharatiya Akhada Parishad president Narendra Giri, general secretary Hari Giri and other seers also accompanied the CM .

While expressing satisfaction over the ongoing work, the CM said "quality of work should be maintained at all costs and Kumbh preparations should be speeded up." He also inspected the Baiaragi Camp area where four bridges are being constructed to connect the Kankhal locality of the city.

Keeping in view the demands of the akhadas for more land and better facilities for their inmates and disciples coming to the Kumbh, Rawat said that the administration will ensure that they face no problem due to lack of facilities.

Meanwhile, the administration has decided to give Y-category security to the president and general secretary of the Akhada Parishad, official sources said, adding that names of around 26 other seers are also being considered who might get more security ahead of the mega festival.

Title: Amid protests, Urdu back on signboards at rly platforms in U'khand
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dehradun: Barely days after replacing Urdu with Sanskrit, Dehradun railways authorities have now gone back to Urdu on signboards at railway stations.

The move comes days after name of Dehradun railway station was written in Sanskrit as Dehradunam, along with Hindi and English, when the station re-opened for public after three months. The name for Doiwala railway station, also in Dehradun, was written ‘Doiwalah’ and a new railway station in Rishikesh as ‘Yog Nagari Rishikeshah’.

However, soon after the railway ministry issued a notification stating that Sanskrit can be used as an additional language apart from the existing languages on railway signboards. Following which, the authorities went back to the format of English-Hindi-Urdu on February 10. But now the authorities are in a fix after members of right-wing outfits gheraoed the Dehradun station manager and demanded Sanskrit back on the signboards.

Ganesh Chandra Thakur, station director of Dehradun railway station, told TOI that the railway manual states that signboards at railway station should be in three languages — English, Hindi and regional/second language of the state. “It was right to replace Urdu with Sanskrit here. But adding a fourth language needs special provisions and approvals from both railways and state government. This will take some time and we are worried of the law and order situation as those who want Sanskrit back have threatened to protest and changing it immediately is not in our hands,” he said.

Meanwhile, members of right-wing outfits have announced to launch a protest if the authorities fail to include Sanskrit on the signboards by next week. RB Bijalwan, state president of Sanskrit teachers association, told TOI that removing Sanskrit from signboards was an insult to the language. “We have given a week’s time to the district magistrate and railway authorities to fix the issue. We want Sanskrit back on the signboard and have no problem with Urdu as an additional language,” he said.

Cabinet minister and government spokesperson Madan Kaushik said that the state government will write to the Centre and railway ministry to include Sanskrit on signboards at railway stations. “When we were part of UP, our second language was Urdu. Now, we are a different state and Sanskrit is our second language. We will be writing to the Centre seeking Sanskrit on our signboards,” Kaushik said.

Title: Smart road: Works going on at a slow place, say traders
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dehradun: The Smart Road construction work in Paltan Bazaar is drawing mixed responses from local traders. Currently, works on a 30-metre stretch of the road is ongoing but several traders complain that the pace is slow.

“The work on this small stretch of the road was supposed to be completed within a week but it has been almost four weeks and the work is still incomplete. I believe that officials should use more advanced methods,” said Ashok Chopra, a local trader.

Several traders claimed that the pace of works increased quite significantly only after they complained to the administration. “The pace of work was slow and no proper safety measures were being taken by the workers. Things changed for better after the matter was brought to the notice of officials,” said another local Anil Jain.

However, some traders also expressed their content with the ongoing works. “Traders will have to suffer for a while but things will get better after the construction is completed. Smart Road will make the market more spacious. These works are being undertaken for our welfare,” said Prateek, a local trader.

Meanwhile, the assistant general manager of Dehradun Smart City Limited (DSCL) Surya Kotnala told TOI, “For the convenience of traders, the construction work begins late at night. We don’t stack the material in the market and make sure that all the open spots are covered before the shops open.”

Title: No loudspeakers without permission in shrines in US Nagar from today
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Rudrapur: Almost one-and-a-half years after Uttarakhand high court (HC) ordered a ban on the use of loudspeakers in shrines , the administration of Udham Singh Nagar district conducted a meeting with representatives of all religious organisations on Friday and decided to implement the HC order from February 15.

In an order issued in June 2018, the court had told the government that the use of loudspeakers, even during day, will be contingent on the user giving an undertaking that the noise level will not exceed five decibels.

The court directed the state government to ensure that no loudspeaker or public address system is used by any person or organisation, including religious bodies, without the written permission of the relevant authorities. District magistrate (DM) Neeraj Kharwal and senior superintendent of police (SSP) Barinderjit Singh called a meeting with representatives of religious organisations from all across the district. DM Kharwal said that as per the HC order, the use of loudspeakers at temples, mosques, and other public places without permission is banned from February 15 and it is also the deadline to remove amplifiers from these places.

"On court directions in relation to implementation of noise pollution control rules, a government order giving detailed instructions has been issued," Kharwal said.

SSP Singh added, "A survey of permanently installed loudspeakers has been done and notices have been served to those who are using them without requisite permission. If the permission to install loudspeakers at religious or public places was not sought before February 15, we would remove it. After that, action will be initiated under Environment Protection Act 1986.”

Religious leaders also hailed the administration's move to remove unauthorised loudspeakers.

Cleric at the city’s Jama Masjid, Mohammad Imamuddin said, "We welcome the order and have already applied to fill up the form provided by the district administration for permission.”

Tilak Raj Behar, patron of the Sanatan Dharam Sabha, added that cacophony had no place in a religion and that he, too, welcomed the order.

Title: Lobbying begins to get on to Madras univ VC search panel
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Chennai: The tenure of University of Madras vice-chancellor P Duraisamy is set to end in May and intense lobbying has begun to be on the search panel to pick his successor. The syndicate of the university, which convened on Friday to choose nominees to the vice-chancellor search panel, was surprised to see industrialist Nalli Kuppusamy’s name be proposed. After discussion, however, the syndicate unanimously elected P Ramasamy, former vice-chancellor of Alagappa University, as its nominee to the search panel.

“Despite the new law specifying qualifications for panel members and VC aspirants, a section of members proposed an industrialist’s name to the search panel,” a syndicate member said. As per the law enacted by the state government, universities can only nominate eminent academicians to the committee . But another member pointed out that the law is not binding on the university and proposing a prominent member of society was not a wrong move.

“The Madras University Act, 1923, was framed before Independence. The amendment will be applicable to Madras University only after getting the President’s assent,” a syndicate member said.

Professors said VC aspirants are trying to push members supportive of their candidature. “Many people are eyeing Madras University VC post. The intensive lobbying has just begun,” a senior professor said.

In 2016, following disappearance and non-cooperation of R Surendira Prasad, a members of the Madras University VC search panel, the state government brought the amendment fixing minimum qualification for search panel members and time limit to shortlist VC candidates.

A special senate meeting has been convened on February 20 to elect the senate nominee to the search panel. After that, the governor-chancellor would appoint his nominee and convener of the search committee. The new committee needs to submit a panel of three to five names to the chancellor within four months. It is the governor’s discretion to either dissolve the committee or give it time beyond that.

After taking over as vice-chancellor at critical juncture, P Duraisamy has so far provided a corruption-free administration.

Title: Health dept orders probe as college student denied ambulance dies
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Chennai: The state health department has ordered inquiry into why an ambulance wasn’t sent for a patient who made a distress call to 108 helpline on Sunday. The deceased is Ganesh Kumar, a 19-year-old college student who was playing cricket with friends. He had stepped aside to get water and was alone, when he experienced uneasiness and called for an ambulance. He died waiting for help.

Police said Ganesh was playing cricket with friends at Pachiyappan ground in Kancheepuram. “He developed uneasiness when he stepped aside to fetch water and called ‘108’. He explained the situation and requested an ambulance. But the call centre employee assumed it to be a prank call and refused to dispatch an ambulance,” a police officer privy to the case details said. He later died due of suffocation.

After his funeral, his family members checked his mobile and found the recording of his call to ‘108’, requesting an ambulance be sent to rescue him. The audio was shared on social media with his father saying Ganesh died due to the negligence of the ‘108’ call centre staff.

Sources said the call centre employee who attended his distress call insisted that he hand over the phone to someone nearby as he suspected it to be a prank call. Nearly 60% of the calls to 108 are not for emergencies. But that was no excuse.

“There is no reason why ambulance should be denied to anyone. The protocol is to take the risk and still send an ambulance,” said state health secretary Beela Rajesh. A detailed inquiry has been ordered.

“The staff is absconding now. He will appear before a committee,” she said. The department is also working to strengthen training of staff besides developing protocols that can prevent ineffective calls.

Title: Pulwama attack: Remaining compensation given to martyrs’ families
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Dharamkot SDM Narinder Dhaliwal handing over a cheque to Pulwama martyr Jaimal Singh’s father Jaswant Singh an... Read More

BATHINDA/AMRITSAR: The Punjab government has provided remaining compensation due to widows of Pulwama martyrs — CRPF head constable Jaimal Singh and head constable Sukhjinder Singh — on the first anniversary of the terror attack on Friday.

Dharamkot sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) Narinder Singh Dhaliwal presented a cheque of the remaining Rs 5 lakh of compensation amount to Jaimal’s wife Sukhjit Kaur. Apart from the pending amount, Rs 43,750 was also provided to Jaimal’s father Jaswant Singh, which was the part payment from the collection of one day salary of ministers, MLAs and IAS officers’ association.

At the time of martyrdom, Punjab government had announced a financial assistance of Rs 12 lakh each to family members of four CRPF personnel martyred in blast at Pulwama on February 14, 2019 apart from job each to one of the family members. Sukhjit has made a written request to reserve a job for his son till he comes of age.

Pulwama martyr Sukhjinder Singh’s family also received the pending compensation on Friday. His brother Gurjant Singh said the additional deputy commissioner, Tarn Taran, had handed over a cheque of Rs 7 lakh to the family during a function held at Gandiwind . He said the administration had also assured to provide a job to martyr’s widow Sarabjit Kaur so that she and her one-and-a-half-year-old son Gurjot could have some financial security.

Former CRPF constable Lakhvish Singh, who is brother of martyr Maninder Singh, said cabinet minister Aruna Chaudhary had announced to recruit him as a constable in Punjab Police in the near future. After Maninder’s martyrdom, Lakvish resigned from his job to take care of his ailing father.

A religious ceremony was also held at a gurdwara at Kot Ise Khan town of Moga in memory of the sacrifice of the Pulwama martyr where Moga ADC Subash Chandar, district sainik welfare officer Major (retd) Yashpal Singh, CRPF assistant commandant Ajay Kumar Sharma paid tributes.

Of the 40 CRPF personnel who died in Pulwama terror attack, five were from the region — four from Punjab and one from Himachal. Now, all the families have got the compensation money promised to them and job offers, which have either been taken up or kept pending. While Jaimal was from Moga, Sukhjinder from Tarn Taran, Maninder Singh Attri from Gurdaspur and Kulwinder Singh from Anandpur Sahib , Tilak Raj belonged to Kangra district of Himachal Pradesh .

Title: Punjab: NHM stops free girl care, reverses order day later
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

BATHINDA: In a flip-flop, the National Health Mission (NHM) withdrew its orders on Friday of stopping free treatment facility to girls up to the age of 5 and for first 24 hours in emergency cases after the admission of patients in government hospitals in Punjab.

State-run hospitals had stopped free treatment on Thursday after the director health services wrote to officials of the department in all 22 districts of Punjab and three government medical colleges, informing them that the Union government had not approved the scheme of free treatment to girl child up to 5 years in the programme implementation plans (PIP) 2019-20.

A total of Rs 1,054.82 crore has been approved under NHM for Punjab’s PIP for the financial year 2019-20 for various purposes, including immunisation.

Patients heading for emergency and getting treatment for small girls were taken by surprise when they were asked to pay. “We were told to pay for stitches, dressing applied on our four-year-old daughter. Earlier the treatment was free,” said Karamjit Kaur of Bathinda, who had taken her daughter for treatment at a government hospital.

On January 31, NMH Punjab had written to the director, health services (family welfare), that the approval had not been given in PIP 2019-20 for free treatment to girl child up to 5 years and free treatment for first 24 hours in emergency. Following the letter, the health department had written to all district officials on February 10 and free treatment facility was stopped on Thursday, sources in the health department said.

Bathinda civil surgeon Dr Amrik Sandhu said, “Free facility was stopped in some of the components of the treatment like medicines for various types of operations but the accidental cases are being handled as previously. It was being done as the Union government has not approved two schemes under Punjab NHM.”

When contacted, Punjab NHM mission director Kumar Rahul said, “The health authorities had some misunderstanding. Actually, along with the girl child, everyone is being given free treatment with a small token money on issuing the treatment slip. We have withdrawn the wrongly issued orders and free treatment facility will continue.”

Title: Ahmedabad cops file FIR over old Odisha video gone viral
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: City cybercrime cell has filed an FIR under Section 153 (a) IPC at crime branch against unknown persons for circulating on social media an old video shot in Odisha. The video posted on Facebook shows police evicting roadside vendors, stated the complainant, a sub-inspector of cybercrime cell.

Crime branch sources said after learning about the video doing rounds on social media, they had asked the cybercrime cell to investigate it. Police believe the sudden circulation of the old video ahead of US President Donald Trump’s visit to Ahmedabad has been done with mala fide intention.

“The intention of making this video viral is to create a law and order situation before the US president’s visit to the city” said a crime branch source.

Crime branch sources said they have requested the service provider to give them the IP address of the device from which the video was uploaded. “We have interrogated a few persons, who said the video was forwarded to them. We will trace the accused once we learn the IP address,” a cop said.

Title: No secret deal with AAP in Delhi polls, says Rajeev Shukla
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Rajeev Shukla

INDORE: Senior Congress leader Rajeev Shukla on Friday rubbished the notion that his party had a secret deal with Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) in Delhi elections and that people voted against BJP to keep communal politics at bay.

“In Delhi assembly polls, voters wanted to ensure BJP’s defeat at any cost. They were afraid that division of votes would result in BJP’s win, which was contesting on communal issues. As such, they voted for AAP, which was contesting with more intensity than BJP,” Shukla told mediapersons.

About speculations that his party had entered into a ‘secret-deal’ with AAP to defeat BJP, the Congress leader said, “Why any ‘secret-deal’ would be made? Our party contests every election with full might and in last assembly elections of Punjab, Congress had defeated AAP,” Shukla said.

When asked about Congress failing to open its account in Delhi, Shukla said, “The party is unhappy over the defeat and will work to remove weaknesses of the organization.”

Referring to union home minister Amit Shah’s claim that inflammatory statements by BJP leaders had led to party’s defeat, Shukla said, “People would only believe Shah (his sincerity) if his party will take disciplinary action against (BJP) leaders, who made hate speeches during electioneering.”

On external affairs minister S Jaishankar's remarks that a book had claimed Jawaharlal Nehru did not want Sardar Patel in his cabinet, Shukla said, “We did not expect such a statement from Jaishankar. Historical documents contradict his statement. So, it would be appropriate that he apologises for this statement about Nehru.”

Shukla also targeted Prime Minister Narendra Modi, saying that his intention was not clear over present system of giving reservation to SC/ST and OBC in jobs and education and the party wanted to deprive people of said categories from the benefits of reservation.

Title: Kafeel Khan slapped with NSA for anti-CAA speech at AMU
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Anuja.Jaiswal@timesgroup.com

Agra: The Uttar Pradesh police late on Thursday night slapped the stringent National Security Act (NSA) on Gorakhpur paediatrician Dr Kafeel Khan, hours before he was expected to walk free from Mathura jail , four days after he was granted bail by Aligarh chief judicial magistrate.

Aligarh district magistrate CB Singh said, “Protests had continued in the city and AMU for days after Khan delivered an inflammatory speech on the university campus. In fact, students turned violent on the campus on December 15”.

Deputy inspector general (Aligarh) Akash Kulhary told TOI that the NSA allows preventive detention for months if the authorities feel that the person is a threat to the national security or law and order.

Dr Khan was booked by Aligarh police on December 13 for delivering a provocative speech in Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) during an anti-CAA protest on the campus a day earlier and was arrested from Mumbai airport on January 29 by UP Police’s special task force. He was remanded to judicial custody for 14 days on January 30.

Khan had been lodged in Mathura jail despite bail granted being to him by the CJM’s court on February 10.

Khan’s younger brother, Kashif Jameel, who visited Mathura jail on Friday hoping to take his brother back home, told TOI that he was very disappointed with the government’s decision of slapping NSA on his brother.

“My brother is unnecessarily being harassed by the government because of his surname ‘Khan’. Many political leaders, including those from BJP, had given several inflammatory speeches, but none of them were harassed like my brother. They are trying to suppress his voice as he stands with others, demanding justice for the victims,” he said.

On Friday, Khan’s wife Shabistan Khan also reached Mathura jail to meet her husband but she started feeling unwell after she came to know about the NSA charges against him.

Khan’s lawyer Irfan Ghazi said they will soon challenge the NSA in a higher court. “The state government doesn’t want him to get out of the jail. That’s why his release was delayed by the jail authorities even after he was granted bail,” he said.

Claiming a threat to his life in jail, Ghazi said that Khan has been isolated from other prison inmates and is not getting his medicines.

After his arrest in Mumbai, Khan was brought to Aligarh, from where he was immediately shifted to the district jail in neighbouring Mathura.

According to the police, this was done as a precautionary measure in view of the anti-CAA protests on the AMU campus and at Eidgah grounds in the old city.

Police had said that Kafeel Khan's presence in the Aligarh jail could have worsened the law and order situation in the city.

The doctor was earlier arrested for his alleged role in the death of over 60 children in one week at the BRD Medical College in Gorakhpur in August 2017. Short supply of oxygen at the children’s ward was blamed at that time for the deaths.

About two years later, a state government probe cleared Kafeel Khan of all major charges, prompting him to seek an apology from the Yogi Adityanath government.

Title: Kal Bionics lends a ‘smart’ helping hand to millions
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: When Gayatri Roy Choudhury, who was born without an arm, was asked about the first thing she would do if she got her arm back, she said she would hold her child. Similarly, when Venketesh, who had lost both arms in an accident, was asked the same question, he sheepishly said he wanted to scratch his forehead first.

And fulfilling these wishes is a homegrown startup, Kal Bionics Private Limited, that was set up by five friends, Pranav Kumar, Philip Thomas, Sai Prasad, Harsha Reddy and Suren to leverage technology to solve some of the pressing needs of humankind.

The startup, that was set up two years ago, has built an indigenous bionic arm that does not only costs nearly 10 times cheaper at around Rs 2.5 to 3 lakh than the ones available in developed countries (Rs 30-60 lakh), but can also accomplish more number of tasks.

"There has not been much innovation in the prosthetics industry in India in the past couple of decades. But globally, innovation in bionics is moving at a very rapid pace and that is why we thought of working in this area,” says the 26-year old CEO and co-founder Pranav Kumar.

Explaining the working of a bionic arm, he says that unlike the conventional prosthetics arms available in the market that are either cosmetic in nature or are capable of limited movements like the myoelectric prosthetics, a bionic arm functions like a real one because of a better grip.

"Unlike a leg, the functioning of an arm is very complex. For instance, if you want to tie a shoe lace, the grip required is very different from that of the grip one needs to hold a bottle...," he says, adding that typically a bionic arm has 14 grips but the one developed by Kal Bionics has 16.

What is interesting is that Kal Bionics has not only ensured that its arm, named KalArm, has a better grip but it is 'smart' too. "As and when we teach the arm more types of grips, KalArm will get updated on its own. Therefore, customers need not keep buying new arms," he says, adding that the arm can also be customised as per the unique requirements of the customer.

The startup has been testing its bionic arm for over three months and many of its features have been modified based on the feedback received from over 10 amputees using it. "We have tested our product and now will be applying for certifications from the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). Once we receive it, we expect to launch KalArm by April-May this year, in India. And as and when we plan to hit other markets, we will also apply for that country’s specific certification," he says. The startup is also planning to set up an assembly unit in Hyderabad with a capacity to manufacture anywhere around 5,000-10,000 units a year.

Even as it gets ready to launch its bionic arm, the startup is gearing up to work on its next project of building exoskeleton, which can help paralyzed people or older ones move freely.
