Title: End monopolistic rights on Gurbani telecast: Punjab cabinet minister Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

A delegation meets Giani Harpreet Singh to seek his intervention in the matter

AMRITSAR: Punjab cabinet minister Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa led a delegation of Sikh leaders to meet acting Akal Takht jathedar Giani Harpreet Singh. They sought his intervention to end the monopoly on the live telecast of Gurbani from Golden Temple and to facilitate the availability of a signal to all channels within the framework of guidelines.

Talking to mediapersons later, the panchayat and rural development minister said Gurbani was not a commodity and could not be traded. “The message of the gurus articulated in the Gurbani must be taken to every corner of the world for free rather than be made a business,” he said.

Saying that the jathedar assured him of looking into the matter, Bajwa condemned the monopoly rights given by SGPC to a TV channel owned by the SAD (B) president on the grounds that it violated the basic tenets and teachings of the Gurbani.

“The signal should be made available free of cost to every channel interested in spreading Gurbani after getting an undertaking on observing the norms laid down,” he said, adding that the SGPC should make its own arrangements for distribution of signal. He also pointed out that more than two decades after the proposal for setting up of a channel by SGPC, nothing had been done on the ground.

Title: Ahmedabad likely to get police commissioner
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Gandhinagar is likely to get a police commissionerate. A proposal in this connection has been made by the state DGP before the state government. After the state government’s nod, Gandhinagar will become the fifth city to get a new commissionerate in the state. Sources in the home department said that the proposal was made last week.

An official of the rank of IG will be made the first police commissioner of Gandhinagar, sources said.

Jurisdiction of some police stations of Ahmedabad will also get changed after this move. Kadi and Kalol police stations, which are under the jurisdiction of Gandhinagar SP office, will also be included in Gandhinagar commissionerate .

Sources said that parts of Sabarmati, Sola high court and Chandkheda police stations will be under the new commissionerate. It will also get four deputy commissioners of police.

Title: Punjab: Parkash Singh Badal’s BJP jibe morale booster for SAD cadres
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Prakash Singh Badal

JALANDHAR: While political leaders and experts are trying to figure out the reasons behind Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) patron Parkash Singh Badal’s indirect jibe at ally BJP over “discrimination on basis of religion”, Akali cadres are feeling elated by it.

The boost of assertiveness has come at a time when Akalis were reeling under the treatment meted out to them by BJP in Delhi. The saffron party did not do well in Delhi polls, giving a breather to SAD. Akali cadres are happy that the former chief min-ster has sho-wn mirror to BJP, putting it in dock over its brand of politics. On the other hand, BJP functionaries may also find it tough to hit back at Badal given his age and stature, about which they themselves had been gushing.

SAD insiders said that they were happy at the remarks as BJP appeared to be embarrassing Akalis by moves in Delhi and also by asserting that in 2022, they would be the senior partner in the alliance in Punjab. The developments in Delhi had come when SAD was facing attacks from dissidents and Rajya Sabha member Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa had managed to bring them on one platform.

“These remarks have boosted morale of our cadres. Some had earlier called up to say that they were finding it difficult to explain party position to ground workers or people regarding Delhi poll drama. What’s more, sentiment in Punjab, especially among Sikhs, is against exclusion of Muslims from CAA and recent provocative statements by a few BJP leaders in Delhi elections,” said a SAD functionary, who also happens to be a SGPC member.

“It will also send a message to Punjab BJP leaders whose repeated statements to contest on more seats has been embarrassing Akalis,” said another Akali leader.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Where are the masks in Ahmedabad?
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

Ahmedabad: With the city hosting large events with delegates from across the world, the first precaution many citizens thought of taking against the novel coronavirus (NCoV) when being exposed to crowds, was to get N95 masks, to prevent the spread of the virus that has claimed more than 1,000 lives.

If you go to the market and ask for the mask, chances are it will not be available. Owners of medical stores in the city say there are two reasons for the phenomenon — the first is the reluctance of smaller shops to stock these masks which are now selling for twice their usual price, and the the second is a lack of awareness about the protocols for NCoV.

Dashrath Patel, the owner of a medical store in the city, said that for the past few days stocks of genuine N95 masks are not being received. “Masks sold in the market today are not respirators, having a filter to arrest particles. Most of these are being imported from the US,” he said. “These masks are also no guarantee that one won’t get the infection. There is still a lot to know about NCoV.”

Many blame wholesale dealers. A pharmacist in Paldi said the masks were earlier available in the city for about Rs 100-130. “Today, these same masks are being sold for Rs 200-250. Is this not profiteering? It is largely due to the scare among the citizens and the lack of awareness about ways to prevent the viral infection,” said the pharmacist.

Jayendra Rana, the owner of a medical store in Vastrapur, said they are waiting for new stocks of masks to arrive while demand rises. “Several stores are selling surgical masks or non-N95 masks at a premium,” he said.

Medical experts had earlier said that the masks can prevent respiration of viruses and the accidental touching of hands to the nose and mouth.

Title: After CAA, rise in number of applications forbirth certificates, some locals get fake docus
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bareilly: A large number of worried families, particularly from minority community, are approaching officials at the Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) for their birth certificates and other documents since the recently amended Citizenship Act (CAA).

“In the past two months, we have been receiving nearly 200 applications for birth certificates every day - which is quite unusual. Earlier, on a given day we used to get only 20 such applications,” BMC health officer Sanjeev Pradhan said.

Moreover, with the locally authorised certificate centre, the Lokvani Kendra, not issuing birth certificates for over a year now, people are depending more on cyber cafes to enroll themselves on civilian registration system (CRS) and apply online for such documents, especially for children who are above one year old. Here, some people are being tricked by touts and a few cyber cafes. These cafes are said to be charging somewhere between Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 for “instant birth certificates”.

The BMC officials have also found several cases of fake birth certificates “issued by cyber cafes”. In fact, Pradhan has lodged a complaint with police to take action against those responsible for issuing such fake certificates.

Once a person is registered with the CRS after a year of the child’s birth, the individual has to go through a long procedure acquiring various certificates from the hospital to subdivision office to complete registration process on the CRS and get the birth certificate. Some parents, whose child is over two years of age, are now approaching touts who lead them to a cyber café which are issuing such fake birth certificates.

The BMC health officer explained, “Cyber cafes are not issuing proper certificates, but handing out a print out of a birth certificate of some other person where the name and address are usually doctored. These people are then contacting us to add their child’s name in the records. But, the certificates which they are providing are found fake upon scrutiny.”

Khalil Ahmad, an official at BMC health department, told TOI on Friday, “I have found at least six such cases so far following which I reported to my senior and registered a complaint with the police. Since, most of these fake certificates were issued to the people of Muslim community it cannot be denied that some cyber cafes are taking advantage of the people who are worried after the CAA.”

Meanwhile, municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said that he would write to the police to know what action is being taken in the matter.

Title: Girls pricked with syringe, probe begins
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Ahmedabad: Two minor girls from the Amraiwadi area on Friday alleged that an unidentified person had pricked their hands with a ‘syringe-like’ object. The girls have been admitted to LG Hospital. Biological samples have been sent for testing to ascertain if they had been injected with any substance and the results are awaite.

“It cannot be said at present that the girls were injected with any liquid, but it is clear that they were pricked with a sharp object. We have taken an application of complaint and are investigating the case. We are gathering CCTV footage to identify the person who pricked them,” said Inspector R T Udavat of Amraiwadi police station.

“We are also get help from our local informers.”

The father of one of the girls said that they were on their way to school when the incident occurred.

“My daughter did not see the man. Surprisingly, she was not the only victim. We don’t know why someone would target her but it is worrying,” he said.

“Fortunately, her health is fine,” he added.

Title: 1,855 dog bite cases reported in Bareilly district hospital in January
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

1,855 cases of dog bite have been reported at Bareilly district hospital in January alone

BAREILLY: A report by the state health department has revealed that 1,855 cases of dog bite , 166 cases of monkey bite, 27 cases of cat bite, 2 cases of horse bite and 1 case of crocodile bite have been reported at Bareilly district hospital in January alone.

The report further stated that a person died due to rabies in the same period. Officials said the actual number in the entire district is likely to be high.

The data was provided by the Bareilly district hospital after the health department asked the government and private hospitals, including military hospital and community health centres, to provide monthly data on dog, monkey and cat bites, and number of rabies cases.

District epidemiologist Meesam Abbas said, “As the centre has started national rabies control programme, the government is compiling data on dog bites and rabies across the country. The data being sought is very detailed, and once the data bank of such cases is being compiled at the country level, the government will come up with a plan and policy to control rabies. Besides, a few hospitals face a shortage of anti-rabies vaccine as the cases of dog bites are growing. With the compilation of data, the government will be able to know the actual number of vaccines needed and could ensure its supply.”

He added, “Only the district hospital in Bareilly has provided data on rabies to Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) cell in Bareilly for January. We will now educate other hospitals about the importance of the programme.”

Health officials said Virendra (35) who died due to rabies at the district hospital on January 26 was bitten by a stray dog when he was playing with the canine at Hafizganj village under Majhagav block of Bareilly district.

“Angry villagers killed the stray dog, but they did not take Virendra for anti-rabies vaccination. However, after a few months, he stopped drinking water and when his family brought him for treatment, he died due to rabies,” said Abbas.

According to World Health Organisation, rabies is an infectious viral disease that is almost fatal following the onset of clinical symptoms.

Dogs are the main source of human rabies death and the transmission of the virus is spread to people through bites or scratches, usually through saliva.

Experts said fever with pain and unusual tingling are the initial symptoms, but after the virus spreads to nervous system, it causes fatal inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. People with rabies also develop hydrophobia, and a change in behavior is also witnessed.

Title: Nothing wrong in draw of lots for election tie, says court
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Chennai: The Madras high court has dismissed a plea challenging election of candidates to local bodies through draw of lots in case of tie. The procedure is not ultra vires of the Constitution and is permissible under law, the court said.

Dismissing the plea moved by K Devadass, the first bench of chief justice A P Sahi and justice Subramonium Prasad said, “To us, it appears that the legislature was conscious of such situations and, therefore, in order to provide a workable and operational system, and to avoid further uncertainty by prolonging the process through fresh elections , thought it appropriate to provide an additional vote amongst those who had secured equal number of votes by the draw of a lot .”

This wisdom of the legislature is in one way a logical solution by viewing the situation where two candidates have been found to be equally fit by the electorate to represent them as the village head. The voter’s interest being equally divided also amounts to reposing equal confidence in both the candidates. It, therefore, cannot be said one is inferior or superior to the other and, hence, democracy in its republican way is directly reflected through an exercise of franchise, where both the candidates have been selected by an equal strength of voters, the court added.

Title: AMC to introduce microbes to clean 61 nullahas discharging sewage into Yamuna
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Agra: To prevent discharge of 18 million litres per day (MLD) of sewerage from 61 small drains (nullaha) into the Yamuna every day, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration is going to use bioremediation and phytoremediation treatment process. In this regard, a survey has been initiated. The civic body administration has taken up the matter following National Green Tribunal (NGT) strict stand over the issue of waste management in the city.

Bioremediation refers to the use of microbes to clean up contaminated water, soil and sub-surface material. The microbes such as bacteria are introduced to use the contaminants as a source of food and energy and break down the pollutants.

Phytoremediation is a bioremediation process that uses various types of plants to remove, transfer, stabilize, and/or destroy contaminants in the water and soil. The plants are used for removal, degradation, and containment of contaminants in soil, surface waters, and groundwater.

Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “We are working on a plan for remediation of contaminated water of 61 nullahas discharging sewage into the Yamuna, using naturally occurring plants and microbes. The system does not require construction or any major modification of drains or diversion of flow. It takes place in open drains without displacement of sewage. The bioremediation process also does not require any additional land or power, making it a simple and easy system.

“We have called an expert from Delhi to conduct a survey and help us in the process. Soon, a detailed plan will be prepared and sent to higher authorities for approval. Internationally, the technology has been used in several countries,” Prakash added.

Under the bioremediation process, bacteria is cultured in bulk and introduced in flowing sewage. Then, the microbes get activated and multiply—with or without oxygen -- using organic matter present in the sewage as food. Sometimes, enzymes are also added to activate the microbes.

AMC executive engineer (environment) Rajiv Rathi said, “Microbes consume the organic mass of the waste water and utilize the nutrients from sewage for their growth, ultimately enhancing the cleaning action of waste water. The treatment can restore water quality and increases the self-cleansing capacity of the water body. The process also helps reduce biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) in sewage and odour.”

Title: Lakhimpur becomes first tehsil in UP to get certification for eco-management
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bareilly: Lakhimpur has become the first tehsil in Uttar Pradesh to receive ISO:14001 certification for making efforts towards environment management

Lucknow divisional commissioner Mukesh Kumar Meshram awarded the certificate to sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) Arum Kumar Singh in presence of DM Shailandra Singh on Wednesday.

According to officials, Lakhimpur tehsil cleared all norms of eco-management and audit scheme to qualify for the award. The officials observed the successful efforts towards water conservation, water harvesting, electricity savings and eco-friendly work culture in the tehsil.

Lakhimpur tehsil was awarded ISO:9001 certification a year ago, which endorsed its quality management in fulfilling the citizens' charter, effective upkeep of tehsil records and properties, and amenities on the tehsil premises.

While awarding the certificate to the SDM, the Lucknow divisional commissioner lauded the official for his effective action to bring ponds back to life, removing encroachments from existing water pools, and ensuring water harvesting system on the tehsil premises.

“We discouraged the use of plastic and organised several quizzes amongst the locals. Nearly 62 hectares of lost ponds were found and made encroachment free and efforts were made to save paper a well. We tried to create paperless environment to save trees. The consumption of electricity was decreased in the tehsil. The ponds were searched with the help of records prepared in 1951 as many ponds were removed from the latest records as well. We ensured to bring back the ponds in its original form,” Arun Kumar Singh told TOI.

“We have rainfall water harvesting system in tehsil office and every drop of rainwater is harvested by us this last year. Similar efforts will continue in the tehsil to ensure that environment is saved,” he added.

Title: SAD-BJP wants government to withdraw affidavit backing Haryana Sikh body
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

This image has been used for representational purpose only

CHANDIGARH: A SAD-BJP joint delegation met the Punjab governor on Friday urging him to direct the state government to immediately withdraw its affidavit filed in the Supreme Court in support of a separate gurdwara body for Haryana. The affidavit filed by the government claimed that the state assembly of Haryana was competent to enact a law after the Sikh Gurdwara Act, 1925.

The delegation also demanded a judicial inquiry to expose the alleged conspiracy of the Congress government to jeopardize the interest of Sikh community and the apex body for the management of shrines — SGPC.

The joint delegation also urged the governor to direct the Punjab government to immediately register a criminal case against minister Gurpreet Singh Kangar; adviser to CM Kushaldeep Singh Dhillon; and Manjinder Singh Dhillon for allegedly causing death of former Akali sarpanch Surjit Singh. Surjit was a witness in the Behbal Kalan firing incident. The delegation also demanded Kangar and Kushaldeep’s removal.

SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal alleged that Surjit was mentally tortured and humiliated at the behest of the Congress leaders “who wanted to stop him from disposing as a witness” in the case in order to save accused policemen. “Kangar and Dhillon used one way or another to deter Surjit from giving testimony against the culprits by mentally harassing him through the discom officials by imposing heavy penalties, as well as, insulting his family members, including ladies,” Sukhbir alleged, adding these disclosures were made by the wife and son of deceased.

BJP’s Madan Mohan Mittal said not providing protection to a prime witness of an important case proved the malafide of the present Congress government in Punjab.

Title: Tribal development secretary not prepared well for court proceedings: Bombay HC
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The Bombay high court on Friday made critical observations against tribal development secretary Manisha Verma that she was not diligent about the proceedings and did not completely understand implications of her statements in court.

The HC was hearing an eight-year-old public interest litigation filed through advocate Rajendra Raghuwanshi demanding an investigation into a Rs 6,000 crore scam in purchases of certain material by the tribal development department between 2004 and 2009. Following the HC’s intervention, a committee led by former Judge M G Gaikwad was set up to probe the scam, and it recently submitted its report.

The tribal development department, on its part, submitted a series of affidavits on the action taken against erring officials and institutions involved in the procurement of material.

“We need not refer to all faces of the probe, but presently we are concerned with another issue and that is primarily of not disclosing to the court the full details. We do not know why this principal secretary does not realize that if our orders are not read carefully and properly, possibly, she herself may have to lose out on prime postings and may face departmental action. She may have to quit office as well,” Justices S C Dharmadhikari and R I Chagla observed in their 17-page order.

“We do not think that we derive pleasure when we make this observation, but the way she files affidavits in this court leaves a lot to be desired. She must realize that when details are being placed before the court, it is bound to raise queries if the same are incomplete or there are gaps, which may not be a deliberate job. However, when the principal secretary says that out of 104 prosecutions, prosecutions against eight can not be launched as they have expired, whether these persons expired within the three-year period after the report was submitted or during pendency of action. As against the 96 persons, the affidavit does not say that these 96 have been named as accused for causing financial losses,’’ HC observed.

Further, the court observed her affidavit does not inform if 89 of the complaints have been converted into FIRs, how many arrests have been effected till date, how many have secured bail, when the charge sheet was filed and the status of the case, the judges remarked.

“This affidavit should therefore now set an example before all the officers how not to file affidavits with incomplete details. The highest court being misled means enormous blow to the reputation, dignity and prestige so also the status of the state as well,’’ they added. HC is expected to give final orders on the PIL on March 5.

Title: Gujarat: Impasse over LRD reservations persists
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

GANDHINAGAR: The deadlock over protests by members of reserved and non-reserved communities continued on Friday, and the state government was forced to shut most gates of the secretariat, fearing that protesters would pour in. Members of communities in the reserved category and non-reserved category are agitating over an August 2018 government resolution concerning recruitments to government departments.

Women of reserved and non-reserved categories, who took competitive exam for Lok Rakshak Dal (LRD) recruitments, continued their protest in Gandhinagar . The state government is expected to call their representatives on Saturday yet again, as it hopes to end the impasse before US President Donald Trump visits later this month.

Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel said, “We had a long meeting with the CM, senior officers and legal experts.

There will be meetings tomorrow as well. A solution acceptable to all will be arrived at soon.”

Title: Revenue custody death: Three months on, police yet to file FIR
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bareilly: The family members of Brijpal Shakya, who died in revenue custody in Sahaswan tehsil of Buduan district, staged a protest outside the district administration office on Friday, claiming that the police have still not filed an FIR against the sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) and others responsible for Shakya’s death despite an order by the court of Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM).

Shakya, who was lodged in revenue jail for 11 days for his pending power bill of over Rs 80,000, died on October 3 after he allegedly fell ill while in detention. The issue went unnoticed until a few local leaders raised it after watching the video uploaded by Shakya went viral on social media.

Later, district magistrate Dinesh Kumar Singh sought a report from SDM Sanjay Kumar Singh, and suspended naib nazir Madan Mohan, kurk amin Ram Niwas and peon Kanhai Lal, whereas tehsildar Dheerendra Kumar Singh and naib tehsildar Raj Kumar Singh were attached with district headquarters, and were asked to provide a written explanation in three days.

A magisterial inquiry was also ordered in this case which was completed by additional DM Ram Niwas Sharma. However, the report stated that Brijpal died due to the negligence of the lower staff and not because of SDM or tehsildar.

Brijpal’s brother Mahesh Shakya told TOI that the administration is trying to "save the culprits in this case.

“My brother had clearly said in the video that he was insulted and dragged inside the jail and kept without basic facilities like food and water. Even when he fell ill, the officials kept him in unhygienic conditions. He was shifted to a hospital only when he was on the verge of dying. The officials didn’t even share the autopsy report for two months and now they are not even following the court’s order.

When additional superintendent of police (rural) SP Singh contacted, he said, “We are following the court orders.” When asked why FIR has not been filed till now, the officer said, “We are only answerable to the court.”

When TOI contacted DM Budaun Kumar Prashant to inquire about the delay in filing FIR, he said, “The CJM court on January 28 ordered to register an FIR against the SDM, tehsildar and others for the death of Brijpal Shakya. We received the court order on February, and it was forwarded to the police. I am not aware why they have delayed in registering the FIR.”

He added, “The SDM and tehsildar have gone to the higher court to seek a stay against the lower court order. The investigation by our department suggests that Shakya had died because of the negligence of a lower staff who was responsible for maintaining the barracks. Necessary action has already been taken against him.”

Title: ‘Audit report vindicates actions of revenue dept’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The report of Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has vindicated the actions of revenue department till date, the office of revenue minister E Chandrasekharan said in a statement here on Friday.

He said that the audit report has said that in the five districts that have been selected for the examining, it has been found that out of total 23,15,13,770 hectares of surplus land, the revenue department has taken over 21,56,33,358 hectares, which comes to 93%.

Of the 24,967 cases for taking over of surplus land, only 169 cases are left out. These remaining are those which have been declared by the forest department has vested forests, those in which there are court stays and those which are under adverse possession that have been clarified in the audit report itself, the statement said. The statement further said that when these are the facts, a section of the news that have claimed that the revenue department has faced criticism for delay in taking over of surplus land, is ill-motivated.

The audit had chosen Kasargod, Kottayam, Malappuram, Palakkad and Wayanad. While out of 169 cases, 64 are pending with the court, in 40 cases, the land has been declared as vested forest by the forest department, in 32 cases the land is in adverse possession and 15 cases are pending with the survey department. However, the audit report also said that the verification of land tax payment details in respect of land holdings above 15 acres (maximum land that can be held by an individual) furnished by 140 out of the total 534 village offices in the selected five districts also revealed that, in 358 out of 372 cases (94%) no ceiling case was initiated by the Taluk Land Boards and these cases were not reported by the village officials to the state land board or taluk land boards for initiating land ceiling cases.

Title: Duo swap woman’s debit card, withdraw Rs 25,000
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: The Samarth police on Thursday booked two fraudsters after they discreetly replaced a woman’s debit card with an inoperative one on the pretext of assisting her in withdrawing cash at an ATM in Nana Peth on February 5. Later, they withdrew Rs25,000 from the account.

Sadhana Shivle (50) of Shukrawar Peth had visited the ATM to withdraw Rs4,500 from her husband’s pension account. She put her card in the machine and typed the PIN but the transaction failed, an officer from the Samarth police said.

The fraudsters, who were standing behind her, striked a conversation with her. They told her the ATM did not contain currency notes of Rs500. They advised her to withdraw Rs4,000 instead.

The woman then put the card in the ATM, while one of the fraudsters diverted her attention and kept his hand on the card reader and replaced it with an inoperative one. Shivle walked out of the ATM after it did not dispense cash, the police said.

After Shivle reached home she received a text message stating that Rs25,000 had been debited from the account. On February 6, she visited the bank and inquired how much money had been debited. A bank official checked the account details and informed her that the debit card was used to withdraw cash.

The woman in her FIR stated that on checking the debit card Shivle realized that the fraudsters had tricked her by exchanging it with an inoperative one and stole her PIN to withdraw cash.

Assistant inspector Pervez Shikaljar of the Samarth police said, “Shivle filed a complaint application with the cyber crime police station immediately after the incident. The cyber crime police conducted a preliminary inquiry and transferred her application to the Samarth police.”

The woman gave the description of the fraudsters in her complaint. “We will write to the bank to get CCTV camera footage. We are working and certain clues,” he said.

Title: 3-day Orchha fest to promote incredible MP
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Indore: Get a glimpse of Incredible Madhya Pradesh in the three-day tourism festival to be held in Orchha of Niwari district.

Madhya Pradesh State Tourism Board on Friday announced that the cultural extravaganza – Namaste Orchha - will be organised in the historic town from March 6 to 8, 2020.

“State tourism board is hosting the three-day event with help of a private agency, and it will feature diverse activities of music, dance, heritage tours of famous temples forts like Orchha Fort Complex, workshops, local cuisine, arts and handicrafts. And all these activities will be led by experts in their respective field with participants. A special Maha Aarti will also be held on the banks of river Betwa during the event,” said the board’s deputy director (event & marketing) Yuvraj Padole.

He said that renowned vocalist Shubha Mudgal, noted lyricist Swanand Kirkire, singer Shilpa Rao, composer Clinton Cerejo, actor Manoj Bajpayee have also been invited to create engaging experiences for the audiences at the festival.

“Madhya Pradesh is one of the most exciting tourist destinations in the country. And this festival will find a place of pride in the lives of locals,” he added.

He also said that they also have plans to recreate Indore’s famous ‘Sarafa Gali’ at Orchha to give participants local feel of Indore’s famous food street. “A special tour is also being planned for participants which would cover at least 10 prominent tourist locations of state,” he added.

The organizers also said that the state sees three lakh foreign tourists footfall every year and of these, at least one lakh visit Orchha. “This prompted the department to host this festival in Orchha to promote its rich culture, natural and architectural heritage and traditions,” they said.

Orchha is also considered a part of golden triangle tour which covers famous temples of the country with three states Delhi, Agra and Jaipur.

Title: ‘Pitra Dosh hampering Indore’s devpt’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Indore: BJP general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya on Friday said that Indore was suffering from ‘Pitra Dosh’ (ancestors’ curse) which was hampering its development and a large statue of Lord Hanuman would be installed at Pitra Parvat to get rid of the same.

“We had invited some architects to Indore to know how its development can be carried out. They had informed that this city suffered from a curse. Just like people get rid of it, we started construction of Pitreshwar Hanuman Temple, offered prayers to Pitra (ancestors) and planted trees in their memory at Pitra Parvat to get rid of this dosh,” Vijayvargiya said.

The BJP general secretary was addressing a press conference on the starting day of 19-day-long ceremony to install 66-ft high statue of Lord Hanuman.

Vijayvargiya also reacted strongly to Rahul Gandhi’s tweet asking who was benefited the most from Pulwama attack and called him ‘naive’. “There are some subjects on which politics should not be done. Rahul Gandhi is naive. He should have not asked such questions,” Vijayvargiya said.

Talking about statement given by AICC general secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia in Tikamgarh on Thursday that state government should fulfil all promises made to people in its manifesto, Vijayvargiya said that he respected senior Congress leader’s courageous comments.

Reacting to Vijyavargiya’s comment that Indore was facing ‘Pitra Dosh,’ MPCC media cell chief Shobha Oza said, “Kailashji talks about setting the city on fire, then what ‘Pitra Doush’ is he talking about …. It’s beyond my understanding. Indoreans are proud of this city and they will not let wishes of such politicians be fulfilled.”

Title: Punjab: Girls outshine boys in judicial service exam
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

CHANDIGARH/LUDHIANA: Girls outperformed boys in the Punjab Civil Services (judicial branch) examination, results of which were announced on Friday. Out of the 28 selected candidates, 22 are girls. Shivani Garg, from Ludhiana district , is the topper.

Interestingly, three girls who topped in general category, were also among the toppers in Haryana judicial services examination, result of which was declared recently. Among them, Shweta Sharma who was Haryana topper, has come ninth in Punjab; Shivani, who is the Punjab topper, was second rank holder in Haryana; and Harleen, who has secured third position in Punjab, was fourth topper in Haryana.

Of the 13 selected candidates in general category, 12 are girls. Even top five positions in the general category are taken by girl candidates. Similarly, all six posts reserved for SC, SC (dependent of ex-servicemen) and Balmiki/Mazhbi Sikh of Punjab category, have gone to female candidates. Among the nine candidates selected under BC category of Punjab state, five are girls.

Shivani, 24, has scored 603.88 out of 1,050, while Mandeep Kaur, who is seventh, has a score of 544.44 in general category. In BC category, Khushdeep Kaur has 498.21 marks and is ranked third, while Charanpreet Kaur has come ninth with 480.50 score.

Shivani’s father Krishan Lal is a businessman while her mother Luxmi Devi is a homemaker. She has three siblings. She did her BA LLB with distinction from Rajiv Gandhi National Law University, Patiala, and is pursuing LLM from Kurukshetra University.

Mandeep, 27, cracked the exam in her second attempt. Her father Swaranjeet Singh is also a businessman and mother Gurmeet Kaur a homemaker. She has two siblings and has done her BCom from Ramgarhia Girls College and LLB from Punjab University Regional Centre and is doing her LLM from Kurukshetra University. She loves watching cricket.

Title: International conference on migratory species begins today
Content: Ahmedabad: The weeklong Thirteenth Meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Migratory Species (CMS COP13), whose theme is ‘Migratory species connect the planet and we welcome them home’, will begin on Saturday in Gandhinagar.The CMS COP13 is being held from February 15 to 22. On February 15 and 16, pre-COP meetings will take place including the stakeholder dialogue, high-level segment meeting and the ‘Champions Night’ award ceremony. The opening ceremony and plenary session will take place on February 17, which will be addressed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi via video conferencing. This will be followed by side events and working group meetings, till the closing ceremony on February 22.As host, India will be designated President for the next three years. The government of India has been signatory to the Convention on Conservation of Migratory Wild Animals (CMS) since 1983. The government of India has been taking action to protect and conserve migratory marine species. Seven species — including the dugong, whale shark, marine turtles (two species) — have been identified for preparation of conservation plans.The mascot for CMS COP13 is ‘Gibi’, a great Indian bustard (GIB). The GIB is a critically-endangered species which has been accorded the highest protection status under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. The Indian sub-continent is also part of the major bird flyway network, the Central Asian Flyway (CAF), which covers areas between the Arctic and Indian Oceans and has at least 279 populations of 182 migratory water birds, including 29 globally-threatened species.

Title: PWD min: Construction of Alappuzha bypass to be completed by April-end
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Alappuzha: Public works department (PWD) minister G Sudhakaran has said that construction of the long-delayed Alappuzha bypass will be completed by April-end. The minister on Friday visited Kuthirapanthy where a rail over-bridge (ROB) will be constructed as part of the project.

The construction works of the bypass project were stuck at the last leg due to the delay in getting permission from railways to install girders as part of the construction of two ROBs at Malikamukku and Kuthirapanthy.

Meanwhile, a PWD senior official said the decision on collecting toll at Kommady toll plaza will be taken later. tnn

Title: With bugs headed for extinction, will birds starve?
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Ahmedabad: With insects forming an essential part of the diet of most migratory bird species, the alarming drop in insect numbers has raised concerns about bird migrations. A discussion paper in the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals, scheduled to begin from Saturday, has revealed that half of all insect species are declining rapidly, and many are threatened with extinction. The paper states that if there are no changes to the situation, then 40% of species of insects in the world will become extinct in the next few decades.

According to the study, insects are essential food resource for many vertebrate species that feed on them or depend on them for rearing their offspring. The report states that decline in number of insects can equally impact migratory insectivorous species, especially bats and birds. The report stated that some studies also reveal long-term loss in insect biomass on local level, up to a 76% decline in protected areas

The main drivers causing insect decline are habitat change and loss, pollution from synthetic pesticides and fertilizers, invasive species and pathogens, as well as climate change. “Insect biodiversity plays a vital role for functioning ecosystems, especially for insectivorous migratory species such as birds and bats,” says the report.

Most worryingly, these insect population drops are not only among rare species with narrow ecological requirements or restricted habitats, but also among species which were once common and widespread.

The discussion paper calls upon the scientific council is to assess the most important factors causing the insect population decline and evaluate its cascading effects on migratory insectivorous species. Further, the scientific council was also requested to consider the development of guidelines to improve the situation.

To combat insect decline, the draft resolution recommends a series of actions. These include increased scientific research to understand the impact of insect decline on migratory insectivorous animals. Scientists also recommend a precautionary approach with respect to the use of pesticides, especially in habitats important for migratory birds and bats. The report stated that caution has to be taken so that the food base of migratory insectivores is not harmed and action is taken to conserve insects.

Title: Spurt in tiger sightings at Dudhwa Tiger Reserve
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Experts said luck too matters in sighting of tigers but tourists should look forward to enjoying the ecosystem... Read More

BAREILLY: A visit to Dudhwa Tiger Reserve (DTR) this year is proving to be a memorable trip for tourists as there has been a spurt in tiger sightings. Forest officials say at least one batch of tourists manages to spot a tiger every day. DTR boasts of nearly 100 tigers but these shy felines were rarely seen in the past.

Field director, DTR, Sanjay Pathak, told TOI, “Tigers are being sighted almost every day across the reserve either in the morning or evening shifts. The tiger sightings have increased here in comparison to three years ago.”

Giving reasons behind the rise in tiger sightings in DTR, Pathak said, “From December, we start grassland management and a large number of herbivores came out to consume fresh grass. Tigers too followed as they prey on herbivores. The tourists did not spot the big cats on days when it rained last month but as the weather has become clear, tigers are coming out to bask in the sun. Even in summer, herbivores come near water bodies to drink and the big cats lie in wait there to capture them.”

Fazlur Rahman, wildlife photographer who spends much time in the forest and has sighted tigers a few times over the past two months, said, “Better management by Dudhwa authorities and good population of tigers are the reasons why tourists are spotting tigers here.”

According to forest officials, UP governor Anandiben Patel who visited DTR in the first week of this month was able to “catch a glimpse of a tiger”. However, her family members “sighted a big cat”, they said.

In November last year, a few tourists who visited the reserve spotted a tigress along with its five cubs. However, for the protection of tigress and cubs, forest authorities have restricted movement of tourists on routes near its location. A tigress can become very aggressive in order to protect its cubs.

Experts said luck too matters in sighting of tigers but tourists should look forward to enjoying the ecosystem rather than focusing only on tigers. “Tourists should enjoy their visit to the forests and soak in the beauty of nature. They should not come with an aim only to see tigers,” said Pathak.

Leeladhar Sonu, a guide at Dudhwa, said, “It is a good sign that there has been increase in tiger sightings but the big cats are not the only the highlight of Dudhwa. Apart from tigers, tourists can spot rhinos, elephants, migratory birds and five types of deer.”

Forest officials, nearly 40,000 to 50,000 tourists visit DTR every year and they are expecting the same number this time.

Title: After a ‘jhumka’ to Bareilly, Pilibhit set to get a ‘bansuri’ as landmark
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bareilly: Widely known for tiger safari in the country and abroad, Pilibhit set to get a bansuri as a landmark on the lines of newly-installed jhumka in Bareilly to promote the traditional flute industry among thousands of tourists visiting here every year.

Divisional commissioner Ranvir Prasad said, “The project is being considered under the UP government’s ‘One District One Product (ODOP)’ scheme to highlight the signature industry.”

The flute industry in Pilibhit is more than 150 years old and is known for producing handmade best-quality bamboo flutes mainly by Muslim artisans. According to a 1991 estimate, Pilibhit contributed 95% of flutes manufactured in India, and the instruments were in high demand abroad, including the US and European countries. The district is also known for making various types of flutes such as ordinary straight-blown flute, side-blown flute and Musical 1.

Speaking to TOI, Prasad said, “On the lines of Bareilly's jhumka, we are planning to develop a prominent crossing in Pilibhit as ‘Bansuri Chowk’ (Flute Junction) as a landmark. As the embroidery on Bareilly’s jhumka promotes city’s handicraft industry, besides being an attraction for tourists, the bansuri will also play a dual role of providing a landmark to Pilibhit city and promoting its traditional flute industry under the ODOP scheme.”

The Uttar Pradesh government launched the ODOP scheme to encourage locally-made specialised products and crafts. The scheme aims at promoting traditional industries synonymous with their respective districts to spur the local economy and create employment.

Taking about the bansuri project, Prasad said, “A survey will be conducted and based on which a prominent place will be finalised and developed as Bansuri Chowk. The modalities are yet to be finalised.”

Prasad said artisans in Pilibhit import bamboos from Assam to craft flutes. “But, plans are afoot to promote bamboo farming in Bareilly and Pilibhit districts. Forest department will also be engaged and we will see if the bamboo species currently being imported from Assam can be cultivated here.”

Meanwhile, Prasad on Wednesday visited Pilibhit, where he tried his hand at the ongoing wall painting, a drive launched by the Public Works Department (PWD), near Tanakpur highway.

Prasad said, “Recently, a drive under UP governments’ Paint My City scheme was launched in the district under which walls of most of the government buildings and offices are being painted with the images of bansuri. The campaign is aimed at making people aware of the rich cultural heritage of the city.”

Title: Lulu group eyes bigger play in Hyderabad, India
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: The $8.2 billion UAE-based Lulu Group International is eyeing a bigger play in the Indian retail and hospitality markets, with large-format malls and hotel projects in the pipeline in Hyderabad and other cities, a top official of the group told TOI here.

While it is planning to pump in Rs 1,500-2,000 crore for Lulu mall projects in Hyderabad, Lucknow and Bengaluru, it has lined up a Rs 2500 crore for setting up hotel projects in cities like Bengaluru where it has two upcoming properties, Adeeb Ahamed, managing director, Tablez and Twenty14 Holdings, said here on Friday.

“We have malls spread over nearly 1 million sq ft coming up in Hyderabad, Lucknow and Bengaluru. We already have two projects under development in Bengaluru, even as we are evaluating other retail and hospitality projects in India,” he explained.

The Lulu group will also be investing Rs 350 crore in India by 2021 end through its organised retail venture Tablez, which brings global brands to India, by setting up multiple outlets across eight brands across the country, said Ahamed, who was in town to announce American ice-cream brand Cold Stone Creamery’s foray into Hyderabad with two stores.

Tablez is the master franchisee for international brands like Springfield, Women’s Secret, ToysRUs, BabiesRUs, Build-A-Bear, GO Sport, YOYOSO and Cold Stone Creamery.

“By 2020 end, we hope to be a Rs 250 crore turnover company (Tablez) with 85 stores across the country as against the existing 61 outlets cutting across brands. In the next 12-24 months, we expect to bring all the brands in our retail portfolio into the Hyderabad market. We will start with expanding our Cold Stone chain here.” he said.

Title: NMC deploys trash skimmer to clean Godavari
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has deployed a trash skimmer machine to clean Godavari river. The machinery has been procured under the smart city project.

The one-year contract that was signed with the existing contractor is expiring on Feb 29 and the civic administration has decided not to renew the contract. Instead, they have decided to have a different approach to clean the river.

“We have now started mechanical cleaning of Godavari. A new trash skimmer machine has been procured for the purpose under the smart city project,” an NMC official said.

The official said that prior to this, the municipal corporation would manually clean the river and had appointed a private contractor for the same. “We would clean the river manually through contractor who was assigned with the task of removing water hyacinth, filth and other waste from the river. But the one- year term of the contractor is ending on February 29. We are not going to continue him after the contract ends,” the official added.

The cost of the machine is Rs 2.61 crore, including operation and maintenance for a period of 5.5 years.

Earlier, the municipal corporation would pay Rs 75 lakh per year to the contractor for manual cleaning of the river through boats.

Besides, there were some limitations to cleaning the river manually. However, using trash skimmer machine for cleaning will ensure faster and better results. The machine will operate in an eight hour shift from 9am to 5pm.

Apart from the trash skimmer machine, the municipal corporation has procured a robot machine which will be used to clean three tributaries of the Godavari — Nandini, Waldevi and Waghadi — in the city, said NMC officials.

“We are planning to buy two more robot machines to clean the Godavari and other three tributaries. We will put forth a proposal in the NMC budget for the next financial year 2020-21, they said.

The civic body is not planning to clean city roads by using sweeping machines. The civic administration has decided to make the necessary financial provision in the budget.

Title: Eight booked for duping two goldsmiths of Rs 22 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Faraskhana police have registered offences against eight gold jewellery craftsmen for fleeing to their native place in West Bengal along with 600gm of gold bars collectively worth Rs22lakh.

Two goldsmiths from Peth areas have lodged separate FIRs with the Faraskhana police. The police have registered offence against the eight men under section 406 (criminal breach of trust) of the Indian Penal Code.

Y P Suryavanshi, sub-inspector, Faraskhana police, told TOI that Allahrakhha Shaikh, a 46-year-old goldsmith who also hails from West Bengal, had appointed four men for making gold ornaments at his shop in Raviwar Peth. The men had been working with him since March last year. “In December last year, he gave them 300gm of gold worth Rs11lakh and made proper agreements with the suspects. He even took post-dated cheques of the value of the gold from them as a precautionary measure,” he said.

Suryavanshi said that on December 31 last year, the suspects fled from the city along with the gold bars. “As the complainant Shaikh knew their native village, he went there to check but did not find them. He requested their family members to tell the suspects to return the gold and even informed the local panchayat there,” Suryavanshi said, adding, “When Shaikh did not get his gold back, he returned to Pune and lodged an FIR.”

The sub-inspector said that the probe revealed that the suspects have also duped some more goldsmiths.

Suryavanshi said on Wednesday that one more goldsmith, Dinesh Pavatekar, lodged an FIR stating that four gold jewellery craftsmen he had appointed fled with 300gm of gold bars worth Rs11 lakh. “Investigations revealed that the suspects were debt ridden and fled to West Bengal. Our probe is on,” Suryvanshi said.

Title: Mayor opens second smart health centre
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Agra: Developed with an investment of Rs 75 lakh, the second smart city health centre commenced functioning at the old Women Hospital of Agra Municipal Corporation in Chatta locality here on Friday. The clinic, developed under the smart city project, will be a model centre for treating tuberculosis.

After inaugurating the health centre, Mayor Naveen Jain said, “Due to mismanagement, the civic body medical centres were non-operational for the past several years. Now, under the smart city project, clinics equipped with advanced machines are being set up. Two centres have been made operational. Soon, eight more centres will start serving citizens in different parts of the city.”

He added, “At all the eight smart health clinics, we will be providing medicines and diagnostic facilities at concessional rates up to 70%. Experienced doctors will be appointed at all the centres. Initially, the centres will operate from 10 am to 6 pm,” he said.

Apart from the low cost diagnosis, citizens will be able to consult a doctor (general physician) at the health centre by paying a nominal fee of Rs 50.

Besides the smart health clinics outside the AMC head office and Chatta locality, two other centres proposed to be made operational are located at Hanuman temple crossing in Khandari and Central Park in Awas Vikas locality. The remaining centres are proposed to be set up in Arjun Nagar, Fatehabad road, Trans-Yamuna, Kamla Nagar, Soron Katra and Freeganj

Title: Hardikar urges civic employees to lodge complaints if harassed or assaulted
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar on Friday urged civic employees to not shy away from lodging police complaints even against office-bearers and corporators in case of harassment or assault by such individuals.

Hardikar made this request while responding to a question about steps being taken to avoid recurrence of the recent incident when BJP corporator Asha Shedge and local residents locked up senior civic officials of water supply department on February 1.

The civic body had started alternate day water supply from November 25 to ensure equitable supply at good pressure, which failed to address complaints of poor supply. “We will lodge police complaints if civic officials and employees face harassment or are assaulted in their offices. But if such incident occurs outside, the individual must lodge a police complaint. I will firmly support such affected civic official and employee,” Hardikar said.

He said public outbursts could be prevented by taking timely action regarding complaints.

Title: Rampur court directs SP to provide adequate security to Khasbagh palace
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Rampur: District and sessions Judge Alka Srivastava on Wednesday directed the Rampur superintendent of police to provide adequate security to Khasbagh palace.

Directing SP Santosh Kumar Mishra to provide adequate police force for the security of the palace, said advocate Saurabh Saxena, the court ordered that all expenses incurred by the police force deployed at the palace would be borne by the family members of the erstwhile Rampur Nawab, who are parties in the case.

Eight months after the Supreme Court ordered distribution of Nawab’s property among his heirs, local administration and court-appointed commissioners are busy evaluating the assets.

Saxena said, “Following the SC’s directions, the evaluation of moveable and immovable properties is going on. In the presence of the family members and administrative officials, the armoury was opened for the counting of weapons. However, the strong room of the palace will be opened on February 26. Thus, the court directed the deployment of police force for the security of the property at Khasbagh.”

Khasbagh is under the possession of Muhammad Ali Khan, alias, Murad Mian, and his elder sister Naght Abedi, both children of the late Nawab Murtuza Ali Khan.

Title: Rs50k cr & counting, activist claims excess billing scam
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nagpur: Consumer activist Pratap Hogade has alleged over Rs50,000 crore excess billing scam in Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Ltd (MSEDCL). He has urged Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC) to take into account this fact while deciding the power tariff hike petition of the discom.

TOI has been repeatedly highlighting jugglery of figures by MSEDCL for the last 10 years. According to Hogade, the jugglery is done by the discom to cover up its failure in curbing power theft.

Hogade of Maharashtra Veej Grahak Sangathana (MVGS) told TOI that about 10 years ago when MERC started pulling up MSEDCL officials for failing to reduce distribution losses, they started inflating the consumption of unmetered farm pumps to artificially reduce losses. “It had a double benefit for MSEDCL as it also got more subsidy from the state government. Not stopping at this, the officials started issuing inflated bills to metered agricultural consumers,” he claimed.

When Chandrashekhar Bawankule of BJP became energy minister, he set up a three-member committee in 2015 to probe complaints of excess billing. He told the media several times that MSEDCL was issuing inflated bills to farmers. The committee was headed by MSEB Holding Company director Vishwas Pathak and Hogade was one of the members. The committee had asked IIT Bombay to conduct a field study to find out the actual farm pump power consumption in the state. The figures were so damning that Pathak refused to sign the final report in July 2017. The report has been gathering dust since then.

As pressure mounted on MERC to do something about excess billing, it set up a working group to investigate the scam. The group submitted its report to the commission in January 2020.

Hogade pointed out that as per MSEDCL’s claim, power consumption of low tension (LT) farm pumps in 2018-19 was 33,853 million units (MU). However, according to the working group report it was only 22,859 MU (67.5% of MSEDCL figure). Hogade feels the actual consumption is 50% of the discom’s figure.

“MVGS has arrived at this figure on the basis of a simple calculation. According to MSEDCL’s own data, the consumption of high tension (HT) agricultural pumps, which get water from lift irrigation schemes (LIS), is 117 units per HP per month. These pumps operate for 16 hours a day for 300 days a year. On the other hand, LT pumps in dryland areas of the state operate for nine hours a day at the most for 200 days a year. However, MSEDCL claims that their consumption is 113 units per HP per month, which is impossible. If the LT consumption is calculated on the basis of HT consumption, then it is 44 units per HP per month. Liberally, it may be 50 units, which is even less than 50% of the MSEDCL’s figure,” said Hogade.

The activist said that he has further proof of MSEDCL’s jugglery. “The discom had held farm pump bill correction camps all over the state. I have obtained data of 3,281 consumers under Right to Information (RTI) Act. Their bill, including arrears, before correction was Rs4.85 crore. After correction, it was reduced to Rs2.31 crore, which is 47% of the original figure,” he added.

According to Hogade, MSEDCL claimed that its distribution loss in 2018-19 was 14.7%. “If the actual farm pump consumption is taken into account, then the figure is 28.5%, which is 13.8% more. According to MSEDCL, 1% distribution loss leads to loss of Rs700 crore. So it is clear that the discom committed a scam of Rs9,660 crore in 2018-19 alone. If the figures of last 10 years are taken into account, then the scam is far above of Rs50,000 crore,” he said. Distribution loss is mainly due to power theft.

This jugglery is going on with orders from the top, suspects Hogade. In November 2011, executive engineer of Akola (Rural) division had written a letter to assistant engineer of Telhara sub-division rebuking him for calculating agricultural pump consumption on lower side.

INFOGX

manipulating figures

* MERC’s working group found that actual farm pump power consumption was only 67.5% of MSEDCL figure

* Activist Pratap Hogade has calculated the figure to be 50% at the most

* MSEDCL inflates farm pump to artificially reduce distribution loss, as it has failed to curb power theft

* It also gets extra subsidy from state government by inflating consumption

* MSEB Holding Company director had refused to sign enquiry report that exposed MSEDCL’s jugglery

* The report is gathering dust in the company office since 2017

Title: Gorewada set to host African lion, cheetah in days to come
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nagpur: With work on Indian Safari nearing completion in Phase I, the Central Zoo Authority (CZA), a statutory body under the MoEFCC monitoring all zoos in the country, has approved designs for an African Safari at Gorewada International Zoo.

In a letter to the Forest Development Corporation of Maharashtra (FDCM) on February 3, CZA member-secretary SP Yadav has said that detail drawings of African Safari have been approved. It will have 26 species including lion, wild dog, cheetah, chimpanzee, colobus monkey, hippopotamus, red river hog, spotted hyena, naked mole rat, puff adder, vervet monkey, Barbary sheep, rock hyrax, banded mongoose, klipspringer and others.

The FDCM had submitted the drawings and designs on December 6, 2019. The proposal was placed before the expert group on zoo designing of the CZA on January 23-24, 2020.

Talking to TOI, PCCF & FDCM managing director N Rambabu confirmed the development. “CZA has approved the drawings and designs of the Phase II project paving way for physical structures for the enclosures. However, we will start work on African Safari only after commissioning Indian Safari.”

The African Safari will be set up in the backyard of Indian Safari. “With grasslands all around, the site of proposed African Safari is ideally located,” said divisional manager Nandkishore Kale.

Indian Safari is being constructed in 115 hectares excluding buffer area and includes leopard, tiger, sloth bear and composite herbivore safaris. It is in the final stages and FDCM expects to throw it open by March 31.

The African Safari will be constructed in 63 hectares (excluding buffer area) by the joint venture company (JVC) FDCM-Essel World Gorewada Zoo Private Limited.

In the Rs451-crore project cost, the state government has announced a viability gap funding (VGF) of Rs200 crore while the remaining amount has to be invested by the JVC partner Essel World.

The African safari will display biodiversity and species of African origin which will be seen from specially designed vehicles like trams, buses etc.

The components of African Safari include lion, herbivores, bird park (aviary), tribal and walking trails and night safari. This will be the first night safari in India based on the lines of Singapore night safari.

The bird aviary will house variety of local and exotic species making it a memorable trip for the visitors. Walk-in aviary will be the major attraction.

The Phase II project will also include deep time trail. Tribal village will be developed to showcase the life of local Gond and Madia tribes in the region through vernacular architecture of their houses and shelters, display of a few live activities such as their traditional dancing and music, arts, crafts, weapons, tools, clothing and musical instruments etc

Another attraction will be trail of senses where nature ought to be smelled, heard, touched, tasted and seen. Trail of senses will stimulate one’s sensory responses to the environment. There will be explanatory signs explaining these five senses, as also, depicting general information about the healing herbs and local wildlife.

WHAT THE CZA SAID

* Design of enclosure must be according to animal collection plan

* Availability of animals within Indian zoos and foreign zoos must be ensured

* Arrangement of proper circulation of water in wet moat should be made

* Care should be taken while using optimum space required

Title: School students among 30 injured in 2 road accidents
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

School students among 30 injured in 2 road accidents

Times News Network

Agra: At least 34 people, including students of a private school, were injured in two different road accidents on Yamuna Expressway and state highway in Mathura and Agra districts.

The first accident occurred at 5:19 am near milestone 105 of Yamunapar police jurisdiction in Mathura district, when a speeding mini-truck returning to Ghosali village of Bah in Agra district with the mortal remains of a woman hit the divider.

Pramod Kumar, station house officer of Yamunapar, said, “Prima facie, the driver of the truck fell asleep on the wheel and lost control of the vehicle. In the accident, 27 people were injured. After the accident, rescue team of Yamuna Expressway shifted the victims to the district hospital.”

Surender, one of the injured victims, said, “A woman relative had succumbed during childbirth in a hospital in Delhi and we were returning to our village with her mortal remains when the truck hit the divider.”

Meanwhile, in Agra district, a school van rammed into a mini truck from behind on the state highway, injuring seven, including students and teachers.

The accident occurred around 7:30 am near Bajitpur village of Dauki police jurisdiction.

Abhishek Kulshetra, an eyewitness, said, “The truck was taking a turn when the speeding school van hit it from behind. All the occupants of the van suffered minor injuries.”

Title: Rampur court gives bail to 26 anti-CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

RAMPUR: A court in Rampur has given bail to 26 anti-CAA protesters on Thursday. Hearing their bail pleas, court of district and sessions judge Alka Srivastava directed the protesters, who were arrested for their alleged involvement in the anti-CAA violence in Rampur on December 21, to furnish two bail bonds of Rs 1 lakh each.

Defence counsel Muhammad Rehman Ali, who appeared before the court, said, “The court had granted bail to 26 anti-CAA protesters and directed them not to tamper with any evidence and not influence witnesses. While granting bail, the court had also directed them to appear before the court whenever required.”

According to prosecution, the FIR complainant, Manoj Kumar (station officer of Bhot police station) had alleged that a mob of 300 to 400 people started gathering at Bareilly gate, raising slogans against the police and the Centre. They then allegedly fired on to the police deployed in the area and had been involved in arson and violence which resulted in “injury of cops on duty”.

The Ganj Kotwali police had arrested the anti-CAA protesters and sent them to jail under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapons), 149 (unlawful assembly), 307 (attempt to murder), 333 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant), 353 (assault or criminal force) and sections 3 and 4 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984. Section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act (CLAA) was also invoked against the protesters.

Later, Amar Singh, the investigating officer of the case, had produced an application before the court in which he had stated that “no offence with charge of attempt to murder could be made out against 26 of the jailed protesters”.

Earlier, the court had granted bail to 15 protesters who were sent to jail after they were allegedly involved in the violence which erupted during anti-CAA protests at Hatikhana square in which one of the alleged protesters Faiz Khan was “shot dead”.

A magisterial probe had been ordered by Rampur district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh into the death of the 27-year-old Faiz Khan. Singh said that the probe was still on in the matter and “the appointed magistrate is out of town at the moment”.

The Rampur administration had also issued recovery notices to 28 alleged anti-CAA protesters after damages of nearly Rs 25 lakh was reportedly assessed by the police and the administration across the district.

Title: No invite yet for Anna for Kejriwal’s swearing-in ceremony
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: Social crusader Anna Hazare has not received an invitation for the oath-taking ceremony of Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday.

During his first tenure, Kejriwal had invited Anna for the swearing-in ceremony but Hazare, while offering his wishes, declined to attend citing health issues. “Even after this, Kejriwal called him, but Anna refused to answer his phone calls,” a close associate revealed.

He said no invitation has been received this time. When TOI tried to reach Kejriwal, his secretary said the chief minister is not speaking to any mediaperson.

On Tuesday, Hazare merely smiled and refused any comment after learning about Kejriwal’s landslide win in the Delhi assembly polls on February 11 and his oath-taking ceremony on Sunday.

“Anna has categorically stated that he will not comment on Kejriwal returning to office,” his secretary Sanjay Pathade told TOI on Friday. The Gandhian is observing ‘maun’ (complete silence) since December 20 to protest against the inordinate delay in executing the convicts in the Nirbhaya case and will break it only after they are hanged. “He writes his response on a piece of paper when he wishes to comment,” Pathade said.

Pathade had informed Hazare about Kejriwal’s win. “Anna wrote on a piece of paper asking for the party-wise break up. I told him that AAP has won 62 seats and the BJP 8. He smiled and wrote “Theek aahe” (okay). I told him the media wanted his reaction but he said he will not comment,” Pathade said.

However, residents of Hazare’s native village Ralegan Siddhi burst crackers to celebrate Kejriwal’s win on Tuesday. It was not too long ago that the villagers were upset with Kejriwal and BJP functionary Kiran Bedi for “deserting” Hazare and choosing to join politics much against his wishes. There was a feeling that they had used Hazare’s Lokpal movement in 2011 to come into the limelight and later ditched him.

But former associates said it was Hazare who had gained from the presence of Kejriwal and Bedi in his core committee. “They (Bedi, Kejriwal) have a clean image. They were good negotiators and useful while dealing with government officials. They added weight to the core team as they knew when to go back a couple of steps for long-term gains,” a former associate said. In their absence, Hazare has become too rigid and will have only limited success and support, they added.

Ralegan Siddhi villagers are happy with Kejriwal’s success. “We consider him one of us because he is a product of Anna’s anti-corruption and Lokpal movement. He was a regular visitor to our village,” a villager who was part of the celebrations said.

Hazare’s associates in the village said that though he has not “forgiven” Kejriwal, he does have a soft corner for him. “There is some softening of the heart. He says Kejriwal is better when compared with other politicians,” a close Hazare aide said.

He said Hazare still feels that Kejriwal cheated the “anti-corruption movement” by joining politics. “Anna wanted to create a permanent pressure group that will launch agitations on important issues. He thought that such a group can make any government take pro-people decisions. When the V K Shunglu commission report indicted the Kejriwal government in 2017 for bypassing the law, nepotism and financial irregularities, Anna was very upset,” he said.

During a previous interview with TOI, Hazare had said that he did not feel he was being used when member after member of Team Anna joined politics. “We live in a democracy. How can I pressure them into doing something? What matters to me most is the support of the common people,” he had said.

But the experience made him wiser, Hazare had said. “I have received over one lakh applications from people who wish to join me. Now, I insist on an undertaking stating that the individual will not use my name or photo for personal gain and he/she will not have connection with any political party,” he had said.

Title: Prakash Javadekar blames Congress for BJP’s loss in Delhi polls
Content:
Prakash Javadekar (PTI)

PUNE: Union minister Prakash Javadekar on Friday blamed the “sudden disappearance” of the Congress for the BJP’s defeat in the Delhi assembly polls.]He said it led to a direct fight between his party and the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP). He was speaking to the media on the sidelines of a District Development Coordination and Monitoring Committee meeting in the city on Friday.The Arvind Kejriwal-led AAP swept the polls by winning 62 of the 70 seats. The BJP won eight seats but the Congress did not win a single one.“Ours is a party that keeps learning. We learn from our victories and defeats. So an analysis of the defeat will be done,” Javadekar said.He blamed the BJP’s defeat on the Congress. “It is a different matter whether the Congress disappeared on its own or people made it disappear or whether their votes got transferred to AAP,” Javadekar said.“Because of the Congress’s disappearance, there was a direct fight between the BJP and AAP. We had expected 42% votes and 48% for AAP, but we got 39% votes while the AAP received 51% votes,” he said.He denied calling Kejriwal a “terrorist”. Earlier this month, Javadekar had said that Kejriwal had called himself an “anarchist” and there is not much of a “difference between an anarchist and a terrorist”.Union home minister Amit Shah on Thursday had said hate speeches like ‘goli maro’ and ‘Indo-Pak match’ made by some BJP leaders during the campaigning may have resulted in the party’s defeat. Javadekar said Shah’s observations are important, but there are other reasons for the defeat and a review will be done.

Title: Karvy fails to keep another payment date with investors
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

(Representative image)

HYDERABAD: With the second week of February drawing to a close, Karvy Stock Broking Ltd (KSBL) has missed yet another self-declared deadline for clearing its client payouts, leaving many of its investors in the lurch.

The beleaguered Karvy Group has now written to investors seeking time till February end to clear its dues. But most of them are not hopeful of seeing their money.

“We had earlier communicated to you that we will be affecting payment on or before February 15, 2020, based on the premise that the funding would be arranged by virtue of sale of our shareholding in one of our subsidiary companies. We would like to apprise you that we are in the final stages of raising the required sources, and unfortunately, though most details have been finalised, the remittances of the funds are taking time. We are confident that we will be in a position to affect payment of the amounts above on or before February 25, 2020,” said a communication by Karvy to investors.

When contacted, a Karvy group spokesperson confirmed that the company has sought time till the end of February to settle its payments to clients.

But what is even more frustrating for investors from smaller towns is that they have been ditched by their local Karvy agents, many of whom have quit because of non-payment of salaries.

“I am awaiting a payout of Rs 1.76 lakh, whereas my son is waiting for Rs 4.19 lakh. We are worried about our money as their local staff too has quit the company. We don’t know whom to reach out to and have no other option but to wait,” said Rakesh Verma, an investor from Raniganj in West Bengal. The father-son duo has been Karvy’s client for over 2.5 years.

Gautam Umaraliya, an investor from Bhavnagar in Gujarat, said he is not surprised about Karvy breaching its promise of clearing dues for the fourth time . “What surprises me is that such a big scam has broken out and market regulator Sebi is silent. This sends out a wrong signal as it will embolden other corrupt brokerages. Whether I will get back my money or not, I do not know, but one thing I know is that even if I get it back, I will be very cautious about investing in stock markets again,” he said. Since the Karvy scam broke out, his shares worth Rs 7 lakh have been out of bounds for Umaraliya.

While many are awaiting payments from Karvy, there are some investors who said they have received partial or token pay-outs in the last two weeks and are hopeful of receiving the residual sum in the coming days.

Title: CR approves revised DPR for new track between Pune and Nashik
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nashik: The Central Railway (CR) has approved the revised detailed project report (DPR) for Pune- Nashik semi-high speed new track that will complete the journey between Pune and Nashik in just 90 minutes, but with a condition that state government should provide land for the entire project.

“The in-principle approval for revised Final Traffic and Financial Report presented in October 2019 for the new railway line between Pune and Nashik has been accorded by the CR general manager with certain observations,” Sanjay Kumar Jain, Chief Traffic Planning Manager (CR) said in letter sent to the executive director (works) of the Railway Board in New Delhi.

“As per guidelines the state government should provide the land free of cost for the tracks, but in the DPR the government has said it would share 20% of the entire cost. This needs further clarification,” the CR has said.

According to the revised DPR, the semi-high speed train with six passenger cars carrying 450 people is expected to complete the journey in 90 minutes. The CR, according to the DPR, plans to put six such rakes making 48 trips in both directions per day.

The CR has said with this only 7,200 passengers would be transported daily against the expected 21,600. “Hence, more planning of rakes has to be carried out to make the project viable,” it added.

The CR has also figured out that new freight terminals are also required to be constructed as the existing ones are either inaccessible or are insufficient to realise the movement of goods.

“The in-principle approval will definitely go a long way in ensuring the train service between Pune- Nashik begins at the earliest,” Member of Parliament (Nashik) Hemant Godse said.
