Title: 2nd leopard trapped in Baramati
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: A seven-year-old female leopard was trapped in a cage at Kanhere village in Baramati taluka early on Thursday morning.

This was the second leopard trapped in this village in the past fortnight.

Forest department officials said they were looking into whether there were other leopards hiding in the surrounding areas.

“Around 4.30am, forest department officials received a mobile phone alert from the cameras installed nearby that the leopard was trapped in the field belonging to farmer Santosh Jadhav,” Trimbak Jarad, round officer, said.

A four-member rescue team and eight forest department officials reached the spot immediately. The leopard was shifted to the animal rescue centre at Bhugaon, near Pune.

“The Nira left bank canal passes through the village and there is abundant water available for irrigation. So sugar cane is grown on a large scale here, providing good hiding place for leopards,” Jarad explained.

“A cage was installed in Jadhav’s field three days ago. The leopard prowled around the cage on Wednesday and was trapped in it on Thursday morning,” Jarad said.

He said the forest department has compensated villagers in eight cases. “We will soon give compensation in the remaining cases too,” Jarad said.

Title: Lush green lawns replace garbage heap at Khajod
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

The Khajod SDB site at present has no resemblance to its ‘dirty’ past as the SMC’s dumpyard a year ago (below)

Surat: The toxic solid waste landfill site of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) near the Surat Diamond Bourse (SDB) at Khajod has now transformed into lush green lawns spread over 30 hectare land.

SDB is coming up on 35 acres land at the Diamond Mercantile and Research (DREAM) city at Khajod at the cost of Rs 2,500 crore.

The civic body on Friday officially closed down the landfill site spread in total 60 hectare by disposing off around 25 lakh tonne solid waste that had accumulated there over the years. As such the SMC had stopped dumping solid wastes at the site in 2014 following order of the National Green Tribunal (NGT), but the site was open as the waste need to be dispose of scientifically.

According to SMC estimates, Surat city generates 1,800 tonne of solid waste every day.

“We started capping solid waste at the site one and a half years ago and followed all the solid waste management rules. We also adopted all the prescribed guidelines in managing the waste. Out of the 60 hectare land at the site, we have fully reclaimed 30 hectare and this open space is now transformed into lush green lawns,’’ said a senior SMC official.

The official further said that Rs 60 crore was spent in disposing off the solid waste scientifically.

“The open space now adds value to the area where the SDB, the second diamond bourse after the Bharat Diamond Bourse (SDB) in Mumbai, is coming up,” an SMC official added.

The construction work for the SDB started in October 2017 and it is likely to be completed by the end of 2020.

The diamond bourse will have 66 lakh sq ft built up area with nine iconic towers housing 4,000 offices of the diamantaires.

Title: Minister inaugurates new mfg facility
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Tirupati: Minister for industries and information technology Mekapati Goutham Reddy inaugurated a state-of-the-art manufacturing facility of Toray Industries, India at Sri City integrated business city, near Satyavedu in Chittoor district on Friday.

The manufacturing facility built on an 85-acre plot with an initial investment of nearly Rs 1,000 crores, has two manufacturing plants, including a polypropylene (PP) spun bond plant and an engineering plastics resin compounding plant. The PP spun bond plant that produces meditech technical textile material will start commercial production by March 2020 with an annual production capacity of 18,000 million tonnes.

After inaugurating the manufacturing facility, the minister announced that the new industrial policy of the statewill be unveiled shortly and expressed confidence that Andhra Pradesh will emerge as the most preferred investment destination in the country.

“The new industrial policy will be one of the best industrial policies in the country aimed at promoting manufacturing,” said the minister.

Title: Plea to speed up work on Masi Streets
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Madurai: Irked by the slow progress in the Smart City work taken up in all four Masi Streets, a large number of traders staged a road blockade, urging the Madurai Corporation to complete the work at the earliest.

More than 200 traders gathered at the Murugan Temple in West Masi Street, one of the busiest commercial places in the city, and staged the protest . The protesters wore masks highlighting the dust pollution, that is one of the major issues they face due to the ongoing work.

As the vehicular movement in the street came to a standstill, police personnel held talks with them urging them to withdraw the protest. As the traders were reluctant, around 80 of them were arrested and shifted to a hall. They were released later.

S Selvapandi, secretary of Federation of Madurai Manufacturers and Traders Association, said they have been running from pillar to post, seeking clarification like date of completion, whether there will be space left for parking two-wheeler after completion, contact details of contractor and corporation engineers, but they did not get any satisfactory reply so far.

“It has been three months since pits were dug up on the roadsides of all Masi Streets. We have been undergoing all sorts of problems. We face difficulty in shifting materials to shops, dust issues and slashed sale and parking space. While trade has already been affected after the implementation of GST, smart city work has come as a double blow,” Selvapandi said. The traders said that while they welcome the project for the overall development of the city, however, work should be expedited by deploying more workers. They also said that night time could be utilized more efficiently to complete work. TNN

Title: Protective mesh on the cards on bridges over water bodies
Content:
The PMC’s proposal also stated that the protective mesh was also required to prevent people from jumping off t... Read More

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) plans to start work on installing protective mesh on bridges over rivers, canal and nullahs in the next fiscal to curb garbage dumping in the water bodies.The plan comes even as the mesh installed along the Mutha canal in the Janata Vasahat and Hadapsar areas has given way due to the lack of maintenance. “The civic authorities need to pay more attention towards maintenance of mesh and protective wall of the canal,” Nitin Kadam, activist from the Parvati area, said, while adding that dumping of waste was the prime reason behind flooding due to Ambil Odha and smaller nullahs in the area last monsoon.The city has more than 15 major bridges on two rivers — Mula and Mutha — none of which presently have protective mesh. Besides, about 10 smaller bridges on canal and nullahs are also located at various spots. “The civic body has set aside Rs 2 crore for the project, which is expected to be taken up in the next financial year,” a civic official said.The PMC’s proposal also stated that the protective mesh was also required to prevent people from jumping off these structures in their bid to commit suicide. Even the state irrigation department has urged the PMC to curb garbage dumping into the water bodies by installing protective mesh.“We are yet to finalize the plan for installing the protective mesh. We will hold discussions with experts on how to go about it to effectively curb river pollution,” a senior civic official said.Residents, however, said the civic body should first install dustbins along the rivers, besides increasing vigil. “ PMC should not only concentrate on preventing garbage dumping from the bridges, but also ensure on their maintenance, taking other steps like installing proper dustbins along the water bodies and bridges,” Vishwas Joshi, from Shaniwar Peth, said.Sanjay Kadam, a resident of Shivajinagar, said while installing protective mesh, the civic administration should also ensure that bridges and aesthetic are not affected. “The PMC should install display boards along the rivers explaining legal action and fines against garbage dumping. This will act as deterrent,” he added.

Title: Display of vehicles at rail stations
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Margao: To improve its asset productivity, Konkan Railway has started displaying showroom vehicles at its railway station premises from Friday. This concept has been framed to kickstart generation of non-fare revenue for Konkan Railway and provide an opportunity to various companies/dealers for promoting their products, thus creating a win-win situation for both, an official said.

“Konkan Railway welcomes companies/firms who wish to display and promote their products at the Margao railway station,” the official said.

Title: Starting today, pay if you want to park on 9 arterial roads in Panaji
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: After multiple delays, parking will be chargeable for two- and four-wheelers on nine stretches in the state capital beginning Saturday. The Rs 1.6 crore pay-parking contract between the Corporation of the City of Panaji and the contractor was signed on Thursday and will be valid for three years.

Special discounted passes will be issued at the mezzanine floor of the Kwality Walls building on M G Road from Monday for motorists who regularly use the areas notified for pay-parking.

“We are in the process of developing an app where citizens won’t have to visit the office for the passes to be issued. This will be ready in the next few months,” contractor Sohan Juwarker said.

The workers engaged to issue electronically generated receipts have also been trained to be polite and to treat customers well. The receipts they issue will contain the date, time and registration number of the vehicle concerned.

Pay-parking signage displaying rates per hour have already been put up around the city, including on 18th June Road, around the Church Square, around Garcia de Orta, around the old secretariat and in the Campal residential area.

Once charged, parking fees will be considered valid for any other parking location within CCP for that time slot for the vehicle concerned. Government vehicles will be exempted from pay-parking in the state capital.

CCP’s last pay-parking contract ended on April 30, 2017, and neither brought in the required revenue for the cash-strapped corporation nor helped ease traffic congestion in the city. Mayor Uday Madkaikar said all this is set to change.

“Pay-parking will reduce congestion. This time around, CCP is also secured as the contractor has deposited a Rs 96 lakh bank guarantee for three years along with a 10 per cent security deposit. He has also given us 36 postdated checks of Rs 4.5 lakh each,” he said.

If the project is successful, CCP will consider implementing it in other parts of the city too.

Title: 4 prisoners among 1,124 to get degrees
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nagpur: The 33rd convocation of Indira Gandhi National Open University (Ignou) will be held on February 17 with the main event being held in Delhi and regional centres holding separate simultaneous ceremony.

From Nagpur regional centre of Ignou, over a thousand students are eligible for various degrees.

Ignou has adopted a technology mediated web-based convocation so that students need not travel to Delhi. They can receive degrees at a nearby regional centre venue. The main function will be held at Ignou HQ where HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal ‘Nishank’ will be the chief guest.

The convocation will be held simultaneously at HQ and selected 39 regional centres, including Nagpur, through web conference method. The conference can be viewed at www.ignou.ac.in and live telecast on Gyan Darshan TV Channel, which is available through many service providers, including Doordarshan Free Dish.

P Sivaswaroop, Ignou’s regional director, said, “We are organizing convocation at Shalom Auditorium at Hislop College. A total of 1,124 students, including four prisoners, are eligible to receive their master’s degree, undergraduate, diploma and PG diploma.

Sivaswaroop said Nagpur centre has continued its record of producing gold medallists every year. “This year also, one student of Ignou Nagpur has stood first at the national level in PG diploma in analytical chemistry. Jyoti Dasila will be receiving a gold medal at New Delhi from HRD minister,” said Sivaswaroop.

Title: British Deputy High Commission flags off climate campaign
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

The British Deputy High Commission in Hyderabad kick-started a climate change campaign focusing on Telangana and Andhra Pradesh. The campaign is part of the mission’s efforts in the run-up to the climate change summit (COP26) to be held in Glasgow later this year.

“Since the 1990s, the UK government’s policies have ensured substantial reduction in emissions while increasing growth,” said Andrew Fleming, British Deputy High Commissioner, Hyderabad. He said, “The focus of the launch is to gather local support and collaboration that will help us to partner and deliver a series of events in the Telugu region over the course of this year leading to COP26 in November 2020.”

Several activists spoke of the need to reduce consumption. SK Joshi, former chief secretary, said it was Mahatma Gandhi’s principle that ‘there are enough resources for everyone’s need, but not for anyone’s greed’ must be followed. tnn

Title: Dutch treat: In a week, 12 shades of tulips to come alive in Lutyens’ Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Shantipath is one of the sites where these plants have been grown in ample number

NEW DELHI: A colourful floral surprise is waiting to bloom in the gardens of Lutyens’ Delhi. Over 20,000 bulbs of tulip, which were imported from Holland , are likely to bloom fully in central Delhi areas within a week.

Instead of conventional red, yellow, purple and cream shades, New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) has this time introduced over 12 new shades to welcome spring in the most colourful manner. Once they all bloom, it will be no less than a visual treat for Delhiites. Tulips usually bloom for 25 days. AIIMS roundabout, Lodhi Garden , 11 Murti Marg, Nehru Park, Shantipath, Talkatora Garden and Panchsheel Marg are some of the sites where these plants have been grown in ample number.

A senior NDMC official said that they had started the preparations well in advance this time. Efforts like importing bulbs before winters, keeping them in nursery for long time and planting them in gardens and roundabouts during peak winters are now yielding results.

“We have grown shades of tulip in combination with flowers of conventional colours. About 60% of them have already bloomed. The remaining flowers will take another week to gain their pristine beauty,” said NDMC horticulture director S Chellaiah.

Over 35,000 imported bulbs and seedlings of other varieties of flowers are also being planted to ensure that the Lutyens’ Delhi area remains colourful throughout the spring season. “Imported seedlings of daffodil, bearded iris, lilium, freesia, hyacinth, muscari and ranunculus have already been planted. In the next 10 days, they will gain full glory. Most of these have been grown at Shantipath. A mixture of varieties will ensure that the area looks like a colourful carpet of flowers,” said another official.

Apart from the exotic imported varieties, indigenous species of flowering plants such as petunia, salvia, chrysanthemum and dianthus will also add to the beauty quotient of the Central Delhi. At least two hues of iris (blue and white) and different types of hyacinth and lilies have bloomed already.

NDMC has also deputed guards to protect these plants. “We request people to treat the plants carefully so that we may introduce more varieties in future,” added the official.

Title: Interdisciplinary law and medical conference at Gitam
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Gitam School of Law and the Gitam Institute of Medical Sciences and Research jointly organised a national-level conference on ‘Law & Medicine: An Interdisciplinary Perspection’ on Friday. Former chief justice of Delhi high court G Rohini attended the conference as chief guest. She said, “People should never take law into their own hands even when there is apprehension of medical negligence. This could lead to destruction of the doctor-patient relationship.”

Title: In a celebration of India, artistes speak up at JNU...
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Swara Bhasker said the event was planned to highlight multiple shades and voices

NEW DELHI: Valentine’s Day can be a celebration of India, actor Ratna Pathak Shah said while performing Ismat Chughtai’s ‘Hindustan Chhod Do’ at ‘India, My Valentine’, an event organised by Jawaharlal Nehru University students on Valentine’s Day.

Calling the event different from a protest , the actor said, “We should remind ourselves through this the idea of India that we remember.” If artistes feel for something, they can find a way to speak, she emphasised.

The event, which started with a one-minute silence for the Pulwama martyrs, also had actor Swara Bhasker as a participant who said it was planned to highlight “multiple shades and different conversations at JNU. We wanted to celebrate love today”.

The programme, though, had its share of the anti-CAA/NRC narratives, with one of the stand-up comics, Varun Thakur, in an apparent reference to the January 5 violence, joking about how he expected to see people beating up students on the campus. He later told TOI his maiden visit was a “welcome change from what you keep hearing about the university”.

Stand-up comic Aditi Mittal said she decided to perform as she regarded India as her Valentine. “We love India and we wanted to show our love for India. CAA is violating Article 14 of our Constitution.” Sanjay Rajoura, another artiste, said, “If I don’t speak up, I have no right to call myself an Indian.”

Manik Mahana, who claimed to be the “most sensible right-winger” stand-up artiste, said sometimes we “need our own people to provoke us so that we know what it is like when someone provokes us”.

Before the event, a few students protested in support of JNU student Sharjeel Imam, facing sedition charges, and questioned the student union’s decision to call off an event in his support on Thursday. However, Saket Moon, JNU Students’ Union vice-president, said the union would hold a protest for Sharjeel on Saturday.

Title: State election body to hold hearings today
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The state election department officials will hold a hearing on objections received from citizens regarding ward reservation and formation on Saturday from 10.15am at Maulana Abul Kalam Azad Research Centre.

The ward reservations for Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) general election set to be held in April were declared on February 3 during a public event held at Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University’s auditorium.

The election department of the AMC received 372 applications from different people objecting to the process followed in deciding the ward reservation, change of names of certain wards, boundaries defined, allocation of enumeration blocks (EB) and reservations fixed for new wards. The last date for receiving the objections was February 11.

The election department, thereafter, sent all objections to the state election department. As per the process, Saturday’s hearing will see EC officials clarify the doubts and questions raised by the people.

EC official Saurabh Rao along with other officials will hear the objections and the hearing is likely to be completed by 5pm.

Title: College-goers hold silent protest to save the Aravalis
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

The protesters also submitted a letter to Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar

NEW DELHI: On Friday morning, a group of college-goers gathered outside Haryana Bhavan and took part in a silent protest to oppose encroachment in the Aravalis and to highlight the depleting forest cover in the green zone.

“On this day of love, we want people to start loving natural resources and understand that we need Aravalis more than they need us. It is a question of our existence,” said 22-year-old Simran Seth, who is pursuing bachelor’s in History from Delhi University .

The primary demand of the green brigade was the rollback of the controversial Punjab Land Preservation (Haryana Amendment) Act, which was passed by the Haryana government in February 2019 and will open 60,000 acres of forests for real estate development.

Under the banner of Aravali Bachao Citizens Movement — which includes residents of Delhi, Gurugram and Faridabad — the protesters submitted a letter to Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar.

The protesters said that another 50,000 acres of Aravali forests, which do not have the protection of the PLPA or any other forest law, were at a greater risk of destruction. “This means that effectively, the entire Aravali range in south Haryana will get impacted by the government’s move to amend the PLPA. The amended bill seeks to benefit the real estate sector at the cost of forests, wildlife, water security, air quality and the health and well-being of millions living in NCR,” Neelam Ahluwalia of the Aravali Bachao Citizens Movement said. The activists demanded the PLPA Amendment Bill be withdrawn and the 50,000 acres of Aravali forests, such as Mangar Bani and other areas, that have not been notified as deemed forests be notified and brought under the protection of law.

Title: Broken footpaths should be repaired & kept clean: Aaditya Thackeray
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The state minister for tourism, environment and protocol Aaditya Thackeray has raised the issue of the absence of footpaths in the city with the civic body which has sought funds from the state government for road development.

On Thursday, Thackeray along with district guardian minister and industry minister Subhash Desai chaired a meeting at the district collectorate to discuss the various projects proposed to be funded by the government.

Talking about the road project, Thackeray said that the government would provide the financial assistance required for the roads but the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation has to ensure the work is completed. He said that he has noticed that there are no footpath at some place and in some the footpaths are either broken or waste lying around it.

He asked the civic body to ensure that during the road construction, there should be a provision for footpaths. The AMC was also asked to make sure that waste is not dumped on footpaths and the broken footpaths are repaired. In place of the railings installed at the footpaths, Thackeray suggested to place plants in pots, for which funds can be obtained from the state government under the Navinya Purna Yojana.

The AMC presented a hefty file of projects demanding Rs 1,534 crore from the state government. The two major projects in the file were road construction project costing Rs 462 crore and Rs 500 crore for Satara and Deolai development.

In a report published on December 16, 2018, TOI had highlighted how the pedestrians in the city have to struggle on a daily basis in the absence of footpaths in the city.

Title: Vision document to boost city’s heritage
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Aurangabad: During a meeting held at the district collectorate on Thursday, it was decided that the vision document prepared under the smart city project of Aurangabad will be used for conservation and promotion of city’s heritage.

The document outlines the heritage conservation projects — the ones that have been initiated and those that have been proposed.

The document states that the Aurangabad Smart City Development Corporation Ltd. (ASCDCL) had proposed a tender for the conservation and beautification of nine historical gates in the city i.e. Barapulla Gate, Mehmood Darwaza, Roshan Gate, Katkat Gate, Jafar Gate, Paithan Gate, Kala Darwaza, Naubat Darwaza and Khijri Gate. The proposal was designed for the ASCDCL by the Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage (Intach). The work is being carried out at the total cost of Rs 3.2 crore. The technical bids for eight gates have been opened. However, the tender for the Mehmood Gate will be recalled as there is no response from any bidders.

The ASCDCL has also proposed to develop a tourist circuit to connect key heritage sites in the city to enhance visitor experience with an aim to boost tourism. According to the draft plan as reflected in the heritage vision document, the tourist circuit development will include removal of encroachments, traffic regulation and public transport connectivity, improvement of approach road, well designed road junctions, proper road furniture, provision of parking space and illumination along the road and on the heritage structures.

The sites are i.e. Quila-e-ark, Himayat Baug, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Museum and green areas such as Salim Ali lake will be conserved and developed as per the plan.

Title: Audit finds funds swindled in river navigation dept
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: In scathing observations over the functioning of the river navigation department (RND), the office of the principal accountant general has blamed the department for “systemic failure” and “lack of financial accountability”. The findings, which are reflected in an audit report for the period 2014-2019, show that lack of oversight and monitoring has led to a near Rs 3 crore loss to the public exchequer.

Auditors have suggested that the loss could be much higher since the cash book for 2018-19 and 2019-20 was not prepared while several other deficiencies were found in the functioning of the department.

The audit found that the RND has no system of recording and tallying how many tickets are sold on each ferry boat and there was no mechanism to ensure that the “entire money” from the sale of tickets was deposited in the government account.

A random audit of ferry routes observed that on the Keri-Tiracol route, cash collected between May 2017 and September 2017 was deposited in April 2018, a delay of six to 11 months.

“One of the flotilla staff who had deposited toll fees after one year from the date of collection was only issued a show cause notice. A staff was promoted even though he had failed to deposit cash collected before promotion and the toll fee collection was deposited after one year from the date of promotion,” the audit report said.

This, stated the audit report, resulted in “leakage of timely revenue due to misappropriation of cash” and indicated “weak internal controls” within the department.

Congress, which released the report after obtaining it through RTI, alleged that senior department heads were involved in the misappropriation of funds.

“Nobody is keeping an eye on what is happening in the department. Officers are looting the department and corruption has increased tremendously,” said party spokesperson Amarnath Panjikar.

The audit report also found that the department had converted a ferryboat into a pleasure craft, incurring “wasteful expenditure” of Rs 30.5 lakh, without preparing a technical feasibility report. At the same time, the department purchased three new ferry boats for Rs 63.7 lakh.

Title: Reopen Aquem pharmacy: Lourenco to CM
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: Congress Curtorim MLA Aleixo Reginaldo Lourenco on Friday sent a reminder letter to chief minister Pramod Sawant asking him to take steps to reopen the pharmacy at Margao under the Pradhan Mantri Bharatiya Jan Aushadi Kendra. He said many senior citizens used to depend on the pharmacy for medicines and have been struggling ever since the pharmacy closed down. tnn

Title: Turmeric farmers fume as traders offer Rs 4k/quintal
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: The first meeting of turmeric traders and farmers on Thursday organised by the Spices Board after the announcement of a regional extension centre in Nizamabad saw growers fuming after having to undersell their produce.

Farmers bemoaned that traders were not offering them a good price despite their produce having a good percentage of curcumin. They faulted the state government for fixing the eNAM price at Rs 4,000 per quintal when their production cost was more than Rs 4,000. “In Maharashtra’s Sangli market, the eNAM price is Rs 6,000 per quintal. We want the Telangana government to fix the price first and bail us out. We cannot survive if we do not get a good price,” rued farmer Madhusudan Reddy.

The national agriculture market (eNAM) is an electronic trading portal which networks with the agriculture market committees to create a unified market for agricultural commodities, including turmeric.

The growers said the traders merely offered Rs 200 to Rs 300 over and above the eNAM price. “Sometimes, we get just Rs 2,000 per quintal and end up with a loss of Rs 25,000 per acre. With the situation not improving and the government not helping us get an MSP, many of us are not willing to cultivate turmeric,” farmer Srikanth Reddy said.

The growers said their counterparts in Maharashtra had sold turmeric at rates as high as Rs 8,500 per quintal two years ago. “Earlier, turmeric there used to be sold at Rs 2,000 or Rs 3,000 per quintal,” another farmer said.

The meeting saw presence of more than 100 traders and 60 farmers. With exporters and traders demanding totally dried turmeric, which fetches a better rate, the growers were caught unawares. “We do not have enough knowledge about this. The horticulture department should help us out,” some farmers said.

Some exporters told farmers that they were forced to import turmeric from Indonesia and African countries. Interestingly, some traders were okay with farmers demanding Rs 15,000 MSP per quintal.

Title: After Fomento exit, waste mgmt corp to decide Sonsoddo’s fate
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: With Fomento Industrial Pvt Ltd deciding to move out of Sonsoddo , waste management minister Michael Lobo on Friday said he would hold a meeting of the Goa Waste Management Corporation (GWMC) to decide who will manage the dump.

Lobo told TOI that he has moved a note to chief minister Pramod Sawant to convene a meeting of the corporation. He said though the corporation doesn’t operate the site, it could appoint a contractor to treat wet waste.

“We have to put a mechanism in place to find out how much wet waste is generated in the Margao Municipal Council (MMC) jurisdiction and the money required to treat the same. We have to ascertain whether the council is in a position to bear the expenses of the contractor,” Lobo said.

He further said that until a solid waste management plant at Verna becomes a reality, it would be tough to solve South Goa’s garbage problem.

The district court on Thursday had disposed of the case upon a plea by Fomento Industrial Pvt Ltd seeking withdrawal of the case it had filed for claiming service agreement payment. The court had set a seven-day timeframe for the civic body to decide whether it would operate the plant or not.

Meanwhile, MMC, at a special meet on Friday, decided to ask the government how to handle the Sonsoddo plant.

Title: Chinese family causes nCoV scare in housing complex
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: A few residents of a housing colony were left in a state of panic after they saw a Chinese family that had recently arrived in the country moving around in the complex. Fearing exposure to the new coronavirus, they informed the state health authorities, who rushed to the colony on Friday morning to assess the situation

“We have spoken to the family and they have told us that they haven’t interacted with anyone. The family is following our instructions,” state epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said.

The Chinese family of three arrived in India on February 1, and has been under the watch of the health authorities since February 8 after the department was notified of their presence in Goa, Betodkar said.

“The family has completed 14 days of house quarantine and none of the three have shown any symptoms of the novel Coronovirus,” he said. As per the disease control protocol, people under home quarantine are monitored for 28 days by a local authority, Betodkar said, adding that his department has been strictly following guidelines in force.

“We cannot lock people in their homes. We advise them not to mingle with people. Even when interacting with their family, they are asked to maintain a distance of about a meter or two,” he said.

One of the building’s residents said people residing in the colony got worried when they spotted the Chinese man walking in the park last evening. “There were lot of people around, including children and elderly people. He has used the building’s elevator, and was seen moving around before completing the 28-day quarantine period,” she said.

To ally fears, a primary health centre official interacted with the residents, Betodkar said, adding that if people suspect that any person with a travel history is not taking necessary precautions, they should talk to the health official of their area to clear doubts.

Title: Brit, who sought to end life, saved at Baga
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Saligao: A British tourist who tried to end her life off Baga beach was rescued on Friday. The incident occurred at around 2.30pm when the lifeguard on duty spotted a woman heading into deep water. When he attempted to rescue her, she said she wanted to end her life, a press note issued by Drishti stated. The lifeguard, however, calmed her down and brought her back to shore.

The woman, who is in her fifties, was holidaying in Goa with her husband who is believed to have abandoned her, taking with him all her travel documents. tnn

Title: Co-op lenders asked to unveil OTS scheme for borrowers
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: In an effort to bring down the number of unpaid loans, co-operative societies in the state have been asked to give borrowers relief by devising a one-time settlement scheme (OTS) for those who find it difficult to repay their loans. The registrar for co-operative societies has also issued guidelines to be followed while implementing the OTS scheme .

Those who took loans before March 31, 2015, and where the loans have been classified as defaults, will be eligible for the scheme, which will remain in force till September 30, 2020.

Sources said that the government has recommended the OTS scheme to provide relief to co-operative societies and agricultural credit societies in the hinterland and the mining belt.

Registrar of co-operative societies Vikas Gaunekar said that the OTS scheme does not apply for co-operative banks and co-operative societies.

“To speed up recovery and also to give relief to the affected borrowers, it is necessary that all the credit co-operative societies shall devise an OTS scheme for borrowers,” Gaunekar said.

Multipurpose co-operative societies, agricultural societies and urban co-operative credit societies face a shortage of funds as several loans remain unpaid and they are also forced to make provisions towards non-performing assets (NPA). “This has resulted into mounting of NPAs against which the appropriate provisioning needs to be done in the balance sheet to avoid further erosion of owned funds,” Gaunekar said.

To prevent abuse of the scheme, the department has specified guidelines based on which each credit co-operatives shall frame their own OTS scheme and obtain approval from their respective board and general body.

“Society having any government share capital contribution or aid in any other form shall compulsorily obtain prior permission of the assistant registrar concerned before implementation of the OTS scheme,” Gaunekar said.

The OTS scheme is open to all except those who are board of directors, former directors and their family members. All proposals received by the co-operative societies have to be put up for approval before the board of directors.

Title: Two farmers crash bike into RTC bus, die
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Two farmers riding a bike died when they crashed into an RTC bus in Nalgonda district’s Chityal town on Thursday. Another person, who was pillion-riding, is critical. G Narasimha, 60, and U Bikshapathi, 61, died on the spot when they were on their way to attend a function. The bus was heading to Hyderabad. A case under Section 304 A (negligence causing death) of IPC was filed. TNN

Title: Flooded with calls for membership in Hyderabad: AAP
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: With support for the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) reportedly swelling in Hyderabad after the Delhi poll results, a meeting will be organised by the party with its leaders, volunteers and new members on February 16 in the city. The party’s Telangana state observer, Priyanka Kakkar, who campaigned for party candidates during the 2018 assembly elections in Telangana, will address the gathering at the party’s office near GHMC office near Liberty.

AAP Telangana state convener, Burra Ramu Goud, told TOI that the party office was inundated with calls from February 8 itself, when Delhi went to polls. The number of calls enquiring about membership increased after the results were out on February 11 when Delhi chief minister Arvind Kerjiwal led the party to victory once again.

According to Ramu Goud, a large number of NGOs, intellectuals, and educated people, including doctors and lawyers had expressed interest to join AAP. In addition, some leaders from other political parties are also expected to attend the meeting on February 16.

After AAP got elected once again in 2014, the party’s membership programme got it 40,000 people. The latest figures, though not accurate, are said to be around one lakh. “AAP volunteers will go door-to-door to find out the problems of the people. They will be invited to take party membership if they so desire,” Syed Gaffar, state core committee member, said.

There is no membership fee but there are some conditions. One of them is the potential member should not have been convicted for any offence involving moral turpitude. In the last assembly elections in December 2018, AAP contested from 50 assembly but did not win from any. With the meetings that will be organised with new members, the party intends to gear up for the GHMC elections in the city.

Title: Two illegally adopted babies saved from village in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Madurai: A casual enquiry by a villager to the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) in Madurai resulted in the rescue of two babies who were illegally adopted by childless couples at Kuppalnatham village, about 50km from Madurai city. The couple had adopted the babies from Hyderabad.

The babies aged 21 months and 3 months were rescued amidst high drama, with the illegal parents pleading with police not to take away the children.

The illegal adoption came to light when a villager called the CWC on Thursday enquiring about the formalities for adopting a child. The caller spilled the beans when the CWC started asking questions. Based on an alert from the CWC, superintendent of police of Madurai district N Manivannan and a team led by the additional superintendent of police S Vanitha conducted the rescue operation that started in the morning and went on till night.

Preliminary enquiry by police revealed that naickers are the dominant community at Kuppalnatham. “Some relatives of these families had migrated to Hyderabad and nearby areas to earn a livelihood. They do odd jobs or run roadside shops there,” said a police officer.

It is through those relatives in Hyderabad that the childless couples at Kuppalnatham illegally adopted the babies. Kasiviswanathan, a lorry driver, and Mathuvathi who were married for 13 years but did not have children adopted a 24-day-old girl baby about 20 months ago. She is 21 months old now.

Venkatesan, a farmer, and Dhanalakshmi who did not have children for 25 years adopted a 5-day-old baby and are raising her for the past three months. There were unconfirmed claims that the babies were purchased for Rs 75,000 to Rs 1 lakh each.

On Friday afternoon, police led by Peraiyur sub division DSP Mathiyalagan, CWC members B Pandiaraja and L Shanmugam, district child protection officer A Ganesan and personnel from the anti-human trafficking unit reached Kuppalnatham. Sensing something wrong, more than 100 villagers surrounded the team.

As tension built up, ADSP Vanitha went to the spot and police explained to the villagers the seriousness of the issue. It was found that the couples were not aware of the formalities involved in adopting children and they had been taking good care of the babies. They requested the officials to allow them to spend two more days with the babies as they couldn’t bear to part with them. Police explained that it is not legally possible and that the CWC will take a decision in the best interest of the children.

CWC lodged a complaint with the Sedapatti police who said a case will be registered late on Friday night. Meanwhile, the biological parents of the two babies were asked to appear before police for enquiry. An officer said they have started from Hyderabad and are expected by Saturday.

“A probe will be conducted to find details about the sale of the babies and to ascertain if there are more such illegal adoptions,” said a senior police officer.

Title: Cancer conference on emerging treatments
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Ahead of three-day Cancer CI 2020 that will begin on Friday, experts in the field of oncology explained about emerging treatments like immunotherapy and heavy particle radiation. They said that these treatments have shown interesting results like a stage 4 patient of melanoma surviving for 5-10 years, which had been unheard of. These emerging treatments will be highlight of conference. TNN

Title: UoH scheme on birth anniv of Sarojini Naidu
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: University of Hyderabad launched its public outreach initiative to mark 141st birth anniversary of Sarojini Naidu at Golden Threshold, the residence of the poet in Nampally on Thursday. UoH will leverage its campus to host lectures, book readings, concerts, theatre and dance performances. TNN

Title: More than 100 govt officials promoted in first half of Feb
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: Goa Public Service Commission ( GPSC ) has promoted 135 government employees in various departments in the first half of February.

Speaking to TOI, GSPC Jose Manuel Noronha said that every month, on an average around 30 government employees are being promoted. However, in the first two weeks of this month, the commission has promoted a bulk of employees, he said.

GPSC promoted 39 officers to the post of junior scale officer and 25 officers to the post of senior scale officer. The junior scale officers include deputy director, deputy collector and under secretaries, whereas the senior scale officers include a director and joint secretaries.

The commission also lifted the probation period of five DySPs -- Gajanan Prabhudesai, Mahesh Gaonkar, Lourenco D’Souza, Sammy Tavares and Serafin Dias -- and have confirmed them as junior scale officers of the Goa Police Service.

GPSC also promoted 20 persons to the post of assistant account officer under the common accounts cadre in the directorate of accounts as well as 18 employees to the post of section officer in the secretariat.

Seven persons have been granted promotion to the post of deputy director of accounts. Two doctors have been also promoted to the post of lecturer in the department of pharmacology, Goa Medical College.

In the directorate of women and child development, three persons have been promoted to the post of child development officer.

Title: Tamil Nadu economy: On a wing and a prayer
Content:
O Panneerselvam (Left) with Edappadi K Palaniswami (Right)

CHENNAI: O Panneerselvam has made some assumptions in preparing his tenth state Budget. But they may be way too optimistic.His assumes the economy, in slowdown mode for the past few fiscals, will not just revive, but do so significantly. So the state has budgeted tax collection to rise 10% next fiscal when it fell 3.22% in the current year based on revised estimates.The finance minister admitted in his Budget speech on Friday that the state would grow at 7.27% in the current fiscal as against 8.17% the previous year. But he assumes that the state will grow faster than the 7.27% witnessed in the current year, notwithstanding economic headwinds. The Indian economy is expected to grow at 5%. There is no growth guidance from the government for 2020-21.Tamil Nadu continues to live beyond its means. The revenue deficit (when realized income is less than projected income) soared to Rs25,071 crore from the budgeted Rs14,314 crore. The government hopes this deficit will drop to Rs21,617.64 crore, even though it is an election year. Simply put, the government’s revenues are used to pay interests and salaries when it should be used to create assets.With GST collections slowing with the economy, funding the state’s ambitious welfare schemes, seen by some as freebies, would become a stretch. However, with elections next year, the state cannot afford to withdraw any of its announcements, which includes free goats and ceiling fans. In a weak year (2019-20) the subsidies and transfers are pegged to grow 8%.“Though there is a slowdown at present, the Indian economy is expected to gain momentum in the coming years. Tamil Nadu’s growth is higher than that of national GDP, which is a positive sign. This growth is expected to further strengthen in the coming years,” said Panneerselvam.“The revenue deficit in the revised estimates has increased by Rs7,000 crore compared to the 2019-20 budget due to the lowering of Central’s tax share. Due to slowdown the tax revenue in the Central pool came down and due to this our share also lowered,” said finance secretary S Krishnan in a post-budget interaction.“The state finances are weak, and it has been unable to meet tax revenue targets in the past few years. It is borrowing to meet the expenditure in the revenue account,” said Madras School of Economics director K R Shanmugam.Economists accused the government of hiding behind GSDP numbers expecting a 7.24% growth to show fiscal deficit under 3% of GSDP as per the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act (FRBM). “As per the Act there must be no deficit in the revenue account or if there is, it must be within 1%,” said Shanmugam.

Title: CM Pramod Sawant announces third district for Goa by next year
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

The administrative building at Dharbandora was inaugurated on Friday

PONDA: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Friday said Goa could get a third district by next year that would include the Dharbandora taluka. The move, he said, was aimed at speedy development of the region. Sawant, who spoke after inaugurating the administrative building of the Dharbandora taluka, said the state’s population was increasing and that facilities needed to be within the reach of all people. During his tenure as minister, incumbent Congress Ponda MLA Ravi Naik had proposed a third district for the state by including the talukas of Ponda, Sattari and Sanguem and by setting up the headquarters in Ponda town. Stating that this would aid the speedy development of Ponda and surrounding areas, Naik had said it would also benefit Mollem, Collem and Sanvordem, whose residents presently have to travel to Margao or Panaji to get their work done. Land for a collectorate building had also been identified. The administrative building at Dharbandora that was inaugurated on Friday is spread over 3,400sqm and will house major offices, including that of the deputy collector and mamlatdar.

Title: How their fight for love ended in forever after
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Akansha and Shoaib

NEW DELHI: When Ankur Bihari, a government employee, met Nasreen Sheikh, it was love at first sight for both of them. However, when they planned to tie the knot a few months later, their families not only opposed the interfaith wedding, but Sheikh was locked up in her house in Mumbai, which forced her to quit her job.

What followed was nothing short of a Bollywood flick. Bihari approached a Mumbai court demanding Sheikh be produced there. Following the court ruling, Sheikh stayed in a dormitory till Bihari made arrangements for their wedding.

Seven months into the wedding, the couple are now advocates for interfaith marriages. They attended an annual confluence named “Love Against Hate” organised by NGO Dhanak, which also provides aide to couples who wish to marry out of their religion or caste. The confluence was organised on Valentine ’s Day to celebrate the love between 51 such couples.

Sheikh recalled that her elder brother was the one who opposed the marriage. Her phone was taken away, but she managed to converse with Bihari on Facebook messenger. Ankur’s family saw the Facebook post of their wedding and blamed Sheikh for “trapping” him. However, they eventually accepted her. “The family will gradually introduce me to relatives,” she said.

The story of Pavitra and Khateeb is no less intriguing. Khateeb picked up Pavitra from her house in Mangalore and they fled to Dehradun. After Pavitra’s parents informed police, she was taken back to Mangalore. The duo breathed a sigh of relief after a strenuous legal battle. “We now share a good laugh over it at the dinner table,” Khateeb said.

Another couple, Shoaib and Akansha, had a similar tale to narrate. They had approached Dhanak to solemnise their marriage. “Shoaib’s family is yet to accept me fully as they haven’t told anyone that we are married,” said Akansha. Asif Iqbal, co-founder of Dhanak, said, “The campaign will continue for a year to boost the confidence of such couples to come out and talk about it. We have a home for couples in Shahdara too.”

Title: ‘Govt aiming for sustainable mining’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Friday said the state was not aiming for a mere six-month mining period but for sustainable mining that would “continue for a long time”. During his address after inaugurating the administrative building in the Dharbandora taluka, Sawant said some people had resorted to “abrupt” mining that had affected the people dependent on it. “We do not want such type of mining. If we carry out mining systematically, we can mine for next 30 years,” he said. Dharbandora lies in the mining belt. tnn

Title: Now, MCOCA against human traffickers
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The special cell of the state police — cracking down cases of human trafficking and Prevention of Atrocities against women (PAW) — has sent out a letter asking authorities to arrest habitual offender and gangs involved in human trafficking under the stringent Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA).

The letter issued by special inspector general of police (PAW) Pratap Dighavkar has been sent to all commissioners and superintendents of police in the state citing that of late investigation in cases of human trafficking have revealed unheard trends.

Issuing a list of directives, the letter has asked the authorities to impose amended sections 370 and 370-A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) instead of sections 372, 373, 376 and 363 of the IPC, sections of Prevention of The Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act (ITPA) 1956, provided the contents match these sections.

The authorities have also been directed to initiate stringent preventive action against habitual offenders involved in human trafficking, prepare a list of habitual offenders in their respective jurisdictions and initiate steps for cancellations of their bails.

The communication specifically mentions that the authorities should obtain legal opinion and accordingly initiate the process of slapping MCOCA on gangs involved in human trafficking.

All deputy commissioners of police (DCP) rank officers in commissionorate areas and deputy superintendent of police (DySP) rank officials in district areas have been directed to mandatorily carry out two review meetings each month in cases registered for rape, kidnaping for marriage, kidnapping for human trafficking and flesh trade.

The senior officers have been asked to personally supervise the investigation in these cases and closely coordinate with the investigation officers to ensure that these cases not only sustain the test of law and evidence in the court of law, but also reach their logical end.

Legal experts maintained that Criminal Law (amendment) Act, 2013, has come into force wherein section 370 of the IPC has been substituted with section 370 and 370A, which provide for comprehensive measures to counter the menace of human trafficking, including trafficking of children for exploitation in any form including physical exploitation or any form of sexual exploitation, slavery, servitude, or the forced removal of organs.

Authorities confirmed that as the amended sections provide more stringent action against the culprits involved in human trafficking, the investigative agencies are being asked to opt for these sections instead of the old ones.

Title: ‘Original scene of offence was not available to cops’
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: In a major revelation regarding the investigation into the death case of former Merces sarpanch Prakash Naik, the prosecution on Friday told the high court of Bombay at Goa that the “original scene of offence” was not available to the police.

The prosecution’s statement came after the court asked about the position of Naik’s body and whether there was any residual gunpowder from the gunshot. The court was hearing the anticipatory bail application filed by panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho’s brother, Wilson, in connection with Naik’s alleged suicide.

Additional public prosecutor Pravin Faldessai told the court that the scene of offence was lost and later reconstructed, and that the police came into the picture only after Naik was declared brought dead at the Goa Medical College and hospital, (GMC) Bambolim.

There was also no conclusive gunpowder residue, he said, adding that a team has been constituted to travel to Delhi to obtain an immediate report to ascertain whether the gun was used by Naik himself, instead of relying on the laboratory at Hyderabad which could take some time.

In her complaint to the police, Naik’s sister had stated that when she saw his body, she found the revolver used in the incident lying on his chest. She said that while the revolver was under a blanket, her brother’s mobile phone was above the blanket. She also said both his hands were under the blanket.

Faldessai told the court that no angle of investigation was closed and that all angles were being probed. He said the possibility of murder is also being considered and presented the names of three additional suspects identified on February 11, 12 and 13. He, however, did not disclose the names in the open court.

Senior counsel Nitin Sardessai, representing Wilson, told the court that the cheque of Rs 35 lakh dated December 20, 2019 signed by Naik and produced by his sister to the court, was in not submitted to the investigating officer as evidence.

He said that the authenticity of the WhatsApp message sent by Naik minutes before his death must be verified and added that the police were under pressure to file an FIR after Naik’s family threatened that they would not cremate the body.

Sardessai also said that Wilson’s custody was not required as the police already had the messages that Naik had sent and that Wilson had already produced property documents to the police.

Wilson had knocked the doors of the high court after the sessions court rejected his anticipatory bail application last month.

The case will continue on Tuesday.

Title: Delhi: Hindu College students hold decade-old ‘puja’ amid protest
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

File photo of Hindu College

NEW DELHI: Despite issuing a statement against it, several students at Delhi University’s Hindu College boys’ hostel held the infamous “Damdami Mai Puja” on Valentine’s Day. However, another set objected to this “tradition” alleging that it objectified women and sat on dharna outside the principal office.

Meanwhile, just across the road, St Stephen’s College decided not to conduct its Valentines’ Day event of ANGA oath for second year in a row.

For the Hindu College “tradition”, which has been going on for decades, students gather to worship a V-shaped “Virgin Tree” and paste pictures of an actress, christening her as “Damdami Mai”. But due to protests for the past couple of years, the students had decided to do away with it. The groups from both the girls’ and the boys’ had even landed an agreement to change the decade-old practice. However, despite it, several students gathered on Friday to celebrate the tradition.

In their agreement, the students had decided to make the practice inclusive by celebrating “all forms of love, friendship and romance.” “No puja of any conventional sense, which has taken place in the past, will be held and only a mutual celebration organised by both the hostels will take place for the entire college,” the statement said.

Despite this, many students from the boys’ hostel on Friday shouted slogans of ‘Damdami puja hoke rahegi’ and pasted pictures of actors Ranveer Singh and Deepika Padukone.

Ujjwal, president, Hindu College boys’ hostel, who had signed the agreement earlier, did not want to comment on this issue.

Speaking to TOI, Anju Srivastava, Hindu College principal said, “There was an agreement to keep the event inclusive. However, there are students who claimed that the agreement was violated. We will look into the issue.”

Title: Works to restore roads begin in Secunderabad
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

A road in Sithaphalmandi that was marked for repair works

SECUNDERABAD: To ease traffic flow in Secunderabad constituency, the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) and Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) began road restoration works on Friday, almost a year after announcement for the works was made. The works began after deputy speaker T Padma Rao Goud inaugurated a 1.5 km stretch between Shahbazguda and Mohammadguda at Sitaphalmandi division in the constituency.

Though the state government had sanctioned nearly Rs 8 crore for the works and roads on various stretches in Secunderabad were dug up, the works were stalled as contractors could not take them up due to rains during monsoon last year. Around 50 km to 60 km of road has been dug up by the GHMC at various places in Secunderabad.

Padma Rao said that the internal roads in Secunderabad will get a facelift after completion of works that will be carried out in a phased manner. “Stern action will be taken against contractors who fail to complete the works on time,” informed the deputy speaker.

He also inaugurated water and sewer pipeline works at a cost of Rs 50 lakh in slum areas that include Kindi Basti, Bidala Basti, Shahbajguda, Mohammadguda and Gampala Galli in Chilkalguda and Sitaphalmandi.

Title: Showing the way: Cops open library to promote reading habit among youths
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Aurangabad: With an aim to promote the habit of reading among youths and also provide a calm atmosphere for those preparing for different examinations, Osmanabad police have established a library-cum-study centre for commoners as well as policemen in Tuljapur—260km from Aurangabad city.

The library is the first in the region to be operated by the police that will remain open for all. The facility has been started in a spacious hall provided by the Tuljapur temple trust to Osmanabad police.

Superintendent of police Raj Tilak Roushan told TOI, “The huge space was lying idle for a long time. Hence, we decided to put it to good use by setting up a library, thereby creating a win-win situation for everyone, especially the youths. This initiative is also helping us in our outreach programmes.”

Roushan, who is an IIT alumni and an author himself, said there were several options for initiating different welfare programmes. “However, considering the addiction of youths to smartphones and social media, we were compelled to take the initiative of promoting reading culture and providing serene space to those preparing for school, college and competitive exams,” he said.

As a part of the initiative, several books sourced from different educational institutes and obtained from book enthusiasts have been made available for those visiting the library. Some academicians have been roped in for preparing a detailed list of books to be kept at the library. The books will include the ones required for preparating for state and national-level competitive exams, apart from the professional courses, so that the youths who are unable to purchase these books can read them at the library.

An officer said that as for now, the library was being operated only during the day and an assistant sub-inspector had been deployed for supervising the day-to-day affairs at the library.

Police said with the examination season drawing close, they were thinking of making the library available round the clock.

Title: Property owner told to pay Rs 50k to cut 4 trees
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Secunderabad: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) on Friday directed a property owner to pay Rs 50,000 as compensation before felling four trees in Kacheguda.

Nitin Ganeriwal approached the civic body officials and sought permission to fell four trees in front of a commercial building that he owns.

Maqsood Mohiuddin, deputy director of Urban Biodiversity (UBD) wing, GHMC (North Zone) who responded to Ganeriwal’s requisition, directed him to deposit Rs 50,000 for felling of four trees that were almost a decade old.

When TOI contacted Mohiuddin, he confirmed that Ganeriwal was told to pay the amount before cutting down the trees.

He added that the property owner had mentioned in the requisition that the trees were obstructing the elevation of a proposed commercial complex. “During inspection, we found that the area falls under GHMC’s jurisdiction and the trees were planted by us. So, we allowed the property owner to cut the trees provided he pays the compensation,” he said.

Title: Andhra IPS officer moves CAT, says suspension against rules
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Suspended senior IPS officer AB Venkateswara Rao on Thursday approached Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT), Hyderabad, questioning his suspension from service. The AP government had placed Rao, a DGP-rank officer, under suspension on February 8 stating the way he acted in the matter pertaining to procurement of security equipment during his stint as additional DG falls under serious misconduct.

Rao, in his plea, said state’s decision was contrary to All India Service Rules. A separate competent authority was designated for procuring security equipment and matter came to additional DGP at final stage for a formal approval, he said.

He said he was transferred from his post, DGP (ACB) post, on May 30, 2019 and was asked to report to general administration department. “In last eight months, no posting was given and no salary was paid to me,” Rao said, adding “I wrote two letters in January 2020 requesting the government to pay my salary and also give me some posting. It was not done.”

He questioned his suspension because it came without any notice and without formal inquiry against him. He sought cancellation of his suspension GO and payment of his salary with arrears. The tribunal said it would take up the case on Friday.

Title: Goa: One more held in PWD mantri extortion case
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Goa police on Friday arrested a sixth person in connection with an attempt to extort money from PWD minister Deepak Pauskar .

The crime branch said Candolim resident Savio Alfie Lobo, 35, was arrested after a SIM card from which a call was made to Pauskar was found in his possession. Lobo has denied making the call.

The minister had said in January that some persons had threatened to defame him or get him killed if he didn’t cough up Rs 3 crore. He claimed to have received 30 extortion calls from Dubai and Gujarat. When they persisted, Pauskar said he called them to his official residence to collect the money.

There a trap was laid and three persons, who were natives of Maharashtra, were arrested on January 22.

A few days later, two others, this time from Gujarat, were arrested.

Title: Anti-CAA stir in Chennai ends in violence
Content:
Agitations began after police picked up 41 protesters at Washermanpet

CHENNAI: A protest by a 1,000-strong group, including 600 women, against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Population Register at Washermenpet on Friday evening ended in violence with some protesters hurling stones and chappals at policemen and the law enforcers resorting to what a senior officer said was ‘mild force’ to disperse them.The police action triggered protests across the state including in places like Madurai, Trichy and Coimbatore where several people raised slogans against police excesses. The protesters subsequently called off the agitation, following talks with Chennai police commissioner A K Viswanathan.In Chennai, people came out on to the main roads in places like Alandur, Mylapore, Tambaram and Red Hills. Condemning police high-handedness, they uploaded images of the events on social media and WhatsApp groups. The violence in Washermenpet which began after police picked up 41 anti-CAA protesters left joint commissioner (west Chennai) B Vijayakumari with a cut to the forehead, while Rajamangalam inspector Rajkumar had his hand slashed with a blade. Two women constables were hit with stones.In Video: Watch: Scuffle breaks out between police, protestors in Chennai’s Washermenpet

Title: With cut in funds from centre, Karnataka’s debt to increase
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: The government could be forced to borrow heavily to fund development and welfare schemes in 2020-21, what with it set to incur a huge shortfall in revenue especially its share of central funds.With the Centre yet to reply to chief minister BS Yediyurappa’s letter seeking release of the special grant recommended by the 15th Finance Commission and with the Centre yet to release promised funds, finance department officials say the state might have to borrow over and above estimates in the previous budget.The 15th Finance Commission had recommended a special grant of Rs 5,495 crore for the state after it realized that it would get a raw deal under its new tax devolution formula. However, the Centre is reluctant to pay.Besides, the Centre owes the state Rs 17,270 crore in tax devolution for 2019-20. The state had hoped to get Rs 15,008 crore as central grant-in-aid, but the Centre has only released Rs 7,000 crore so far. There is also no word on when the Centre would pay GST compensation dues of about Rs 10,000 crore.Yediyurappa will broach the subject with Union finance minister Niramala Sitharaman, who is expected in Bengaluru on Sunday.It’s unclear how much the government is planning to borrow in 2020-21, but officials say it could be “huge”. “The shortfall in central funds is unprecedented, but we cannot divulge details now,” said a senior official, who added the budget will reveal all.Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) norms allow a state to borrow 3% of gross state domestic product (GSDP), which means Karnataka can borrow up to Rs 54,000 crore. However, former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy, in his budget for 2019-20, estimated borrowings at Rs 42,051 crore (2.6% of GSDP). The state therefore can borrow only Rs 12,000 crore more.Officials say this is inadequate, indicating the government may opt to borrow over and above FRBM limits. This will require the Centre’s sanction. “It may oblige since the Centre itself is borrowing heavily. There is no option but to borrow,” said Vinod Vyasulu, former director of Centre for Budget and Policy Studies.BDA Satya Babu Bose, executive director of Budget Centre, said Karnataka is among the few states which have shown robust tax collection despite the economic slowdown, but it is still being punished.“The Centre must set its house in order, otherwise progressive states like Karnataka will suffer because of the financial mismanagement by the Centre,” Bose said.

Title: Four corporation seats vacant after Delhi polls
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kuldeep Kumar

NEW DELHI: By-elections will be held for four municipal corporation seats as four sitting councillors of the Aam Aadmi Party ( AAP ) were elected to the Delhi assembly on Tuesday.

Abdul Rehman, who was AAP’s first leader of opposition in the East Delhi Municipal Corporation (EDMC) in 2017-18, won from Seelampur. Kuldeep Kumar, councillor from Kalyanpuri and second leader of opposition in EDMC in 2018-19, won from Kondli; while Rohit Kumar Mehrolia, councillor from Trilokpuri 2E ward, emerged victorious from Trilokpuri.

The fourth candidate is Jai Bhagwan, former BSP councillor from Rohini (north corporation), who joined AAP before the assembly polls. He won from Bawana constituency with over 11,000 votes. “All three candidates in east corporation have submitted their resignations to mayor Anju Kamalkant on Thursday. As soon as EDMC issues the official notification, the election commission will have to finalise date and make arrangement for by-elections,” an official said.

“As per norms elections have to take place within six months of a seat becoming vacant,” the official added.

Besides four councillors, two aldermen-one from EDMC’s Haji Yunus and second from south corporation’s BS Joon have also won elections from Mustafabad and Bijwasan, respectively.

Title: Anti-CAA stir in Chennai ends in violence
Content:
Agitations began after police picked up 41 protesters at Washermanpet

CHENNAI: A protest by a 1,000-strong group, including 600 women, against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Population Register at Washermenpet on Friday evening ended in violence with some protesters hurling stones and chappals at policemen and the law enforcers resorting to what a senior officer said was ‘mild force’ to disperse them.The police action triggered protests across the state including in places like Madurai, Trichy and Coimbatore where several people raised slogans against police excesses. The protesters subsequently called off the agitation, following talks with Chennai police commissioner A K Viswanathan.In Chennai, people came out on to the main roads in places like Alandur, Mylapore, Tambaram and Red Hills. Condemning police high-handedness, they uploaded images of the events on social media and WhatsApp groups. The violence in Washermenpet which began after police picked up 41 anti-CAA protesters left joint commissioner (west Chennai) B Vijayakumari with a cut to the forehead, while Rajamangalam inspector Rajkumar had his hand slashed with a blade. Two women constables were hit with stones.In Video: Watch: Scuffle breaks out between police, protestors in Chennai’s Washermenpet

Title: Delhi: Keep your fight on, Anurag Kashyap tells Jamia protesters
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Filmmaker Anurag Kashyap during a protest against CAA and NRC at Jamia Millia Islamia

NEW DELHI: Filmmaker Anurag Kashyap on Friday urged the protesters at Jamia to continue their fight against Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens with perseverance.

Addressing them outside gate number 7, Kashyap said, “I saw a video made by Jamia students, which made me realise that I cannot keep quiet. This movement gives us strength. It lets me believe that we also have existence and we are not just cattle.” These lines were received with a rapturous applaud from the protesters, who have been sitting near the varsity for the last 64 days.

Raising slogans of “Inquilab Zindabad” along with the students, the filmmaker said that this movement was about taking back the Constitution and the country. “We need to come out in large numbers and protest silently and without any violence. This is a long fight and will not get over with one election. We will continue to stay here till they come out and answer all our questions,” he added.

Taking a jibe at the central government, Kashyap said: “This government engages only in monologue, and not dialogue. It understands violence, but not empathy and love.” “They say that CAA is not for the ones living in the country. But we don’t believe in what they say. We will fight till they take the law back or answer all our questions,” he added.

When students asked him to lead the slogan raising, Kashyap said, “I speak from my heart and will follow you guys”.

He went on to add, “If a kid dies at Shaheen Bagh, the government puts a question mark on the entire protest. But when anyone speaks against Modi in Karnataka, the parents are put into jail.”

The filmmaker later visited Shaheen Bagh to extend his solidarity to the protesters there as well.
