Title: Centre assures Goa of Rs 250cr more to complete highway works: Pauskar
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: Union minister of state for road transport and highways V K Singh on Friday assured the state government that his ministry would sanction an additional Rs 250 crore to complete the national highway widening works and set a December 2020 deadline to complete the ongoing works.

Earlier in the day, Singh held a meeting with PWD minister Deepal Pauskar, transport minister Mauvin Godinho and government officials to review the national highway works. During the interaction, the Union minister advocated underground and vertical parking systems and called for better utilisation of land for new projects as land is scarce in Goa.

The new deadline for completing the bridge over Zuari is April 2021, Pauskar told TOI.

He said that due to the delay in completing national highway expansion works, the cost has gone up and Singh has assured to sanction additional funds for the same.

The Centre will sanction Rs 175 crore for the western bypass and Rs 50 crore to construct two underpasses at Colvale, Pauskar said.

The PWD minister said that the Centre would sanction Rs 8 crore for completing the missing link at Loutolim. Singh has assured to release the payment of a contractor who is widening the road from Varunapuri to Sada which has stopped due to delay in payment, the project is a joint venture project, he said.

Pauskar said that the state government has also given the Union minister a proposal of new works, including construction of new Borim bridge, widening of road from Pollem to Karmalghat, Bicholim bypass, Mollem to Khandepar road, Bhoma flyover and Loutolim to Borim road.

Godinho urged the Union minister to consider Goa differently in comparison with the other states while extending financial cooperation.

An increase in vehicular population and the inflow of tourists have led to traffic congestion making widening of roads the need of the hour, Godinho told Singh. He said that the contractor had been directed to start work construction of six-lane flyover at Porvorim. Porvorim residents opposed the project had gone to the court, but there is no stay on the work so we have asked the contractor to start work, the minister said.

People of Porvorim want a four-lane bridge instead of six-lane, but that is not possible, he said. He also said that the government has agreed to increase the height of Porvorim flyover from 5.5m to 6m.

Title: Loudspeaker use: Contempt plea against governments
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Friday sought the Centre and Delhi government ’s stand on a plea seeking contempt action against them for not implementing judicial orders on use of loudspeakers in the national capital. Justice A K Chawla asked them to file status reports on the issue raised in the petition and listed the matter for hearing on May 15.

The plea by Sanjjiiv Kkumaar has claimed that there has been wilful disobedience of the high court’s September 4, 2019 order to abide by the circulars, standing orders and rules which permit use of loudspeakers and amplified music systems only up to 10 pm.

He contended that even the Supreme Court has given directions that loudspeakers should not be used between 10 pm and 6 am.

Apart from seeking contempt action for alleged non-compliance of the high court’s September 4, 2019 order, the petition has also sought directions to the Delhi government and the police to “ban use of loudspeakers (and not holy azaan or fazr) in all mosques in Delhi” between 10 pm and 6 am.

Arguing that loudspeakers were never part of any religion as the instrument came into existence only in 1924, the plea claims use of loudspeakers takes away the right of the citizens to speak with others, their right to read or think or the right to sleep.

The plea has sought directions to the authorities to remove loudspeakers atop any religious structures, saying they violated citizens’ rights, including those of minors and elderly people.

Earlier, another HC bench had asked the police to place before it the standing order issued with regard to usage of loudspeaker at religious places and also apprise it of steps they have taken to publicise the order.

Title: On Valentine’s Day, Kolkata falls in love with East-West Metro as trains start rolling out
Content:
Commercial services of Kolkata’s Line 2, after all, was finally rolling out.

KOLKATA: When the first East-West Metro train chugged out of the station on Friday, love was in the air and the passengers marked the occasion with red roses. “We are falling in love with Metro,” they shouted in unison.Commercial services of Kolkata’s Line 2, after all, was finally rolling out. And it was Valentine’s Day. Officials of Metro Railway and Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC) made everyone feel special by offering roses and a glossy brochure that had information on all passengers needed to know about the Metro line.The first train pulled out of the Sector V station at 8am sharp. Metro Railway and KMRC had the right excuse for celebration: felicitation of the first East-West passenger, Rajib Roy. Everyone clapped and hurrahed. Amid the cheer, some passengers shouted: “We are falling in love with Metro”. KMRC’s general manager N C Karmali and chief engineer Biswanath Deewanjee said they were fortunate to be a part of East-West’s debut run. Railway minister Piyush Goyal had flagged of the section’s commissioning the day before.Though the onus of a seamless service of the state-of-the-art system was on them, Metro Railway’s principal chief operations manager (PCOM) Satyaki Nath and the others were in a light mood, travelling as co-passengers with the 100-odd people who bought the tokens to ride their much-awaited Metro.The commuters were from all age-groups. From 20-year-old college-goer Soumyabrata Chakraborty to 85-year-old Dipali Chowdhury — everyone was smiling, looking happy to travel together on this special day. The octogenarian had Metro Railway’s senior transportation manager Kaushik Mitra by her side for assistance. Helped to swipe the token and then boarding the train, Chowdhury looked intently as the platform screen gates (PSGs) closed in sync with the Metro coach’s doors. “Are these meant to prevent suicides?” she asked.The train was passing the Wipro crossing. Soma De Ghosh looked out of the window to see if she could spot her house at EE Block. The train took 13 minutes to reach Salt Lake Stadium. The timing, in fact, was maintained through the first day of service. Parimal Sharma, 65, a GD Block resident who took two rides to and from Karunamoyee and City Centre in the evening, said, “There are so many interesting features, but the best thing about the new Metro is the timing. The footfall varied at six different stations. Till, 7pm, around 13,495 commuters had travelled the East-West Metro, and Metro Railway had grossed an earning of Rs 1.3 lakh.The ridership peaked in the mid-morning and the evening. Sector V station saw a steady flow of passengers and so did City Centre. But Bengal Chemical didn’t have too many of them, even though it’s next to the Mani Square mall. There were quite a few youngsters who celebrated V-day with groupfies inside East-West Metro trains and stations. Among them were Nilotpal Sen, Nayna Ghosh, Abir Guha and Banya Roy. After taking a ride in the evening, they immediately posted their group picture on the Facebook, with captions like “We love East-West Metro” and “The Metro is our best V-Day present ever”.

Title: Students approach Osmania University as colleges retain certificates
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Osmania University

HYDERABAD: As the academic year is soon set to come to an end, scores of undergraduate and postgraduate students who will complete their course this year are approaching Osmania University (OU) with complaints of colleges retaining their original certificates .

Despite multiple circulars from the University Grants Commission (UGC) and the Union Ministry of Human Resource Development, several colleges in Telangana continue to retain original certificates of students due to the state government’s failure in clearing fee reimbursement dues.

According to college managements, the state government is yet to release approximately Rs 1,000 crore towards fee reimbursement dues for the last two academic sessions to hundreds of private colleges offering engineering, pharmacy, management and other courses. “As I will be appearing for job interviews shortly, I asked the administration to return my original certificates. However, they refused to return the certificates and informed that they have not received my fee reimbursement to the tune of Rs 1.50 lakh for the last two years,” said Thota Vinay, a final year engineering student.

Besides, other students who are yet to complete their course have also complained to OU stating that colleges are insisting students to pay tuition fee for the remaining year(s) of study.

The OU administration has warned managements of such practices and has decided to crack the whip on errant colleges. “Affiliated colleges offering UG/PG (professional/non-professional) courses are directed to return original certificates of the students and not to insist upon payment of tuition fee for the remaining year(s). If any college violates the directions, the university will take stringent action against the college,” read a letter to all its affiliated colleges by the OU deputy registrar on February 12.

As per UGC norms, self-attested certificates of students can be held valid by managements and if there is a need for physical verification of certificates, they should be returned immediately to the student. Collecting advance fees for the entire programme of study or for more than one semester/year in which a student is enrolled is strictly prohibited.

Title: JNU teaching vacancies: Delhi high court seeks reply
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Delhi high court

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Friday sought Jawaharlal Nehru University’s response on a plea challenging its decision to change selection criteria for vacant teaching positions in its Centre for Historical Studies (CHS) after the posts were advertised.

While issuing notice to JNU seeking its stand on the petition, Justice A K Chawla directed the varsity not to fill the advertised vacancies till the next date of hearing on May 6.

The court was hearing a plea by two professors of CHS who contended that the varsity “illegally and unilaterally altered the selection criteria for the posts of assistant professor in CHS during the selection process.”

The petitioners argued that JNU had also shortlisted candidates for the posts based on the new criteria and sought quashing of the list of candidates shortlisted on the basis of the new “diluted criteria” and the interviews conducted.

It contended that JNU, after advertising the posts along with the requisite qualifications, decided to “dilute” the criteria during the selection process by asking the screening committee to remove the need for specialisations.

The petition said that by removing the requirement of specialisation, the varsity has rendered the posts as “open posts” for which someone with a masters’ degree can also apply.

Title: Former CJ passes away
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Former Chief Justice of erstwhile Andhra Pradesh and North Eastern High Courts Palem Chenna Kesava Reddi passed away at the age of 96 at his residence in Banjara Hills on Friday. Palem, who was the oldest living judge in the country, was fondly called Justice PC Reddi. He was born in Kadapa district, AP on November 3, 1924. After his education through a hired English teacher in his village, he went to Pulivendula high school. He completed his BA from Arts College, Anantapur and obtained his law degree from Madras University. tnn

Title: Approvals awaited to set up biomedical incinerator at GMC
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Panaji: Work on installing a state-of-the-art incinerator at the Goa Medical College ( GMC ) and hospital, Bambolim, will be taken up after required approvals are obtained.

“We hope to get all the permissions at the earliest to be able to commence work,” a hospital official said.

The proposed 100 kg per hour biomedical waste incinerator will consist of a primary and secondary chamber and an auto loading device in the form of a bucket elevator.

It will also have a continuous stack monitoring device, as specified under the Biomedical Waste Management (BMW) Rules 2016, and a self-supported mild steel rubber lined chimney.

Over the past few years, GMC has seen a major expansion, with a range of additional facilities being added to the services offered at the state’s premier hospital. With this, the need of a state-of-the-art incinerator is imminent.

The new incinerator will also have an air pollution control device in the form of a high pressure venturi scrubber system, as specified in the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) guidelines, he said.

The system will be equipped with a mechanism to prevent corrosion, as well as a packet column and re-circulation tank.

Other features will include an emergency stack/vent, damper control to allow hot flue gas to pass out of the system in case of power failure, this preventing damage to the downstream equipment. To ensure the burner operations are safe and sound, the incinerator will be equipped with a burner management system.

Title: Many give buses, autos a miss for a ride to workplace
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolkata: Hundreds hopped on to East-West Metro coaches just for the fun of it but for many still, it became a useful means of commute on the first day itself.

The truncated run turned out to be extremely economical for V Agarwal, who, till Thursday, who shelled out Rs 130 to reach his Sector V office from his Kankurgachhi home. On Friday, he paid Rs 6 for an auto ride to Bengal Chemical and then Rs 10 for the 5km Metro ride to Sector V. “From now on, I will only be paying Rs 32 a day for commuting to office,” said this first-day passenger. The thought of saving Rs 220-Rs 230 a day cheered him up.

“But even in its 5km truncated avatar, the new Metro has turned out to be such a handy means of transport,” said scientist and DL Block resident Amit Pal. He took the train from Sector V and travelled till Salt Lake Stadium for Rs 10. He then walked through Subhash Sarovar to reach his destination — Beliaghata ID Hospital. “It’s not possible to go for morning walks when one has to reach the workplace by 9.30am. Not only will I save the money but will also be able to walk to my workplace. The new Metro is changing my commuting habit,” smiled Pal.

People are already ditching cars, overloaded bus and autos to take the comfortable Metro. For months now, Phoolbagan resident Dibyendu Bera, who had to endure three auto rides to reach his office at Shaishali building next to CGO complex. “All this time, I would either look for a bus after an auto ride or split my journey into three auto rides. Today, I took an auto to Kadapara, walked to Salt Lake Stadium and came straight to Central Park station, which is right next to my office,” Bera said happily.

Aniruddha De, who lives near Garia station, too, was celebrating his ‘freedom’ from autos. “I take an AC bus to Beliaghata so that I can board an auto to my office at Bikash Bhavan. Today, I got off near Salt Lake Stadium and came to Karumanoyee Metro station. Life has become so much easier,” the government employee quipped. It was a significant day for De. “I had taken the first-day ride on the north-south Metro with my father. I was a 12-year-old then,” he smiled.

Title: Joyride on ‘notun Metro’ makes the day special
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolkata: As the first East-West Metro train embarked on a truncated 5km journey between Salt Lake and EM Bypass on Friday, Kolkatans set out in droves — young and old, professionals and college students, friends’ groups and families — on Valentine’s Day to check out the “notun Metro” (new Metro). Sector V to Salt Lake Stadium for Rs 10 was as much an attraction as the excitement for the first day first show of the service.

“We came from Belgachhia just to experience the new Metro service and we enjoyed every bit of it. I parked my bike outside the Sector V station and took a ride on the new train, walking around the spick and span coaches and taking selfies before getting down. That’s how we kick-started Valentine’s Day,” said Abhishek Rajbhar.

Salt Lake resident Suman Chowdhury had promised his kids — son Arkaprabha, 10, and daughter Archita, 13 —several months ago that he would take them on a joyride on the new Metro after it was inaugurated. He kept his word on Friday as the family took the Metro from Karunamoyee to reach Salt Lake Stadium in six minutes.

The Chowdhurys were not the only excited family around. Hundreds others came to check out and post photos — swanky coaches, world-class stations and a ringside view of Salt Lake and EM Bypass — on Facebook. Some stood on the seats and leant on the windows to watch the train go by their homes.

“We had great fun. I even asked my brother to record a video of our family taking the train as we rode past our house at EC Block,” said Joyjit Dey, a resident of EC Block in Salt Lake.

There were also friends’ groups and couples riding the train decked up in Valentine’s Day attire, hopping from one station to another, which they said was a major part of their celebration plans for the day.

“We had plans to have lunch at a City Centre restaurant but prior to that, we decided to take a ride on the newly inaugurated train,” said Abhilasha Dutta.

Title: Eggs in mid-day meal for those who want it: Imarti Devi
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Minister Imarti Devi talks to media about the new schemes, initiated by the women and child development depart... Read More

BHOPAL: Eggs are back on the malnutrition battle menu. Women and child development minister Imarti Devi on Friday said that eggs will be given in mid-day meal to those who want it, and the others will be given fruits to combat malnutrition and provide children with healthy and nutritious food at anganwadis.

“It is not compulsory for all students to eat eggs. Those who eat non-vegetarian food or are fine with having eggs with the permission of their parents can have it. Students, who are vegetarians will be given fruits and vegetables to provide them good nutrients and eradicate malnutrition,” said the minister.

The last time the state government spoke about eggs in mid-day meals for those who want it, there were howls of protest from BJP, with leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava going so far as to say eating non-veg food will turn children into cannibals. The government reiterated that eggs weren’t compulsory and stuck to its plan to introduce eggs in mid-day meals from the next fiscal.

“We will not come under pressure from BJP. Those who want to eat eggs will get it,” Imarti Devi said on Friday, adding that the state government is coming up with several new schemes to improve nutrition and education among children of MP.

“We have started mapping 97,135 anganwadis to identify highly malnourished children who need immediate care and treatment. The C-SAM programme (community-based management of severely acute malnutrition) began on February 11 and will go in till February 20 after which a five-day camp will be held where the children thus identified will be given health check-ups and medicines and provided with nutritious food. There will be regular follow-ups,” the minister said.

More than 80 lakh children will benefit from this scheme, Imarti Devi said. “We will set up 50,076 nutrition awareness stalls and distribute 2.5 lakh ‘poshan baskets’ to children in a year. We will also compile a book with local recipes and dishes that are tasty and healthy, using items available in each part of the state,” she added.

Her department has set up 313 ‘bal shiksha kendras’ and plans to open 800 more such centres this month, where pre-primary students will be given education at par with private schools, the minister said.

Title: Delhi: Manoj Tiwari, others look at reasons for loss in polls
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: In a review meeting on Friday, Delhi BJP identified shortcomings in the organisation and the campaign strategy as two primary reasons behind the party’s poor show in the assembly elections. BJP has managed to bag just eight constituencies in the 70-seat House.

According to initial feedback received during a series of meetings at the Delhi BJP office on Friday, the party erred in handling key issues like freebies given by the AAP government and the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protests at Shaheen Bagh.

“The remarks of some leaders calling chief minister Arvind Kejriwal a terrorist and slogans like ‘goli maaro’ did not go down well with the people,” said a functionary, claiming that several participants at the meeting expressed this view.

The deliberations were attended by Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari , national general secretaries Arun Singh and Anil Jain, and Delhi BJP organisational secretary Siddharthan, among others. Local-level party workers, who handled key responsibilities at the assembly constituency level, also participated. The review will continue on Saturday.

Many functionaries pointed out that AAP’s freebies had worked well for it while the absence of anything to counter these in the BJP manifesto didn’t favour BJP. “Initially there was suggestions to include subsidies on water, power and transport, and other facilities for the poor in the manifesto, but the final draft didn’t include them, giving AAP an upper hand,” said a source.

The late announcement of candidates was also flagged as a key problem area. It had left many candidates contesting from new areas with less time to connect with voters, the source said. The party also received complaints against workers on the ground. AAP was the first party to release its list of candidates during the campaign.

Some participants alleged that the door-to-door campaigning by the candidates was hampered by the influx of a large number of star campaigners, who had addressed back-to-back public meetings, said the source.

More feedback will be collected from candidates and councillors. The exercise will be completed in the next three-four days and a report will be submitted to the national leadership.

Title: Use money to build western toilets in old-age homes: High court
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The high court has directed that Rs 10 lakh deposited by two petitioners in court be transferred to the Institute of Public Assistance (Provedoria) to be utilised for building western toilets in old-age homes .

“…the Provedoria, rather than crediting this amount to its general coffers, must consider expending this amount of Rs 10 lakh towards providing sufficient amount of western-style toilets in these old-age homes in case they have not been provided,” Justices Mahesh Sonak and M S Jawalkar stated in their order on Tuesday.

The court noted that there was a grievance raised with regard to insufficient western-style toilets in old-age homes, causing inconvenience to senior citizens, and directed the director of Provedoria to file a report regarding the utilisation of the Rs 10 lakh with the registry by July 31.

Advocate general Devidas Pangam told the court that the Provedoria maintains about 10 old-age homes.

Last month, the court directed two petitioners to deposit Rs 5 lakh each after the court found that they did not participate in a tender process by the directorate of small savings and lotteries despite seeking an interim order from the court in their favour permitting them to participate in the tender process.

Title: 11, including 7 women, remanded in GRP custody till Feb 17
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: The railway magistrate court on Friday remanded the 11 people, including the seven women, arrested in connection with the brutal murder of 26-year-old Kalyan resident on Mumbai-Latur-Beed Express train on Thursday, to the Government Railway Police (GRP) custody till February 17.

The GRP had also detained a minor with the 11 people on Thursday. “He has been handed over to his parents,” senior inspector S R Gaud of the GRP said.

“The suspects kicked Markad and hit him with sticks. The prima facie probe revealed that one of the blows on Markad’s head proved fatal,” he said, adding that the police had recovered three sticks from the suspects. TNN

Title: HDK files plea in I-T protest case
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bengaluru: The Karnataka high court on Friday ordered notice to the Commercial Street police on a petition filed by former chief minister HD Kumaraswamy pertaining to a protest held outside the income-tax department’s office in March last year. The senior JD(S) functionary sought quashing of the complaint. However, as the government pleader requested time, Justice BA Patil adjourned hearing to next week.

In his petition, Kumaraswamy said the initiation of a criminal complaint against him is a clear violation of his fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression. He states he and others had assembled peacefully to protest against the illegal and unauthorised raids conducted by the I-T department against JD(S) and Congress functionaries. He said the department was acting on instructions from the Centre.

Kumaraswamy said the allegations are nothing but an abuse of process of law and was filed to curry favour with a particular political party.

Police were acting on a private complaint filed by A Mallikarjuna, a social activist from Gubbi in Tumakuru district, before a special court for elected representatives. The court had directed the Commercial Street police to investigate.

Title: Lack of RPF escort team on train, breach of protocol after chain-pulling cost assaulted man his life in crowded coach
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: Had the staffers of the Pune railway division followed two protocols, the life of 26-year-old Sagar Janardan Markad could have been saved.

First, no Railway Protection Force (RPF) personnel were deployed to escort the Mumbai-Latur-Bidar Express train in the Pune division in the early hours of Thursday because of manpower crunch. Second, one of the two loco pilots, who twice went to the crowded compartment in which Sagar was assaulted to check why his wife had pulled the chain, did not report anything to anyone.

When Sagar was being assaulted following a row over sharing a seat, his wife, Jyoti, had pulled the chain thrice. The train had stopped at Hadapsar, Manjari and Loni.

A source confirmed one of the loco pilots of the train went to the coach twice to check why the chain was pulled. Unfortunately, he did not report anything, the source said.

“Had there been any message from the loco pilot or the guard, we would have known. If the chain is pulled, the train stops and the guard or one of the loco pilots has to check why the chain was pulled. The regulations also say that they have to inform the railway control, the travelling ticket examiner (TTE) or the RPF about the reason. However, we didn’t receive any message from the loco pilot,” a source in the Pune railway division told TOI, requesting anonymity.

“Since, the compartment in which the assault occurred was near the engine, it was the responsibility of the loco pilot concerned to check why the chain was pulled,” the source added.

Another source in the railways told TOI that when the train started from Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT) and reached Pune station, it had RPF escort. “The escort changes at different divisions. From Pune, ideally, the Pune RPF had to provide escort until Daund. But that was not the case,” he said.

“The Pune RPF provides escort to only 35 trains because of manpower issues. These trains are selected based on prevalence of criminal incidents and this train was not on the list,” the source added.

Manoj Jhawar, the public relations officer of the Pune division, said, “The Government Railway Police is probing the case. If they need any help from us, it will be provided to them.”

Title: Top officials call on Amarinder to allay NPR fears
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: In an outreach to states that have expressed reservations against the proposed updation of National Population Register (NPR), the registrar general of India and census commissioner is likely to visit these states in the coming days and meet their chief ministers or senior representatives to personally allay their concerns.

A start was made by RGI and census commissioner Vivek Joshi who met Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh on Friday to apprise him of the houselisting phase of Census 2021 as well as NPR updation proposed to be done simultaneously between April and September this year. Sources indicated that Joshi may soon visit other states opposing NPR or those seeking modifications in the NPR form to drop the new questions relating to date and place of parents’ birth as well as mother tongue.

Some of the states that Joshi may visit are Kerala, West Bengal, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh. During each of these visits, he will try to reach out to the chief ministers or senior state representatives to explain the legal position regarding NPR; utility of the exercise for formulation and targeting of state-specific welfare schemes; how sharing data on NPR fields is voluntary for the respondent who does not need to show any documents; and that no NRC is planned as of now.

While Kerala has decided that it will skip NPR exercise but cooperate with conduct of census, West Bengal has put the NPR exercise on hold. Congress-ruled states like Punjab, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh have objected to the new questions on date and birth of parents. Even Odisha and Bihar have suggested that these questions be dropped from NPR form.

Sources said that while NPR manual and draft form have been finalised, these are yet to be printed. The format will be forwarded to the states around mid-March and printing the NPR form will be the states’ responsibility. The form — which does not need to be notified — has 23 fields of information, an undertaking that the information declared is true to the best of belief and knowledge of respondent, as well as disclaimer that nationality as declared will not confer any right to Indian citizenship. However, the penalty clause for giving false information may not figure in the new form.

There is apprehension within the government that some of the controversial fields of information being sought for the first time in NPR 2020 may be returned as blank by a large number of residents, especially in states like West Bengal. Also, the states may advise enumerators not to seek information on these fields in the interest of their safety. There is also an underlying fear that NPR controversy may affect the census exercise, with many residents refusing to properly answer census questionnaire. This will adversely affect accuracy of census data, said an officer.

Title: Bird Census: 36 varieties found near 13 ponds in Jaisalmer dist
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaisalmer: During winters, a large number of migratory birds land in desert areas which attracts many bird watchers to Jaisalmer .

The Desert National Park (DNP) had organised a bird fair and conducted an avian census in Jaisalmer whose data was released recently. It was found that hundreds of birds of 36 varieties flock the 13 ponds in the district.

A total of 1,545 birds of 36 varieties were found and according to bird lovers, the number is quite good. More birds can be seen at other ponds in the district. During winters, a large number of migratory birds flock Jaisalmer and after winters they go back to their original place.

DNP deputy conservator of forest Kapil Chandrawal said the census of birds was done on January 25 at Gadisar lake, Gajrup Sagar lake, Shivlotra Nadi, Mawa Talab, Netsi pond, Kavadisar and Jethwai pond in the district by the forest department.

He said demoiselle crane, red-wattled lapwing, black-winged stilt, common coot, northern shoveler, common sandpiper, gadwall, yellow-wattled lapwing, common teal, little grebe, cattle egret, common moorhen, little egret, Indian pond-heron, little stint, little ringed plover, garganey, Indian spot-billed duck, red-naped ibis and many others were found by the authorities.

He said Jaisalmer has established itself on the world tourism map and efforts will be made to showcase the district as a haven for migratory birds so that tourists coming to Jaisalmer can find a new attraction.

Title: Metal detector in hand, Belgian tourist picks up waste on Benaulim beach
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Colva: A trip to the beach for most foreign tourists involves swimming and sunbathing. But for Nicky, a visitor from Belgium, it is an opportunity to clean the shore.

Armed with a metal detector and a backpack, he catches the attention of many as he glides the device over the sand at Benaulim beach for two hours each morning to search for discarded bottle caps, nails and screws, while also picking up plastic trash along the way.

The objective is two-pronged — he not only wants to make the coastline cleaner but also seeks to sensitise people to keep it that way. “India is a wonderful country, specially its tourist states like Goa. People here depend on tourism, but gradually, tourists will stay away because of dirty surroundings,” Nicky tells TOI as he displays a bagful of trash that he’s collected in just 30 minutes. “The internet, magazines and newspapers worldwide are full of articles about how dirty the planet is. Yet, people still throw plastic bottles into the sea with gay abandon,” he says.

Nicky’s tryst with cleaning Goa’s beaches began two years ago, when he set out on a similar mission at Agonda. “Hundreds of people stop and ask me what I am doing. I tell them that I’m helping them understand that they have to respect their land. May be they will stop littering the beach, land and water and may be they will start cleaning the planet in their own way, someday,” he says.

The Belgian suggests a ban on screw-top bottles — like the one being implemented in European nations — if the state’s authorities are keen on reducing waste on beaches and littering in general. “The cap should ideally remain on the bottle and just a small, pop-up opening should be allowed. If this is followed, there will be a drastic decline in littering,” he says.

Title: Karnataka set to amend Lokayukta Act
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Preparations under way on Friday for the upcoming joint session of the legislature at Vidhana Soudha

BENGALURU: The government is likely to amend the Karnataka Lokayukta Act , 1984, to allow Upa Lokayuktas to step in as the competent authority if a complaint is lodged against the Lokayukta or his family. The amendment is aimed at increasing transparency within the quasi-judicial system.

Speaker Vishweshwar Hegde Kageri, on Friday, said the government has placed as many as six bills on the agenda to be tabled during the budget session which is scheduled to begin from March 2. The budget session will precede a joint session of the legislature beginning Monday (February 17). Five of the bills pertain to amendments to existing acts — including the one to the Lokayukta Act — while the other is a new bill.

Incidentally, the recommendation to amend the Act came from Lokayukta Justice P Vishwanath Shetty way back in 2018. It was cleared by the previous coalition government cabinet to be tabled as an amendment to the original act.

The proposed amendment comes in the wake of a number of serious allegations against a former Lokayukta, which raised concerns about independent and impartial inquiry into cases surrounding him or her.

The 2015 scandal surrounding former Lokayukta Justice Bhaskar Rao ’s son in an extortion case involving the quasi-judicial body had embarrassed the state and eroded the credibility of the anti-corruption body.

The government will also table a fresh bill to constitute a Karnataka Innovation Authority for the purpose of assisting startups and setup regulating sandboxes.

Kageri said the legislature session will be divided into two parts — a four-day joint session (from February 17 to February 20) during which governor Vajubhai Vala will deliver his address and a lengthy budget session from March 2 to March 31.

“Besides two days of discussion on the governor’s address, two days will also be set aside for discussion and deliberation on the Constitution of India on March 2 and 3,” Kageri said.

Title: Nayana Gunde to continue as PMPML’s chairperson-cum-managing director
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Pune: Nayana Gunde will continue as the chairperson-cum-managing director of the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) with the state government cancelling the appointment of former Raigad collector Vijay Suryavanshi to the post.

He has now been appointed municipal commissioner of the Kalyan-Dombivli Municipal Corporation. The change was announced on Thursday with sources telling TOI that Gunde’s appointment to the Tribal Research and Training Institute had been cancelled.

“On January 17, the state government had transferred Gunde and Suryavanshi was made the PMPML’s new head. However, he proceeded on leave. It seems that he was not keen on joining his new posting. Gunde, meanwhile, continued to hold the post as she couldn’t join the tribal institute before handing over the charge of PMPML,” the source said.

Suryavanshi is a 2006 batch IAS officer, while Gunde belongs to the 2008 batch. She has been holding the position of PMPML chief since February 2018. Now with the fresh development, Gunde could be among a very few officers who have held the position for two or more years. “Since 2007, the PMPML has had 16 CMDs. Most of them held the post for a year or less before they were transferred. Only R N Joshi remained in the position for close to four years after his appointment in 2011. Gunde’s predecessor Tukaram Mundhe was transferred after 10 months,” another official said.

Sujit Patwardhan of Parisar, a Pune-based NGO, which deals with transport-related issues, said, “It is shocking that the new chief has not joined office. However, it is good that the existing chief will continue in the same post. Gunde has got a hang of the things now, and it is time to deliver and boost the ailing transport body,” he said.

Title: Pune: Judge allows NIA plea to shift Elgar case records
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Special UAPA judge S R Navander on Friday allowed the National Investigation Agency’s plea for moving the Elgar Parishad case records, seized properties and proceedings to the special NIA court in Mumbai.“The investigation has been handed over to the NIA (National Investigation Agency). This court has to abide by the provisions of the NIA Act,” judge Navander said.He observed, “Having regard to the aim and objective of the NIA Act, the order of investigation through NIA cannot be said to be illegal or improper, nor the order has been challenged or set aside.”The judge held, “When investigation is carried out by the NIA, only the special court established as per Section 11 of the NIA Act has the jurisdiction to try the case.”“The special NIA court at Mumbai has jurisdiction over entire states of Maharashtra and Gujarat. Therefore, it can be said that the special court at Mumbai is also the court of local jurisdiction of this case. As such, it becomes clear that this (Pune) court is left with no jurisdiction to deal with the case and it falls in the jurisdiction of special NIA court, Mumbai,” the judge added.On the argument that the Pune court on its own had no powers to transfer the case, the judge held, “This court was having jurisdiction till the (central government’s) order under Section 6 (5) of the NIA Act was passed and NIA took up the investigation. As soon as NIA stepped in, the jurisdiction of this court stands ousted. In such situation, the case has to be moved over to the court which has jurisdiction i.e. special NIA court, Mumbai. In the eyes of law, it is not a transfer of case, but sending of the same to proper court due to lack of jurisdiction.”On the state having constituted a special NIA court in Pune under Section 22 of the NIA Act and the same should have jurisdiction to try and decide the case, judge Navander held that such special courts were only empowered to deal with cases investigated by a state agency and Section 22 of the Act was specific on this count.The judge held that Section 13 of the NIA Act empowered the central government to constitute special courts for trying scheduled offences under the Act and only such courts could entertain the matter. The only recourse I have is to send the case records to the appropriate court. I cannot hold it and, therefore, the matter is being sent to the court in Mumbai,” the judge said. “It is in the interest of everyone,” he added.The judge pointed out that the Pune police’s investigating officer (ACP Shivaji Pawar) had filed a report that the case records and seized properties were being handed over to the NIA as per the consent given by the state government.The court directed that all the nine activists arrested so far in the case be produced before the NIA court in Mumbai for the next hearing on February 28.The development means that all further investigation into the case, fresh arrests and filing of supplementary chargesheet(s) would be done by the NIA before the special court in Mumbai and the trial, too, would be held there.The Pune court requested the NIA to make arrangements for the transportation of the case records and seized properties to Mumbai, and to coordinate with the state director-general of prisons for the transfer of the arrested activists from Pune’s Yerawada central prison to one of the jails in Mumbai.

Title: Wang Qi fears ‘coronavirus’ may land him in jail, again
Content:
Chinese Army veteran Wang Qi with his grandkids in Balaghat

BHOPAL: The coronavirus epidemic is giving sleepless nights to Chinese Army veteran Wang Qi, who had come to visit his family in Balaghat, Madhya Pradesh. His multi-entry visa expires on February 29 but with flights to China uncertain, he fears he may be arrested for visa violation.Wang Qi, who returned to his homeland after spending 54 years in India, frequently comes to Balaghat where his family lives. His son Vishnu Wang said he has been very anxious ever since the coronavirus epidemic broke out. “Father fears being arrested by local police for visa violation if he has to continue to stay in India because of coronavirus. I am writing to the embassy for help,” said Vishnu.The former PLA soldier has faced several problems even after he reached China, says his family. He was asked by Beijing to produce proof of the alleged ‘torture’ he faced during his ‘exile’ in this country. Wang Qi was even put on ‘truth test’ after four of his platoon mates, who were suspended, reportedly objected to financial benefits the Chinese government is likely to provide. “My father’s troubles are far from over. Now, this coronavirus is the latest,” said Vishnu.Wang Qi was also expecting retirement benefits from Chinese Army, but they are on hold as he was declared ‘dead’ in official records, said sources. To clear his record, PLA has ordered an inquiry into his “disappearance from duty” in January 1963, two months after the India-China War ended, and the circumstances under which he was considered dead, said sources.Wang Qi was arrested by Indian Army on January 3, 1963. He said he was a mechanical survey engineer and inadvertently crossed the border. Since the war was over, he was treated as a spy and not accorded POW status. After being moved from one jail to another for eight years, he was freed and settled in Tirodi village, Balaghat, under an Indian name Raj Bahahdur. He married and had children but always yearned to return home. After struggling for years, Wang and his family finally visited China on February 10 last year and were given a grand welcome in Xiaozhainan, where his elder brother lives. His return to China hit front-pages in Chinese media even as the government tried to cash in on the situation by showcasing how they got one of their lost citizens after much effort.

Title: Delhi Police hunt for man who flashed in metro
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

A Delhi Police barricade

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has launched a manhunt for the pervert, who had allegedly flashed at a women travelling inside a metro train going towards Gurugram on Thursday. The woman has lodged a complaint at Ghitorni metro police station in this regard.

According to the police, a case under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) has been registered and efforts are on to nab him. “The woman had tweeted a picture of the accused, but it did not have his face clearly visible. We have now seen his face in the CCTV footage and efforts are being made to identify him,” said a police officer.

The victim earlier alleged inaction by the cops when she approached Ghitorni metro police station on February 13 morning.

“There was no lady constable there, but the male head constable present there was cordial and took the details and the picture from me, said he will forward it to trace it. But, he told he can’t file an FIR (sic),” she tweeted.

Around 1 pm on February 12, the victim had posted a tweet saying a man with a backpack and wearing a grey jacket flashed his penis at her inside the metro around 6pm while she was returning from work.

“Feel shaken, numb and angry. Didn’t remember I had taken this picture till I spoke to a friend hours later,” the complainant tweeted. The woman had also tagged Delhi Police in her tweet. In the picture the accused could be seen holding his backpack in the front and standing close to the door.

Title: Face (your) book! How schools are using social media positively
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Apps, social networking sites, and teachers on call are coming in handy for students preparing for their board examinations. A majority of the schools in the city, especially those affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) or Council for the Indian School Certificate Examination (CISCE), are using technology to help students prepare better for the examinations.

“Each teacher has created a WhatsApp group and it is used to clear doubts and send instructions or tips,” said Sunitha Rao, principal, Delhi Public School, Nacharam, adding that as soon as a student posts a query, either peers or teachers clear the doubt immediately.

She said that besides asking students to call teachers directly if they are stuck with a topic, teachers too are advised to call and find out the progress of students, especially the ones who are weak or are lagging behind. “A teacher will be on call for an hour everyday and their timings are circulated at the beginning of the academic year. However, students appearing for the board examinations generally don’t follow these timings, but are encouraged to call teachers at any time,” added Rao. She said that even psychologists or student counsellors are available on call for the students and their parents.

Besides clearing doubts and sending instructions, schools are also using technology to send important learning material and organise video conferences. Some are even allowing students to take pre-board examinations from the comfort of their homes. “Many parents do not want their children to waste time commuting. So, we are allowing students to take exams from home. All they have to do is download the question paper from our app, write answers, and scan the papers and send them to us so that teachers can evaluate the answers,” said Simi Nagi, principal, Pallavi Model School.

Title: Govt hosp sets up facility to provide clothes for patients
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Thrissur: For the first time in the state a government hospital has set up a cloth bank to provide clothes for patients.

The new project was set up by Pudukad Taluk Hospital in Thrissur and was implemented by its staff council.

Pudukad Taluk Hospital health inspector P N Vidyadaran, told TOI, “The taluk hospital is situated near the national highway and five to six accident cases are reported daily in the region. Most accident patients and bystanders come in with bloodstained clothes. We can’t provide treatment or shift them to Medical College hospital without a change in clothes. Last month the staff council members collected money and set up a cloth bank.”

“Now the cloth bank has clothes for 5-year-olds to 80-year-olds. After hearing about the initiative many were ready to donate clothes, he added.

“Most patients are unaware of the need for new clothes when they come to the hospital. Some seniors reach the hospital with their clothes in a soiled state and we can’t provide treatment without a change of clothes. We will provide new clothes to the patients and bystanders in need. A staff nurse of the hospital Shela, was behind the idea,” he said.

Taluk hospital superintendent Dr Binoj Mathew inaugurated the second phase of the project last week. Staff council president Dr Jesna Muhammed and P N Vidayadaran led the cloth bank initiative.

In addition, the staff council of the hospital adopted the kids ward of the taluk hospital and completed the renovation work with the fund of staff council. “In the new kids ward we set up facilities for playing,” said the health inspector.

Title: Leakages in pipe at Shinganapur major concern ahead of summer
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolhapur: The persistent leakages at the Shinganapur barrage, which is a key water supply point for the city, are giving sleepless mights to the civic officials. Over 50% of water is lost through leakages.

At the barrage, the water level of Panchganga river should be 535.3 meters. Only then, all the pumps of total capacity 86 million litres a day can run to their full capacity.

However, the drop in water level in the dams during summer is expected to reduce the level at the barrage too and affect the supply. The leakages in the barrage are only going to worsen the situation, citizens said.

The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) had invited tenders to carry out the repair work of the barrage eight times; however, it has not received any bidders. The KMC has set aside Rs 40 lakh for the work.

KMC’s deputy hydraulic engineer Ramdas Gaikwad said, “The work is risky as there is continuous flow of water. We tried to get it repaired, however, the exercise turned out to be futile. The material gets washed away immediately. There is need to stop the water flow and then carry out the work.”

He added that there is a need for a copper dam to carry out the work and they had requested the water supply department to provide the expertise to initiate the task.

The irrigation department has asked the civic administration to get the barrage repaired and this time they have set the deadline May to complete the task.

The irrigation department releases water at a rate of 400 to 700 cusecs after every ten days. This lasts for about four to six days. The water released from the dams in summer gets used upstreams for irrigating farms.

A senior official of water resources department requesting anonymity said, “We are requested to release the water from the dams by the KMC. We have to ensure that adequate stock level is maintained in dams especially for irrigation. We have been verbally asked by some officials for help but no formal proposal to get us involved in the repair work has been made.”

Several complaints were made about the quality of the Shingnapur scheme. The barrage was constructed in 1998. There are 20 columns of the barrage out which leakage is taking place from two columns. The officials claim that if the two columns are not replaced, then further damage to other columns will start.

Title: Separate SVEEP plan for every district: CEC
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jaipur: Chief Election Commissioner Sunil Arora on Friday announced that separate Systematic Voters' Education and Electoral Participation (SVEEP) plans for all the 33 districts will be prepared looking at their peculiarities, requirements, literacy rate and other factors. Each district will have separate SVEEP plans and those will be compiled into a composite state SVEEP plan.

"The objective of SVEEP is common all over India, but, at the same time, whatever is relevant in Jaisalmer, can't be relevant in Jhunjhunu or other districts. There is a meeting in Delhi on February 18. The officials from Jaipur will be invited in that to share there proposals for innovations," said Arora.

"The literacy levels of various districts will be taken into account, local population and other factors. There are many common factors of the districts, but every district has its peculiarity and uniqueness," he added after a review meeting of the election department here on Friday. He directed that the officials to select 10 higher educational institutions of the state for conducting SVEEP activities.

Electoral roll to be publishhed on Feb 19, 6 lakh new voters added

Jaipur: Following the summary revision programme, the final electoral roll for the state of Rajasthan will be published on February 19. CEC Arora expressed satisfaction over 6 lakh new voters having registered in the state during special summary revision programme of the electoral roll. More than 3 lakh young voters have added their names in the voters' list.

EC’s regional office to be set up in Mansarovar

Jaipur: The Election Commission's regional centre for state activities will be set up on a one acre land identified in Mansarovar and the land will be made available to the commission by Rajasthan Housing Board. The office of the chief electoral officer (CEO) and a separate wing for SVEEP activities will be housed here. Arora said budget can be allocated for the construction of the building only after estimating the capital expenditure. "If the state government gives us land at a concessional rate, the capital expenditure for it will be borne by the commission. I will speak to chief secretary in this regard," said Arora.

Title: Ensure presence of convicted UCIL officials at hearings: Judge to CBI
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Bhopal: The court of district & sessions judge, here, has asked the CBI to ensure presence of Union Carbide of India Ltd (UCIL) officials convicted in the Bhopal gas disaster criminal case, to attend the court proceedings.

During Friday’s hearing, the court asked the CBI counsel about the whereabouts of the only local accused in the case, Shakeel Qureshi, who is missing for quite some time. At the previous hearing, the court had asked the CBI to find out Qureshi’s whereabouts and present him in court during the next hearing.

On Friday, district & sessions judge, Rajendra Kumar Verma, not only asked about Shakeel Qureshi, but also asked the CBI why other convicts in the case don’t come to court on hearings in the case. When the CBI counsel said one or two of the convicts in the case – Keshav Mahindra are too old to appear before the court and another convict is suffering from cancer, the judge said, “At least those who can come should be present in the court during hearing”.

He also asked for the presence of SP, CBI, on the next date of hearing to brief the court on Shakeel Qureshi’s mysterious disappearance and the investigating agency’s attempts to trace him.

Earlier, arguing on behalf of Keshav Mahindra, who was chairman of UCIL at the time of Bhopal gas tragedy, senior counsel from Mumbai, Amit Desai, said the CBI has not been able to produce any evidence so far indicating that Mahindra had knowledge that the Carbide plant in Bhopal was dangerous. He stressed that Mahindra was a non-executive chairman of the company and had no role in the plant’s day-to-day functioning.

He cited several Supreme Court rulings which held that a non-executive director of a company is not responsible for the company’s day-to-day functioning and he may or may not have complete knowledge about the company or the plant it operates.

On the next date of hearing, i.e. February 26 and 27, defence arguments for convicted Union Carbide officials would wrap up and counsel for the prosecuting agency would commence his arguments.

Title: Thieves steal two sandalwood trees from NIBM campus in wee hours
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

One of the axed sandalwood trees

PUNE: Thieves chopped and stole two sandalwood trees from the NIBM campus at Kondhwa early on Thursday.

The theft occured mere hours after a function, attended by President Ram Nath Kovind, concluded on the institute’s premises on Wednesday.

The National Institute of Bank Management’s (NIBM) estate and security manager, Shyam Sunder Lilani (59), lodged an FIR with the Kondhwa police against two men soon after campus security notified him about the theft.

Assistant inspector Chetan More of the Kondhwa police said, “Investigations revealed that the thieves bent the barbed-wire fence of a housing society on NIBM-Undri Road and sneaked into the NIBM campus. They axed and stole logs of two sandalwood trees and took to their heels after the security guards on patrol spotted them.”

“The thieves climbed the wire fence and fled barefoot with the logs in their hands in the direction of NIBM Chowk and Cloud9, which is a gated housing society on NIBM annexe road,” More said.

“The complainant and the security guards on duty were not able to describe the thieves. The CCTV cameras on campus do not cover the incident spot. We are working on certain clues and hope to solve the case at the earliest,” he added.

NIBM director KL Dhingra, in response to a text message sent by TOI, said, “Sandalwood thieves entered the NIBM campus on February 13 around 2.30am by breaking open the barbed wire fence. While they were cutting the trees, the guards heard noises and rushed to capture them but they fled with the middle portion of the two trees. They left behind the instrument that they used to chop the trees, besides a slipper. The matter was immediately reported to the senior police inspector of the Kondhwa police and an FIR was lodged.”

Title: Thriller ‘DusTak’ gives scary time
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Nagpur: What will you do if you are deserted on an island with completely unknown individuals, and one after the other dies? Scary, isn’t it?

Play ‘DusTak’, staged by Insignia Productions in association with Hislop Centre for Performing Arts (HCPA) and Chitnavis Centre, at Banyan Hall on Friday, really made the audience panicky.

The play, produced by Rahuldev Mukherji, was directed by Arkdev Bhattacharyya.

The play was a Hindi adaptation of Agatha Christie’s best-selling novel ‘And Then There Were None’.

Ten people, all strangers to each other, are invited to Indian Island. The actors were Anil Kumar Saxena (Roger Stephen), Parvati Patil (Annie Jacob), her husband Manohar (Aniket Jadhav), Shalini Singh (Lipika Choudhary), Justice Siddheshwar Bose (Supantha Bhattacharya), Shakti Kaul (Vivek Thaware), Vidya Sinha (Meghna Mulchandani), Dr Varun Prabhakar (Yash Borokar) and colonel Badal Gupta (Padmanabhan Pillai).

When they arrive on the island, the guests are greeted by Mr and Mrs Patil, the butler and housekeeper, who report that the host, someone they call ‘Mr Jain’, will not arrive until the next day.

As the guests gather after dinner, they hear a recorded voice accusing each of them of a murders committed by them in the past and never uncovered. They compare notes and realize that none of them, including the servants, knows ‘Mr Jain’, suggesting they were brought according to a plan.

As they discuss what to do, Saxena chokes on poisoned whiskey and dies. Frightened, the party retreats to bed where almost everyone is plagued by guilt and memories of their crimes.

The next morning, the guests find that Mrs Patil apparently died in sleep. The frightened guests decide to leave the island but the boat does not come.

Meanwhile, Gupta feels sure he is going to die. The next moment, he is found lying dead on the terrace. Everyone starts doubting each other.

The remaining guests meet to discuss their situation. They decide that one of them must be the killer. Many make vague accusations, but Bose reminds them that the existing evidence suggests any of them could be a killer.

The next morning, they find Mr Patil killed while chopping wood for making breakfast. The guests feel the murders are being carried out according to the dictates of the nursery rhyme ‘Ten little Indians’. They realize that the dining room table initially featured ten Indian figures. But with each death, one of it disappears.

After breakfast, Shalini feels slightly giddy and found dead with her neck slit. Bose initiates search for everyone’s belongings for a possible weapon. Others cast suspicious looks at each other. Finally, Vidya goes to take a bath but she is startled by a piece of seaweed hanging from her ceiling.

The remaining run to help her only to return downstairs to find Bose shot in the head.

Dr Varun then disappears that makes others think that he had been killing everyone, until they discover his body lying in the bushes.

Later, Vidya and Karan hear Shakti’s screams and discover he is lying dead. Bose suddenly appears in front of Kartik and Vidya and confesses he has been murdering everyone to punish them for their crimes. A furious Karan shoots him.

Title: Multiple failures, but now successful bizman
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Ritesh Naredi had failed during his schooling multiple times and was an average student. After Inter, he started his own business and is now into manufacturing fans and other appliances for leading companies including Orient, Usha, Crompton, Bajaj.

Naredi has his manufacturing plants in multiple states including Telangana and has employed thousands of workers. “I entered into manufacturing business after Class 12 and managed to complete my B. Com,” he said, adding that he soon began liking what he was doing after realising he was making good money. He said that he, however, managed to complete his graduation by attending college once a week. “Although I started my business very early, I ensured that I joined degree college and managed to complete my graduation. I used to study after completing my work,” he added. Naredi said that irrespective of the percentage of marks one scores, it is important that everyone studies and gives their best.

Title: Chilly, windy weather likely in Delhi today
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Maximum temperature on Friday was 25.4 degree Celsius (File photo)

NEW DELHI: It was a chilly , windy day for Delhiites on Friday and according to Met officials, similar conditions are likely to prevail on Saturday too.

“On Friday, the passing western disturbance led to persistent strong surface wind speed and higher ventilation in the region. The wind speed was as high as 25km per hour along with spells of gusty winds, which went up to 40km per hour. Because of the strong wind, the maximum temperature on Friday didn’t rise as much as on Thursday,” an official said.

Track the pollution level in your city

The maximum temperature on Friday was 25.4 degrees Celsius, a notch above normal. On Thursday, it had gone up to 27.8 degrees Celsius. The minimum temperature on Friday was 13.7 degrees Celsius, three notches above normal.

“On Saturday, too, strong wind is expected till evening. On Sunday, it is expected to decrease. The maximum and minimum temperatures on Saturday is expected to be around 26 and 12 degrees Celsius respectively,” the official added.

The windy day in the city also helped clean up Delhi’s air as the AQI reached “moderate” levels at 173. On Thursday, it was 241 — in “poor” category.

According to SAFAR, the air quality may improve further on Saturday and even reach “satisfactory” levels for a brief period of time. On Sunday, however, it would get foul again and may reach “moderate” and on Monday, lower end of “poor”.

Title: Delhi: Cops cremate Bhajanpura family
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Police personnel stand outside the house where five members of a family were found dead at Bhajanpura area in ... Read More

NEW DELHI: A day after a 28-year-old man was arrested for the murder of five members of a family in Bhajanpura, police cremated their bodies as their relatives did not have enough money to take the bodies back home to their village in Bihar. Meanwhile, police have taken the killer, Prabhunath, into custody to find out whether he was aided by someone.

During questioning, Prabhunath said that he had first murdered his cousin Shambhu in his room and kept waiting for his wife to return from the kitchen. As soon as she entered the room, he hit her with an iron rod on her head due, to which she fell unconscious. He then hit her a few more time to ensure that she died. However, Shambhu’s daughter Komal saw Prabhunath bludgeoning her mother and tried to raise an alarm and alert her brothers, but Prabhunath gagged her and then throttled her. He left the body near the second room where Shambhu’s sons were asleep. He then hit them with the iron rod multiple times.

Officers probing the case, however, were suspicious of his narrative and probing whether someone else had helped him in overpowering the family, since it would be difficult for a single person to attack and kill five people without others coming to know about it. He would be taken to the crime scene to recreate the sequence. The autopsy was conducted by a panel of three doctors.

Title: Only 39% water tax collected
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolhapur: The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) is able to collect only 39% of its targeted revenue through water tax. As a result, this month, the salaries of the entire staff of the water supply department was stopped till Thursday owing to poor tax collection.

Over 134 million litres of water is lifted from various schemes, however, bills for water usage of only 54.6 million litres are collected.

Prashant Pandat, chief water tax superintendent of KMC, said, “We need to reform the system of water supply. It is often perceived that the system is working for profit. In reality, we are even unable to recover the expenses to run the system.”

“We have to convince to the citizens to pay the water tax dues regularly. We have found that while they pay their electricity bills, mobile and cable recharges regularly, but are reluctant to pay water tax bills. The attitude must change,” he added.

The KMC has set aside budget of Rs 22 crore for electricity bills for the power used for pumping and treating water. This year, most of the funds have already been spent two months before the end of the financial year.

Ramdas Gaikwad, deputy hydraulic engineer at Kolhapur Municipal Corporation, said, “This year, the work of the Kalammawadi dam project will be completed and we won’t have to rely on the old pumping stations. There will be less expenditure and adequate water supply.”

Title: Forget peers, focus on yourself: IAS officer
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Hyderabad: “Don’t look at peers, focus on yourself,” is the advice of Commissioner of Collegiate Education and IAS officer Navin Mittal to students, who are set to appear for the board examinations.

He said that many might just show off by saying that they have already covered the entire syllabus, but one should not get demotivated by such claims. “In my experience, I have seen that people who show off might not get better results,” said Mittal. “Do not look at others and worry. This is between you and the exam, what others do should not force you to change the way you are preparing for the exam.”

Mittal said that as the exams are just a few days away, it is best to stick to the basics and focus on revision. “There is no point in running after too much material. Just refer to your notes or material and concentrate on the basics. For subjects like Physics, Chemistry or Mathematics, concentrate on problem-solving,” he advised and asked them to focus on exams and stop worrying about the result.

He added that students should avoid unnecessary distraction and stress as this will only harm their preparation. “Parents must not add to their stress. Instead, they should support and motivate their wards.”

Title: Minister’s U-turn after remark on agri loan waiver sparks controversy
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

GAD minister Govind Singh

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh general administration department (GAD) minister Govind Singh stunned his party leaders when he admitted that the Congress-led government has failed to fulfil Rahul Gandhi’s promise of waiving farm loans in 10 days if the party came to power. The debts left behind by the former BJP government were to blame, he said.

“Rahul Gandhi ji had announced waiver of farm loans up to Rs 2 lakh in 10 days if Congress forms the government in Madhya Pradesh. But we failed to keep that promise. Opposition leaders allege that Congress ‘betrayed farmers’, but I would like to point out that the state's financial condition is terrible, hence the delay in waiving the entire loan as announced,” Singh said at a district-level meeting on ‘Jai Kisan Rin Mafi Yojana’ in Mehgaon village of Bhind district, 500km from Bhopal , on Thursday.

On Friday evening, however, he made a U-turn. “It’s 1000% false that I said we could not fulfil loan waiver promise. In fact, we are continuously doing this. The government is writing off farm loans in instalments. The ministers are monitoring the process in each district,” said Singh despite their being a video of his Bhind speech.

The minister, said to be loyal to the Digvijaya Singh-Ajay Singh faction in Madhya Pradesh Congress, is known for being outspoken. In December 2019, he had acknowledged that the government had not been able to keep the agri loan waiver promise, but assured that it would do so. A month before this, AICC general secretary Jyotiraditya Scindia had said that the government hadn’t been able to keep the farm loan waiver promise “in entirety”.

On Friday, Singh said blamed the financial burdens and empty coffers left behind by the erstwhile BJP government for the delay. “The then chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan had drawn huge debts. During Digvijaya Singh ’s Congress regime, the state had only Rs 5,500 crore as debt, which was drawn for development work. But Shivraj Singh Chouhan left Rs 1.87 lakh crore on the state’s debt accounts. Moreover, Rs 13,000 crore dues to contractors, for so-called-development works, turned out to be another big liability for the incumbent Congress government,” Singh said in Bhind.

“The previous BJP regime also did not clear Rs 16,500 crore-Rs 17,000 crore debt on the power subsidy scheme Sambal, which turned out to be the biggest farce. The state’s coffers were empty, still the BJP government announced subsidy in Sambal scheme. The government could not pay huge debts which resulted in another big liability for the Congress government,” said Singh.

The BJP hit out at Congress, saying Singh’s statement is evidence that the government “betrayed farmers”. “We respect Govind Singh for coming clear on Congress’ biggest fiasco, which they claimed was a game-changer during the 2018 assembly elections. BJP has been raising this issue since the formation of Congress government. Now, it’s up to Congress to decide if they should follow Rahul’s announcement and ask CM Kamal Nath to resign, or cheat public again,” Leader of Opposition Gopal Bhargava told TOI.

“Congress was aware of the financial situation of Madhya Pradesh during BJP rule, still they made fake promises of waiving farm loans and did not keep it. Congress will lose credibility among the public for this failure,” added Bhargava.

The state Congress said that debts of 21 lakh farmers have already been waived in the first instalment, and the second phase is underway. “Minister Singh spoke about the heavy debt and empty coffers left by the previous BJP government and it is true,” said Congress state spokesperson Bhupendra Gupta.

Title: State steps taken to curb drug menace: HC to Raj
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Jodhpur: Taking suo moto cognizance of the flourishing drug trade in and around Jodhpur based on the media reports, the Rajasthan High Court on Friday asked the state government about the measures taken to curb the menace .

The court has also sought to know the steps taken by the state government for the rehabilitation of the drug addicts terming it to be a mandatory requirement as per the provisions of the NDPS Act and rules under it.

Registering the petition as a PIL under the title of “Illicit Drug Trade-The Rising Menace”, the division bench of Justice Vijay Bishnoi and Justice Sandeep Mehta has also directed the principal secretary (Home) and the DGP to file affidavits in this regard on the next date of hearing.

The court observed that huge recoveries of narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances, especially in medicinal forms, suggested that dealers of these illicit drugs are indulging in nefarious activities which have been affecting the labourers, the students and the young children all alike without any distinction.

The court observed “while hearing the bail applications and other similar matters, we have come to know about huge recoveries of medicinal tablets and cough syrups having narcotic and psychotropic contents and such instances are unabated”.

It may be noted that the commissionerate police of Jodhpur had seized a huge consignment of psychotropic medicines from a chemist of the city on February 2 and had arrested three persons, including the owner.

“From four godowns of the chemist, we recovered 17.39 lakh tablets, 1,750 injections and 4,320 bottles of the prohibited medicines,” DCP (West) Priti Chandra said.

The drugs included Orthodex 100mg Tramadol injections, Codeine Phosphate syrup and tablets like Tromanil, Cetadol, Trika, Mindset, XL Pam, Lemotil, Addnok, Editax, Nitrazepam, Teucare and tramadol etc.

Similarly, Jalore SP, Himmat Abhilash Tak said that 90,000 tablets of prohibited medicines like Tramadol etc. have been seized in the year of 2019 in the district, which was for the first time.

Barely a month back, Jodhpur police had seized 1 kg smack and had arrested eight persons from different places of the city in possession of the drug, while attempting to sell it.

Title: Peruvannamuzhi Dam gets Rs 3 crore for renovation
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kozhikode: The Peruvannamuzhi Dam site , which is part of the one of the two dams in Kozhikode will soon get a makeover. A tourism development and amenity improvement project submitted by the tourism department for the development of the destination has received administrative nod.

The Peruvannamuzhi Dam beautification project has received nod for Rs 3 crore works at the dam site. The initiative is to develop the destination modelled on the Malampuzha Dam site.

A detailed estimate for the project will be prepared soon by the nodal agency, entrusted for carrying out the work, said Beena Madhusoodhanan, secretary of District Tourism Promotion Council. We hope to get technical and financial sanction for the project at the earliest, she said.

The Kerala Irrigation Infrastructure Development Corporation is the nodal agency for carrying out the work. The project includes 10 different works for the development of the site.

A significant proposal is the construction of parking zone at Peruvannamuzhi, said the DTPC secretary. Absence of proper parking facility is a major shortcoming of Peruvannamuzhi and we hope to address this soon, she said.

Apart from parking centre, the work of a children’s park, cafeteria, new entrance, walkway and other amenities will also come up at Peruvannamuzhi as part of the initiative. The overall beautification of the destination in Chakkittapara grama panchayat is proposed in the DPR prepared by the DTPC.

A Tourism Information Centre will also come up at Peruvannamuzhi under the project. The centre will provide information about Peruvannamuzhi and nearby destinations. The details of other destinations in the district will also be made available at the centre.

An interpretation hall to help students and researchers to learn more about Peruvannamuzhi destination is also planned under the project.

The development of Peruvannamuzhi is expected to give boost to the tourism sector between the two dams Kakkayam and Peruvannamuzhi. While Kakkayam dam, under the KSEB is already a major destination with boating facility, children’s park and other amenities, Peruvannamuzhi dam site, under irrigation department, has been lagging behind in development owing to various reasons.

Many already sought-after destinations including Thonikkadavu, Karayathumpara, also falls in the tourism zone. The Thonikkadavu destination was recently developed by the DTPC.

Title: Biggest ward gets least supply due to high losses
Content:
This story is from February 15, 2020

Kolhapur: Shailaja Bhosale, who lives in Rajendranagar, is awake every day till midnight just to store water. Thousands like her who live in the E ward, the largest and most populous ward in the city, struggle every day as their area gets just 30% of its required water supply.

“Ours is area located at the fag end of the scheme that bring provides water from Kalamba lake. Water supply, whatever little we get, is late and often starts at midnight. We are told that water is withdrawn mid way and there is very little amount left for us,” she said.

The E ward, which makes up the northern and eastern parts of the city, has a requirement of around 70 million litres of water per day (MLD). However, every day, just 20.90 million litres of water reaches the ward. This is because the large distance between the pumping stations and the residential areas and the leakages along the route, said an official.

While most other parts of the city receive water twice a day for an average of two hours every time. Most of the areas from E ward such as Shahu Market Area, Temblaiwadi, Shivaji University, Uchgaon road area and some parts of Jadhavwadi receive water for just half an hour a day.

Ironically, the ward is flanked by the mighty Panchganga river that had inundated the city for nearly two weeks during the monsoon season last year. The flowing river in their vicinity is of little direct use of the residents because of water pollution. The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation lifts water from the upper streams of the river where it is pure.

KMC’s chief hydraulic engineer B M Kumbhar said the E ward receives water from Shinganapur scheme, which was commissioned twenty years ago. “The scheme was designed to meet the requirements of the residents of E ward till 2011.
